                               The New York Times

                 April 3, 1997, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Business Linked to Berries Is Not New to Controversy

BYLINE: LAWRENCE M. FISHER

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 583 words


Epitope Inc. is no stranger to controversy.

The biotechnology company, based in Beaverton, Ore., has produced products as
diverse as the first saliva-based AIDS diagnostic test and genetically
engineered grapevine rootstock intended to thwart the phylloxera louse, but it
has not generated a profit in its 16-year history.

Analysts who follow the biotechnology industry say Epitope has a history of
hyping its programs, which has led to great volatility in its stock. They say
that even the AIDS diagnostic kit, which is marketed by SmithKline Beecham and
is the company's one clear success, has been a far smaller product than Epitope
management suggested it would be. The company is not currently followed by any
major Wall Street investment firm.

Yesterday Epitope said its recently acquired subsidiary, the Andrew & Williamson
Sales Company, had begun a voluntary recall of 13 lots of frozen, sliced
strawberries shipped to distributors for institutional use in six states, after
the berries were blamed for an outbreak of hepatitis A in several Michigan
schools.

The company said it had learned that Andrew & Williamson inaccurately described
some of the strawberries as having been grown and processed in the United
States, as required by the Department of Agriculture school lunch program. In
fact, some of the berries were grown in Mexico and processed in the United
States, Epitope said yesterday.

In Nasdaq trading, Epitope shares closed at $8.25, down $1.875. It was a 52-week
low for the stock, which has traded as high as $22.87 in the past year. The
company has long been a favorite of short sellers, who profit when a stock's
price falls.

"We have notified the U.S.D.A. of our concern with regard to this matter and
have today accepted the resignation of Fred L. Williamson, the president and
chief executive officer of A. & W.," Adolph J. Ferro, Epitope's president and
chief executive, said in a statement. "As the health and well-being of the
public remains our foremost concern, we will continue to work with appropriate
governmental agencies."

Founded in 1981 as a paternity testing company, Epitope in 1996 received Food
and Drug Administration approval to market the nation's first H.I.V. testing
system that did not rely on blood. Epitope's OraSure uses fluid from the mouth,
which is sent to a laboratory for testing.

Epitope acquired Andrew & Williamson in November in a stock swap worth about
$7.7 million, as part of a plan to spin out Agritope, its agriculture operations
as a separately traded stock. Earlier Agritope had joined with Andrew &
Williamson, a major fresh fruit and vegetable grower and distributor in San
Diego, in a joint venture to grow and wholesale new varieties of longer-lasting
tomatoes. Shareholders are scheduled to vote on the arrangement on April 29.

"The only good thing is this all happened before they made the acquisition,"
said James McCamant, publisher of the Agbiotech Stock Letter, an industry
newsletter. "If their lawyers wrote the contract properly, this will probably
come out of whatever they paid. That's the biggest single question mark: who's
going to end up being liable."

Epitope reported $6.2 million in revenue for the year ending Sept. 30, 1996, but
that included a one-time $5.2 million fee from SmithKline Beecham as a result of
the F.D.A.'s approving extending the shelf life of the OraSure device to two
years from nine months. The company reported a net loss of $1.4 million for the
year.

                  The State Journal-Register(Springfield, IL)

                           November 23, 1999 Tuesday

Disaster aid approved for area counties

BYLINE: SEAN DAILEY STAFF WRITER

SECTION: BUSINESS, Pg. 29

LENGTH: 333 words


Central and southern Illinois farmers whose crops suffered from dry weather over
the summer have some relief coming courtesy of the federal government.

Illinois' U.S. senators, Peter Fitzgerald and Dick Durbin, announced Monday that
69 counties in the state will be eligible to receive federal disaster-relief aid
in the form of low-interest loans from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm
Service Agency.

The loans can be used to restore or replace farm essentials such as animals,
fences, equipment or orchard trees, according to a press release is sued by the
senators.

Other possible uses for the USDA loans include paying all or part of this year's
production costs, essential family living expenses, reorganizing farm operations
or refinancing farm debt.

Locally, Christian, Greene, Montgomery and Pike counties were among the 44
designated as primary disaster areas. Counties designated as contiguous disaster
areas included Sangamon, Morgan, Macoupin, Macon and Cass.

"In Sangamon County, it was really rough," said Matt Montgomery of the
University of Illinois Sangamon-Menard Extension Unit, noting that corn in the
western and southern parts of the county was especially hard hit.

"If you were to look at corn crops around New Berlin and Auburn and around there
in August, you could still tell where the rows were. By August, we would have
hoped that the corn had formed a canopy. That means they were losing
interception of light."

The dry conditions were spotty. Just to the north, Menard County received enough
rainfall to keep farmers there from qualifying for disaster-relief loans,
Montgomery said.

And while a violent windstorm in August did take out a lot of crops, "that
wasn't part of this declaration," he said.

Montgomery suggested that farmers contact their county Farm Service Agency to
inquire about applying for the loans. Fitzgerald spokesman Brian Stoller said
farmers from qualifying counties also may contact a local USDA office directly.

                              504 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                     San Mateo County Times (San Mateo, CA)

                           December 20, 2001 Thursday

Farm bill waiting for allotment of subsidies

BYLINE: By Lisa FriedmanWASHINGTON BUREAU

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 951 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


A $171 billion bonanza for grain, cotton and corn farmers is mired in
legislative muck, bogged down until next year by a partisan tug-of-war over how
subsidies should be spent.

"We're just waiting for the Senate to do something," said Rep. Richard Pombo,
R-Tracy, a leading member of the House Agriculture Committee negotiating the
legislation.

California growers, while anxious as any for the bill to move forward, know that
farmers in the Golden State will see just a sliver of the government munificence
that rains dollars down on Midwest states.

Only 9 percent of all California farms receive government subsidies, despite the
state's status as the largest agriculture producer in the nation.

By contrast, 75 percent of Iowa farms benefit from farm aid, and 70 percent of
all South Dakota farms.

That's because only corn, grain and cotton -- not grapes, strawberries or the
other fruits and vegetables that dominate California's $27 billion-a-year
agricultural production -- are eligible for aid.

"One thousand acres of rice will bring you a big check, but 1,000 acres of
tomatoes gets you nothing," said Sarah Feinberg, spokeswoman for the
Environmental Working Group [EWG], a Washington, D.C.-based, advocacy
organization that has published an online database of all USDA farm subsidies.

Since 1996, farmers in California have received about $2.2 billion in aid,
compared to $5.6 billion that poured into Illinois and $6.7 billion to Iowa
during that same time period.

Most of the California money goes to cotton farms in the Central Valley and rice
producers in the northern region.

But according to data compiled by EWG, the largesse is hardly limited to working
farmers. Some of the country's richest men and women collect government farm
assistance as well.

Schwab, worth an estimated $4 billion, receives $564,000 a year to support rice
crops on his 1,550-acre duck hunting club in Glenn County.

Rep. Charles Stenholm, a West Texas Democrat who helped write the farm bill,
received $39,298 for family farm operations in the past five years, while the
family farming business of Rep. Cal Dooley, D-Visalia, received $306,902 during
that time.

Watchdog groups complain that since a limited number of farmers who apply for
subsidies actually receive them, politicians who collect federal aid are guilty
of at least the appearance of a conflict.

But advocates said they are far less concerned about politicians whose extended
families reap subsidy benefits, like Pombo.

According to figures compiled by EWG, seven Pombos in the Tracy area received a
combined $117,012 over the past five years for wheat and barley production. The
congressman identified all of them as cousins and uncles, and noted he does not
receive any federal aid.

"My brothers and I just have cattle. We don't qualify," he said.

Pombo said he doesn't see a conflict of interest in his work on the farm bill.
Neither did Scott Faber, an attorney with the lobbying group Environmental
Defense.

"He's one of the last people in Congress to feather his own nest," Faber said of
Pombo. "He's an ideologically-driven guy. Obviously I don't agree with him a
lot, but he's one of the few members who serves his beliefs more than his self
interest."

What advocates said is worrisome is that too much money is going to large farms
that need it least. Many environmental groups argue that more money should be
put into conservation.

That is one of the main sticking points in the Senate, which is trying to boost
funding by more than $1 billion for programs that pay farmers to grow wetlands
rather than crops and to give growers incentives to use fewer pesticides and
other chemicals.

California received $42.5 million over the past five years for conservation
programs -- compared to $150 million during that time to Indiana -- and
environmentalists maintained the Golden State needs more to stave off the
damaging effects of development. Many complain California needs more aid because
of the state's high land value.

"California is among the leaders in the nation with a wide variety of species in
trouble," said Faber. "Conservation payments are really the only hope of
providing farmers and ranchers with the tools they need to help."

California Sens. Barbara Boxer and Dianne Feinstein plan to introduce an
amendment when Congress reconvenes that would force the Agriculture Department
to equitably distribute conservation funding on a regional basis, and to prevent
discrimination against regions where the cost of land is high.

According to Faber, the government furnishes an average $1,100 per acre to
purchase easements -- hardly enough to convince a farmer or company to sell a
swath of land.

Not all California farming advocates are in favor of more money for conservation
funding.

Pombo, for one, said he is opposed to taking farmland out of production. He
charged that paying farmers to convert land into wetlands is equally onerous as
paying farmers not to grow certain crops, a practice that has engendered
widespread criticism.

"Now they wrap it in an environmental cloak and suddenly it's okay," he said.

When the farm bill came before a House vote in October, Pombo voted against
siphoning $2 billion from subsidy programs into conservation. And, he said, he
is reserving judgment on Feinstein and Boxers' proposal -- even if it will mean
funneling more money to California.

"I'm not just in this to give money to farmers," he said.

The 1996 farm bill expires in 2002. Senate leaders said Wednesday despite the
impasse they are confident about passing a new bill before the current one
expires.

                                The Independent

                            August 15 1989, Tuesday

900m dollars aid package for US farmers

BYLINE: From JOHN LICHFIELD in Washington

LENGTH: 324 words


WITH some US states struggling through their second year of intense drought,
President Bush yesterday bowed to congressional pressure and signed a bill
granting almost dollars 900m (pounds 570m) in disaster aid to farmers.

In severity and geographical scope this year's drought does not compare with
last year's, but crop analysts warned yesterday that world cereal stocks would
be exceptionally low at the start of next year. US winter wheat and some spring
wheat crops are especially hard hit. The US Department of Agriculture says the
world will consume more wheat than it produces in the 1989-90 season for the
third year in succession.


Congress originally asked for dollars 1.3bn in special payments to farmers
stricken by drought in Kansas, North Dakota, California and parts of Minnesota
and Montana as well as crops ruined by flooding in the South. At first, the
White House resisted making any payments at all and threatened to veto the bill.
But a figure of dollars 897m was agreed, which will not affect the federal farm
budget when reduced subsidies through lower harvests and higher prices are taken
into account.

The worst affected state is Kansas, the biggest producer of bread-quality wheat,
where over half the autumn-sown crop was wiped out. Spring-sown wheat is now in
trouble in North Dakota, Minnesota and Montana. But corn (maize) and soy-bean
production in Mid-West states, severely damaged in 1988, looks reasonably
healthy. Peter Leavitt of Weather Services International, a respected
independent weather and crop analyst, said the world would start the 1990
growing season with the lowest wheat stocks, in relation to demand, for nearly
two decades. Other commentators say the bill signed yesterday relaxed some of
the planting restrictions imposed when grain surpluses were at record levels
three years ago and temporary shortages could again become embarrassing
surpluses.

Foreign News Page 8

LOAD-DATE: September 28, 2000

                              506 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The Washington Post

                     April 11, 2000, Tuesday, Final Edition

WASHINGTON IN BRIEF

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 372 words


Helms Suspends Haitian Aid


Sen. Jesse Helms has quietly ordered the suspension of more than $ 30 million in
U.S. assistance to Haiti because Haiti confiscated a rice company almost wholly
owned by U.S. investors.

Haitian authorities said the confiscation of the Rice Corp. of Haiti was the
result of customs fraud, though the company has denied any wrongdoing. The
suspension of aid went into effect in March without announcement.

The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has the power to
independently suspend aid to a foreign nation, even if the money has already
been appropriated by Congress.


Fla. Customs Enforcement Hit


Fruit and other prohibited food items that can carry agricultural pests are
getting into the United States because of lax federal enforcement at Florida's
seaports and airports, investigators say.

Florida handles 70 percent of all perishable commodities, fresh-cut flowers and
plants that enter the country by air. But in Miami fewer than one in every 100
airline passengers caught trying to enter the country with prohibited food items
is ever fined, according to a report by the Agriculture Department's inspector
general. Cruise ship passengers are not fined at all.


Complaint Against First Lady


The disciplinary arm of the Arkansas Supreme Court, which is looking into a
complaint seeking to disbar President Clinton, said it will review one against
first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton for her actions in the Whitewater venture.

In a letter to a conservative group last week, the executive director of the
court's committee on professional conduct said he will evaluate information from
federal regulators that Hillary Clinton, as a lawyer in Little Rock, created a
real estate document later used by her Whitewater partners' savings and loan to
deceive federal regulators. Clinton says she recalls nothing about the matter.

The conservative group, Landmark Legal Foundation, said the information provides
"credible information suggesting that Clinton may have violated" the Arkansas
code of conduct requiring lawyers to act with honesty and integrity. Clinton's
lawyer, David Kendall, called the conservative group's complaint ridiculous.

                              507 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                       May 1, 1998, Friday, ALL EDITIONS

Health Watch;
NEWS & NOTES

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 03B; Pg. 03B

LENGTH: 702 words



Recalled beef sent to Georgia

Some of the 280,000 pounds of ground beef recalled by a processor for possible
contamination with a virulent form of E. coli bacteria was sent to stores in
South Georgia and Florida, the Georgia Department of Agriculture said Thursday.

The Ira Higdon Grocery Co. of Cairo, Ga., received 12,368 pounds of the beef,
which it shipped to 23 stores in Georgia and nine in Florida. The company is
working to retrieve and destroy the beef, which may still be in meat cases, said
Tommy Irvin, Georgia commissioner of agriculture. IBP Inc. of Dakota City, Neb.,
the largest beef processor in the United States, announced Wednesday that it was
recalling one day's worth of production from its plant in Joslin, Ill. A sample
from beef processed April 14 was found to contain E. coli O157:H7, a bacterial
strain that can cause severe illness and death in vulnerable groups.

Health departments in all 50 states have been warned to watch for cases of
illness resulting from E. coli O157:H7, but according to the Georgia Division of
Public Health and the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, no
problems have yet been traced to this batch of beef. To prevent problems, the
agencies said, beef should be thoroughly cooked, and hands, implements and
cooking surfaces should be washed before and after food preparation. The towns
in Georgia where the meat is believed to have been sent include Arlington,
Ashburn, Blackshear, Cairo, Doerun, Douglas, Edison, Georgetown, Hahira,
Leesburg, Morven, Newton, Nicholls, Quitman, Ray City, Shellman, Smithville,
Tifton, Unadilla, Valdosta and Willacoochee. CONDOM USE: For the first time
since the AIDS outbreak, major producers of heterosexual pornographic videos
will require actors to wear condoms on camera to prevent spread of the virus.
The move is prompted in part by reports that three ''adult'' movie actresses
have tested positive this year for the AIDS virus, industry representatives said
Thursday. The condom requirement extends to some of the biggest companies in the
multibillion-dollar industry, including Vivid Video, VCA and Wicked Pictures.
The gay adult video business has used condoms for the past 10 years, but the
heterosexual porn business resisted the safe-sex practice because companies
feared that use of condoms would diminish the fantasy appeal of their films. The
heterosexual porn industry instead required actors to show proof of being
HIV-free before being allowed to work on a set. MENTAL DISTRESS: Women,
especially separated or widowed women, are more likely than the rest of the
population to report mental distress or mental illness, according to a national
survey released Thursday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. So
are those who are unemployed or undereducated, who earn less than $ 15,000 a
year, who are Native American or Native Alaskan, or who are from ages 18 to 24,
the agency said. The national telephone survey, which included an unspecified
number of adults in Georgia, was an attempt to measure the true incidence of
poor mental health in the population. The problem is believed by health
authorities to be vastly underreported; according to surveys conducted in 1992
and 1993, only 14 percent to 34 percent of those with emotional problems and
depression seek help for those treatable conditions. SMOKING CONCERN: Elderly
smokers may lose the ability to think clearly, perceive and remember more
quickly than people who never smoked or who quit smoking, according to a new
study. A report during the American Academy of Neurology's annual meeting this
week in Minneapolis suggests that the mental decline may be tied to silent
strokes --- very small strokes that go unnoticed by their victims, said study
coordinator Laura Launer of Erasmus University Medical School in Rotterdam,
Netherlands. The researchers pooled data from four European studies that looked
at 9,223 nondemented people age 65 and older. Twenty-two percent were smokers,
36 percent were former smokers and 42 percent never had smoked. All three groups
experienced a decline in cognitive abilities, but older smokers had a
significantly larger decline. --- M.A.J. McKenna and news services

                               The New York Times

               February 29, 1988, Monday, Late City Final Edition

Jewish Groups Examine Farm Crisis

BYLINE: By MAURA REYNOLDS

SECTION: Section A; Page 16, Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 673 words


Representatives of Jewish groups from around the country met with state and
Federal Government officials and agricultural leaders in New York City yesterday
to discuss the farm crisis and formulate a national Jewish response to the
plight of small farmers.

''Jewish religious tradition and history are soaked with the importance of
agriculture,'' said Rabbi A. James Rudin, director of interreligious affairs for
the American Jewish Committee, a civil and human rights group. ''I am convinced
that the inexorable wrenching of the family farm from American society threatens
all of us.''

The conference, sponsored by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, a
Reform group, addressed farm problems in general and Jewish concerns, including
rural anti-Semitism. The meeting was held at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish
Institute of Religion in Manhattan.

''The farm crisis is a topic that should be of special concern for Jews for
several reasons,'' said Mark Green, a speaker. ''First, there is a long Talmudic
tradition. Second, poor farmers in the central part of the country have blamed
Jews for their plight. And third, there needs to be an urban-rural coalition
formed in order to overcome the farm crisis.''

Restructuring of Policy

In his keynote address, Jim Hightower, Commissioner of Agriculture for the state
of Texas, urged a restructuring of basic tenets of agricultural policy, saying
he gained many new ideas on a trip to Israel.

''I saw in Israel what we wanted to do in Texas, particularly in the area of
diversification of production,'' Mr. Hightower said. ''Israel is always
anticipating 5 or 15 years down the road where consumer trends are going.''

Mr. Hightower promoted a theory to end farm subsidies and surpluses, ''supply
management,'' in which crop production is limited to how much the market can
bear and floor prices set to equal farmers' production costs. It is the concept
embodied in the farm aid bill now before Congress and sponsored by Senator Tom
Harkin, Democrat of Iowa, and Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of
Missouri.

Other Government officials, including Jim Nichols, the Minnesota Commissioner of
Agriculture, and Peter C. Myers, Deputy Secretary of the Federal Department of
Agriculture, disagreed sharply over the state of the agricultural sector and
what direction Federal policy should take.

Subsidies Termed 'Welfare'

Mr. Nichols charged that farm subsidies amount to ''welfare'' and blamed the
Agriculture Department's desire to increase exports with forcing crop prices
below the cost of production. ''Let's run the agricultural sector more like a
business and not like a welfare program,'' Mr. Nichols said.

Mr. Myers contended that ''the agricultural industry is in better shape'' since
the last Federal farm aid bill and that current policy ''allows the United
States to be very aggressive in the world.''

''If we can increase the buying power of smaller countries now, they will
ultimately become better consumers,'' Mr. Myers said.  The participants,
including representatives of local congregations and officials of religious and
non-religious special interest groups around the country, said they hoped to
educate their members about the farm crisis and encourage efforts for solutions.

David Goldstein, executive director of the Jewish Community Relations Bureau in
Kansas City, Mo., said: ''There are things that you can do right here in the
city, from supporting the efforts of groups who are working in that area to
supporting legislation in Congress.''

Several of the speakers expressed concern that anti-Semitism was rising in rural
areas especially hard hit by farm foreclosures.

''Since the late '70's a network of far-right extremist groups have been
capitalizing on the plight of farmers,'' said Bea Forrest, vice president of
Women's American ORT, the national organization of American Jewish women. ''The
groups share the same basic theory that blames bankers, the Federal Reserve and
Jews in particular for their situation.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company

                             The Salt Lake Tribune

                            January 20, 2012 Friday

USDA announces $308M for disaster-stricken states

BYLINE: By Bill Draper

SECTION: NEWS; National; World; Local

LENGTH: 1074 words


BC-US--Agriculture-Disaster Funds, 3rd Ld-Writethru,962

USDA announces $308M for disaster-stricken states

AP Photo CER101, UTSAL501, CER102, UTOGD501, CER103, UTSAC501

Eds: Updates with details about how funds are allocated, comment from states.
Edits to trim. Will be updated. With AP Photos.

By BILL DRAPER

Associated Press

KANSAS CITY, Mo. » The nation's top agriculture official on Wednesday announced
more than $300 million in emergency assistance to 33 states and Puerto Rico to
help them recover from an unusually intense year for natural disasters across
the U.S.

Utah and Missouri will receive the most disaster aid, together taking in $109
million, or more than one-third of the $308 million in aid from Department of
Agriculture watershed and conservation emergency funds, USDA Secretary Tom
Vilsack told The Associated Press ahead of Wednesday's formal announcement.

The emergency funds are part of USDA's annual budget and money allocated from
them will be used to repair and stabilize agriculture and public safety
infrastructure. The federal money covers 75 percent of the cost of such repairs,
and is distributed based on local agencies' applications and ability to pay the
balance, according to the USDA.

Vilsack spokesman Matt Herrick said states were largely approved for the amount
of money requested. Applications are most often handled by local Natural
Resource Conservation Service and Farm Service Agency offices.

"We rely on the county offices because they are right there," said Gerald
Hrdina, head of the Farm Service Agency's conservation section in Missouri. "The
requests are funneled through here, and we decide whether to forward them to the
national office. We very seldom deny an application."

Flooding last spring inundated thousands of acres of farmland in Utah, costing
farmers tens of millions of dollars lost to damaged and destroyed crops or
delayed planting. Utah will receive $60 million in watershed money for repair
work and preventative measures in 13 cities and counties hit by floods within
the last 13 months, said Bronson Smart, state conservation engineer for the U.S.
Natural Resources Conservation Service.

He said his agency requested that amount to deal with two rounds of flooding,
including flash flooding in southern Utah in December 2010 and flooding last
spring in northern and central parts of the state caused by a record snowpack.

Missouri suffered months of flooding along the Missouri River after the U.S.
Army Corps of Engineers authorized unprecedented releases from reservoirs in the
northern river basin all summer to deal with unexpectedly heavy rain in May and
above-average mountain snowpack. Farmers in the Missouri Bootheel, meanwhile,
saw their crops swamped when the Army Corps of Engineers exploded a levee to
relieve water pressure on an upriver town in Illinois. The intentional breach
sent water cascading over thousands of acres of prime farmland.

Missouri will receive around $49 million, of which $35 million will come from
the watershed program and the rest from the Farm Service Agency's Emergency
Conservation Program.

Harold Decker, assistant state conservationist for water resources in Missouri,
said most of the watershed money will go toward clearing and redeveloping
drainage ditches filled with silt and debris by flooding on the Missouri and
Mississippi rivers.

"Without that work, those systems aren't going to function," Decker said. "If
ditches aren't draining properly, it retards plant growth and the drainage of
the plants and lowers production."

Vilsack noted that natural disasters wreaked widespread, but varying, havoc in
2011.

"There have been years that have had more intensive damage in a particular
geographic area, but what's unique about last year is that virtually every part
of the country was affected," Vilsack told the AP. "It was different in every
part of the country. We've not seen tornadoes as devastating as last spring.
Flooding on the Missouri River, because of the longstanding nature of the
flooding -- not a two- or three-week situation -- was unique. Fires in the
southwest part of the country were historic in magnitude. It's been a tough
year."

Slightly more than $215 million of the aid comes from the Emergency Watershed
Program, about $80 million will come from the Emergency Conservation Program and
nearly $12 million is from the FSA's Emergency Forest Restoration Program.
Texas, for instance, will receive nearly $6 million after wildfires charred the
southern part of the state.

The watershed funds will go toward public safety and restoration efforts on
private, public and tribal land, Vilsack said. Projects funded by that money
will include removing debris from waterways, protecting eroded stream banks,
reseeding damaged areas and, in some cases, purchasing floodplain easements on
eligible land.

New York trails only Utah in the amount of watershed protection money received,
at $37.8 million.

New York's money is earmarked for repairing erosion and other damage left behind
by back-to-back late summer tropical storms Irene and Lee.

Dennis DeWeese, acting state conservationist with the conservation service in
New York, said 51 communities have asked for assistance and damage assessments
have been completed for 15. The agency's staff of 25, mostly engineers, had
visited 160 sites by the end of last week and is continuing work that may extend
into the Adirondacks.

One challenge, he said, will be asking already cash-strapped towns and villages
to pay their shares to qualify for the federal money and begin design and
construction.

"A lot of these municipalities are overwhelmed," DeWeese said.

In addition to flooding, 2011 was a big year for tornadoes, including record
outbreaks in the South and a monster storm that leveled a large portion of
Joplin, Mo.

Alabama is scheduled to get nearly $7 million in assistance for tornado
recovery, followed by nearly $4 million in Georgia. Missouri, at the other end
of the spectrum, is to receive only $130,000 to fix tornado damage to
agricultural land.

Vilsack said the emergency money is being used to help agricultural interests
beyond what is covered by crop insurance. He said the USDA paid out $8.6 billion
in crop insurance payments last year, and $17.2 billion over the past three
years.

------

Associated Press writer Josh Loftin in Salt Lake City and George M. Walsh in
Albany, N.Y., contributed to this report. Alt Heads:

USDA announces $308M for disaster-stricken states

                             The Salt Lake Tribune

                            January 20, 2012 Friday

USDA announces $308M for disaster-stricken states

BYLINE: By Bill Draper

SECTION: NEWS; National; World; Local

LENGTH: 1074 words


BC-US--Agriculture-Disaster Funds, 3rd Ld-Writethru,962

USDA announces $308M for disaster-stricken states

AP Photo CER101, UTSAL501, CER102, UTOGD501, CER103, UTSAC501

Eds: Updates with details about how funds are allocated, comment from states.
Edits to trim. Will be updated. With AP Photos.

By BILL DRAPER

Associated Press

KANSAS CITY, Mo. » The nation's top agriculture official on Wednesday announced
more than $300 million in emergency assistance to 33 states and Puerto Rico to
help them recover from an unusually intense year for natural disasters across
the U.S.

construction.

"A lot of these municipalities are overwhelmed," DeWeese said.

outbreaks in the South and a monster storm that leveled a large portion of

                              513 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     April 26, 1992, Sunday, Final Edition

Addenda

From news services and staff reports

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A24; AROUND THE NATION

LENGTH: 180 words


" Touching a woman's breasts without permission is not a crime in Arkansas if no
force or threats are used, a judge ruled in dismissing a sexual abuse charge by
a 16-year-old girl against a Little Rock teacher. John Latting, a high school
teacher and coach, was accused of touching the girl's left breast Oct. 16, 1990,
after calling her into his office for counseling. Latting denies touching the
girl.

" For the second year, the Agriculture Department will post marksmen at New
York's John F. Kennedy International Airport to shoot thousands of sea gulls in
an effort to prevent bird-plane collisions.

" Sterling Drug Co., makers of Bayer aspirin, must pay $ 7.8 million to a
15-year-old girl whose mental growth was stopped by Reye's syndrome after she
was given aspirin for a fever at age 5, a Louisiana appeals court ruled.

" William Lucas Barker, 25, of Oakland, Calif., was sentenced to three years in
prison for assault with a deadly weapon -- the AIDS virus -- after having
unprotected sex with a 22-year-old woman in an unsuccessful attempt to give her
AIDS.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS

                       Copyright 1992 The Washington Post


                              514 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                             April 28, 1989, Friday

SIMON SAYS

BYLINE: Howard Simon

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 487 words


THE EASTERN REGIONAL BUSINESS CONDUCT COMMITTEE of the National Futures
Association has barred State Street Futures Corp. of Quincy, Mass., permanently
from NFA membership.

As a result of the strong action by the Chicago-based industry watchdog, State
Street's two principals, David Joseph Condon and David L. Westbook, agreed not
to act as principals for any NFA member for three years from the ate of the
decision.

The firm was a Futures Commission Merchant. As an FCM, it could solicit orders
to buy or sell futures contracts or options on futures for customers and accept
customer money or other assets.

The NFA decision follows a seven-count complaint filed by NFA against the
company in February. In the complaint, NFA charged State Street with failing to
maintain adequate books and records and failing to prepare complete, accurate
and timely daily and monthly trade settlements.

* * * * *

AS TEMPERATURES HEAT UP in the Midwest, so does the debate about whether the
nation's midsection will experience the same hot, dry weather conditions that
caused extensive grain damage last summer.

U.S. Department of Agriculture chief meteorologist Norton Strommen Wednesday
reiterated his view that the United States isn't entering into a widespread
drought similar to that of 1988 despite pockets of dryness (particularly this
spring in hard winter wheat growing ar eas).

Meanwhile, John Schnittker, head of the Washington, D.C.-based agriculture
consulting firm of Schnittker Associates, said he is alarmed for the crops
because of depleted soil moisture.

In either case, the dry weather for Midwest crops prompted the USDA this week to
announce new assistance to farmers and ranchers hit hard by drought conditions.
Acknowledging the serious weather problem, the USDA said its aid includes
allowing emergency haying and grazing on land set aside for conservation. It was
not until late July and August, the peak of last summer's drought, that the USDA
eased restrictions on using conservation land.

The aid also provides feed assistance to livestock and poultry producers.

* * * * *

THE CASE OF AUSTRALIAN BEEF found by South Korean authorities to be tainted may
be the fault of Korean importers and Australian exporters both.

As a result of the spoiled beef, South Korea has imposed an indefinite ban on
beef imports from Australia.

Knight-Ridder Financial News reported Thursday that the 2 million metric tons
found spoiled in Seoul showed signs of bone taint, and South Korea's Livestock
Products Marketing Organization will issue its report on the case as early as
today.

The cause of the bone taint, which is marked by a deterioration in the meat
around the bone, remains unknown, but the problem would have arisen either
during initial freezing of the beef in Australia or due to storage problems in
Seoul, an Australian Meat & Livestock Corp. official said.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE: SIMON SAYS. Briefs

                  Copyright 1989 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              515 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     The Post-Star (Glens Falls, New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 1, 2009 Thursday

Schumer urges aid distribution method that favors smaller dairy farmers

BYLINE: Nick Reisman, The Post-Star, Glens Falls, N.Y.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 222 words


Oct. 1--U.S. Sen. Charles Schumer is pushing the Department of Agriculture to
use the Milk Income Loss program to distribute funds aimed at helping dairy
farmers.

Schumer, D-N.Y., along with U.S. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, D-N.Y., announced on
Wednesday that $350 million was inserted into an agriculture spending bill that
is aimed at helping the flailing dairy industry.

New York's share of that money is believed to be $45 million.

Schumer will conduct a telephone news conference with reporters at 12:45 p.m. on
Thursday to discuss the issue of how the money will be doled out.

He is pushing for the funds to be distributed through the Milk Income Loss
Contract program because that will help smaller farms, he said.

Many producers are struggling to make ends meet, as low wholesale prices
continue to plague the industry.

The current wholesale base price for dairy is $11.60 per hundredweight, or 100
pounds of milk sold.

To see more of The Post-Star, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.poststar.com Copyright (c) 2009, The Post-Star, Glens Falls, N.Y.

tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

LOAD-DATE: October 3, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20091001-GN-DAIRY-AID-20091001

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: GN


                          Copyright 2009 The Post-Star


                              516 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                September 13, 1991, Friday, Late Edition - Final

FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Grain and Soybeans Higher On Prospect for Soviet Aid

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section D; Page 13; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 443 words


The prospect of food shipments to the Soviet Union and the threat of a
diminished crop in this country sent grain and soybean futures prices higher
yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

After the close of trading, however, the Agriculture Department released new
data estimating that the harvest of major crops would be about what had been
expected.

While there were no public developments in arranging for food shipments to the
Soviet Union, the market sustained the belief that such aid was inevitable.

Traders said there were indications that the United States might be planning
direct help for the Soviet Union, rather than merely extending credit
guarantees.

The market's expectations for a bullish crop report were fulfilled in only a
minor way.

Estimates on Crops

The Agriculture Department estimated that farmers would harvest 1.817 billion
bushels of soybeans, only slightly below the market projection; 7.295 billion
bushels of corn, slightly above what the market was expecting, and 2.013 billion
bushels of wheat, a little below the Aug. 1 estimate.

The Government also estimated lower-than-expected stocks of the three crops left
after the 1991-92 year.

"These are not the catastrophically small numbers that some had feared," said
Doug Jackson, an analyst in Des Moines with the Farmers Commodities Corporation.
"But they still show us reduced carryouts, with wheat and corn relatively
tighter than beans."

On the Board of Trade, wheat for delivery in September settled 3 3/4 cents
higher at $3.22 1/2 a bushel. September corn was 3 3/4 cents higher at $2.51 3/4
a bushel. September oats were 1 1/4 cents higher at $1.21 1/2 a bushel and
September soybeans were 6 1/2 cents higher at $5.89 1/4 a bushel.

Strong Cattle Gains

Cattle futures prices posted strong gains at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange,
spurred by better cash prices for feed cattle a day earlier. Traders also said
they expected cattle prices to go higher for the rest of the year.

Live cattle for delivery in October gained 0.62 cent and settled at 72.02 cents
a pound. September feeder cattle were 0.45 cent higher at 85.27 cents a pound.
October hogs were unchanged at 45.40 cents a pound and February pork bellies
were 0.80 cent higher at 49.77 cents a pound.

Energy futures were lower in featureless trading on the New York Mercantile
Exchange.

Crude oil for delivery in October lost 11 cents and settled at $21.53 a barrel.
October heating oil was 0.40 cent lower at 61.17 cents a gallon. October
unleaded gasoline was 0.11 cent lower at 61.35 cents a gallon and October
natural gas was 3.3 cents lower at $1.596 for 1,000 cubic feet.

LOAD-DATE: November 5, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              517 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               January 26, 1981, Monday, Late City Final Edition

SHARP REDUCTION EXPECTED IN FOREIGN AID REQUEST

BYLINE: By JUAN de ONIS, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 7, Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 611 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25


A foreign aid request sent to Congress by the Carter Administration with major
increases for population control and food in developing countries is likely to
be cut back sharply by President Reagan's budget managers.

The requested aid authorization for fiscal 1982, a total of $8.8 billion, was
described by Douglas J. Bennet Jr., President Carter's administrator for the
Agency for International Development, as ''the minimum that any Administration
will need to conduct United States foreign policy.''

However, officials at the agency said this request is likely to be reduced by
David A. Stockman, the new director of the Office of Management and Budget. They
have already been notified that the Carter Administration figures will be
reduced.

The Reagan Administration has not yet named an administrator for the Agency for
International Development, but agency officials said M. Peter McPherson, a
Republican lawyer, is a strong candidate. Mr.  McPherson served on the White
House legal staffs of Presidents Nixon and Ford and is now a deputy to E.
Pendleton James, the White House personnel director.

He Prepared Report for Reagan

During the campaign, Mr. McPherson prepared a paper on foreign aid for Mr.
Reagan recommending more emphasis on technical assistance and less transfers of
agency money to developing countries.

Mr. McPherson, who is 40 years old, grew up in Michigan's fruit orchard country,
was a Peace Corps volunteer in Peru and has been a member of the Board for
International Food and Agriculture Development, a government committee that
coordinates work by American universities and consultants in overseas
agriculture projects.

For the past two years, Congress has failed to pass an updated foreign aid
spending bill, with the result that the program through which the United States
provides development assistance to 61 countries has carried on at the 1979 level
with no increase to offset inflation.

The continuing resolution for United States foreign aid spending that was
approved in December by Congress provided $1.97 billion for the current fiscal
year. The Carter Administration request had been for $2.27 billion.

Aid Policy Is Defended

Although budget-cutting arguments by the Office of Management and Budget have
generally prevailed against increased foreign aid requests, Mr. Bennet said in
an interview before leaving the Government that ''reassertion of United States
leadership in the third world requires a foreign assistance program that serves
both our humanitarian and national security interests.''

''We cannot expect peace and stability in the Caribbean, Africa or any other
part of the third world until greater equity and economic development have been
achieved,'' Mr. Bennet said.

The Carter Administration request for agency funds during fiscal 1982, which
begins Oct. 1, earmarks $1.8 billion for agriculture, health, population, energy
and science and technology. This is 52 percent more than Congress authorized in
the continuing resolution for this year.

In addition, the new request calls for $1 billion for the United States
contribution to replenishment of the funds of the International Development
Association, the ''soft loan'' window of the World Bank.

The proposed authorization also would provide $711 million to increase the
United States capital subscription in the World Bank, $359 million for the
Inter-American Development Bank and $17 million for an initial capital
subscription in the African Development Bank.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1981 The New York Times Company

                              The Washington Post

                      July 25, 1986, Friday, Final Edition

Lyng Promises to Speed Drought Aid

BYLINE: By Ward Sinclair, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A3

LENGTH: 433 words


Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng said yesterday that the government plans
no special new federal aid for drought-stricken farmers in the Southeast, but he
promised to cut red tape and speed help under existing disaster programs.

Lyng described the months-long drought as "painfully severe" across most of the
region and said he believes crop losses will be "gigantic," perhaps in the $1
billion range, and will "seriously and dramatically" affect the region's
economy.

The secretary said the economic losses from crop devastation, along with debt
problems faced by many farmers, will touch "every community" in the drought zone
that has parched much of Alabama, Georgia and the Carolinas.

"Farmers spend all the money they get in these communities. When their income
drops, the whole community suffers," Lyng said.

The secretary also announced changes in various Agriculture Department programs
that he said will help ease the drought's effects. He said a Washington-based
task force headed by James Boillot, a deputy assistant secretary, has been
assigned to expedite aid to farmers.

Lyng said he had ordered the department's "response time" to requests for
individual aid and disaster declarations -- which open the way for low-interest
disaster loans and other federal assistance -- to be cut "from the usual days or
weeks to the absolute minimum."

The secretary's announcement followed a report from a task force headed by
George Dunlop, an assistant secretary, which earlier this week visited some of
the region's hardest-hit farming areas. Dunlop predicted yesterday crop losses
ranging to 100 percent in some cases.

Lyng said that on Monday he will visit parts of south-central Pennsylvania, also
afflicted by dryness since early spring, and a second task force will go to
Maryland, Virginia and Delaware to complete a USDA survey of conditions in a dry
belt that extends through the mid-Atlantic and southeastern states.

Lyng said potential crop losses in the South would have little impact on overall
U.S. supplies of major commodities, all of which are in surplus and most of
which are anticipating bumper harvests in other agricultural areas.

He acknowledged complaints about USDA's slowness in reacting to the weather
crisis, but said it has taken time to comply with rules governing emergency
declarations.

"I think I would be misleading people if I suggested that the federal government
is going to be able to come in and save all these farmers," he said. "But we're
going to do the best we can do to minimize as much as we possibly can in a
compassionate way.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Picture, L.C. and Lavonne Smith inspect a pond, normally 15 feet deep,
that dried up at their Carnesville, Ga. farm during the summer drought. AP

                              520 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                          Australian Financial Review

                            October 22, 1999 Friday
                                  Late Edition

Clinton's free trade rhetoric is worth peanuts;
Washington Observed

BYLINE: Joanne Gray

SECTION: NEWS; International News; Pg. 34

LENGTH: 907 words


Chastened by its humiliating defeat on the nuclear test ban treaty vote last
week, the Clinton Administration is facing another test of its international and
domestic clout in the next round of trade liberalisation talks, which will kick
off next month in Seattle.

The biggest debates of the so-called millennium round of the World Trade
Organisation will be over which industries in the world economy should be freed
up next.

But the US is facing sceptical audiences both internationally and at home,
because the collapse of the free trade consensus in Congress and domestic
political concerns are lending a contorted character to US trade policy going
into Seattle.

Arguing that the new round must be about jobs and development, Bill Clinton is
trying to woo Democrats, the labour movement and international interest groups
which have gone sour on free trade and globalisation. The sweetener he is
offering in Seattle with support likely from the European Union is higher labour
and environmental standards in trade deals.

Both the US and the EU hope these, and better access to the secretive WTO
process for non-government activist groups, will neutralise their hostility and
convince them and unions to embrace another painful episode of more intense
foreign competition and freer trade.

But the push for higher environment and labour standards in trade agreements is
anathema to developing countries. They argue that they cannot match the first
world on workers' pay or environmental safety, and this push is just another way
of protecting rich economies.

Like Australia and other Cairns Group countries, the United States the world's
biggest economy wants agriculture to be the centrepiece of the talks. US
agricultural exports are suffering and the current account is heading into
record territory, so Clinton is promising to prise open markets to US farm
products.

The US wants a recalcitrant Europe and Japan to remove agricultural subsidies,
price supports and tariffs. But while it is urging other countries to phase out
aid for the farming sector, support for agriculture in the US is thriving.

Congress has just promised US farmers an emergency package of $US8.7 billion
($13.4 billion) to help them through a period of low commodity prices. Aid to
the sector is expected to top $US20 billion this year.

This largesse hasn't escaped international attention, and is ammunition for the
EU, which is trying to deflect attention from its Common Agricultural Policy.

"If we're going to discuss subsidies, we're going to have to discuss all
subsidies European as well as American," said the French Agriculture Minister,
Jacques Glavany, adding that US aid payments to farmers "are the highest I've
seen".

Japan and the EU want the WTO to accept the idea of "multi-functionality" when
it comes to agriculture. This holds that farm aid can be justified if it
preserves rural lifestyles and promotes a scenic landscape. But the Cairns Group
and the US suspect this will become another way of justifying protection.

Europe is trying to introduce up-front exclusions from the Seattle talks for
beef and dairy products, and Japan doesn't want to talk about opening access for
rice imports. The US Trade Representative, Charlene Barshefsky, has ruled out
any exclusions, but she did suggest that the US might want to protect
"sensitive" industries when talks start. Peanuts and sugar would be prime
targets. The EU is also at odds with the US over genetically modified food and
hormone-treated beef.

The EU and Japan want talks on the investment and competition policies of WTO
members, but the US is baulking at adding these issues to the agenda, fearing
they will be used to deflect attention from agriculture. Nor will the US back a
global review of anti-dumping rules, which Japan and Europe argue are
protectionism by another name.

Australia has joined the EU in attacking US use of export credits for
agricultural goods, arguing that they are akin to a subsidy, but the US will not
acknowledge that they are subsidies.

To outsiders, the US stance so far on the millennium round looks like a rather
unwieldy, if convenient, mixture of free trade advocacy and protectionism. This
has much to do with the forthcoming presidential and congressional elections in
November 2000, and the "globophobia" felt by some core Democratic supporters.

For example, in the midst of his campaign for the Democratic Party's
presidential nomination, Vice-President Al Gore won the endorsement of the 13
million strong labour umbrella group, the AFL/CIO. In return, it seems, Gore
promised to act on union concerns about job losses.

Union boss George Becker said Gore had promised him he would change US trade
policy to protect US business and jobs if elected president.

David Smith, policy director for the AFL/CIO, argues that if the Clinton
Administration and trade advocates want to hold onto the consensus for
globalisation, they "should stop taking the credit for the `dog-eat-dog"'
character of the international

economy, and start working out how the benefits of freer trade can be better
shared.

Now Clinton is talking of putting a "human face" on globalisation and expanding
the "circle of winners" from trade. To head off accusations that the WTO is
secretive and an elitist club that makes rules to suit the rich countries, he
has promised a day of talks in Seattle where environmental, labour and other
lobby groups can meet international officials to have their say.

LOAD-DATE: March 21, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Two Illus: Free trade advocacy with a protectionist twist ...The US
wants to protect the `sensitive' peanut industry. Photos: AP, REUTERS Charlene
Barshefsky

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              521 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 October 3, 1994, Monday, Late Edition - Final

REPORTS DESCRIBE WIDESPREAD ABUSE IN FARM PROGRAM

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ

SECTION: Section A;  Page 1;  Column 3;  National Desk

LENGTH: 1344 words


Federal investigators have uncovered far-reaching fraud and mismanagement in the
Agriculture Department aid program that provides billions of dollars to farmers
who suffer crop losses in disasters like the Midwest floods of 1993 and
Hurricane Andrew in 1992.

Many farmers have collected excessive payments by inflating crop losses,
misstating the acreage they planted or failing to harvest crops when market
prices fell below the amount paid in disaster assistance, according to sweeping
new reports by the Agriculture Department and Senate investigators.

The inquiry by the Senate Agriculture Committee was limited to just eight crops
in nine states. Still, the investigators found $92.5 million in questionable
payments from 1988 to 1993. A draft of an unreleased committee report prepared
in August, which was obtained by The New York Times, said $80 million of the
total represented excess payments that appeared to be unrelated to disasters.

In one striking example, the owners of a farm received $200,000 in Federal money
for crop losses resulting from last year's Midwest floods although three weeks
before the damage they had paid only $138,000 for the property, including land,
a house and equipment.

The head of the aid program, Grant B. Buntrock, acknowledged in an interview
that he and other department officials were aware that serious problems existed
in the program and were trying to clean them up. He estimated that total
potential overpayments in 1992 and 1993 nationwide were $200 million to $300
million, or about 8 percent to 16 percent of the $2.4 billion paid out during
that period.

Mr. Buntrock said the problems were not always just with the structure of the
program. "Unfortunately, we have identified instances of complicity on the local
level in our offices," he said. "It was not the system itself, but the people at
the local level in these cases."

A confidential draft of a separate report by the Office of the Inspector General
at the Agriculture Department concluded that the agency did not analyze payment
data to determine where abuses were occurring and that it did not spot-check the
program to find fraud.

The report also said that penalties were too light to deter fraud. The only
penalty for abuse is the loss of payments for the crop year, which the report
said often represented only money to which the farmers were not entitled in the
first place.

"In a sense, producers have nothing to lose by making false certifications on
their disaster program applications," said the report, which was compiled under
the direction of the assistant inspector general for audit, James R. Ebbitt.

Since Congress expanded the disaster aid program in 1988, farmers have received
more than $8 billion. After the 1993 flooding damaged 20 million acres of
Midwestern farmland, Congress appropriated $1.6 billion to pay for crop damage
from the flood and other disasters.

At a hearing in April, the Senate Agriculture Committee heard testimony about
abuses, including information that squash producers in two Georgia counties may
have received almost $2 million in questionable payments. In response to that
hearing and the report resulting from it, the Agriculture Department's Inspector
General expanded existing investigations, hoping to gauge the extent of the
abuses.

The department's investigation focused on disaster aid in 1993 for specialty
crops in 17 states, but the Inspector General portrayed a program plagued by
systemic problems. The report did not calculate the dollar value of potential
losses or identify suspected abusers.

Fraud reduces disaster payments to the many farmers who actually suffered losses
because a finite amount of aid is available each year. From 1990 to 1992,
payments on disaster claims were cut in half because there was not enough money
to go around, according to a Congressional study, but fraud was only one factor
in that move.

Crop insurance bills passed by the Senate and House this year contain changes
that could save an estimated $187 million over five years by reducing fraud. The
two bills differ in some areas, and compromises are being discussed in the hope
of winning passage before Congress adjourns.

"Given the information in these two reports, it is absolutely critical that the
crop insurance reforms pass so that the same kinds of abuses never happen
again," said Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont, the Democrat who heads the
Senate Agriculture Committee.

Most of the disaster money is administered by the Agricultural Stabilization and
Conservation Service of the department. Mr. Buntrock, the administrator of the
conservation service, said his agency had been trying to develop programs and
regulations to clean up the problems.

"We take this very, very seriously," Mr. Buntrock said in a telephone interview
from Washington. "We are putting all of our available resources to work to
uncover past wrongdoings and make sure we have a system in place for going
forward."

The inquiries focused on producers of vegetables and fruits because they are not
regulated as carefully as larger crops, like feed corn and soybeans. Although
they are a smaller segment of the industry, these producers of specialty crops
received 35 percent of disaster payments in 1992 and about 20 percent last year.

The draft report by the Inspector General, which was completed on Sept. 16,
describes a litany of fraud and abuse that has proliferated with little apparent
scrutiny by the Agriculture Department.

Some abuse was by big farmers who understated income to qualify for payments.
The law prohibits aid to farmers with gross incomes in excess of $2 million a
year. But the Inspector General's investigators discovered that $620,000 was
paid last year to five farmers with incomes above $2 million.

One Missouri farmer received a $100,000 payment -- the maximum allowed --
although his income was $6 million. A California prune producer received $90,000
despite a gross income of $9.7 million, the department's report said.

In another example, the largest tomato grower in an Alabama county received a
$99,432 payment last year after declaring a drought on 152 acres, although he
had an irrigation system that he did not use. He stopped harvesting after the
price of tomatoes fell by 50 percent.

"The producer admitted he left some tomatoes in the fields because of low
prices," the report said.

Among the most common abuses were inflating the acreage planted and backdating
planting dates to get assistance once disaster aid became available. The
Inspector General's report said that 31 of 48 producers in a single Georgia
county provided inaccurate information that resulted in $1.3 million in
questionable payments.

The report said that officials in local offices of the Agricultural
Stabilization and Conservation Service often did not check data provided by
farmers and in some cases did not follow up on suspicions.

In some cases, the Inspector General's report raised questions about farmers who
served on the county agricultural service committees that established benefit
levels for disaster payments. In one Arkansas county, the report said, three
committee members were paid $225,779 in 1993 for losses on crops that were not
planted properly or irrigated.

The Agriculture Department fails to monitor the disaster program adequately or
examine data to look for patterns, like farmers who collect payments year after
year, the report said. Further, it said, the agency should impose civil fraud
penalties to increase the punishment for anyone caught abusing the system.

Mr. Buntrock said $15 million in overpayments made last year had already been
recovered and disciplinary action had been taken against local agency officials
in several offices. He said the legislation before Congress contained several
provisions that would enable the agency to develop new monitoring programs.

For example, Mr. Buntrock said the agency hoped to develop computer programs
that would let it compare planting and pricing records to identify trends in
abuse.

LOAD-DATE: October 3, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Chart: "HOW IT'S DONE: Turning Certain Loss Into Guaranteed Gain" shows
the Agriculture Department's report detailing one instance in which an Alabama
tomato farmer recieved almost $100,000 in disaster payments even after he chose
not to finish harvesting because of low prices. (Source: U.S. Department of
Agriculture)(pg. B12)

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Yogurt
Products Commodity Requirements Document"

LENGTH: 273  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Yogurt Products Commodity Requirements Document."

Solicitation no. AG-DPD-DYO1-Notice      Posted on: September 08, 2014

Notice Type: Special Notice

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Description:  Agriculture is a buyer of domestic origin food commodities for use
in various U.S. Government  food aid programs and, from time to time, issues
solicitations to purchase a variety of commodities. Specifications for commodity
purchases are generally published in Commodity Requirements Documents (CRD)
available on the Kansas City Commodity Office's (KCCO) website. Each
solicitation to purchase for  food aid programs will clearly identify the
requirements document applicable in accordance with FAR 11.201(b)


A CRD for Yogurt Products (DYO1), is being published today via this Federal
Business Opportunities (FBO) notice (see document package 1). The effective date
for DYO1 is June 04, 2014. Once effective it will be available with other
current CRDs on the commodity operations website at
:http://www.fsa.usda.gov/FSA/webapp?area=home&subject=coop&topic=pas-da

Set Aside: N/A

Deadline for All responses: N/A

Contact Details:  P.O. Box 419205
Mail Stop 8698
Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Contract Specialist
hilary.cole@kcc.usda.gov
Phone: 816-926-6645

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Yogurt
Products Commodity Requirements Document"

LENGTH: 269  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Yogurt Products Commodity Requirements Document."

Solicitation no. AG-DPD-DYO1-Notice     Posted on: May 27, 2014

Notice Type: Special Notice

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Description: Agriculture is a buyer of domestic origin food commodities for use
in various U.S. Government food aid programs and, from time to time, issues
solicitations to purchase a variety of commodities. Specifications for commodity
purchases are generally published in Commodity Requirements Documents (CRD)
available on the Kansas City Commodity Office's (KCCO) website. Each
solicitation to purchase for food aid programs will clearly identify the
requirements document applicable in accordance with FAR 11.201(b)


A CRD for Yogurt Products (DYO1), is being published today via this Federal
Business Opportunities (FBO) notice (see document package 1). The effective date
for DYO1 is June 04, 2013. Once effective it will be available with other
current CRDs on the commodity operations website at
:http://www.fsa.usda.gov/FSA/webapp?area=home&subject=coop&topic=pas-da

                                   USA TODAY

                    December 4, 1992, Friday, FINAL EDITION

Somalia: A land torn asunder

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 451 words


The more than 7 million Somalians have been living in the midst of civil war
since the overthrow of their president in January 1991. Here's a look at the
country:

Size comparison: About size of California

Ethnic background: Darot (north-northwestern), Hawiya (central), Rahanwein
(South) and Ishaak (north central) are collectively referred to as Somalis,
which is approximately 85 percent of the population. Those of Bantu derivation
make up about 14 percent of the population; Arabs and Europeans the remainder.

Population centers: (major cities) Mogadishu, Hargeysa, Chismimayu (Kismayu),
Berbera, Merca (Marka)

Civil War: Started in January 1991 with the overthrow of President Siad Barre
and has since intensified with Barre attempting to regain power and tribes
fighting each other for supreme power.

History: Somalia became an independent country in 1960, formed out of two
colonies, Somaliland (colonized by the British) and the Italian Somali
Protectorate.

Somaliland: Breakaway republic run by strongman Abdiraham Ahmed Ali Tur.
Comprises the former British colony of Somaliland.

Situation in Mogadishu: Two rival Hawiye factions of the United Somali Congress,
one loyal to Ali Mahdi and the other siding with General Aideed, remain locked
in a bitter power struggle. The city remains unstable.

Weather: May to October is the most pleasant period in Mogadishu due to the
southwest monsoon, a cool sea breeze. Dec. to Feb. (period of the northeast
monsoon) is also comfortable. There are ''Tangambili'' periods - intervene
between the two monsoons (Oct.-Nov. and March-May) are hot and humid.

Agriculture center: 25% of population lives between Giubba and Shabell rivers

Time difference with USA: 8 hours

Agriculture
Nomadic ranchers who raise sheep, cattle, goats and camels make up 60% of the
population. Bananas are the most important cash crop, along with livestock.
 Agriculture        82%

Industry/business 13%
Government          5%

Ready to land
The Pentagon has assembled a force of 27,800 to sweep into Somalia and launch an
effort to aid the starving population.

The force
Marines on ships           1,800

off Somalia
Marines from              16,000

Camp Pendleton, Calif.
Army infantry from        10,000

Fort Drum, N.Y.

Ships off Somalia
Tripoli with helicopters, Marines
Rushmore with helicopters, Marines, medical facilities
Juneau with helicopters, Marines

En route
Merchant ship carrying 600 vehicles - tractors, trailers, trucks and fork lifts;
water purification units, generators, fuel, supplies

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC, b/w, Marty Baumann, USA TODAY, Sources: USA TODAY research,
Associated Press, State Department, Europa World Year Book; Africa 1992; The
International Year Book; Africa; and The World Book Encyclopedia, Stand alone
graphic, Stand alone graphic (Map, Somalia, Pie chart)

MISSION TO SOMALIA

                      Copyright 1992 Gannett Company, Inc.

                              Journal of Commerce

                          November 14, 1991, Thursday

GRAINS ADVANCE ON OPTIMISM OVER EXPORT CREDITS FOR USSR

BYLINE: Wire and Staff Reports

SECTION: COMMODITIES, Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 479 words


Grain and soybean markets Wednesday moved higher on continued optimism that the
United States will offer the Soviet Union a credit package to buy U.S. grains.

Expectations that the United States would announce such a package this week has
been a feature of grain futures trading in the past few weeks, analysts aid.

However, many analysts believe the U.S.S.R. probably will not get outright aid
from the United States.

Short-covering and new speculative buying pushed corn and soybeans higher
Wednesday morning on anticipation of an announcement from President Bush on a
grain package to the Soviets that probably would not include aid money.

Wheat futures also were lifted by a slight cut in U.S. wheat stocks at the end
of the crop year stocks seen in Tuesday's U.S. Department of Agriculture crop
report.

However, both the USDA's monthly supply and demand and crop production reports
contained no bearish surprises.

Initial market bullishness followed a report in the Chicago Tribune Wednesday
morning that the president would announce $ 1.5 billion in credits and $ 500
million in food aid and medical assistance, which was denied by the Bush
administration later in the day.

The White House is seen likely to wait for the return of Richard Crowder,
agriculture undersecretary, from a visit to the U.S.S.R. before making a final
decision on credits. However, the size of the package mentioned cited by the
newspaper story is somewhat higher than the $ 1 billion the grains market has
been anticipating.

Meanwhile, the USDA's supply/demand report for U.S. 1991-92 wheat was deemed
slightly bullish because of tighter ending stocks. Some initial support was
offset by the USDA's increase in U.S. 1991 corn and soybean production.

The USDA placed U.S. 1991-92 wheat ending stocks at 514 million bushels next
October, down from its October estimate of 531 million and at the lowest level
in several years. Stocks in 1990 stood at 866 million bushels.

Wheat market support also reflected reports of additional moisture forecast this
week for hard red winter wheat areas, which is expected to weigh on deterred
futures contracts.

Overall tight wheat stocks in the United States will continue to prop up the
December 1991 wheat futures contract relative to the March contract, but there
is no indication that the nearby monthly will surge to a significant premium,
said John Kleist, director of research for Merchants Trading Co.

The ability of December futures to continue trading firm compared with March
this year is consistent with previous years of very low wheat stocks and heavy
government subsidies of U.S. wheat exports, he said.

About 80 percent to 85 percent of U.S. wheat exports now are subsidized by the
government. The USDA is likely to continue chipping away at its 1991-92 U.S.
wheat ending stocks estimate, Mr. Kleist said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                   USA TODAY

                              July 15, 2013 Monday
                                 First EDITION

Closing a gap at farmers markets;
Many slow to adopt technology to serve recipients of food aid

BYLINE: Meghan Hoyer, USA TODAY,

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 755 words


Getting healthy food to low-income households and children is a priority for
first lady Michelle Obama, but red tape, suspicion and a lack of manpower have
kept many farmers from selling fresh fruits and vegetables to thousands who need
them most.

Last year, the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced a $4 million
initiative to bridge what is often the biggest divide between farmers markets
and recipients of aid from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, the
successor to the federal food stamp program: the lack of technology at many
markets. SNAP uses electronic debit cards, so if a market can't accept credit
cards, it can't process SNAP purchases.

Despite the $4 million the USDA has pledged to get markets wireless debit card
machines, few markets have accepted the offer. By the time the program was
supposed to be wrapping up in late February, only $263,900 had been spent.

The issue comes at a time when proposed cuts to the overall food assistance
program are under debate in Congress. The House of Representatives last week
dropped food vouchers from a farm bill that traditionally has combined aid to
rural farms and food-buying assistance to the poor. Before the food aid was
stripped from the farm bill, a proposed 3% cut was under consideration. House
Majority Leader Eric Cantor, R-Va., said Republicans would "act with dispatch"
to get a food stamp bill to the House floor.

Today, of the nearly 8,000 farmers markets in the USA, fewer than half accept
food-voucher payments. At the same time, SNAP has grown significantly in recent
years -- more than one in seven Americans now receive government help to buy
food.

The number of direct-sales farms and farmers markets who accept SNAP has
quintupled -- rising from 750 to 3,824 -- over the past five years. But
officials say they need to do better.

"Our goal is to close the gap," said Kevin Concannon, undersecretary for Food,
Nutrition and Consumer Services at the USDA. "Low-income folks will often buy
foods that are calorie-dense. We want to try to nudge them in the direction of
farmers markets and purchasing healthy, less-processed foods. This is part of
that strategy."

Concannon acknowledged the agency started the process late, offering the
equipment last May, just as markets ramped up for the busiest part of their
season. Jan Walters, a member of the Farmers Market Coalition board who oversees
a national task force on SNAP, said some states didn't have the personnel or
administrative ability to promote the program and disburse the money.

Farmers said the paperwork and fees associated with the card machines, which
also accept bank debit and credit cards, often were too much, she said. Seven
states -- Arizona, Idaho, Iowa, Nevada, New Hampshire, Oklahoma and Pennsylvania
-- declined the funding outright.

Pennsylvania turned down nearly $180,000 because an earlier 2010 federal grant
left the state with a surplus of card-reading machines and not enough interest
from markets in using them. Sixty-seven machines are still available free to
qualified farmers markets across the state, said Donna Morgan, a spokeswoman for
the Department of Public Welfare.

"The people who use it, they say they like it," she said.

In May, USDA officials announced they were expanding the program so individual
farmers could apply for the machines. That, coupled with educational seminars
and a push on state departments to use the money, has made it more successful,
Concannon said. In the past two months, 330 new markets and farmers have signed
on.

He said the agency hopes to expand the funding and the program to help farmers
complete paperwork and get enrolled.

In the Paso del Norte region of Texas and New Mexico, La Semilla Food Center, a
non-profit that advocates healthful eating and supporting local agriculture, has
helped two New Mexico farmers markets this year get grants and complete the
paperwork to become approved to accept SNAP. El Paso's downtown market is on
track to join them later this year.

Aaron Sharratt, the organization's founder, said fast-food restaurants make up
half the eateries in the area. According to the Texas Department of State Health
Services, more than 73% of adults in the area say they don't eat enough fruits
and vegetables. Federal data show that low-income families eat less nutritious
food than the general population.

"The border region is pretty notorious for a lack of veggies and fruit in the
diet," Sharratt said, "but the interest and desire -- I think it's there."

Contributing: The Associated Press

LOAD-DATE: July 15, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: NEWSPAPER
