                               The New York Times

               September 15, 1992, Tuesday, Late Edition - Final

U.S. OFFERS RUSSIA AID IN BUYING FOOD

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE,  Special to The New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 6; Column 1; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 471 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 14


The Bush Administration offered Russia $1.15 billion in loan guarantees and food
aid today to help it buy American grain and livestock feed over the next six
months.

Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan said 30,000 export-related jobs and $3
billion in economic activity would be created by the credits and assistance,
raising immediate suggestions in Congress and among agricultural organizations
that the decision was primarily motivated by politics.

Two weeks ago, President Bush announced in the Midwest that he was authorizing
export subsidies for up to 30 million metric tons, or 1.1 billion bushels, of
wheat.

But one agricultural expert said today that if the Administration had wanted to
make a stronger impression on many farmers, officials would have found a way to
increase exports of meat or processed dairy products, which have a higher value.
Food processing also creates more jobs.

Who Will Benefit Most?

Russia has been offered up to 30,000 tons of pork at subsidized prices, but has
yet to buy any.

The package announced today consisted of $900 million in loan guarantees and
$250 million in food aid or other assistance.

Mike Dunn, vice president for government affairs at the National Farmers Union,
said it might have also come too late to help farmers on small holdings.

Mr. Dunn, whose union's political branch has endorsed Gov. Bill Clinton for
President, said in an interview that because most of the grains sought by Russia
had already been harvested, middlemen and not farmers would profit most.

"Announcing it this long after the harvest means a real boom for the export
companies, grain handlers and processors, with only a little dribble down to
farmers and ranchers," he said. "If this wasn't politically motivated, it could
have been more timely and helpful to family farmers."

In Congress, there is some concern about the ability of the Russians to repay
about $4.4 billion in credits outstanding now. Credits have a way of turning
into outright aid, a Congressional agricultural expert said.

Secretary Cites Russia's Need

According to the Agriculture Department, Russia will have access immediately to
$100 million in credits, which it will use to buy $66 million in feed grains,
$24 million in soybean-based protein meal and $10 million in wheat. Russia also
has $18 million in previous credit guarantees to buy wheat this fiscal year,
which ends Sept. 30.

The remaining credits will be released in two installments: $500 million on Oct.
1 and $300 million on Jan. 1.

"These measures will assure that United States agricultural exports to one of
our largest markets continue at a normal pace," Secretary Madigan said.
"Although Russian agricultural production is higher and reforms are well under
way, we know there is need for this kind of assistance."


LOAD-DATE: September 15, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

requirement for "Various Subsistence Items for use in U.S. Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: AG-INAP-S-16-0006

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: November 23, 2015

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue [the July solicitation for Foreign Agricultural Service
programs] solicitation AG-INAP-S-16-0006 (2000003735) for procurement of various
subsistence items for U.S. international food aid programs. The solicitation may
include various small business set asides pursuant to the Small Business Act (15
U.S.C. 631, et seq.). This may include partial small business set-asides,
service-disabled veteran-owned set-asides, quantities reserved for 8(a) and
AbilityOne firms, and price evaluation preferences for qualified HUBZone small
businesses. Deliveries are to various locations in the United States.

                       Tweed Daily News (New South Wales)

                             May 14, 2011 Saturday

By George, a life packed with adventure

SECTION: Pg. 14

LENGTH: 481  words



HIGHLIGHT: COMMUNITY CHAMPION


DR GEORGE Ryland, of Currumbin, has had an interesting life, from lecturing in
economics and statistics and international consultancy in agriculture during his
career to now volunteering as a driver for medical appointments and mentoring
international students.

Born at Innisfail, his family was evacuated in 1944 with the family coming to
Currumbin to live first at Garrick St, Coolangatta, and subsequently at Rutledge
St, Kirra.

He attended Coolangatta School from 1949. When his father was transferred with
the Commercial Bank of Australia to Brisbane in 1956 he attended Norman Park
State School and Brisbane State High School before going on to Gatton
Agricultural College.

He won a scholarship to the University of New England, where he studied
agricultural economics, graduating with honours.

He gained his Masters in Economics, majoring in statistics, and became a
lecturer at the University of Queensland in 1969.

He spent seven years there also gaining his PhD in Economics in 1975.

Dr Ryland then spent six months at the University of Illinois, near Chicago,
before returning to Monash University in Melbourne. He then had seven years as
chief economist in the agricultural department at South Australia. During this
period Dr Ryland was appointed by FAO of the UN to assist the UN Committee on
Food Aid in their tasks of allocating food aid to aid-dependent countries.

"I started my own international consultancy company in 1986 and travelled widely
throughout China and South East Asia," he said.

In 1995 he went to Tonga as an economic adviser and spent some time there as
acting secretary of finance in 1997. In 1998 Dr Ryland moved to Fiji to assist
in improvement in the revenue collection mechanisms, mainly through Fiji
Customs. He remained in Fiji until 2000, when the coup occurred.

"We came home and I retired to redevelop our original family block at Currumbin
Hill," he said.

Dr Ryland has been far from idle since retiring.

"I volunteered for the Kidney Network Service, transporting patients for
dialysis at Southport Hospital for seven years," he said.

He also mentored students at Palm Beach-Currumbin, Miami and Southport high
schools through the SCISCO scheme. He has been a driver for Uniting BlueCare,
operating out of Akirra Cottage, for three years.

Dr Ryland has been a member of Uniting Toastmasters at Elanora for eight years,
being at various times president, treasurer and secretary.

He is currently on the board of the Gold Coast Tenancy Advice and Advocacy
Service and is treasurer of that organisation.

He is a Griffith University mentor for international business students and coach
for students in the industry innovation program.

His hobbies are reading, swimming, attending the gym, walking, surfing and
visiting their grandchildren.

He has been married to Carole since 1968 has three children and five grandsons.

LOAD-DATE: May 13, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: DDN

                              All Rights Reserved


                              562 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                The Irish Times

                                 July 26, 2003

US food aid a form of export subsidy - Fischler

BYLINE: By SEAN MACCONNELL, Agriculture Correspondent

SECTION: CITY EDITION; HOME NEWS; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 588 words


The European Commissioner for Agriculture, Dr Franz Fischler, yesterday
challenged the US to show it was not using food aid as a form of export subsidy.

At a press conference in Dublin with the Minister for Agriculture and Food, Mr
Walsh, Dr Fischler said the US was using a lot of money on food aid and he
believed the system was a form of export subsidy.

Dr Fischler, who was flying to Canada for a meeting with 25 World Trade
Organisation members to prepare for the Cancun, Mexico negotiations on
agriculture, ruled out any further concessions on CAP reform.

The Commissioner, who will lead the EU negotiations on agriculture when the
round begins in September, repeated the assurance that European farmers could
not be expected to "pay twice", having reformed the CAP. He said there had been
a positive international response from outside the EU, particularly from New
Zealand.

On the package itself, Dr Fischler said the greatest criticism had come from the
dairy sector during his short visit here. "What the reform has done is to
provoke change in the dairy sector and this will be a good thing."

He said that while some countries may opt for the partial decoupling of direct
payments from animal and cereal production, they should be aware that the more
schemes that were decoupled, the more money would be available to farmers. "An
OECD report has found that decoupling all the schemes will double the money
which will be available to farmers," he said.

Earlier yesterday, the Commissioner met the Irish Creamery Milk Suppliers'
Association (ICMSA), which complained that calf and weanling producers would
lose under the decoupling arrangements.

ICMSA president Mr Pat O'Rourke said the Commissioner agreed to review the
income loss which calf producers could suffer and to have his officials look at
market and economic data the organisation would submit.

The Commissioner also heard complaints from the young farmers' organisation,
Macra na Feirme, whose president, Mr Thomas Honner, warned there was a danger
the new CAP deal could become a retirement package for older farmers with
substantial amounts of entitlements going to people who were not farming in any
serious way.

"These reforms will suit the 45 per cent of farmers who are over the age of 55
who may have no successor and see the new system as a mechanism to drastically
reduce production while retaining entitlements," he said.

The Commissioner also met the only farm group which fully supported his reform
package, the Irish Cattle and Sheepfarmers' Association, and thanked it for its
support and constructive contribution to the debate.

ICSA president Mr John Deegan impressed on Dr Fischler the need to ensure the
maximum number of member-states chooses the option to fully decouple supports.
"The gains that have been made during the recent CAP deal are now dependent on a
successful WTO round. Now is the time to go on the offensive against the USA in
the WTO talks. The USA has never been as vulnerable in its position now that the
EU has its own house in order following the recent CAP deal," he said.

The state of Irish agriculture

From Monday, Irish Times journalists will examine the state of Irish agriculture
in the aftermath of Commissioner Fischler's reform of CAP. In the first part of
a three-day series, Agriculture Correspondent Sean MacConnell will look at the
challenges facing Irish farmers as EU subsidies are reduced, while Liam Reid
will examine if organic farming has a future in Ireland.

LOAD-DATE: July 26, 2003

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Copyright 2003 The Irish Times

                            The Blade (Toledo, Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 16, 2012 Friday

$2M in U.S. aid targets algae in west Lake Erie

BYLINE: Ignazio Messina, The Blade, Toledo, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 590 words


March 16--DUNDEE, Mich. -- In an effort to combat the toxic organic sludge known
as blue-green algae, which has plagued western Lake Erie for years, killing fish
and hampering water recreation, the U.S. Department of Agriculture will be
handing out $2 million to farmers in three states.

Two U.S. senators, two congressmen, and U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom
Vilsack announced the plan Friday at Cabela's in Dundee.

The money is to be used to help farmers in designated parts of Ohio, Michigan,
and Indiana prevent phosphorus from entering Western Lake Erie Basin waterways.

Mr. Vilsack was joined by senators Sherrod Brown of Ohio and Debbie Stabenow of
Michigan, and U.S. Reps. Marcy Kaptur (D., Toledo) and John Dingell (D.,
Dearborn, Mich.).

The funding allocation is part of an effort to improve water quality and support
jobs in Ohio that are generated through the hunting, fishing, and outdoor
recreation industries tied to Lake Erie, Senator Brown said.

"A healthy Lake Erie is vital to Ohio's prosperity, and achieving this goal
requires a comprehensive, all-hands-on-deck strategy," Mr. Brown said. "These
new resources will enable farmers to employ the best conservation practices
possible and demonstrate how farmers can contribute to revitalizing Lake Erie
and the recreation, tourism, and boating industries the lake supports."

Applications for funding are expected to be available at local Natural Resources
Conservation Service offices by April 27.

Selected projects will pilot innovative new practices, such as biofilters and
controlled drainage, to address phosphorus runoff.

Mr. Vilsack said farmers and ranchers are on the front line of this
environmental concern.

"This funding will help farmers take necessary steps to improve and protect the
environmental health of the Lake Erie Basin, preserve habitat for the region's
fish and wildlife, and protect the over 100,000 jobs that Lake Erie helps
support," he said.

Mr. Vilsack also said the program would require farmers to use strategies proved
to capture phosphorus and that the efforts would be monitored.

Mr. Dingell said the region's access to Lake Erie has made it incredibly
attractive, and Lake Erie needs to be cleaned up as it was decades ago.

He said efforts to divert the water to other states would be blocked.

Senator Brown, a member of the Senate Agriculture Committee, launched "Grown in
Ohio," a listening session tour to get input from Ohio farmers, this year. Last
year, he invited Dave White, chief of the Natural Resource Conservation Service
at the U.S. Department of Agriculture, to visit the Western Lake Erie basin.

The algae bloom contributed to the "dead zone" in Lake Erie's central basin,
where fish can't live, and officials worry that it will threaten the lake's
tourism industry, valued at $10 billion and derived from counties along the Lake
Erie shoreline.

Blue-green algae, or cyanoÂ­bacteria, can excrete liver and nerve toxins that
can sicken animals and people who come into contact with it. Runoff of
fertilizer, manure, and sewage contributes phosphorus that feeds blue-green
algae.

Warning signs were posted at public beaches in eight state parks last summer,
including Maumee Bay and Kelleys Island on Lake Erie, and Grand Lake St. Marys
in west central Ohio. The state spent millions last summer fighting blue-green
algae in Grand Lake St. Marys.

Contact Ignazio Messina at: imessina@theblade.com or 419-724-6171.

___ (c)2012 The Blade (Toledo, Ohio) Visit The Blade (Toledo, Ohio) at
www.toledoblade.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

-targets-algae-in-west-Lake-Erie-0316-20120316

                              564 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             April 25, 2006 Tuesday

SECTION: DAKOTA WIRE

LENGTH: 309 words


Associated PressAssociated Press

Gov. John Hoeven and Agriculture Commissioner Roger Johnson are leading a group
that will lobby officials in Washington, D.C., for farm disaster assistance.

Hoeven and Johnson will be joined this week by representatives of numerous
agricultural groups and some state lawmakers.

Hoeven said farmers in the Red River Valley and the northern part of the state
need disaster aid for crop losses due to flooding last spring and summer. He
said there also needs to be improvements to crop insurance in the next federal
farm bill.

"One of the problems we've got now with the farm program is crop insurance is
inadequate," Hoeven said.

The group will meet with members of Congress to lobby for aid. Hoeven also
planned to meet with Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns on Tuesday.

Farm-state senators earlier this month attached an estimated $4 billion in
agricultural disaster money to a spending bill designed to pay for the Iraq war
and Hurricane Katrina recovery.

Rep. Earl Pomeroy, D-N.D., said the fate of disaster assistance likely will be
decided in conference committee.

"The House version doesn't have it in; the Senate version does," he said. "Can
we get House conferees to go along? I believe the governor's visit with ...
Johanns will also be extremely important."

Johnson, who is vice president of the National Association of State Departments
of Agriculture, said he will present a letter from the group to members of
Congress supporting the disaster legislation.

Johnson said a North Dakota State University Extension Service report shows that
farm profit in the Red River Valley last year fell nearly 50 percent, and in
northeastern North Dakota producers suffered an average 80 percent drop in net
farm income. Statewide, he said, small grains producers lost more than $150
million.

Hoeven, Johnson to lobby for farm disaster aid

LOAD-DATE: April 27, 2006

                                   USA TODAY

                     July 27, 1999, Tuesday, FINAL EDITION

Drought expected to drag into the fall

BYLINE: Gary Fields

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 601 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON -- The drought plaguing farmers in the Middle Atlantic
and portions of the South is expected to last through the fall
and could spread to other agricultural areas. Douglas LeComte,
senior meteorologist for the Climate Prediction Center at the
National Weather Service, says rainfall levels in some counties
in New York, Pennsylvania, Maryland, Virginia and West Virginia
are 15 inches below normal for the past 12 months.

As a result, dozens of counties in Pennsylvania, Virginia and
West Virginia are seeking federal emergency aid. Officials in
Maryland will meet next Tuesday to discuss the impact of the drought
there.


Ohio agriculture officials are doing preliminary assessments of
the 39 hardest hit counties to determine whether the state should
seek federal aid.

"The recent rains have helped, but we need a widespread blanketing,"
LeComte says. "We'd be happy to see remnants of a tropical storm."

Without it, "we'll see this lingering into the fall," he says.
"It's hard to end a drought in the summer."

Other potential problem areas that forecasters have begun to watch
are parts of Texas, Oklahoma, Arkansas and Missouri.

"It's been dry there, and now they are getting higher temperatures,"
LeComte says.

Despite the difficulties being created by the drought, officials
with the U.S. Department of Agriculture say there is no indication
that prices for produce will be affected.

That's because the areas hit are not the primary crop producers.

"The impact is local and regional," says Al Peterlin, the chief
meteorologist for the Department of Agriculture. "In those places,
it's as dry as they've been since the 1930s. We're talking the
Dust Bowl and The Grapes of Wrath."

But, he says, the center of the country -- the primary producer
of wheat, corn and soybean -- has gotten the right amount of rain
and is expecting plentiful harvests.

That means prices at the grocery stores will remain steady.

Peterlin says the combination of low prices and small harvests
in the drought-affected areas will create "a double whammy"
for the farmers in the hard-hit counties.

Mark Anthony, spokesman for the Ohio Department of Agriculture,
says prices for crops such as corn and soybean are at record lows.
"If you have a commodity with a low price on it, you at least
want to have a lot of it to sell."

Anthony says another critical issue from the drought is the damage
to grazing land. "We have pastureland drying up," he says.

Because there is no place for the animals to graze, cattle farmers
already are feeding them hay they had stored for the winter. Anthony
says farmers usually begin using their hay in November and December.

Now, farmers are auctioning off their animals. "They don't have
enough water and food to feed and water their herds, so they are
selling them and cutting their losses," he says.

Carl Anderson, an agriculture economist at Texas A&M University,
says that Texas went through a similar problem last year when
drought destroyed thousands of acres of grazing land.

The high cost of transporting huge amounts of hay led many cattle
farmers to sell their herds, he says.

The price of meat went down as a result, because there was more
available than usual for the summer and fall.

Now, Texas has a surplus of hay and is prepared to help others
who do not, Anderson says. "I talked to one guy last week who
said he had a couple hundred rolls of hay just sitting in the
field," he says. "Folks moved hay to us last year. We could
do likewise this year."

LOAD-DATE: July 27, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, B/W, John Gillis, AP; In Monrovia, Md.: Michael Wilcom scans his
damaged corn crop. State officials will meet next week to discuss the drought.

                         Portland Press Herald (Maine)

                   November 15, 2001 Thursday, Final Edition

U.S. AID PLANNED FOR MAINE SALMON FARMS;
Officials say the Bush administration will spend $16.4 million over two years to
fight infectious salmon anemia in Cobscook Bay.

BYLINE: JOHN RICHARDSON Staff Writer

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 723 words


The Bush administration has agreed to spend $16.4 million over the next two
years to fight a disease that threatens salmon farms in Cobscook Bay, according
to federal and state officials in Maine.

Federal veterinarians in Maine and Mass- achusetts reported the news through
phone calls and e-mails to a handful of state officials. A spokesman for U.S.
Sen. Olympia Snowe said the Office of Management and Budget had reached a
preliminary decision to help the industry and that the amount of aid may
increase.

The funding and technical help from federal scientists will be the first such
assistance for aquaculture operators, placing the young industry on par with
chicken and cattle farmers. And it will restore a measure of hope to Maine's
$100 million-a-year salmon industry and the struggling Down East communities
that rely on it.

"Clearly that's a very significant amount of money," George Lapointe, Maine's
marine resources commissioner, said Wednesday. "It helps the companies deal with
this massive economic blow and it helps all of the people who rely on this for
employment."

Outbreaks of infectious salmon anemia have forced farms in Cobscook Bay to sell
or destroy 900,000 fish this year in an effort to control its spread. Had the
fish all reached market size, they would have been worth an estimated $12
million.

Dozens of workers at salmon processing plants in Lubec and Eastport have been
laid off, partly because of the disease and partly because of the economic
downturn.

Despite quarantines and daily diver inspections, the disease remains a threat,
killing salmon as it sweeps through pens and coves. It is not a health risk to
humans.

The money may clear the way for the industry to remove the remaining 2 million
to 3 million salmon this winter in order to flush the bay and sanitize the
farms. Those fish represent an estimated $10 million investment by the industry.
Most would be too small for the market and would be disposed of at a landfill or
used in compost.

Fish pens would be sanitized and placed back into the bay over the following two
springs, with new controls to fight and contain the disease.

"That would be probably the best chance of getting this thing beat," said Steve
Ellis, a veterinarian with the U.S. Department of Agriculture who is based in
Augusta. Ellis said he received word of the funding level from the agency's
regional office in Massachusetts on Wednesday.

Without federal help, salmon farmers have said they could not afford to clear
the bay and start over.

The aid is expected to come with some guidelines and restrictions on how it is
spent. Those details were not known Wednesday, Ellis said.

The federal assistance also includes a team of experts in detecting and tracking
diseases. The USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, or APHIS, is
expected to come to Maine to assess the problem before any final decisions are
made about how to control the disease.

U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Ann Veneman, at the urging of Maine's
congressional delegation, agreed last month to seek $22 million in emergency aid
over two years. She sent that request to the administration's Office of
Management and Budget for final approval.

The OMB has not formally announced its approval and would not confirm the
reports Wednesday. An OMB spokesman referred questions to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture, where a spokeswoman said she could not confirm such a decision
until it is officially published in the Federal Register.

Members of the salmon industry received no official notification Wednesday.

"Obviously, if that's the case, then we are encouraged by their willingness to
support us," said Sebastian Belle, executive director of the Maine Aquaculture
Association.

Dave Lackey, spokesman for Snowe, said officials in the Department of
Agriculture confirmed the preliminary decision to assist the industry. The way
the information was released suggests that the actual amount of aid may still be
negotiable, he said.

"At this point, we need to be very pleased that OMB is making this investment,"
Lackey said. "It demonstrates the severity of the problem. It demonstrates that
aquaculture has arrived here in the United States."

Staff Writer John Richardson can be contacted at 791-6324 or at:

jrichardson@pressherald.com

LOAD-DATE: November 15, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                 Copyright 2001 Blethen Maine Newspapers, Inc.


                              570 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                April 29, 1983, Friday, Late City Final Edition

FARMERS LOOKING TO A TOP NONHARVEST

BYLINE: By SETH S. KING, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 12, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 1148 words

DATELINE: HUXLEY, Iowa, April 24


Middle Western farmers are a bit happier this week, certain that they will have
cash or its equivalent in hand this fall, no matter what the weather or the
grain markets do.

An estimated 70 percent of them will not plant some portion of their land this
spring. In return for participating in the Reagan Administration's new
payment-in-kind and acreage-reduction program, they will receive corn from
Government-controlled stocks for most of what they do not plant and will get
cash allotments for part of the remainder that they leave idle.

They know that the Government's latest plan for limiting grain and cotton
production will do little to reduce the huge grain surpluses that are slashing
farmers' profits. But by not planting part, or in some cases all, of their corn
land, they will save money now and have grain to sell when the harvest ends in
October.

Nationwide, more than 36 percent of the land normally planted in wheat, corn,
cotton or rice will be left idle. The Agriculture Department expects
participating farmers to save more than $2 billion in operating costs, though at
the expense of the companies that provide their planting supplies.

$20 Billion in Aid This Year

For the fiscal year 1983, before the effects of the payment-in-kind program will
be felt, the Agriculture Department was originally expecting all commodity aid
programs to cost more than $18 billion.  This is being revised upward, and a
total cost of more than $20 billion for this year is now projected.

In 1982 all farm commodity aid was a little under $12 billion, and in 1981 it
was slightly more than $4 billion.  But for calendar year 1984, with so much
land going out of production, the department is hoping these costs will drop to
about $6 billion. Private analysts disagree, figuring that next year's cost for
wheat and corn supports alone will exceed $13.7 billion.

Although livestock feeders, like Orville Kalsem and his sons John and David,
will get little directly from the program, they say it has already given farmers
a psychological lift.

The Kalsems feed more than 2,000 beef cattle each year, using the corn they grow
on 550 acres near this village in central Iowa.  ''This new p.i.k. thing won't
directly help us cattle feeders, and it shouldn't have any effect on beef prices
this summer, and it shouldn't make any difference on what a steak will cost at
the grocery,'' Orville Kalsem said.

'Get Money in Circulation'

''But it's going to get some money in circulation this fall, which always helps
the meat business because people can buy more,'' he said. ''And it's going to
bail out a lot of young grain farmers who are too far in debt for comfort.''

In Jefferson, two counties west of Huxley, the impact of the payment-in-kind
program was even more positive.  Like many other small communities in the corn
and wheat areas of the Middle West, Jefferson has suffered severely from the
recession.  The merchants who depend on the farmers for business have been
barely hanging on the last two years. Small industries, most of which make farm
equipment, have laid off many workers.

But now more than 37 percent of the corn land in Greene County, one of the
richest grain areas in the world, will not be planted as it usually is in the
next two or three weeks, when the rain-soaked fields should be dry enough to
plow.

Nearly three-quarters of the county's farmers are in the paymentin-kind and
acreage-reduction prorgrams to some extent. Some will leave idle the entire
acreage they normally plant in corn.

Can Sell or Store Gift Corn

Consequently, on Oct. 15, when the harvest should be in, all of them will be
given corn amounting to 80 percent of what they would have grown on these fallow
acres. They can sell this corn or store it, at the Government's expense, for
five more months.

Later they will receive cash payments for the corn equivalent on an additional
10 percent of their acreage-reduction land.  And the farmers will not have to
spend money for seed, fertilizer and pesticides on those unplanted acres. Nor
will they have to worry as much about the weather turning bad.

The townspeople say economic recovery has not yet begun in Jefferson.  ''But the
mere prospect of the farmers getting that p.i.k. cash in October has made people
around the square feel a lot better,'' said Rick Moraine, publisher of The
Jefferson Herald. ''When that p.i.k.  money comes in, we expect to see a lot of
farmers buying again.''

Del Van Horn, a leading Greene County grain farmer, seconded this, saying, ''I
feel so damned much better than I did last fall, though I'm not real sure why.''


Enrolls All of Corn Land

Mr. Van Horn has enrolled 755 acres, all of his corn land, in the program. He
said he has already contracted to sell, at what he considers a favorable price,
most of the corn he will get in October. And he figures he will save several
thousand dollars in planting costs.

He was lounging in Hap Springer's farm supply store on the antique church pew
that local farmers use as a kind of complaint forum.  Mr. Springer said he was
pleased by the return of Mr. Van Horn's confidence, ''but not by what he'll save
on what he doesn't plant.'' ''I'm going to lose at least 40 percent of my gross
this year because of the p.i.k. program,'' he said. ''But I know the Government
had to do something, even if it hurts me. If they hadn't, we'd all be in twice
as much trouble this fall.''

Pioneer Hi-Bred International, the Iowa-based corporation that grows about a
third of the country's hybrid seed corn, this year expects to produce only 40
percent of what it usually does, a company spokesman said today.

Youths Will Lose Jobs

He also noted another negative effect of the p.i.k. plan: There will be no
part-time jobs for hundreds of youngsters in North Carolina, Michigan, Indiana,
Illinois and Iowa who last summer were paid $75 per acre for detasseling hybrid
corn plants. The youngsters last year earned more than $9 million.

Although Iowa farmers said this week that they were grateful for the temporary
benefits the acreage-reduction program offers, they were also well aware of its
limitations.

''It's a one year help, at best,'' said Max Naylor, another of Greene County's
leading corn and soybean farmers.  ''The programs won't do anything to increase
consumption of grain this year, which means the surplus won't be any lower or
average prices any higher until next year,'' he said. ''Right now we've got
excellent growing conditions almost everywhere. We may not be planting a lot of
land, but we can still pile fertilizer on what we do plant.

''So don't be surprised if we produce a 6 billion bushel corn crop this fall,''
he continued. ''If we do, we'll be right back where we were this year, wondering
what we'll ever do with it all. But right now, a lot of farmers around here
think Ronald Reagan is Santa Claus.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: photo of farmers in Huxley, Iowa

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                   February 2, 1999, Tuesday, JOURNAL EDITION

NATION IN BRIEF;
;
Florida cancels sale of drivers' photos to firm

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 05A

LENGTH: 512 words


Florida Gov. Jeb Bush has canceled the sale of state driver's license
photographs to a private company as outrage over the release of millions of
images by motor vehicle officials in several states continued to build.
Thousands of drivers in Florida, South Carolina and Colorado have contacted
their governors, legislators and other officials to complain about an effort by
Image Data LLC of Nashua, N.H., to build a national database of driver photos
and personal images for use in a new anti-fraud service for retailers. But after
learning about the arrangements, thousands of residents complained they were not
informed. And many expressed fears about their privacy and the security of the
company's databases.
 Bell Atlantic, IBM offer futuristic home wiring You're at work. Suddenly you
get the nagging feeling that you might have left the stove on at home. You could
drop everything and drive back home, or you could use your office computer to
check your home electronic system. The futuristic option is being pushed by Bell
Atlantic Corp. and IBM Corp. in a deal being announced today, the Baltimore Sun
reports. The companies are teaming up to market a pricey home wiring system that
prepares residences for the latest in Internet, television and audio technology
as well as such goodies as home security and automated climate control.  The
Home Director system, costing from $ 900 to $ 3,000, is available to new-home
buyers in Bell Atlantic's Maine-to-Virginia local telephone service region and
will be offered to existing homes by year's end.
 Air conditioning linked to listeriosis outbreak Federal investigators suspect
dust kicked up during summer maintenance on an air-conditioning system at Sara
Lee Corp.'s Bil Mar Foods plant in Zeeland, Mich., may have been the source of a
listeriosis outbreak that has killed 15 and sickened about 75 people in 16
states. The U.S. Department of Agriculture and the federal Centers for Disease
Control and Prevention are seeking the source of the bacteria in the meat
products.
 AIDS treatment urged during pregnancy Researchers trying to reduce the rate of
AIDS among the world's poor have found that giving mothers standard medicines
for just a week cuts the risk they will pass on the virus during childbirth by
more than one-third. ''Even if we start treating very late in pregnancy, we can
make a difference,'' said one of the researchers, Dr. Joseph Saba of the United
Nations AIDS program. He presented the results Monday at the 6th Conference on
Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections in Chicago.
 O.J. Simpson items to be auctioned online More than 100 items, including O.J.
Simpson's 1968 Heisman Trophy and his Buffalo Bills jerseys seized from his
Brentwood, Calif., home two years ago will be auctioned online Feb. 16. As many
as 10,000 virtual bidders will compete with those sitting in Butterfield &
Butterfield's Sunset Boulevard gallery. The auction will help satisfy a $ 33.5
million judgment in the civil lawsuit brought by the families of Nicole Brown
Simpson and Ronald Goldman.

LOAD-DATE: February 3, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Today's News

                    Copyright 1999 The Atlanta Constitution


                              572 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                     March 8, 1990, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

Helping the Soviets is not in our interest

BYLINE: Phyllis Schlafly, Guest columnist

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 10A

LENGTH: 396 words


Phyllis Schlafly is president of Eagle Forum and a columnist for Copley News
Service.

 ALTON, Ill. - Taxing Americans to send aid to the Soviet Union is a harebrained
scheme that could come only from congressmen who already proved their
insensitivity to the pocketbooks of the American people by voting themselves a
fat pay raise.

There are a hundred good causes right here in the USA more worthy of our tax
dollars than Mikhail Gorbachev.

The reason the Soviets are short of cash and don't have enough to eat is that
they have a socialist system.

Soviet agriculture falls 30% short of the nation's needs; shelves are bare and
people must queue up on long lines; such items as oranges and coffee are
unavailable at any price.

In the USSR, 25% of the labor force is in agriculture. The government owns 98%
of agricultural lands. The 2% in private hands produces one-fourth of the total
agricultural output.

When it comes to housing, 25% of Russian units have no running water, and
families typically share kitchens and bathrooms with neighbors in cramped
apartments. Russians have a 15-year wait for an apartment. Coal miners have to
strike to get soap to wash themselves. No wonder life expectancy is declining,
hoarding is a way of life, and the only market that thrives is the black market.

Gorbachev covets the fruits of capitalist prosperity to prop up his bankrupt
socialist system. Sending U.S. dollars into the bottomless pit of trying to make
collective farming and socialist industry marginally less wasteful is not only
unjust to U.S. taxpayers, but a betrayal of the rising expectations of the
captive peoples behind the Iron Curtain. Any U.S. aid would just go to line the
pockets and enhance the power of the socialist bureaucrats.

Gorbachev is still unwilling to abandon the essential element of his socialist
system - state ownership of industry and agriculture. This week's modest reform
to allow some limited small private business will not accomplish much unless it
is followed by a breakup of state industries still in the grip of communist
bureaucrats.

The best way the United States can help perestroika succeed is to do nothing and
let the inexorable demands of street demonstrators escalate until the lack of
food forces Gorbachev to accept private property and economic freedom.

The USA should praise perestroika but not pay for it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: PHOTO; b/w (Phyllis Schlafly)

TYPE: Opinion

Ribbon Label; FACE-OFF; FEEDING THE RUSSIANS; 2

SOCIAL MEDIA IDS:  http://www.facebook.com/pages/American-Lift-Aids
-Mobility-Specialist/234132453310158
https://twitter.com/TexasLiftAids

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY IDENTIFIERS * * * * * * * * * *
COMPANY ID: 18457693

* * * * * * * * * * COMPANY INFORMATION * * * * * * * * * *
EMPLOYEES:
EMPLOYEE RANGE:  Small (21-100 Employees)

GLOBAL SALES:  Yes
COUNTRY:  United States

* * * * * * * * * * DESCRIPTION * * * * * * * * * *
American Lift Aids is a distributor, manufacturer, and supplier focussed on
Chairs, Lifts, Platforms, Scooters, Seating, and 19 other Product & Service
categories tracked by NetWise Data. American Lift Aids does business in the
Agriculture, Automation, and Automotive Industries, as well as 17 other major
Manufacturing Industries. American Lift Aids has at least 2 business locations.

INDUSTRY TYPE: distributor; manufacturer; supplier; Other Electronic and
Precision Equipment Repair and Maintenance

* * * * * * * * * * MARKET AND INDUSTRY * * * * * * * * * *
NAICS CODES:
81121900
SIC CODES:
76990700

     ·    Chairs
     ·    Lifts
     ·    Platforms
     ·    Scooters
     ·    Seating
     ·    Solutions
     ·    Vans
     ·    Wheelchairs

     ·    Automotive Seats
     ·    Lifts
     ·    Platform Lifts
     ·    Platforms
     ·    Seats

     ·    Sliding Doors

     ·    Wheel Drives

     ·    Security Services

                                US Official News

                           December 1, 2016 Thursday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri)
Issues Solicitation for "Various Subsistence Items for use in U.S. Food Aid
Programs"

LENGTH: 200  words

DATELINE: New York


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Various Subsistence Items for use in U.S. Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: 12-1NFP-17-S-0004

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: November 30, 2016

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue [the July solicitation for Foreign Agricultural Service
programs] solicitation 12-1NFP-17-S-0004 (2000004430) for procurement of various
subsistence items for U.S. international food aid programs. The solicitation may
include various small business set asides pursuant to the Small Business Act (15
U.S.C. 631, et seq.). This may include partial small business set-asides,
service-disabled veteran-owned set-asides, quantities reserved for 8(a) and
AbilityOne firms, and price evaluation preferences for qualified HUBZone small
businesses. Deliveries are to various locations in the United States.



Set Aside: N/A

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205 Mail Stop 8698 Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s): Jessica Howlett, Senior Contract Specialist
jessica.howlett@kcc.usda.gov Phone: 8169261109


LOAD-DATE: December 2, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

LENGTH: 248  words

for "Various Subsistence Items for use in U.S. Food Aid Programs."

Solicitation no. AG-INMP-S-13-0011                 Posted on:  June 18, 2014

Notice Type:  Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Description:  USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue [the July solicitation for Foreign Agricultural Service
programs] solicitation AG-INMP-S-13-0011 (2000001618) for procurement of various
subsistence items for U.S. international food aid programs. The solicitation may
include various small business set asides pursuant to the Small Business Act (15
U.S.C. 631, et seq.). This may include partial small business set-asides,
service-disabled veteran-owned set-asides, quantities reserved for 8(a) and
AbilityOne firms, and price evaluation preferences for qualified HUBZone small
businesses. Deliveries are to various locations in the United States.

                          The Herald-Sun (Durham, NC)

                             June 15, 2004 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

N.C. farmers to get storm aid

BYLINE: Associated Press

SECTION: DURHAM; Pg. C3

LENGTH: 76  words


RALEIGH -- Farmers will receive $2.4 million in federal aid for fence repairs,
debris removal and farmland restoration after Hurricane Isabel last September,
state officials announced Monday.

The U.S. Agriculture Department's Emergency Conservation Program has agreed to
repay the state farmers, who applied for $8 million in program assistance
following the storm.

Eligible farmers will receive reimbursements of up to 64 percent of the cost of
approved work.

                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

                           February 10, 2008, Sunday

BUSINESS FACES

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P5D

LENGTH: 475 words


Law

Bowles Rice McDavid Graff & Love LLP has hired Robert Hogan and Erin Bailey to
the firm's Charleston office. Hogan, a law graduate of the College of William &
Mary, practices in professional liability, complex litigation, products
liability and insurance litigation. He has been an adjunct professor of
engineering law at Marshall University College of Information Technology and
Engineering. Bailey, a law graduate of Emory University, practices in trusts and
estates.

---

Legal Aid of West Virginia has hired Jennifer Jordan as resource development
director. She earned a master of arts degree in public policy from West Virginia
University and had worked for Terrell Ellis & Associates and the West Virginia
State University Gus R. Douglass Institute for Agricultural, Consumer,
Environmental and Outreach Programs.

Banking

First State Bank has promoted Tina Wellman and Tanner James. Wellman, a First
State employee for five years, is now branch manager at the bank's Huntington
branch. She had been a customer service representative. James is now full-time
personal banker, having been a part-time personal banker for a year.

Higher education

West Virginia State University Gus R. Douglass Institute for Agricultural,
Consumer, Environmental and Outreach Programs has hired Mary Legg as its rural
business services program coordinator, responsible for Fayette, Greenbrier,
Nicholas, McDowell, Mercer, Monroe, Pocahontas, Raleigh, Summers, Webster and
Wyoming counties. Legg is a graduate of West Virginia University with a bachelor
of science degree in animal and veterinary sciences and has worked for the state
Department of Agriculture in Oak Hill.

Telecom

U.S. Cellular has promoted Bertram Daniels to area sales manager for West
Virginia, Maryland and Pennsylvania. Daniels has worked for U.S. Cellular since
2003 and had been interim area sales manager. Before joining the company he
worked in management at Kmart Corp. and Montgomery Ward Co. Daniels has a
bachelor of science degree in business management from Benedict College in
Columbia, S.C.

Engineering

Chapman Technical Group has hired Amy Farnsworth as the receptionist for its
Buckhannon office, Ashley Starcher as a computer-aided designer specializing in
architectural work in its St. Albans office and Matt Deal as a civil engineer in
the St. Albans office. The architectural and engineering firm has offices in St.
Albans, Buckhannon and Martinsburg.

E-mail announcements of hires, promotions, elections and awards received from
outside your organization to gazette@wvgazette.com, attaching photographs in
JPEG format. Make sure that e-mail submissions allow for content-copying.
Submissions can also be mailed to Business Editor, The Charleston Gazette, 1001
Virginia St. E., Charleston, WV 25301, and text-only items can be faxed to (304)
348-1233. Call (304) 348-5179 with questions.

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                    September 1, 1989, Friday, DAILY EDITION

U.S. ponders expanded food donations to Poland

BYLINE: United Press International

SECTION: SECTION 3, THE MARKETS; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 208 words

DATELINE: Washington,D.C.


  U.S. President George Bush is considering an expanded emergency food aid plan
for Poland, Senate Republican leader Robert Dole said yesterday

''There are a lot of things they need, but primarily it's food,'' said Dole, who
visited Poland last week and then briefed Bush on the trip. ''I don't think
people are starving, but they want to fill the shelves.'' He specifically
mentioned products such as pork and butter.

Dole said Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter is ''looking at options'' and
Yeutter said yesterday that while no decision has been made on any additional
food aid, the idea of including pork in a proposal is ''on the front burner.''

The administration has already announced a food aid plan for Poland, including
products such as corn and butter. Pork would be a addition.

Dole would not place a dollar figure on the plan.

Bush, during a July address to Poland's new parliament, proposed a
US$115-million aid package.

However, since then, the non-communist government headed by Tadeusz Mazowiecki,
a former leader of the once-banned Solidarity trade union, has been formed and
the Bush administration has come under pressure to show the U.S. is firmly
behind the pro-democracy movement.

                              The Washington Post

                    July 30, 1986, Wednesday, Final Edition

Drought Disaster Aid Asked for 34 Va. Counties

BYLINE: By Donald P. Baker, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: Metro; B1

LENGTH: 798 words


Gov. Gerald L. Baliles asked the federal government yesterday for disaster aid
for 34 Virginia counties, including Loudoun, Prince William and Fauquier,
because of "unabated drought conditions."

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng, acting on an earlier Baliles
request, yesterday declared farmers in 17 other Virginia counties eligible for
low-interest federal loans and reduced prices on livestock feed.

Baliles said that in the 51 counties, "Our crops -- corn, hay, soybeans,
vegetables -- will lose 47 percent of their value," or about $200 million.

Maryland Gov. Harry Hughes also appealed to Lyng yesterday, asking him to "cut
through the red tape" at the Department of Agriculture in processing requests
for disaster relief for farmers in 21 of Maryland's 23 counties.

"More needs to be done," Hughes said in a letter to Lyng, adding that one-third
of Maryland's farmers are in financial difficulty and that "at least 10 percent
may encounter financial ruin."

Drought damage in Maryland has reached $118 million, or about one-third of the
cash annually received for crops in the state, Hughes said.

Throughout the rain-starved Southeast, drought damage is estimated at $1.9
billion.

Hughes called on the Agriculture Department to "consider free feed assistance"
by giving "government-owned grain, stored at government expense," to needy
farmers. He said low-interest federal loans are "likely to help few farmers, due
to stringent eligibility requirements."

Baliles also asked Lyng to "determine what other action USDA can take to assist
Virginia farmers and livestock producers to acquire necessary hay and feed."

He noted that farmers in declared disaster areas must qualify for loans on an
individual basis and that "given the existing heavy debt loads held by many
farmers, another loan may be little or no help."

In Prince William County, hay and pasture lands are suffering the most. "We lost
the first and second cuttings, and you just can't make that up," said Neal
Vines, an area farm management agent for the state cooperative extension
service.

Because of the parched pastures, Vines said, farmers have resorted to feeding
cattle with hay that had been set aside for the winter. Others are buying hay,
but "at $100 a ton delivered, you have to push a pencil hard to make that pay,"
he said.

Some farmers are selling calves at lighter weight and culling heavy cattle from
their herds in an attempt to retain enough forage to carry them through the
winter, he said. "But with grain, there's nothing to cull. You just have to take
your lumps and hope for better next year," Vines said.

Virginia agriculture officials estimate that 58 percent of Prince William's
normal agricultural production, valued at $3.1 million, has been lost. In
Fauquier, losses were estimated at $11.6 million, or 63 percent.

Corn is the big cash crop in most Virginia counties, and except for some fields
that were planted late and benefited from recent rains, it is too late for help,
officials said.

"It's all gone now; the damage is done for this year," said Gary Hornbaker, the
agriculture extension agent in Loudoun County, where damage to the 500 full-time
farmers is estimated at $11.1 million, or 56 percent of normal production.

"Farmers say it's as bad as the '30s because it got so dry so early," Hornbaker
said.

Because Loudoun is contiguous to one of the 17 counties -- Clarke -- declared a
disaster area yesterday, it will automatically qualify for relief; 37 other
counties will qualify in the same manner.

Baliles said that 12 of the 34 counties for which aid was sought yesterday still
need to qualify. Also, 15 counties that did not request aid have qualified under
the contiguous-area policy. State officials are assessing damage in eight other
counties whose boards of supervisors have requested help since Friday.

The Virginia Department of Emergency Services is discussing with the federal
Small Business Administration the possibility of getting economic injury
assistance for businesses that have suffered losses as a result of the drought.

The Virginia Department of Agriculture has set up a toll-free telephone number
-- (800) 552-1833 -- for farmers who need hay. Persons who want to donate hay
and feed are asked to call (804) 786-3947.

"Americans usually show their best when times are toughest, and now is no
exception," said Baliles in announcing "a true act of kindness" from farmers and
business leaders in Bucks County, Pa., who plan to deliver hay to Virginia on
Saturday.

The hay is to be distributed at the Southside Market in Blackstone on a
first-come, first-served basis, with a 50-bale limit.

Hughes' press secretary, Hirsh Goldberg, said Hughes will announce a series of
state initiatives tomorrow to aid farmers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Map, no caption, THE WASHINGTON POST

                              Chicago Daily Herald

                          November 17, 2010 Wednesday
                                   L2 Edition

Help support global agriculture efforts

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 16

LENGTH: 555 words


Help support global agriculture efforts

One in six people around the world goes to sleep hungry every night. This is a
global emergency which has significant impact on health, education and work
productivity in Africa and other parts of the world. This Thanksgiving season,
as it's customary to look back and be thankful for what we have, I hope many
would consider joining me in sharing our good fortune as Americans by helping in
the global fight against poverty and hunger.

Investing in agriculture is one of the best ways to combat extreme poverty.
According to World Bank estimates, growth in the agriculture sector is twice as
effective at reducing poverty as growth in other sectors. Smart aid targeted at
agricultural development is far more effective and less expensive than emergency
food response. We must not wait for another food emergency before we act.

In addition, investing in agriculture in Africa is an investment in Africa's
women. Women produce nearly 80 percent of Africa's food, and more than
two-thirds of African women are employed in agriculture. When women earn money
they feed their children and send them to school, directly improving health care
and education in their families and in their communities.

This week I called Sen. Durbin and our newly elected Sen. Kirk to ask for their
support in protecting the proposed $1.3 billion for global agricultural programs
as part of the FY2011 budget. This is the kind of aid that would ensure that
less aid is needed in the long run -- it will help Africa help itself.

I still plan on giving to a local food bank, I care about the problem of hunger
in the Chicago area, but I'll know that I've also made a difference in the
global fight against poverty. Please join me and call your senators today.

Tzviatko Chiderov

Glenview

Keep tax funds away from Wrigley fixup

It sure didn't take long to come begging, and now the Ricketts family wants the
taxpayers, and it will be the taxpayers, to pony up $200 million bucks to
renovate Wrigley Field. The money is to be paid back with higher ticket and
concession prices.

The Ricketts family paid somewhere around $850 million to buy the Cubs. Maybe if
they check under the couch cushions in their homes they can find enough to
finance their own remodeling job.

Timothy D. O'Reilly

Chicago

You are free because of their sacrifices

This morning you woke up and were able to choose from a myriad of newspapers to
read that tell you what is happening in our world, what good (and bad) our
nation's leaders are up to, what our favorite sports teams did.

After reading the paper you headed off to your job, or maybe you started a new
business or you did something else you were free to do. Maybe you wrote a letter
to your congressman or senator, or you wrote a letter to the editor of your
local paper, or you stood on a street corner telling people about something you
feel is wrong with this country.

You were able to do all of those things -- and more -- because of a veteran who
stood up and fought against an enemy who thinks that our way of living is
immoral or unjust or too free. Find a veteran to thank. Buy him or her a coffee
or a meal. Ask veterans to tell you about their service or how their families
and friends supported them while they supported us. To all of you who gave so
much for all of us, thank you!

Bill Tucker

Palatine

LOAD-DATE: November 17, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              595 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     The Post-Star (Glens Falls, New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            June 24, 2009 Wednesday

Senator calls for help for farmers

BYLINE: Nick Reisman, The Post-Star, Glens Falls, N.Y.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 633 words


Jun. 24--U.S. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, D-N.Y., plans to introduce legislation
she said will provide temporary aid to dairy farmers reeling from historically
low wholesale milk prices.

The measure would double the amount of money producers receive from the Milk
Income Lost Contract, a program designed to help dairy farmers recoup losses
during periods of low wholesale prices.

The measure, she said, is estimated to cost $200 million. It would be
retroactive to March 2009, around the time milk prices began their most recent
decline.

At the same time, Gillibrand is also calling for a series of hearings to reform
the archaic milk pricing structure that she said is broken.

She plans to hold a special committee meeting of the Senate's Agriculture
Committee in August in Batavia.

"Clearly, the system is not working," Gillibrand said in a conference call with
reporters Tuesday afternoon. "The cyclical prices do not reflect cost of
production. There's no correlation between the price our farmers pay and the
price we pay at the supermarket."

Farmers receive payments for the milk they produce based on the hundredweight,
which equals 100 pounds of milk. A healthy wholesale price is considered to be
$19 or more per hundredweight. The price stands at $13.33 and has fluctuated
wildly over the past five years.

Agriculture advocates are concerned the recent price decline, combined with the
economic recession, will drive smaller dairy farmers out of business.

Gillibrand acknowledged any change in pricing policies would be fraught with
disagreements between milk haulers and states with huge dairy operations.

"We're going to look at the whole chain," Gillibrand said. "We want to make sure
this works for everyone."

The goal is to have a fairer pricing structure in place for the 2012 Farm Bill,
a massive agriculture bill passed every five years by Congress.

In the meantime, Gillibrand is also hopeful the additional funds for farmers
would be approved by the end of the summer.

"We're making sure that when we do give funding for farmers we're giving it to
the small farmers," she said. "I would like to do it before the break because
our dairy farmers are hurting."

Gillibrand said she has asked to meet with U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom
Vilsack, the former governor of Iowa, to discuss the issue.

New York Farm Bureau spokesman Peter Gregg said the expansion of aid to farmers
isn't a cure-all.

"But every little bit helps," he said.

As for changing the way the pricing system works, Gregg said it is long overdue.

"It's very cumbersome and outdated by many people's opinion," he said. "As an
industry, we need to take a look at it and have different solutions."

Sandy Buxton, a farm business educator at the Washington County Cornell
Cooperative Extension, agreed that increasing aid to the program, commonly known
as MILC, is a short-term solution.

"The MILC thing is a Band-Aid," Buxton said. "But in times of desperation, it's
better than nothing. The risk we take is basically trying to spend ourselves to
a better position."

Farmers are finding it increasingly difficult to reduce costs, as bills and debt
continue to increase.

Regular funding from the government earmarked for farmers struggling to pay off
debt and everyday bills dried up earlier this year, Buxton said.

"It's not possible for farmers to cut back enough," she said. "You have to
borrow money just to pay your bills."

To see more of The Post-Star, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.poststar.com Copyright (c) 2009, The Post-Star, Glens Falls, N.Y.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

LOAD-DATE: June 26, 2009

ACC-NO: 20090624-GN-HELP-FARMERS-20090624

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: GN

                              596 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     July 18, 1981, Saturday, Final Edition

U.S. on Verge of Initiating Food Aid;
Administration Is on the Verge of Initiating Food Aid to Poland

BYLINE: By Murrey Marder, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A1

LENGTH: 1182 words


The Reagan administration is on the verge of initiating emergency food aid to
Poland, and is exploring the question of possible parallel East-West long term
support to salvage the shattered Polish economy.

Sources in the administration and in Congress confirmed yesterday that both
approaches to the crisis in Poland are under serious consideration.  The
question of emergency food credits to Poland is awaiting President Regan's
decision, and will require some form of congressional action.  The broader issue
of possible loans or credits for Poland in the multibillion-dollar range, by
contrast, is in the most preliminary stages of exploration.

In its unique Communist Party Congress this week, Poland is searching
precariously for a degree of democracy that can provide Poles with greater
freedom and simultaneously forestall the threat of Soviet intervention to crush
Poland's year-long experiment in reaching for new freedom within the Communist
bloc.

Informed sources said the long-term problem in Poland may be discussed in a
preliminary way at the economic summit conference in Ottawa next week.  Even
raising the question of possible parallel East-West efforts for long-term aid to
a foundering Communist economy is virtually unprecedented since the Soviet Union
blocked Czechoslovakia from entertaining the Marshall Plan after the end of
World War II.

It is improbable, several administration officials said, that the heads of
government meeting in Ottawa can do much more at this stage than underscore high
western interest in the fate of Poland.  At this stage, no one -- including the
Soviet Union -- can forecast with certainty what will emerge from the current
Polish Communist Party Congress, one senior official said.  "Nobody will make
any commitments," he said, "until we know where the Poles are going."

Several members of Congress said yesterday that Secretary of Agriculture John R.
Block has now "signed on" to a plan to authorize supplying Poland with 400,000
tons of corn in new credits under the Commodity Credit Corp.'s program.  The
cost of that grain, intended to provide emergency food to Poland and to prevent
the collapse of its American-stimulated chicken breeding industry, was
previously said to be $80 million.  An administration official said yesterday
that a recalculation of the cost now puts it at $60 million.

In Columbus, Ohio, where Block yesterday addressed the annual convention of the
National Corn Growers Association, he limited himself at a press conference to
stating that the question of emergency corn aid for Poland "is being discussed
at the highest levels of government."

House Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Clement J. Zablocki (C-Wis.) said in
mid-afternoon that "is is my understanding that just today the secretary of
agriculture has okayed the emergency shipment." However, Zablocki said, "there
is a problem that has to be resolved on the floor of Congress, by legislation or
by [evidence of] legislative intent" to clear the legal barriers to send the
corn to Poland.

A prime mover in the campaign to obtain new food aid for Poland, Rep. Edward J.
Derwinski (R-Ill.), said "the whole administration is now on board" for the corn
shipment.  What is under way, Derwinski said, is "a politically
non-controversial approach to the Polish problem." He added that in this
process, "I do not see anything that would provoke Soviet reaction," and in
addition, providing new food aid for Poland "also conforms with [American]
agricultural interests."

"I am very optimistic" that the Reagan administration will carry through the
food commitment for Poland, Derwinski said.  The intention to do so, he said,
will be supportive of Poland's political reformers at a very delicate time for
the future of Poland.  State Department officials said they fully agree.

Another advocate of emergency aid for Poland, Rep. Paul R. Findley (R-Ill.) who
is a member of the Foreign Affairs and the Agriculture committees of the House,
said that "if it requires legislation, we will try to get it through as a
separate piece of legislation." To wait until the new agriculture bill reaches
the floor, as some others suggested, Findley said, means waiting "until
September" and then entangling the Polish issue in the "highly complex" and
controversial legislation on American agricultural.

Administration officials at all levels generally declined to talk for the record
at this time on what they are discussing about possible long-term remedies for
Poland's massive economic dilemma.  Poland's new economics minister, Zbigniew
Madej, said in his first public address earlier this month that Poland faces a
grueling struggle for at least five years in order to get back to its 1978 level
of national income.  "Unless we start on economic reform immediately, from
today," he said grimly, "nothing can save us from catastrophe, from a total
breakdown of our economy."

Various ideas are being canvassed inside the administration about possible
western efforts to help salvage the Polish economy.  All of them, as one
official said in private, "are based on the assumption -- the expectation --
that the Soviet Union will pay its share and that means at least 50 percent."
tPoland's current debt to the West is about $26 billion.  According to an
official American calculation, the Soviet Union during the past year extended to
Poland about $3 billion worth of financial and credit benefits, including debt
rescheduling, of which "something under $1 billion" was in "hard currency," and
the balance in "soft currency" benefits.

What some analysts within the Reagan administration are speculating about is
that in order "to save Poland from bankruptcy," in addition to the support in
might get from the Soviet Union and other Eastern European nations, it may need
something on the order of $1 billion to $2 billion of western loans and credits
for several years, perhaps five or more.

"This is all hypothetical," one authoritative official source emphasized.
Nevertheless, in embryonic form, specialists are beginning to "try to think
through the problem," as one expressed it, "even though there is no specific
plan worked out," and "no hard calculations can even be made" by anyone except
the authorities in Poland.

Some specialists think it improbably that the Soviet Union ever would agree to
permit an institution such as the International Monetary Fund to operate a
stabilization plan for Poland's economy; others argue, "what real alternative
does the Kremlin have, except [military] intervention?" And that, they
underscore, would "only compound the problem for the Soviet Union -- not solve
it."

Poland's current failure to meet its commitments to deliver goods and raw
materials to neighboring Communist nations already is seriously disrupting their
economic planning.  Soviet military intervention in Poland would not produce
more goods; it almost surely would produce less -- even at gunpoint -- western
specialists are convinced, with rippling consequences throughout the Soviet
bloc.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1981 The Washington Post


                              597 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            January 13, 2015 Tuesday

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Various
Subsistence Items for use in U.S. Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 227  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Various Subsistence Items for use in U.S. Food Aid Programs."

Solicitation no. AG-INFP-S-13-0013      Posted on: January 13, 2015

Notice Type: Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue [the July solicitation for Foreign Agricultural Service
programs] solicitation AG-INFP-S-13-0013 (2000001665) for procurement of various
subsistence items for U.S. international food aid programs. The solicitation may
include various small business set asides pursuant to the Small Business Act (15
U.S.C. 631, et seq.). This may include partial small business set-asides,
service-disabled veteran-owned set-asides, quantities reserved for 8(a) and
AbilityOne firms, and price evaluation preferences for qualified HUBZone small
businesses. Deliveries are to various locations in the United States.

Set Aside: N/A

Deadline for All responses: Feb 20, 2014 9:00 am Central

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205
Mail Stop 8698
Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s): Cita D. Trice,
Contracting Officer
cita.trice@kcc.usda.gov
Phone: 816-926-1438

In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com


LOAD-DATE: January 14, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                              All Rights Reserved

                                US Official News

                            September 8, 2014 Monday

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Various
Subsistence Items for use in U.S. Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 248  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Various Subsistence Items for use in U.S. Food Aid Programs."

Solicitation no. AG-INAP-S-13-0021      Posted on: September 08, 2014

Notice Type:  Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Description:  USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue [the July solicitation for Foreign Agricultural Service
programs] solicitation AG-INAP-S-13-0021 (2000001842) for procurement of various
subsistence items for U.S. international food aid programs. The solicitation may
include various small business set asides pursuant to the Small Business Act (15
U.S.C. 631, et seq.). This may include partial small business set-asides,
service-disabled veteran-owned set-asides, quantities reserved for 8(a) and
AbilityOne firms, and price evaluation preferences for qualified HUBZone small
businesses. Deliveries are to various locations in the United States.

Set Aside: N/A

Deadline for All responses:  Jun 11, 2014 9:00 am Central

Contact Details:  P.O. Box 419205
Mail Stop 8698
Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s): Debbie Martinek,
Contracting Officer
deborah.martinek@kcc.usda.gov
Phone: 8169266088

For more information visit:
https://www.fbo.gov/?s=opportunity&mode=0435636a29da1bd3ca5e676e9810d619&tab=cor
e&_cview=1. In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs
please contact: editorial@plusmediasolution.com

LOAD-DATE: September 8, 2014

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire


              Copyright 2014 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

subsistence items for U.S. international food aid programs. The solicitation may
include various small business set asides pursuant to the Small Business Act (15
U.S.C. 631, et seq.). This may include partial small business set-asides,
service-disabled veteran-owned set-asides, quantities reserved for 8(a) and
AbilityOne firms, and price evaluation preferences for qualified HUBZone small
businesses. Deliveries are to various locations in the United States.
