                              649 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           October 15, 2015 Thursday

New Mexico: NMSU's College of Agricultural, Consumer and Environmental Sciences
ranked sixth nationally as best value

LENGTH: 441 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Santa Fe: New Mexico State University, The State of New Mexico has issued the
following news release:



 New Mexico State University's College of Agricultural, Consumer and
Environmental Sciences took sixth place in a recent ranking by College Values
Online as one of the nation's best values among agriculture colleges.





 NMSU's Gerald Thomas Hall

 New Mexico State University's College of Agricultural, Consumer and
Environmental Sciences has been rated sixth in the nation as a Best Value
Agriculture College.



 The Best Value Agriculture Colleges ranking measured the top 30 agriculture
schools in the country by comparing each school's average 20-year net return on
investment as calculated and posted by payscale.com. The schools also were rated
on the cost of tuition, percentage of students receiving financial aid and the
number of agricultural programs available at the school.



 &ldquo;This ranking is a direct recognition of the hard work and effort as well
as the amazing dedication of all of the faculty and staff of the College of
Agricultural, Consumer and Environmental Sciences at New Mexico State
University,&rdquo; said Interim Dean Jim Libbin. &ldquo;It is also a major
tribute to the leadership of our former dean, Lowell Catlett, who led the
college during the decade before the announcement. We already knew this ranking
to be true, now the rest of the country and world know what a true gem the NMSU
College of ACES is.&rdquo;



 College Values Online noted that ranking the Best Value Agriculture Colleges is
relevant for students today when one realizes that agriculture is still one of
the largest industries in the United States. It noted that in 2010, $115 billion
in agricultural goods were exported from the United States, according to the
American Farm Bureau Federation.



 &ldquo;The agriculture industry doesn't just grow food. It also engineers food,
evaluates soil, finds ways to minimize environmental impact, develops new
methods for resource and energy conservation, and sells and markets agricultural
products,&rdquo; according to College Values Online. &ldquo;And that's just the
tip of the iceberg. The agricultural industry offers a huge number of career
options, and we want to connect you with the top 30 agricultural degree programs
that constitute the best value for your time and money investment.&rdquo;



 NMSU was rated ahead of numerous other larger universities, such as the
University of California, Davis ( number 20), Penn State (number 22) and
Colorado State University (number 26).



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com



LOAD-DATE: October 17, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH


              Copyright 2015 Plus Media Solutions Private Limited
                              All Rights Reserved


                              650 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                           August 15, 2007 Wednesday
                                  City Edition

Bush approves livestock disaster aid for producers excluded in earlier bill

BYLINE: Chris Casteel, Washington Bureau

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 4B

LENGTH: 289 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


WASHINGTON - President Bush has signed legislation co-authored by Sen. Jim
Inhofe that will ensure livestock producers affected by natural disasters in the
past few years are eligible to receive disaster aid approved by Congress earlier
this year.

The bill became necessary after the U.S. Department of Agriculture interpreted
the disaster aid legislation in a way that excluded all livestock producers who
didn't have Noninsured Crop Disaster Assistance coverage. Bush signed the bill
Monday.

According to the National Cattlemen's Beef Association, that interpretation
excluded the majority of the nation's livestock producers.

Inhofe said recently, "Oklahoma's agriculture producers have suffered serious
setbacks in the past few years from natural disasters. Due to USDA
interpretation of language currently in the agriculture disaster aid package, up
to 90 percent of those eligible for livestock disaster assistance would be
prevented from receiving aid. This legislative fix restores Congress' original
intent, providing needed disaster assistance to Oklahoma farmers and ranchers."

Rep. Frank Lucas, R-Cheyenne, authored an amendment to the farm bill passed by
the House last month to accomplish the same objective as the bill signed by
Bush.

The $3 billion in agriculture disaster aid was part of the wartime supplemental
spending bill. The assistance for livestock producers can come from the
Livestock Indemnity Program, for livestock losses, or the Livestock Compensation
Program, for grazing and other losses.

Livestock producers in counties that experienced a USDA-declared disaster can
apply for aid for losses in one of the past three years. Lucas said Oklahoma
producers were hit by  wildfires, drought and heavy snow.

LOAD-DATE: August 16, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


               Copyright 2007 The Oklahoman, All Rights Reserved


                              651 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                    July 16, 1993, FRIDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

CLINTON PLANS SUMMIT WITH EIGHT GOVERNORS DURING ST. LOUIS STOP

BYLINE: Charlotte Grimes Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 470 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


With eight Midwestern governors on hand, President Bill Clinton will convene
what amounts to a flood summit in St. Louis on Saturday.  The unusual gathering
is expected to include state and local disaster relief officials, as well as
members of Congress from the affected areas.  Details of Clinton's trip to St.
Louis were sketchy.  Several members of the Missouri and Illinois congressional
delegations are expected to attend. Among them will be House Majority Leader
Richard A.  Gephardt, D-Mo., Sen. Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo., and Rep. Jim
Talent, R-Chesterfield.  In a briefing with the bipartisan congressional
leadership and delegations, Gephardt said that Clinton had described the meeting
as "a blocking and tackling" session on flood relief.  Bond said that he hoped
"better communications" among federal, state and local officials would come out
of the session.  With Clinton's proposed $2.48 billion aid package, his
administration's overall response to the flood was winning praise Thursday from
flood-state Republicans and Democrats. And administration officials and members
of Congress predicted that federal spending is likely to quadruple - to between
$8 billion and $9 billion.  "We're going to have to have an additional package"
of disaster relief money, said Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill.  Clinton has left open
the possibility of asking for more money, White House spokeswoman Dee Dee Myers
said.  Bond and Sen. John C. Danforth of Missouri were among the Republicans
applauding the administration's handling of the disaster. The Federal Emergency
Management Agency, sharply criticized for its sluggish response to the
devastation left by Hurricane Andrew in south Florida last year, has "responded
very promptly" to the flood, Bond said. Danforth said Clinton has been "very
attentive" to the disaster.  Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy said farmers will
get the "lion's share" of their $1 billion in losses from the proposed $2.48
billion aid package. If Congress passes the package, he said, he also would have
the discretion to tap other agriculture department budgets. Even farmers who are
not in the federal crop insurance program will probably recover 50 cents on the
dollar of their losses through a variety of federal aid, Espy said.  Espy,
Simon, and James Lee Witt, head of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, all
predicted that the federal spending will reach $8 billion.  Clinton stressed
that the federal government won't be able to cover all the losses from the
flood.  "The federal government has never compensated natural disasters
dollar-for-dollar," Clinton said at a press conference after his meeting with
members of Congress. Some losses could be covered only by low-interest loans and
some federal aid also must be matched by state and local governments, he said.

LOAD-DATE: October 11, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1993 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


                              652 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   December 24, 1983, Saturday, Final Edition

Virginia Poultry Farmers May Get Aid for Animals Lost to Avian Flu

BYLINE: From news services and staff reports

SECTION: Metro; Around The Region; B2

LENGTH: 253 words


The office of Sen. John W. Warner (R-Va.) said yesterday advisers to the
Agriculture Department could recommend emergency aid for Virginia poultry
farmers who have lost animals to avian flu.

Warner spokesman Peter Loomis said the group is expected to meet next Wednesday
and could decide whether to declare an emergency in Virginia to move against the
low-strength avian flu.

A mild form of the virus has appeared in Rockingham County, where the state has
destroyed 11,000 turkeys, 36,000 turkey eggs and 24,000 chickens.

The flu claimed 5 million birds in Pennsylvania.

Meanwhile, Virginia state veterinarian George Estes said more cases of avian flu
will probably surface in the Shenandoah Valley.

He said he thought the state had the problem under control.

Estes said he did not expect an epidemic, but said he believed the virus has
been carried to other farms.

Gov. Charles S. Robb expanded a quarantine in an effort to contain the virus.

Warner said the state's congressmen were not seeking at this time to have an
emergency declared with the quarantine.

But Loomis said the advisers could recommend that U.S. Agriculture Secretary
John Block take steps to relieve the farmers who have lost birds to the flu.

Warner met with Virginia Agriculture Commissioner Mason Carbaugh, C.W. McMillan,
assistant agriculture secretary of animal and plant health inspection services,
and representatives of the Virginia poultry industry and Sen. Paul S. Trible Jr.
(R-Va.) and Rep. James R. Olin (D-Va.).

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1983 The Washington Post


                              653 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                      July 14, 1989, Friday, Final Edition

Senate Panel Mulls Drought Aid for Farmers

BYLINE: Arthur S. Brisbane, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A3

LENGTH: 547 words


A Senate committee considering drought aid for farmers yesterday heard accounts
of wildly varied weather conditions across the country -- from North Dakota
drought to Gulf States flooding -- amid indications that the Bush administration
may be softening its stand against broad-based farm relief.

Sen. Kent Conrad (D-N.D.), speaking a day after North Dakota Gov. George Sinner
(D) declared a statewide drought disaster, said spring wheat farmers there would
"shudder" to hear that federal assistance would be targeted at winter wheat, as
is proposed in legislation introduced by Sen. Robert J. Dole (R-Kan.).

"Clearly, there is a recognition that other crops besides winter wheat are going
to have to be addressed," Conrad said at the Agriculture Committee hearing.

While North Dakota is baking in dry 100-degree heat, some Gulf states are awash.
"We have had excessive moisture that would flood Noah's Ark," said Sen. John B.
Breaux (D-La.). "Some farmers can't even find the fields."

The hearing, scheduled to be followed by a committee vote on relief next week,
underscored a debate over the allocation of scant federal resources.

Dole, whose state is the top winter wheat producer, has urged Congress to
earmark available funds to protect winter wheat farmers. He argues that the
drought conditions of 1988 are only now being felt on the winter wheat crop and
that those farmers did not benefit from a $ 3.9 billion relief bill aimed at
adverse weather effects on 1988 crops.

Winter wheat, which comprises about 75 percent of the nation's wheat crop, is
planted in the fall and harvested the next year.

Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has sought to limit 1989 relief to winter
wheat, largely because aid for a wider range of crops could worsen budget
problems for the Bush administration. Yeutter opposes a House bill passed last
month to give out $ 1 billion in disaster aid for an array of farm commodities.

Recent climate conditions that threaten to damage crops other than winter wheat,
however, appear to have undercut the positions of Dole and the administration.

Yeutter, in comments to reporters after a closed-door session with Senate
Republicans Wednesday, said the volatile weather situation is unusual and added,
"We should be open-minded on the issues because of changes of circumstances."

Meanwhile, Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.) issued a call
yesterday for relief targeted at "all farmers who need it."

Citing USDA's July crop report, the chairman noted that corn production is
likely to be off this year and that cotton production is sharply down. "We have
a problem in more than just wheat," he said.

In general, analysts say drought conditions are not as severe as in 1988, which
was one of the worst droughts in the nation's history. But changeable weather,
combined with poor subsoil moisture attributable to last year's drought, leaves
open the possibility of more widespread damage to crops than has so far been
reported.

A study by the Congressional Research Service found that drought conditions this
year have undergone "a distinct westward shift" to the Great Plains, the western
Corn Belt, the mountain states, the Pacific Northwest and portions of North
Dakota, Idaho, Washington, Texas and Florida.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS

                       Copyright 1989 The Washington Post


                              654 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                            December 16, 2016 Friday

Farm Aid Supports New GIPSA Rule

LENGTH: 414  words

DATELINE: New York



 Atlanta: Growing Georgia has issued the following news release:



  The U.S. Department of Agriculture's (USDA) Grain Inspection, Packers and
Stockyards Administration (GIPSA) published a series of rules supporting poultry
growers farming under contract with major poultry companies. The trio of rules,
called the "Farmer Fair Practice Rules," address the long-criticized
"tournament" payment system for poultry growers, as well as promote fair
business practices and competitive environments to market livestock and poultry.





 The new regulations are as follows:



 o A rule to clarify that farmers are not required to prove that harms they have
suffered as a result of poultry company violations have also caused harm to
competition throughout the entire poultry sector.



 o A rule to define the term "undue or unreasonable preference or advantage" and
address practices like retaliatory actions against free association and free
speech that many poultry growers have experienced for speaking out against
company practices.



 o A rule to address the "poultry grower ranking" payment system, also called
the "tournament" system, used to force growers to compete against each other
based largely on factors that are controlled by the company and not growers.



 "The people who grow our food need a fair shake and the chance to make a decent
living," said Carolyn Mugar, executive director of Farm Aid. "The majority of
chicken that Americans consume is produced in an industry where the power of a
few giant corporations leaves farmers trapped in a rigged marketplace. We have
worked to tell their stories and are pleased to see this important step in their
fight for justice come to fruition." Mugar applauded Secretary Vilsack and those
who worked tirelessly at USDA "to ensure these critical protections for farmers
saw the light of day."



 Last week, Rural Advancement Foundation International (RAFI-USA) debuted its
documentary, called "Under Contract," on Capitol Hill with support from Farm Aid
, National Family Farm Coalition, National Farmers Union, the National
Sustainable Agriculture Coalition and others. "Under Contract" tells the stories
of poultry growers who have struggled with the current system, and shows why the
way that the U.S. does agribusiness must change in order to protect not only
farmers, but also the food supply, from industry abuses.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content needs please
contact: editorial@plusmediasolutions.com



LOAD-DATE: December 16, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

                  Wisconsin State Journal (Madison, Wisconsin)

                           November 25, 2006 Saturday
                                  ALL EDITION

STATE WILL GET DROUGHT AID

BYLINE: Nathan Leaf

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. D12

LENGTH: 137 words


Twelve northwestern Wisconsin counties have been declared eligible for federal
agricultural drought assistance, a state agency announced Friday.

The counties listed in the declaration are Ashland, Barron, Bayfield, Burnett,
Douglas, Iron, Polk, Price, Rusk, Sawyer, Taylor and Washburn.

Friday's announcement said the U.S. Department of Agriculture has allocated
$575,062 for Wisconsin. The money is for livestock producers who suffered forage
production losses.

How to apply

Farmers in the eligible counties can apply for assistance between Dec. 1 and
Jan. 5. To apply, farmers should go online to www.datcp.state.wi.us; e-mail:
center@datcp.state.wi.us; or visit a local county Farm Service Agency.
Applications must be returned to the state Department of Agriculture, Trade and
Consumer Protection and postmarked by Jan. 5.

                              659 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                             March 25, 2001, Sunday

Harkin gets input for farm-aid-bill; 'Freedom to Farm': Some think the future of
the family farm depends on it

BYLINE: ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Pg. a11

LENGTH: 443 words


LEWIS (AP) - Iowa farmer Bill Ortner thinks the future of the family farm
depends on the farm-aid bill Congress will develop to replace the soon-to-expire
Freedom to Farm Act.

"What you decide in the next five years on this farm program, in my belief, will
decide whether we have corporate farming in this country or whether we have
family farms," said Ortner, of Danbury.

Ortner was one of 125 farmers and members of agriculture groups who met with
Sen. Tom Harkin on Saturday at the Wallace Foundation Learning Center to discuss
the bill, set to expire next year. Congress plans to work on the proposal later
this year.

The next federal farm bill should offer farmers assistance based on farm prices
and income and give them more incentives to conserve land, agriculture groups
told Harkin, the ranking Democrat on the Senate Agriculture Committee.

"Although Freedom to Farm had its positive features, it has serious shortcomings
that's quite obvious," he said.

Many farmers have criticized the 1996 Freedom to Farm Act, saying it failed to
help them reduce their dependency on government aid and resulted in billions of
dollars in additional assistance.

In Iowa alone, government payments averaged 55 percent of the net farm income
from 1990 to 1999, said Mike Duffy, an Iowa State University agriculture
economist.

Payments to Iowa farmers in 1999 reached $ 1.8 billion while net farm income
only hit $ 1.45 billion, underscoring the importance of the payments to farm
income, Duffy said.

Farm state Democrats want to make farm subsidies counter-cyclical, meaning they
would vary with the condition of the farm economy. When prices are low, payments
would be higher.

Harkin said the bill will include a plan to expand federal conservation programs
and pay farmers to conserve tillage, soil, energy and water and manage pests.

Called the 'Conservation Security Program," it creates tiers of payments to
farmers - between $ 25,000 to $ 50,000 annually over five to ten years - to
practice conservation on their farms or ranches. Farmers already doing so would
also benefit.

Farm groups also said the next bill also needs to emphasize foreign trade
because officials failed to fulfill promises made in the last farm bill that
would have expanded trade and markets overseas.

"If these promises had been kept, the large government outlays that have been
required in recent years to support farm income may not have been needed," said
John Askew, president of the Iowa Soybean Association.

Harkin said the Senate would likely hold hearings on the bill later this year
and begin actual work on the legislation early next year.

LOAD-DATE: March 29, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        Copyright 2001, Telegraph-Herald


                              660 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    December 22, 1978, Friday, Final Edition

Potato Farmers Expecting Aid;
USDA Likely to Aid Potato Farmers

BYLINE:  By William H. Jones, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION:  Business & Finance; E1

LENGTH: 740 words


Special government aid of about $18 million to help potato farmers - now
suffering from sharply depressed prices in the wake of a bumper fall crop-is
expected to be announced today by the Agriculture Department.

Critics of the USDA move say the government support will only fuel inflation and
encourage some farmers to plant even larger crops next year, which could in turn
lead to another round of aid to the farmers in 1979.

Some investors in the commodities markets also may suffer from the potato
support plan - those who have speculated that prices will be lower than they
will be if the government steps in.

Members of Congress and White House aides concerned about the question of
inflation have become involved in the conflict, but concern about the plight of
potato farmers in Idaho, Oregon and Washington state is expected to override
worries about the economic impact.

Largely because of unusually good growing weather this year - "perfect moisture,
temperatures, and length of the harvest season," said one congressional aide -
Idaho produced a bumper crop of 97.3 million hundred - weight russet potatoes
this year, compared with 80 million in 1977.

Nationwide, the nation's stock of potatoes stands at a record 218.7 million
hundredweight, up about 6 percent from last year.  Earlier this fall, Maine
growers complained when they began receiving $3 a hundredweight for their crops
compared with $6 last srping, and the Agriculture Department authorized a $5
million program t "divert" part of the crop for cattle feed.

Sen. Frank Church (D-Idaho) subsequently led a delegation of his state's potato
growers to USDA in November, to seek a similar aid plan for western growers.  In
Idaho, it costs farmers about $3 to grow a hundredweight of potatoes, and the
current market price there for the best russets is $1.85-$1.90.

Reportedly, the western growers asked the Agriculture Department to divert 15
million hundredweight of potatoes, and the agency has agreed to a diversion
program involving 9 million hundredweight.

Sources said yesterday the USDA will permit farmers to sell their potatoes for
the cattle-feeding program at $2 a hundredweight for 30 days and $1.75 for the
next 30 days.  Idaho would be allocated 4.7 million hundredweight, Washington 2
million, Oregon 1.2 million and Maine, 0.3 million.

A spokesman for Rep. Al Ullman (D-Ore.), chairman of the Ways and Means
Committee, said yesterday that the congressman "always has considered potato
farming to be one of the last bastions of free enterprise and hates to see the
government involved."

But in one area of Oregon, the spokesman continued, farmers are in "bad trouble
. . . and to allow the farmers to get on an even keel, he won't oppose the
diversion ardently."

However, the aide said, Ullman has told Oregon growers and state officials "they
won't be able to rely on this next year . . . the government just won't be
there." Ullman has offered to help in cooperative efforts to reduce acreage
planted with potatoes, the aide added.

Another congressional staff member said the situation in 1978 is unique, and
that even if the same number of acres are planted next year it is unlikely to
produce the same bumper crop.  Many of the growers have bank loans that became
due Dec. 1, and selling under a government program at less than production costs
is "hardly a bailout but saving them from financial ruin," said a man familiar
with the Idaho situation.

The USDA aid would not come from the taxpayers but rather from a special
assistance fund for farmers financed by other government revenues.

A spokesman for the Council on Wage and Price Stability said yesterday his
agency has been in touch with USDA and "is evaluating now" data on the potato
diversion program.  The possible inflationary impact "is the obvious focus of
our concern and interest," he said.

Less clear is the potential impact on commodities speculators.  At least one
western commodities broker was here recently to talk to USDA officials, arguing
that the free market is the best way to allocate goods and urging that no
diversion program be approved.  The broker, who asked not to be identified,
denied that he represents investors with significant "short positions" on
potatoes futures - people betting that prices will remain low.

Another source said, however, that these "short" investors stand to lose up to
10 million if the USDA diversion's approved.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1978 The Washington Post

                       Grand Forks Herald (North Dakota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 19, 2013 Thursday

BRIEF: North Dakota counties eligible for disaster aid

BYLINE: Grand Forks Herald

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 147 words


Dec. 19--The U.S. Department of Agriculture declared an agricultural disaster in
31 North Dakota counties where farmers had major crop losses during the growing
season, the governor's office announced Wednesday.

The designation makes farmers and ranchers eligible for supplemental disaster
assistance and other federal programs.

Heavy snowpack, flooding, frosts and freeze damage and other problems prevented
North Dakota farmers from planting more than 4 million acres this year, the
state's second-largest amount of unplanted crop acreage in recent history.

Counties in the Grand Forks region eligible for aid include Benson, Cavalier,
Grand Forks, Griggs, Nelson, Pembina, Pierce, Ramsey, Rolette, Traill and Walsh.

___ (c)2013 the Grand Forks Herald (Grand Forks, N.D.) Visit the Grand Forks
Herald (Grand Forks, N.D.) at www.grandforksherald.com Distributed by MCT
Information Services

                    Prince George Citizen (British Columbia)

                             July 7, 2005 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Emergency aid among options in mad cow case

BYLINE: Canadian Press

SECTION: CANADA; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 546  words

DATELINE: KANANASKIS, Alta.


KANANASKIS, Alta. (CP) -- Canada's agriculture ministers hope to be ready with
an emergency aid program worth "hundreds of millions of dollars" if the U.S.
border closes to all beef imports following several court hearings later this
month.

Federal Agriculture Minister Andy Mitchell and his provincial counterparts began
three days of meetings Wednesday to devise plans for the worst-case scenario,
which Saskatchewan's Mark Wartman identified as the Americans rejecting all
Canadian beef exports.

"We want to make sure that we have some way of dealing with the build-up of
product there will be," said Wartman. "We will have to be able to support the
industry despite a shut-down of that magnitude."

Wartman said the emergency program, which would involve millions of dollars,
needs to be ready for the day that the U.S. judgments come down. He would not
give specifics, but said the cost would be split 60-40 with the federal
government.

Mitchell said Canada must be prepared for a whole range of possibilities,
including if a Montana judge extends the current ban on live cattle to include
boxed cuts of Canadian beef.

"We understand the importance of being prepared for any contingency," Mitchell
said.

"We're going to work very hard to make sure that we're prepared to deal with any
eventuality, and we don't want to have surprises."

Canada's beef industry, which has already suffered more than $7 billion in
export losses in two years since mad cow disease was first found on an Alberta
farm, is deeply concerned about two U.S. court dates in the coming weeks.

On July 13, an appeals court in Seattle hears a U.S. federal government appeal
of a lower court ruling in March that kept the border closed to live Canadian
cattle.

Two weeks later on July 27, a separate hearing over possibly closing the border
permanently to Canadian beef imports will be conducted in Montana by the same
district court judge who issued the March decision.

Dennis Laycraft of the Canadian Cattlemen's Association -- one of several
industry officials who attended the ministers' meeting -- said there is a "great
deal of apprehension" surrounding the Montana hearing.

"We're facing some uncertainty because of one individual in Montana that's going
to make a ruling," he said. "Hopefully we'll see the legal process move in a
sound direction but we're also preparing for any eventuality so that our
industry will be able to move through this."

Currently forbidden to ship live animals over the border, Canada's beef industry
has been ramping up its domestic slaughter capacity and now ships more than
30,000 tonnes of meat to the U.S. each month, worth an estimated $135 million.

Canada's largest packers, including Tyson Foods and Cargill in southern Alberta,
have both increased their slaughter capacity to deal with the growing demand for
boxed-cuts of beef in the U.S.

But all this would change if the court hearings result in greater restrictions
placed on Canadian beef or closing the border entirely.

As such, the industry has been devising strategies to brace for further
hardship.

The "worst case" includes a proposal to immediately concentrate slaughter
capacity on cattle under 30 months, which would mean up to 18,000 older animals
a week would be bound for rendering plants or outright disposal.

LOAD-DATE: February 17, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC:
Photo: Canadian Press; Alberta Agriculture Minister Doug Horner speaks to the
media during a break at the agriculture ministers meeting in Kananaskis, Alta.,
on Wednesday. As a series of impending U.S. court dates casts Canadian beef
exports once more into question, provincial and federal agriculture ministers
gathered Wednesday to devise worst-case scenario plans. ;

                              664 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The Washington Post

                      July 16, 2000, Sunday, Final Edition

VOTES IN CONGRESS

SECTION: SOUTHERN MARYLAND EXTRA; Pg. M05

LENGTH: 825 words



The following is a report of how some major bills fared last week in Congress
and how Southern Maryland's representative, Steny H. Hoyer (D-5th District), and
Democratic Sens. Barbara A. Mikulski and Paul S. Sarbanes voted.


HOUS


EELIMINATING THE 'MARRIAGE PENALTY'

For-269 / Against-159

The House passed a bill (HR 4810) on Wednesday to eliminate the penalty that
occurs when married couples pay more income taxes than they would if filing
individually. While ending a "marriage penalty" for some couples, the bill also
benefits other couples who pay lower taxes--a "marriage bonus"--as a result of
their union. The cuts are to begin in 2001 and are projected to cost $ 182
billion over 10 years. The bill raises the standard deduction for all married
couples filing jointly from $ 7,350 to $ 8,880, or twice the deduction for
single taxpayers. It expands the 15 percent bracket for couples filing jointly
to cover incomes up to $ 52,500, several thousand dollars above the existing
bracket ceiling, and raises the Earned Income Tax Credit for low-income families
filing jointly. Of the 51 million joint returns filed in 1999, nearly half paid
a marriage penalty that averaged $ 1,141 per couple, and about 40 percent
received a marriage bonus averaging $ 1,274 per couple, according to the U.S.
Treasury. A yes vote supported the changes.

HOYER-NO


BUYING PRESCRIPTION DRUGS FROM CANADA, MEXICO

For-363 / Against-12

The House voted on Monday to permit individuals to buy U.S.-made prescription
drugs in Canada or Mexico for personal use, without interference from the U.S.
Food and Drug Administration. The vote denies the FDA funding to bring criminal
prosecutions during fiscal 2001 for such purchases. It occurred during debate on
a U.S. Department of Agriculture spending bill (HR 4461). In one price disparity
cited in debate, 100 capsules of Prilosec, a popular U.S.-made drug, cost $ 400
in Queens, N.Y., $ 184 in Canada and $ 107 in Mexico. A yes vote was to
decriminalize prescription drug purchases in Canada or Mexico for personal use.

HOYER-YES


THIRD WORLD DEBT RELIEF

For-216 / Against-211

The House voted on Thursday to more than triple the amount of Third World debt
the United States will forgive in a bill (HR 4811) providing $ 13.3 billion in
foreign aid in fiscal 2001. The amendment increased debt forgiveness in the bill
from a committee-approved level of $ 69.4 million to the full $ 225 million
requested by President Clinton. The additional funds are to be obtained from
foreign military aid accounts. Supporters of the bill said heavily indebted
nations in Africa and Central America need relief from high interest payments if
they are ever to reduce their poverty. They called it unfair to keep the poorest
nations pinned down by crushing debt incurred by corrupt regimes no longer in
power. Foes said that by cutting foreign military aid, the amendment could lead
to war and turmoil in the same countries it seeks to help. A yes vote supported
more than tripling U.S. debt relief to the Third World in fiscal 2001.

HOYER-YES


INCREASING GLOBAL FUNDING TO COMBAT AIDS

For-267 / Against-156

The House voted on Thursday to transfer $ 42 million from foreign military aid
to a World Bank program to fight AIDS primarily in Africa. The vote, which
occurred during debate on the fiscal 2001 foreign aid bill (HR 4811, above),
increased global AIDS funding to the administration-requested level of $ 244
million. A yes vote was to increase funding to fight AIDS in Africa.

HOYER-YES


SENATE


PHASING OUT FEDERAL ESTATE TAX

For-59 / Against-39

The Senate passed a bill (HR 8) on Friday to phase out the federal estate tax,
which, as a result of large exemptions, applies to about 2 percent of U.S.
inheritances. The tax is levied on farm and business estates above $ 2.6 million
and on other estates in excess of $ 675,000. The bill is projected to cost $ 28
billion over its first five years and $ 50 billion annually after 2010. Under
the bill, marginal rates would drop by one to five percentage points per year
between 2001 and 2009. The top rate, now 55 percent for estates above $ 3
million plus a 5 percent surcharge, would drop to 42.5 percent in 2009 before
vanishing in 2010. A yes vote supported phasing out the federal estate tax.

MIKULSKI-NO SARBANES-NO


DEMOCRATS' ESTATE TAX PLAN

For-46 / Against-53

The Senate rejected on Thursday a Democratic alternative to the Republican
estate tax repeal (HR 8, above). It differed mainly by keeping the tax but
applying it to only the wealthiest estates. It exempted from taxation the first
$ 4 million of farm and family-owned business estates and the first $ 2 million
of other types of estates. It was projected to eventually cost $ 19 billion
annually, compared with $ 50 billion a year for the GOP bill. A yes vote backed
the Democrats' estate tax plan.

MIKULSKI-YES SARBANES-YES



LOAD-DATE: July 16, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2000 The Washington Post

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                    September 18, 1992, Friday, City Edition

Suncoast Catholics send $ 450,000 in aid

SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; ANDREW DIGEST; Pg. 4B

LENGTH: 348 words

DATELINE: ST. PETERSBURG; FORT MYERS



Donations for hurricane victims in Florida, Louisiana and Hawaii totaled  $
450,000 from parishioners at 76 Catholic churches in the Diocese of St.
Petersburg, a spokeswoman said Thursday. Of that, $ 250,000 went to Miami;  $
50,000 to Venice; $ 60,000 to Lafayette, La.; $ 25,000 to New Orleans; and  $
15,000 to the Diocese of Houma-Thibodaux, La. The rest is going to Hawaii.

Southwest Florida

expects refugee influx

FORT MYERS - Southwest Florida may have escaped costly physical damage from
Hurricane Andrew, but the region is seeing a surge of hurricane victims from
Dade that may cost millions of dollars. Lee, Collier, Charlotte and Sarasota
counties estimate that up to 11,600 people will move to Southwest Florida in
the next 12 to 18 months, and those people will need everything from housing  to
food stamps. The influx is expected to cost the area $ 15-million to  $
20-million more for education, transportation, social services, health
services, law enforcement, capital improvements and water/sewer expansion.
Estimates were compiled for U.S. Rep. Porter Goss, R-Sanibel.

Briefly . . .

Insurers get deadline: State regulators Thursday gave insurance companies  until
Oct. 15 to get adjusters to every home and auto damaged by Hurricane  Andrew to
put an end to what anxious policyholders feared could be an endless  wait. The
deadline gives companies less than a month to complete the key stage  of claims
service but more than seven weeks since the storm produced a  projected 700,000
claims, a record for any natural disaster in U.S. history.

USDA promises quick relief: The Agriculture Department on Thursday promised  to
help farmers trying to rebuild after Hurricane Andrew, Florida's top  lawmakers
reported after a meeting in Washington, D.C., with Agriculture  Secretary Edward
Madigan. Attending the meeting were U.S. Sens. Bob Graham and  Connie Mack and
Gov. Lawton Chiles. Madigan told the Floridians that farmers  will not have to
wait months or even years for disaster assistance checks.

LOAD-DATE: October 15, 1992

                               The New York Times

               November 21, 1991, Thursday, Late Edition - Final

Why We Might Regret Grain Generosity

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 273 words


To the Editor:
 For some time, voices have been raised in the United States favoring massive
food aid to the Soviet Union, most notably the voice of Agriculture Secretary
Edward R. Madigan. True, Mr. Madigan's voice has been muted lately. But he has a
large constituency in favor of massive shipments of wheat, corn and soy beans.
The legislation for such is already in existence.

To explain: America's largess of grain can be given to any country of the
President's choosing at negotiated interest rates, with as long as three years
to pay, under the Commodity Credit Corporation Act.

Under this act, President Nixon enabled Soviet grain buyers to wipe out our
emergency wheat reserves in the single month of July 1972. A sharp increase in
United States food prices followed this grain-on-credit move.

Such dollar-denominated credits are guaranteed by the Commodity Credit
Corporation, which gets its funds from the Agriculture Department's annual
budget of more than $40 billion, financed by the Treasury. The recipient country
may be careful never to default on the loans. But the loans are continuously
additive to the Federal budget deficit, at least from one accounting year to the
next.

The Soviet Union is the largest importer of corn from the United States. Because
of unusual drought conditions in the corn-producing areas of the Midwest, the
United States corn harvest this year may be low. A massive offtake of corn and
other food grains and feed grains at this time, as under President Nixon in
1972, may cause a sharp increase in food prices at home.

BEVERLY KITCHING
Springfield, Ill., Nov. 5, 1991

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Drawing

TYPE: Letter

                   Copyright 1991 The New York Times Company

                              669 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                The Denver Post

                        May 31, 2002 Friday 1ST EDITION

Disaster area covers state Farmers in all counties now eligible for federal
loans because of drought

BYLINE: By Mike Soraghan , and Steve Raabe, Denver Post Staff Writers,

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A-01

LENGTH: 1112 words


WASHINGTON - Every last parched bit of Colorado real estate  has now officially
been declared a federal agricultural disaster  area because of the worst drought
in decades.

Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman added 60 Colorado counties  Thursday to the
four already designated. That will make farmers in  all of Colorado's 64
counties eligible for low-interest loans of  up to $ 500,000.

According to the U.S. Farm Service Agency, it's the first  time since 1977 that
all of Colorado has been declared a drought  disaster area.

Colorado's winter wheat crop has been especially hard hit,  with estimates of
losses greater than $ 80 million.

Farm experts view winter wheat as an important early  indicator of drought
impact because the crop is harvested in July,  months before fall-harvest crops.
Colorado is the nation's  fifth-largest producer of winter wheat.

'The wheat crop is in pretty bad shape,' said Wiggins farmer  Joe Westhoff. 'I'm
almost 55 years old, and I can't ever remember  a crop this small.'

Some Colorado farms enjoyed a good rain last week that  salvaged a bit of their
crop. Others received almost no moisture  and have begun plowing under hundreds
of thousands of acres of  wheat.

'Out here, it's dry in a good year,' said Colorado  Agriculture Commissioner Don
Ament. 'When you end up with a lousy  snowpack, it all comes to roost. I'm
telling you flat out there  are going to be some guys who are not going to be in
this business  next year.'

Four counties in eastern Colorado - Kit Carson, Lincoln,  Phillips and Yuma -
were declared drought disaster areas on May 2.  Of the 60 declared Thursday, 44
are 'primary' disaster areas,  while 16 received the designation because they
border primary  disaster counties. Among those are Denver County, which borders
  primary disaster areas in Adams and Jefferson counties.       'Farmers and
ranchers in Colorado are suffering from extreme  drought conditions, and we are
examining every available program  to assist during these difficult times,'
Veneman said. 'This  emergency assistance should provide some relief from these
  devastating losses.'

The U.S. Department of Agriculture has declared disasters in  10 other states,
including all of Arizona, 66 of Texas' 254  counties, seven counties in Kansas,
13 in South Dakota and four in  Idaho.

The interest rate on the disaster loans is 3.75 percent,  which could allow a
farmer who has lost a crop to plant another  one for the summer, said Lewis
Frank, a Logan County farmer and  state director of the Farm Service Agency.

The disaster designation also allow ranchers to avoid large  capital gains tax
payments if they have to sell off all their  cattle.

Officials said they can't predict how many of Colorado's  30,000 farms and
ranches will be eligible for disaster loans  because total financial losses
won't be known for several months.

Wheat farmer Westhoff said drought losses are compounded by  low market prices
for crops.

'We've got a poor crop, and the dang stuff isn't worth  anything, anyway,' he
said.

Westhoff said he's not sure whether he'll apply for loans.

'When farmers are having trouble paying off their existing  loans, do they
really want to assume more debt?' he said.

Ament stressed that although the aid may help struggling  farmers, many farmers
will still decide selling out is better.  Loans must be paid back. Other
emergency programs allow cattle to  graze on land set aside for conservation,
but the land usually  doesn't have fences to keep cattle in or stock ponds for
them to  drink from.

'I'm sensitive to people saying, 'The government's bailed  them out. The
problem's over,'' Ament said. 'If you're sitting out  there with two days of
feed left, and I say you can have some  low-interest loans, but there's a lot of
ifs, you'd look at it and  say, 'Hell with it. I'm going to the sale barn.''

But if Congress were to pass an aid package for  drought-afflicted farmers, the
aid would most likely be directed  to the counties that have been designated.
Drought aid was  stripped out of this year's farm bill before it was passed. But

  the $ 2 billion package was reintroduced as a separate bill in the  Senate.

Gov. Bill Owens had requested the aid, and lawmakers  such as U.S. Sen. Wayne
Allard of Loveland U.S. Rep. Scott McInnis  of Grand Junction pressed Veneman to
grant the aid. McInnis wrote  to the Internal Revenue Service on Thursday asking
the agency to  confirm that farmers in disaster areas who sell off their
livestock don't have to pay capital gains tax.

Veneman also announced Thursday that farmers and ranchers in  an additional 10
Colorado counties will be able to grow crops or  graze cattle on land they'd set
aside for conservation, said Sean  Conway, a spokesman for Allard. But they will
have to pay a fee to  use it.

The 10 new counties, which bring the total for the emergency  grazing program to
26, are Adams, Boulder, Crowley, El Paso,  Lincoln, Logan, Morgan, Otero, Routt
and Washington counties.

The idea, Conway said, is to prevent the massive sell-off of  livestock that has
been occurring in southeastern counties.

'Last week, the governor and I went to a sale barn in La  Junta,' Ament said.
'I'm telling you, you couldn't have squeezed  another critter in there.'

Who qualifies

Emergency loans may be made to farmers and ranchers who:

Own or operate land located in a county declared by the  president or designated
by the secretary of agriculture as a  disaster area. (For physical losses only,
the FSA administrator  may authorize emergency loan assistance.)

Are established family farm operators and have sufficient  farming or ranching
experience.

Are citizens or permanent residents of the United States.

Have suffered at least 30-percent loss in crop production or a  physical loss to
livestock, livestock products or real estate.

Have an acceptable credit history.

Can provide collateral to secure the loan.

Have repayment ability.

Producers can borrow up to 100 percent of actual production or  physical losses,
to a maximum of $ 500,000. Loans for crop,  livestock, and non-real-estate
losses must normally be repaid in  one to seven years. In special circumstances,
terms of up to 20  years may be authorized. Loans for physical losses to real
estate  are normally repaid within 30 years. In certain circumstances,
repayment may be extended to 40 years. The current annual interest  rate for
such loans is 3.75 percent.


LOAD-DATE: May 31, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              670 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

             September 20, 1986, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

PHILIPPINE AID PLAN FACING UNCERTAINTY ON THE SENATE FLOOR

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section 1; Page 4, Column 5; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 395 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19


A new package of economic aid for the Philippines, which the House of
Representatives approved Thursday within hours of President Corazon C. Aquino's
visit, faces an uncertain future in the Senate.

Unless the problems are resolved early next week, Senate aides said today, there
is little chance the $200 million in aid can receive final approval despite
support from the Reagan Administration.

Timing is important, because the $200 million must be not only approved but also
delivered to the Philippines by Oct. 1, when the new fiscal year begins and
stringent budget ceilings become operative. The money the House approved, by a
vote of 203 to 197, would be counted as a 1986 expenditure and so would escape
the new limitations.

Threats to the aid package, which is strongly supported by Senator Richard G.
Lugar, Republican of Indiana, the chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee,
came today from both sides of the aisle.

Senator Bob Dole, the majority leader, was notably cool to the proposal. Early
in the morning, the Kansas Republican pronounced it ''the biggest honorarium in
history'' and predicted there would not be an aid bill.

Senator Dole tempered those remarks later in the day, but only slightly, saying
he was ''taking a look at the possibility of some supplemental aid.''

At the same time, he noted that the budget was tight and that there were
''equally high priority demands for any additional funds we can scrape up.''

The other threat came from a Democratic Senator, John Melcher of Montana. He
said he would block the aid package unless it were linked to a donation to the
Philippines of $600 million in surplus agricultural commodities from Federal
stockpiles.

The expedited procedures needed to get the $200 million aid package through the
Senate give individual senators considerable leverage to derail the bill.

The surplus goods covered by the Melcher amendment are wheat, powdered milk,
cheese, butter and soybeans.

Senator Melcher said at a news conference today that a majority of the Senate
would support his amendment if the leadership let it come to a vote.

But the proposal is opposed by the State Department, Senator Lugar, and the
Philippine Government.

According to Mark Helmke, Mr. Lugar's spokesman, the sudden infusion of such
large quantities of agricultural products would ''destroy'' Filipino
agriculture.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1986 The New York Times Company

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                             January 1, 1999 Friday

U.S. AID TO FARMS IN STATE TOTALS $800 MILLION THIS YEAR

BYLINE: Lee Egerstrom, Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS TWIN CITIES; Pg. 6B

LENGTH: 437 words


Federal farm programs and disaster relief measures will have pumped nearly $800
million into the Minnesota farm economy this year as farmers and farm owners
wrestle with the effects of low crop prices, plant disease, weak export markets,
and surplus hogs and major grain crops.

Jim Meisenheimer, spokesman for the federal Farm Service Agency office in St.
Paul that administers U.S. Department of Agriculture farm income programs, said
$740 million in various aid payments and commodity loan program payments were
made before Christmas.

Agency employees in county offices were busy this past week processing more
commodity loan payments, and that work will continue into the new year, he said.

The aid and subsidies come as farm income for major field crop and livestock
producers fell sharply from a combination of factors. Disease plagued the wheat
and small grains crops in northwest Minnesota. Weak export demand from Asia
lowered prices for corn and soybeans. Weather caused damage to crops in several
counties. And farm income continues to be battered by record production of hogs
and by a new federal farm program that encouraged surplus production of grains
and oilseeds.

Most of the federal aid and subsidies paid to farmers and farm owners this past
year involved land and crops. As the year drew to an end, and with pork prices
at their lowest levels in more than 40 years, pork producer groups were planning
to ask Congress for a minimum pricing system for livestock production as well.

The largest federal income transfer to farmers and farm owners in 1998 was from
the Agricultural Market Transition Act, or AMTA payments. This money, totaling
$330 million, was authorized in the 1996 federal farm program as transition
money while other price support programs are being phased out.

Another $180.3 million has been paid to more than 97,500 owners of Minnesota's
approximately 83,000 farms in Loan Deficiency Payments (LDP), which is a
variation of the commodity loan programs of former farm bills that in may be
phased out in future years.

On top of that, the state agency has distributed $164 million in Marketing Loss
Adjustment (MLA) payments, which are special farm relief payments approved by
Congress shortly before the November elections.

Separately, the Farm Service Agency in Minnesota also made $65 million in
payments during 1998 to landowners who set aside environmentally fragile lands
in the Conservation Reserve Program.

Lee Egerstrom covers agriculture and food companies. He can be reached at
legerstrom@pioneerpress.com or (651) 228-5437.

LOAD-DATE: October 23, 2002

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             May 10, 2008 Saturday

'Early phase' drought declared

BYLINE: JONATHAN RIVOLI Bismarck Tribune

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 436 words


With a dry winter and spring leading to predictions of trouble ahead for
farmers, Gov. John Hoeven declared an "early phase agricultural emergency"
Friday afternoon.

The executive order sets the stage for up to $500,000 in state assistance to
farmers who need to buy water supply equipment for livestock and directs the
Drought Task Force to meet.

Later on Friday, Agriculture Commissioner Roger Johnson set a Wednesday meeting
for the task force to meet and strategize on how to deal with a drought.

Hoeven's declaration comes as many farmers across the state are planting their
crops and eyeing the dry conditions. It covers the entire state.

"I think growers across the state are very worried, especially in western North
Dakota," said Dan Wogsland, executive director of the North Dakota Grain
Grower's Association.

Wogsland said the "very abnormally dry" conditions, combined with very high
input costs, have farmers worried about what summer might bring.

According to the U.S. Drought Monitor, western North Dakota is one of three
regions in the country in extreme drought conditions, while all of the state is
classified as abnormally dry. The other extreme drought regions are southern
Texas and a span of the South stretching from northern Mississippi to eastern
North Carolina.

Dennis Feiken, a farmer near LaMoure, knows all about this year's drought.

Feiken, who grows corn and soybeans, said this is the driest spring he remembers
since he started farming 10 years ago. He said other farmers in his area who've
been at it longer than him are chatting about how its also the driest they
remember.

"It's a good thing they're doing this (aid) now because it could really get
critical later this summer," Feiken said.

The aid is still pending official approval from the State Water Commission,
which is set to meet Wednesday to make the decision. Eligible farmers would get
a 50 percent cost reimbursement from the state for permanent water such as
wells, tanks or solar pumps. The maximum eligible per project is $3,500 and the
maximum eligible projects are three.

Lance Gaebe, an aide to Hoeven who manages agricultural issues, said this is the
first time since 2006 that the aid has been activated. In prior years, only
farmers who had applied for federal aid were eligible, but that's no longer the
case, Gaebe said.

Those wishing to apply for the aid are urged to contact the State Water
Commission at 328-2750. Pending Wednesday's approval, an official application
will be posted on the commission's Web site at www.swc.state.nd.us.

(Reach reporter Jonathan Rivoli at 223-8482 or
jonathan.rivoli@bismarcktribune.com.)

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     July 27, 1988, Wednesday, City Edition

Drought-relief bill advances in House

SOURCE: Associated Press; Reuters

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 413 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON



WASHINGTON - The House Agriculture Committee approved a $ 5-billion
drought-relief bill Tuesday to help America's farmers cope with the    worst dry
spell in more than 50 years.

     The bill would provide up to $ 100,000 in disaster payments to    farmers,
increase aid for farmers worst hit by the drought, and raise    the U.S.
milk-support price by 50 cents per hundredweight.

     The legislation is expected to be brought to a vote Thursday by the    full
House.

     The Senate Agriculture Committee met Tuesday to discuss a    drought-aid
package. But the committee broke up without coming to an    agreement on a plan
to increase aid to farmers most severely affected    by the drought and is
expected to resume work today.

     House passage of the bill came after stern warnings from the White    House
to not clutter it with costly amendments that were not directly    related to
drought aid.

     In a letter sent to agriculture committee leaders Monday, President
Reagan said he was concerned about special-interest amendments in the
tentative relief bills adopted earlier this month.

     Administration officials have said they oppose the milk price    increase,
a provision expanding cash assistance to livestock producers    who don't grow
their own feed, and a new subsidy for ethanol producers    faced with higher
corn costs.

     As a potential tempest over drought relief brewed in Washington, a
report issued Tuesday said rains have relieved "drought stress" in    parts of
the Corn Belt, but that crops have shown little improvement.

     "The precipitation gave most crops a boost in the central and    southern
Great Plains, Delta and Southeast," the report by the Joint    Agricultural
Weather Facility. "Soil moisture improved but was still    mostly short in the
eastern half of the nation."

     In the central and eastern Corn Belt, rain during the week of July    18-24
may have come too late to improve corn harvest prospects, the    report said.

     Soybeans were reported in "mostly fair" condition but showed    little
improvement as a result of rain in the central and eastern Corn    Belt areas,
the report said. However, soybeans continued to improve in    the Great Plains.

     Livestock was reported in "mostly fair" condition.

                  Wisconsin State Journal (Madison, Wisconsin)

                           November 1, 2007 Thursday
                                  ALL EDITION

LOW-INTEREST LOANS FOR FARMERS

BYLINE: State Journal staff

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. E4

LENGTH: 217 words


Farmers in 42 Wisconsin counties affected by drought conditions over the summer
will be able to apply for low-interest loans and other assistance from the
federal government. The U.S. Department of Agriculture has approved Gov. Jim
Doyle's Aug. 13 request for a federal disaster declaration.

The counties declared drought disaster areas are: Adams, Ashland, Barron,
Bayfield, Brown, Buffalo, Burnett, Calumet, Chippewa, Clark, Door, Douglas,
Dunn, Eau Claire, Florence, Forest, Iron, Juneau, Kewaunee, Langlade, Lincoln,
Marathon, Marinette, Marquette, Menominee, Monroe, Oconto, Oneida, Outagamie,
Pierce, Polk, Portage, Price, Rusk, Sawyer, Shawano, St. Croix, Taylor, Vilas,
Washburn, Waushara and Wood.

Those counties had at least one farm with at least 30 percent in crop losses
caused by drought. Farmers in those counties may be eligible for financial
assistance.

In addition, farmers in adjacent counties may also receive aid. These counties
are Columbia, Fond du Lac, Green Lake, Jackson, La Crosse, Manitowoc, Pepin,
Sauk, Sheboygan, Trempealeau, Vernon, Waupaca and Winnebago. A disaster
designation will allow farmers in those counties to qualify for assistance,
primarily low-interest loans.

Farmers have until June 18, 2008, to apply for loans by contacting their local
Farm Service Agency office.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                    January 12, 1991, Saturday, City Edition

Keating still faces 34 charges

SECTION: NATIONAL; WASHINGTON DIGEST; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 554 words



A judge in Los Angeles dismissed 12 charges of fraud against Charles Keating and
three associates Friday but let others stand, to leave the former Lincoln
Savings & Loan Association owner still facing 34 counts. The four defendants are
accused of defrauding 23,000 investors, most of them elderly, out of $
250-million through the sale of worthless junk bonds. Keating's case entered the
national spotlight because of his relationship as a major political contributor
to five U.S. senators, and as a visible symbol of the failure of the savings and
loan industry. Superior Court Judge Lance Ito threw out the charges at the
request of the defense on the grounds that they were improperly filed. In
November, Ito set aside 22 of 46 charges against Keating and the others because
they were too vague. The prosecution was asked to resubmit them in an amended
form, which it did, adding more counts. At Friday's hearing, defense attorneys
argued that it was the job of the grand jury that had returned the original
indictments, and not the district attorney, to refile the amended counts. Ito
let stand 10 of the amended charges, meaning Keating and his co-defendants now
face a total of 34 counts.
 Red Cross denies AIDS rumors
 An official of the American Red Cross said Friday there was no evidence the
group's Washington office had accidentally spread AIDS due to sloppy handling of
blood donations. "Yes, we had problems" in the Washington regional office, which
has since been closed down, said Dr. Jeffrey McCullough, director of Red Cross
blood services. "But no one has ever received a transfusion of Red Cross blood
that tested positive for AIDS or hepatitis," McCullough told reporters. The Red
Cross was rocked in July when a Food and Drug Administration inspection turned
up some 230 reports of the possible transmission of AIDS through blood
transfusions donated to the Washington office, sparking rumors. Almost all of
the cases involved sloppy record-keeping on transfusions that occurred before
blood banks began routinely screening all donated blood for evidence of the AIDS
virus. The commercial test for screening donated blood began in March 1985.
 Briefly

    Food and Drug Administration official Carl Peck will temporarily oversee
AIDS-drug testing while the federal agency looks for a replacement for the
current chief, the FDA said Friday. Dr. Ellen Cooper, who has been the FDA's
chief AIDS drug reviewer since 1988, asked last year to be moved to a less
stressful position in the agency.
 Livestock owners who graze animals on public lands in the West will have to pay
8.8 percent more this year, the government said Friday.  Fees charged by both
the Forest Service, an agency of the Agriculture Department, and Interior's
Bureau of Land Management will rise 16 cents per "head month" beginning March 4
1. The monthly rate will be $ 1.97 per animal unit month, compared with $ 1.81
last year.
 Farmers have scaled back winter wheat plantings sharply from 1990, reacting to
abundant supplies and sagging market prices, an Agriculture Department report
showed Friday. The annual survey said farmers planted slightly more than
51-million acres of winter wheat for harvest this year, down 10 percent from
1990.

                              679 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    December 14, 1992, Monday, Final Edition

SECTION: METRO; PAGE D8; OBITUARIES

LENGTH: 719 words


EDWARD F. TENNANT

AID Auditor General

Edward F. Tennant, 75, retired auditor general of the Agency for International
Development, died Dec. 11 at his Silver Spring home after a heart attack.

He retired in 1973 after 20 years with the AID and predecessor agencies,
including four years as AID auditor general. After he retired, he was U.S.
representative in a controllers review and evaluation group at the
Inter-American Development Bank. He also was a consultant for the surveys and
investigations staff of the House Appropriations Committee.

A native of Staten Island, N.Y., Mr. Tennant moved to the Washington area in
1936. He received degrees in accounting from Benjamin Franklin University and
Strayer College. He also studied at the Industrial College of the Armed Forces.

He was an accountant at the Agriculture Department, Social Security
Administration and Office of Education earlier in his career. He joined the War
Assets Administration in 1946, and he later worked for the U.S. high
commissioner in Germany and the Defense Materials Procurement Agency in London.

After joining the State Department, he worked for the Technical Cooperation
Administration, Foreign Operations Administration and the International
Cooperation Administration. He was also deputy director and director of the U.S.
aid mission to Iran.

He received the AID's Distinguished Honor Award.

Mr. Tennant was a director of the American Red Cross Montgomery County chapter,
president of AID's Controller Alumni Association and a member of the Association
of Government Accountants, St. Bernadette's Catholic Church in Silver Spring,
Lakewood Country Club and the Maryland Intra-State Seniors Golfing Association.

Survivors include his wife, Anne Elizabeth Tennant of Silver Spring; a son,
Edward Francis Jr. of Bethesda; and a brother, John J. Tennant of Staten Island.

JEAN C. BYERS

NBS Technician

Jean Campbell Byers, 90, who had been a measurement glassware technician with
the National Bureau of Standards in the 1950s, died of a heart ailment Dec. 11
at the Knollwood retirement residence in Washington.

Mrs. Byers was a lifelong Washington resident. She was a graduate of Central
High School, where she had been a member of the rifle team, and the Corcoran
School of Art. She later taught private classes in ceramic art and jewelry
design.

During World War II, she was an artist-draftsman for the Army Map Service and
did volunteer work for the Red Cross.

Mrs. Byers was a life member and past officer of the Acacia Chapter of the Order
of the Eastern Star. She was a member of National Presbyterian Church in
Washington.

Her husband, Jason H. Byers, died in 1971. Survivors include two children,
Evelyn Byers Surles of Rockville and Donald J. Byers of Aldie; six
grandchildren; and three great-grandchildren.

WILBUR H. TURNER

REA Express Agent

Wilbur H. Turner, 76, a retired REA Express agent who was active in veterans'
groups, died of an aneurysm Dec. 1 at Shady Grove Adventist Hospital. He lived
in Rockville.

Mr. Turner was a Washington native and Central High School graduate. He served
with the Army in the Pacific during World War II. He worked for REA Express in
the Washington area for about 40 years before retiring in 1972 from its offices
at National Airport.

He was a founder and first commander of John M. Carter Post No. 9862 of the
Veterans of Foreign Wars in Gaithersburg. He also was a member of the American
Legion and its 40 and 8 organization.

Survivors include his wife, Berry Anne Turner of Rockville; two daughters,
Carolynn L. Shook of Pittsfield, Mass., and Regina M. Kukucka of Rockville; two
brothers, Arthur G. and Raymond E. Turner, both of Boca Raton, Fla.; four
grandchildren; and a great-grandson.

THEA M. BACCI

Alexandria Resident

Thea Marquardt Bacci, 85, an area resident since 1963, died of cardiac arrest
Dec. 11 at Mount Vernon Hospital. She lived in Alexandria.

She had accompanied her husband, Joseph A. Bacci, now a retired Army colonel, to
posts in Panama and Alaska.

Mrs. Bacci, a native of Burlington, Iowa, was a graduate of the Chicago Art
Institute. As a young woman, she taught art at a high school in Davenport, Iowa.

In addition to her husband, of Alexandria, survivors include a son, Joseph E.,
of Woodstock, N.Y., and a grandson.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: OBITUARY

                       Grand Forks Herald (North Dakota)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            April 29, 2015 Wednesday

EDITORIAL: Aggressive animal-health response can turn avian-flu tide

BYLINE: Grand Forks Herald

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 510 words


April 29--In one key way, Grand Forks lucked out with its monster flood. The
city had the great good fortune to flood in 1997, not 1987 or 2007.

And the timing made all the difference, because America had a balanced budget,
Bill Clinton was president, and the North Dakota congressional delegation had
the president and Congress' ear.

The federal aid that resulted left Grand Forks much better off.

Now, 2015 is no 1997, as far as the federal budget goes. Still, an argument can
be made that if America in general and Minnesota in particular had to endure an
avian flu outbreak, 2015 is better than a lot of the alternative years.

That's because both the budget and political situations are better now than they
have been for some time. And where responding to animal or human public-health
crises are concerned, healthy budgets and functional politics are huge.

The staggering outbreak -- and the mass euthanizations it requires, once a
turkey barn is infected -- has killed about a fifth of the turkey population in
Minnesota, which is America's leading turkey-producing state. The state
Department of Agriculture has responded vigorously, as have other state
agencies.

Meanwhile, the Minnesota House and Senate are coming to terms on massive amounts
of emergency funding.

Their task is made infinitely easier by the fact that Minnesota is running a
budget surplus, rather than suffering through shortfalls as had often happened
in the past 10 or 15 years.

In Washington, Sen. Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., is pressing for federal aid, in the
form of not only reimbursements for farmers whose flocks had to be destroyed,
but also research grants to agriculture schools such as North Dakota State
University.

Here's something that makes this aid much more likely: the fact that
"bipartisanship is busting out all over," as Michael Barone of The Washington
Post reports.

"Exhibit A is the Corker-Cardin legislation, passed unanimously in the Senate
Foreign Relations Committee, providing for limited congressional review of
negotiations with Iran over its nuclear weapons program. Exhibit B is the
legislation combating human trafficking, passed unanimously by the Senate last
Wednesday.

"Exhibit C is the elimination of the annual 'doc fix,' engineered by Speaker
John Boehner and House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi."

Such an atmosphere makes it far more likely that Congress -- in a bipartisan
vote -- will authorize millions of dollars in emergency aid.

Klobuchar's right to pursue that funding, and the other members of North Dakota
and Minnesota's congressional delegations should offer their support.

If they do, and if the rest of Congress goes along, then avian flu will become a
straightforward matter of epidemiology, research and public health. And our
state and federal governments -- when they're functioning -- are very, very good
at solving problems of that kind.

-- Tom Dennis for the Herald

___ (c)2015 the Grand Forks Herald (Grand Forks, N.D.) Visit the Grand Forks
Herald (Grand Forks, N.D.) at www.grandforksherald.com Distributed by Tribune
Content Agency, LLC.

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                      July 17, 1998, Friday, ALL EDITIONS

Senate votes $ 500 million to aid struggling farmers

BYLINE: Curt Anderson

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 06A; Pg. 06A

LENGTH: 405 words

DATELINE: Washington


From wheat disease in the northern Plains to searing drought in Texas, thousands
of farmers are struggling with natural calamities just as exports are drying up
and crop prices are taking a dive. Congress was moving $ 500 million in
emergency aid Thursday for those hit hardest by flooding, pests and scant
rainfall. Sens. Kent Conrad and Byron Dorgan, both North Dakota Democrats, got
Senate voice vote approval to an amendment to the annual agriculture spending
bill that would create the program, which was endorsed by President Clinton. The
overall bill later passed 97-2 and now heads for negotiations with the House.
"We have enormous economic distress out in farm country," Conrad said. "The
little house on the prairie is in danger of being auctioned off." Net farm
income in 32 states is projected by the Agriculture Department to fall $ 5.2
billion this year from 1996. That year, Republicans won approval of their
"Freedom to Farm" law, which gradually phases out subsidy payments that once
smoothed out price valleys, permits farmers to plant the crops they think will
sell best, and substitutes crop insurance for federal disaster relief. Income is
dropping because of low prices for most crops and livestock, driven down by
enormous worldwide supplies and an Asian financial crisis that is throttling
America's most important agricultural export market. That would be bad enough.
But in states hit by drought, wildfires, hurricanes and recurrent wet weather
that triggers disease, farmers have trouble getting crop insurance and financing
to continue in business. Farm debt in 1998 could reach $ 172 billion, the
highest since the height of the farm crisis in 1985. "Our Oklahoma wheat farmers
are experiencing 1948 prices with 1998 expenses," said Terry Detrick, head of
that state's wheat growers association. Although many Democrats want to return
to price supports that were scrapped two years ago, after losing a key subsidy
vote this week they turned to the $ 500 million emergency aid package to remedy
significant income loss. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman would have broad
discretion to decide where to spend the money. In a letter Thursday, Glickman
said the program would pay supplemental crop insurance for farmers who received
insurance payouts in at least three of the last five years. The payment would
equal about 25 percent of total payouts and would help 48,000 farmers
nationwide.

LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
