                                The Moscow Times

                                February 5, 2002

Building Roots That Help Local Charities Grow

BYLINE: By Steven C. Johnson

SECTION: No. 2374

LENGTH: 888 words


Special to The Moscow Times

Not far from the Ukrainian town where he grew up, Eli Livshitz met a pair of
pensioners who somehow managed to live on nothing. Sitting in their dingy
one-room apartment in eastern Ukraine, the couple rattled off the myriad
expenses they had to meet each month: $ 10 for rent, $ 5 for heating, some $ 2
for electricity, another $ 2 or $ 3 for the basic foodstuffs that comprise their
diet - bread, cucumbers, potatoes.

Their combined pension: $ 16.

"I asked them, 'But how do you survive?'" he recalled. "They simply said, 'We
don't know.'" Livshitz's organization, the Global Jewish Assistance and Relief
Network, is trying to help millions like them in Russia and Ukraine by providing
food, clothing and medical care while trying to help local institutions become
self -sufficient.

The New York-based charity was founded in 1992 by an American rabbi with
Ukrainian roots to help the poor in the former Soviet Union.

As one of a handful of global charities that delivers surplus food from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, GJARN has since delivered 5.4 million kilograms of
food to more than 2 million people.

The organization also works to revitalize Jewish communities that had been
suffocated by decades of communism, but humanitarian assistance is delivered to
all in need, irrespective of religion or ethnicity.

The grateful letters GJARN receives from aid recipients betray just how
desperate many are.

"Your food package broke the ice of despair that was on my heart, and your
warmth and kindness reached our distant, Godforsaken village where we old
collective farmers while away the last days of our lives," wrote one pensioner.

"We're talking about hard-working, educated people - teachers, farmers,
engineers - who worked their entire lives and now have next to nothing," said
Livshitz, who left Ukraine a decade ago to study at a rabbinical college in New
Jersey before coming to Moscow to become GJARN's country director for Russia.

Aid programs enable scores to survive without resorting to selling family
heirlooms or vegetables or army medals on muddy street corners, as the couple
Livshitz met in Ukraine did to make ends meet.

The charity reaches needy people in some of Russia's poorest regions, including
the destitute Far East and Far North, where GJARN recently distributed 2,000
tons of USDA apples.

But even in and around Moscow, many people are barely scraping by.

"Life in most places doesn't resemble what goes on within the Garden Ring. Just
half an hour outside of Moscow, you'll find a different world," said Korey
Hartwich, deputy director at the Moscow office. "We've done a lot, but there's
still a tremendous need." At the Etel-Bikur Holim's daily soup kitchen in
Moscow, sacks full of lentils, buckwheat, peas, condensed milk and other goods
distributed by GJARN are piled up in the kitchen and help feed some 150
pensioners from the city's Jewish community who turn up daily for lunch.

Here, the clientele is a heady mix that includes former Soviet military
officers, journalists and actors - all of whom receive pensions of less than $
50 per month.

"These people are like family to me, and I treat them the way I would treat my
parents," said 60-year-old kitchen director Leonid Eichis.

Most are proud and make the best of their lot. Before lunch, a spry 83-year -old
former athlete leads a mixed group in stretches and leg-lifts.

The walls are lined with photos of the veterans in their younger days, and many
still sport their colorful Soviet medals on their chests.

Vera Lipovetskaya, a one-time fixture of Moscow's Jewish theater circuit before
Stalin shut it down, still carries at 80 an air of the sophistication and
glamour that made her a star more than half a century ago.

Wearing a smart blue dress and bright red lipstick, she eagerly pulls out a
stash of magazine articles about her acting days to show anyone who betrays an
interest.

"We come here as much for the socialization as the food," concedes Iosef
Eselson, a former Olympic coach for the Soviet shooting team. "On weekends, when
the kitchen doesn't work, we get depressed. The women say they've no need to put
on their lipstick." Getting food to everyone who needs it can be a tall order;
Eichis estimates his kitchen reaches about 1,000 of the nearly 30,000 Jewish
pensioners who have expressed interest.

But getting local charities to tackle the task is also part of GJARN's mission.
Livshitz said the group has helped set up soup kitchens in St. Petersburg and
Samara, but only once did the local communities agree to undertake the
day-to-day operation.

"We said we'd sponsor the kitchens and donate the food, but they had to keep it
going," he said.

GJARN's other mission is renewing Jewish communities, which Livshitz says are
undergoing a mini-renaissance.

And while he doesn't gloss over the residue of the anti-Semitism that has long
existed in Russian society, Livshitz says the organization has run into very few
problems among the broader community.

"Based on my experience, I've every reason to believe our activities help in
weakening whatever anti-Semitism is out there, " he said.

For more information or to contribute visit www.globaljewish.org (English) or
www.gjarn.org (Russian).

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              686 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                             Ottumwa Courier (Iowa)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            June 17, 2015 Wednesday

OFD aid in Avian Flu cleanup

BYLINE: Danielle Lunsford, Ottumwa Courier, Iowa

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 491 words


June 17--OTTUMWA -- Four members of the Ottumwa Fire Department recently made
trips to northern Iowa to aid in the cleanup of chickens affected by the avian
influenza outbreak.

The Iowa Department of Agriculture have reported more than 31.5 million birds
affected, leading Gov. Terry Branstad to declare disaster in 18 counties. In an
effort to control the spread of the disease both state and federal authorities
are working to euthanize those impacted and cleanup the carcasses.

"Our guys are certified hazmat technicians who go to these sites that need help
and act as supervisors to the guys the state has hired to clean up the deceased
chickens," said Assistant Fire Chief Mike Craff. "They are making sure the
cleanup crew is following the United States Department of Agriculture's (USDA)
guidelines and protocols."

The two-week long commitment requires volunteers to undergo specialized training
and job shadow a longtime supervisor to ensure they have an appropriate
understanding of the process.

The effort requires crews to follow a meticulous regime of loading carcasses and
droppings into bags, placing them in dumpsters and taking them to a disposal
site. Before the truck can leave the impacted site it must be cleaned and must
be cleaned once again before leaving the landfill.

Two of the city's participating firefighters were stationed in the northwest
position of the state near Sheldon and the other two are still aiding the effort
northwest of Ames.

The crew members were eligible to volunteer because the department belongs to
the Iowa State Hazmat Task Force, which allows local level groups to better work
together.

Craff thanked city officials for allowing his crew members to experience the
cleanup effort because they will be better prepared for a potential outbreak at
home.

"You never know what's going to happen or what we'll see because [locally] we
cover a nine-country area and that's rather large," said Craff.

The experience has provided the firefighters with an even deeper understanding
of how not only how to handle a large scale hazmat situation, but the
devastating effects it can have on a community.

"After talking with the first two guys that had come back from there I realized
that people don't have a good understanding of the relevance of this [outbreak]
or the effect it has had on the economy up there," said Craff.

Craff said as more bird flu flocks continue to be reported, it will become more
important for certified hazmat technicians to volunteer time to aid in the
cleanup.

Although the technicians are working in two week intervals, Craff said the
situation will need about another month of volunteers working continuously to
complete the cleanup.

-- Danielle Lunsford can be reached at dlunsford@ottumwacourier.com and followed
@CourierDanielle.

___ (c)2015 the Ottumwa Courier (Ottumwa, Iowa) Visit the Ottumwa Courier
(Ottumwa, Iowa) at www.ottumwacourier.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency,
LLC.

                                   Roll Call

                           September 19, 2011 Monday

In Texas, Disaster Aid Is a Contentious Topic

BYLINE: Ambreen Ali

LENGTH: 793 words



Wildfires, historic drought and a tight state budget may have made Texans more
reliant on the federal government, but that doesn't mean they like it.

As Texas Gov. Rick Perry (R) sought federal aid to fight wildfires in his state
last week, a group of cattle raisers lobbied Congress to lift regulations and
leave them alone.

"We've come to Washington to ask the government to please back off and stay out
of our business," Joe Parker, president of the Texas and Southwestern Cattle
Raisers Association, told Roll Call in between visits with Hill staffers last
week.

In the meetings, he and his fellow ranchers requested tax relief to rebuild
fences destroyed by the fires, but Parker distinguished that from direct aid,
which he said the beef producers do not need. He instead suggested the
government could "back off" by repealing environmental regulations and ethanol
subsidies that hamper businesses.

Texas farmers have lost billions of dollars in crops and livestock in what has
become the state's worst drought on record. Yet rural advocates, many of whom
are conservative, have resisted federal aid and defend state budget cuts that
have made relief harder to get.

"We're proud of the fact that our state has embraced that [balanced budget]
constitutional requirement. We're dealing with that. It's a painful process, but
we're proud," Parker said.

This year's fires and drought have cost Texas agriculture an estimated $5.2
billion, according to the Texas AgriLife Extension Service, a state-funded
nonprofit. In June, the U.S. Department of Agriculture began offering loan
assistance to Texas farmers hurt by the drought and resulting fires.

Last week, as Perry requested $50 million in emergency aid from the federal
government - which he has called overbearing, burdensome and costly - his
critics pointed out that he recently slashed funding for Texas volunteer fire
departments by 74 percent and for the Texas Forest Service by 34 percent. They
argued that the cuts have made the state more reliant on federal aid.

President Barack Obama and Democrats have also highlighted the assistance the
federal government is providing to Texas.

"If you're someone who's homeless as a result of the fire, you want to have
federal support. That's particularly true in Texas, where there's been a
reduction in vital support so the governor can run as a no-taxes-raised
candidate," said Rep. Lloyd Doggett, a Texas Democrat whose district was damaged
by the wildfires.

Doggett said the disasters prove that Texas can't take care of all of its
problems on its own. As the fires quell, he expects his state will need even
more federal aid to rebuild.

"These are legitimate roles for the government to play," he said.

While many Texans have taken the aid that the Department of Agriculture and the
Federal Emergency Management Agency have provided, they still object to the idea
that the federal government needs to swoop in and help them.

"We can take care of ourselves and our families better than [the government]
can," said Maria Acosta, president of the Central Texas 9-12 Project, a tea
party group with more than 1,000 members.

Still, Acosta welcomed the federal help with the fires as a sort of refund on
federal taxes that Texans pay and that she opposes.

"We do feel like if we could send less money to Washington, there are things we
could do for ourselves here and do it better," she said.

Jimmy Clark, executive director of the Southwest Council of Agribusiness, echoed
the sentiment against government aid, saying: "The answer to all the problems
out here is Mother Nature. All we need is rain."

The group's members include cotton farmers, whose drought insurance has helped
them get through the dry season. But the insurance covers only costs, so few of
them have been able to earn the income on which they depend.

Meanwhile, state cuts have downsized the agencies on which Texas farmers rely
during such emergency situations.

The Texas AgriLife Extension Service has set up livestock supply points where
farmers can pick up donated hay and round up lost cattle. But the nonprofit has
had to eliminate other programs and 70 percent of its workforce because of the
cuts.

"The funding presents a significant challenge," said Pete Gibbs, an associate
director with the group.

In July, organic farmer Hardy Purvis pulled out of his local farmers market
because he had too few crops to sell. The Buda Farmers' Market has since shut
down for the season because of low supply.

Purvis has a kennel business that has helped cushion his losses, but he said he
worries for those farmers with more land and more to lose.

"It's just been a disaster for the conventional farmers down here," he said.
"I'm sure they're all clamoring for whatever relief they can get from the
government."

LOAD-DATE: September 19, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                         Copyright 2011 Roll Call, Inc.

                       The Daily Record (Baltimore, MD.)

                            October 16, 1995, Monday

State Seeks Disaster Aid For Maryland Farmers Hit by Drought

SECTION: Pg.  1

LENGTH: 146 words


For the second time in three years, Maryland is seeking disaster aid for farmers
whose crops were damaged by a summer drought. Gov. Parris Glendening sent a
letter Friday to the U.S. Department of Agriculture asking that 12 counties on
the Eastern Shore and in southern Maryland be declared disaster areas. ''What
this will do is make the farmers in those counties eligible for low-interest
emergency loans . . . ,'' said Harold Kanarek, spokesman for the state
Department of Agriculture. ''It is for farmers who have suffered 40 percent or
more loss in crops during the growing season,'' he said. ''These emergency loans
are to help them get the seed, the fertilizer, etc. for the next planting,''
Kanarek said. Dan Shortall, a Queen Anne's County farmer, said results were
mixed for corn this summer with some farmers doing well and some losing much of
their crop.

                               The New York Times

                July 12, 1988, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

Broad Support Seen for Drought Aid

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 14, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 900 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 11


As showers that began Saturday continued to fall on parts of the parched Midwest
and South, the chairmen of the House and Senate Agriculture Committees told
President Reagan today that there was widespread support in both parties for
legislation that would provide billions of dollars in relief to farmers whose
crops have been damaged.

In a meeting at the White House, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, Democrat of Vermont,
chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, and Representative E. (Kika) de la
Garza, Democrat of Texas, chairman of the House Agriculture Committee, said the
President expressed support for the legislation and indicated concern about
drought damage.

Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng, Representative Edward R. Madigan,
Republican of Illinois, and Senator Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana,
also attended the meeting.

'Encouraged' by Response

Senator Leahy said it was his intention to hold hearings on Capitol Hill this
week in order to shape the legislation into a form that could be approved. ''I'm
very encouraged by the response of the President,'' Mr. Leahy said. ''The
President asked us to be mindful of the budget. We are mindful of it.''

Republican Congressional leaders said they would be active in shaping the
legislation. ''There are no areas of disagreement,'' Mr. Lugar said.

The 25-minute meeting came as the Agriculture Department was preparing to
release a special study of the drought's effect on crop production. The study is
due out Tuesday. Mr. Lyng said, ''Perhaps never before in the history of the
United States has there been a July 11 on which so much uncertainty remained as
to the true supply and demand situation for U.S. agricultural production.''

'Wild Card' in Election

The activity at the White House and on Capitol Hill reflects a growing awareness
by both parties of the political consequences if they are seen as failing to
react to the distress caused by the drought. Republican political experts have
called the drought a ''wild card'' in the 1988 Presidential campaign, believing
that it may cause some voters to switch.

Democrats, meanwhile, hope to pick up support in the drought regions of the
northern Great Plains, the Middle West and the South, areas that have supported
Republican candidates in recent national elections.

The House and Senate versions, which are nearly identical, and which would cost
between $5 billion and $6 billion, call for disaster payments to be made to any
farmers who have lost at least 65 percent of their crops to the drought. The
payments are to be directed to farmers who raise vegetables, fruits, soybeans
and grains. Farmers would be eligible to receive payments amounting to
two-thirds of the market value of vegetable and fruit crops, and two-thirds of
the Congressionally set prices for grain crops.

Effect on Support Payments

In addition, some farmers who received support payments in advance from the
Government for grain crops would not have to refund portions of the payments if
the drought caused extensive damage. The Congressional staff members said they
believed that no more than $1 billion was involved in this part of the
legislation.

At the White House the drought has become a principal focus of activities this
week. On Tuesday, the President will meet with Congressional leaders of both
parties. On Wednesday, Mr. Reagan is tentatively scheduled to meet with Dean
Kleckner, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, and presidents of
state farm bureaus. Both meetings will take place at the White House, officials
said.

On Thursday, Mr. Reagan leaves Washington to travel to Iowa and to tour parched
areas near Marion, Ill. He is scheduled to visit the farm of Herman Krone, who
raises corn and soybeans near Du Quoin. The trip, Mr. Reagan's first to assess
damage from the drought, recalled similar journeys by President Franklin D.
Roosevelt, who toured the Middle West and northern Great Plains in 1934 and
1936.

Reagan Wants Cooperation

Mr. Reagan, who has taken an active interest in the drought, has made it clear
to Mr. Lyng that he wants the Administration and Congress to work together to
aid farmers.

Meanwhile, the stubborn high-pressure weather system that produced the hot, dry
conditions over the northern Great Plains and Middle West collapsed over the
weekend, the National Weather Service said.

The weather system has been replaced by another that is helping to bring showers
over the Ohio Valley, the Dakotas, Iowa and parts of the South, particularly in
Arkansas. The showers are expected to persist through Tuesday and possibly into
Wednesday, meteorologists said.

Hot Weather Could Be Back

But the long-range forecast by the National Weather Service calls for the
high-pressure system to return, perhaps by the end of the week.

''The rain over the weekend and what we may get early this week helps,'' said
Ernest Paroczay, a meteorologist at the National Meteorological Center in Camp
Springs, Md., near Washington. ''But it's not going to end the drought.''

Across the Middle West, there were more indications that the corn crop has
already suffered extensive damage. Scientists at Purdue University in Lafayette,
Ind., estimated today that 40 percent of the state's harvest had been destroyed.
At about 650 million bushels of corn annually, Indiana is the nation's
fourth-largest producer.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company

                     BBC Monitoring South Asia - Political
                      Supplied by BBC Worldwide Monitoring

                           February 15, 2011 Tuesday

Afghanistan asks USA not to suspend development aid

LENGTH: 341 words


Text of report by Afghan independent Tolo TV on 15 February

[Presenter] The USA has frozen some 6bn of its aid for Afghanistan. A USAID
official says that 6bn dollars was due to be handed over to the USAID office in
Kabul, but the money has now been held up. Meanwhile, the Finance Ministry
spokesman has regretted this move by the USA.

[Correspondent] This USAID official has said that the 6bn dollars was approved
in November last year for spending in agriculture, energy and agriculture
projects in Afghanistan and was ready to be sent to this country. He added that
the reason for their concern was the dissolution of private security companies
by the Afghan government.

[Text of remark by a senior USAID official in Dari, also read out by
correspondent] We have expressed concern to the Afghan government that this is a
wasted opportunity.

[Correspondent] In the meantime, the Finance Ministry spokesman criticized the
suspension of the aid by the USA, asking Washington to continue its
contributions to Afghanistan.

[Aziz Shams, speaking over the phone] I am very sorry that the USA, which has
been the biggest donor for Afghanistan over the past many years, has decided to
suspend its aid to Afghanistan over very minor issues and on the pretext that
the Afghan government has decided to dismantle private security firms. The
Islamic Republic of Afghanistan is really sorry that the USA has taken such a
stance. Taking into account agreements of cooperation it signed with the Islamic
Republic of Afghanistan and based on our lasting friendship with the USA, the
Afghan government and people once again request and the USA and the US
congressmen not to halt the aid, and hope that such small and minor issues will
not damage the relations.

[Correspondent] It is worth pointing out that President Karzai has earlier
ordered dismantling of private security firms in Afghanistan, and after these
firms are dismantled, the Interior Ministry will be responsible for ensuring
security of aid organizations.

Source: Tolo TV, Kabul, in Dari 0430 gmt 15 Feb 11

                              695 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     The Capital Times (Madison, Wisconsin)

                             June 6, 2009 Saturday
                                  ALL EDITION

USDA NEEDS TO AID BELEAGUERED DAIRY FARMERS

SECTION: OPINION; Pg. WEB

LENGTH: 401 words


These are incredibly tough times for Wisconsin's working dairy farmers.

Milk prices are down, and costs for production are going up.

Dairies that paid premium prices to Wisconsin's small family farmers in order to
get the best quality milk are switching to bigger operations -- including some
factory farms -- which produce lower-quality milk.

The result is devastating. Farm families that have been on the land for
generations are questioning whether they can continue.

Wisconsin's dairy farmers don't expect a lot in the way of help from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, which has historically maintained policies that are
biased in favor of farmers in the Northeast. But in this urgent moment, there
are smart federal interventions that could help a great deal.

The National Farmers Union has asked Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack to take
urgent action. The NFU is asking that Vilsack move to: -- Make available
low-interest and emergency loans, including a foreclosure mitigation program, to
stem the tide of loan foreclosures as a result of the current economic climate.

-- Eliminate authority for dairy forward contracting, which allows processors to
shift all economic risk onto producers, encourages vertical integration of
America's dairy production, and dismantles the Federal Milk Marketing Order
system.

-- Establish a dairy price support program that accounts for the total cost of
production.

-- Provide immediate oversight of the dairy product pricing system to ensure
transparency, fairness and competitive markets.

-- Immediately release the MILC (Milk Income Loss Contract) payments due to
producers.

-- Address bad trade policies and loopholes that stack the deck against U.S.
farmers, especially those in the Upper Midwest.

These are smart proposals.

Vilsack, an Iowan who understands the unique challenges faced by this region --
and who knows the importance of maintaining diverse ownership of the means of
food production -- should follow the NFU's advice.

As NFU President Roger Johnson argues, correctly, "The dairy crisis continues to
cripple family dairy farmers and their rural communities. I hear regularly from
longtime dairy producers who have never experienced such a devastating economic
tidal wave. While the dairy sector is not unique in its economic struggles, the
severity of the dairy situation requires immediate and creative policy
solutions."

An editorial - 6/06/2009 7:01 am

LOAD-DATE: June 7, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES:  To view the Web version of the story, go to -
http://www.madison.com/tct/opinion/453833

GRAPHIC: File photo Wisconsin dairy farmers need help from the government.

                              696 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 November 20, 1993, SATURDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

MIDWEST LEVEES GET HELP UNDER COMPROMISE PLAN

BYLINE: Robert L. Koenig Post-Dispatch Washington Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 1040 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Flood-gouged levees in the Midwest got an extra $ 18 million in repair aid
Friday, while a separate federal action pumped up efforts to expand wetlands in
flood-prone areas.

Those responses to the Flood of '93 came as Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, who
heads the flood-recovery effort, planned a trip Monday to meet with farmers in
Missouri and Illinois and to tour flood-stricken Valmeyer, lll. The city plans
to move to higher ground.

Meanwhile, Congress appeared poised to approve a bill this weekend to quadruple
buyout money for flooded communities. An

The federal interagency group on Midwest flood recovery decided Friday to
earmark an extra $ 18 million to help repair levees that are ineligible for aid
from the Army Corps of Engineers but protect key roads or buildings and have a
public sponsor.

The extra money for levee repair will be taken from emergency flood aid that had
been allotted to the Economic Development Administration for jobs programs. The
new money comes in addition to $ 180 million appropriated last summer for the
corps' levee-aid program.

The new levee money - a compromise between previous plans for no aid for
ineligible levees and the demands of some Missouri officials for $ 100 million
in extra aid - managed to anger both sides in the debate: environmentalists and
pro-levee politicians.

Sen. Christopher S. Bond, R-Mo., said through a spokeswoman that the extra $ 18
million is "woefully inadequate" to help rebuild the 355 ineligible levees along
the lower Missouri River "in time to prevent spring flooding from causing great
damage in Missouri."

Meanwhile, the American Rivers conservation group, which opposed federal aid for
ineligible rural levees, denounced the new levee rules as a "flip-flop" by
President Bill Clinton's administration, which also is promoting alternatives to
repairing some levees.

"We are repeating the mistakes of the past," said Scott Faber, who directs the
group's flood-plain management programs. He argued that helping to repair
ineligible levees is unfair and "removes incentives to properly construct and
maintain levees in the future."

Morrie Goodman, chief spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency,
argued that the new levee rules "are absolutely not a reversal.  This would only
help levees that protect significant public property in the Midwest."

On the same day it moved to rebuild many levees, the administration also
released new rules that aim to make it simpler for farmers to convert
flood-damaged land to wetlands.

Espy's top flood aide, Oleta Fitzgerald, said the new regulations for the
Emergency Wetlands Reserve Programs - rules changes that have been delayed for
two months - "will make it easier for some farmers who want to get out of the
flood plain, and to recover losses."

This week, the Agriculture Department confirmed plans to use $ 15 million in
emergency flood-aid money to buy flooded land suitable for conversion of
wetlands from farmers wwilling to sell.

The flurry of federal action Friday came as agriculture officials from Missouri,
Illinois and Iowa appealed to a House committee for more help.

l Kyle Vickers, deputy director of the Missouri Department of Agriculture, said,
"Delayed planting, poor seasonal growing conditions, cropland erosion, flooded
fields and an early fall freeze have all contributed to conditions in the rural
Midwest that have left farmers facing economic and natural hardships previously
unimagined."

Vickers called for a major expansion of the emergency wetlands program in a way
that would make it easier for farmers to convert flooded cropland.

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1993 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


                              697 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                               May 1, 2006 Monday

Low turnout at tornado aid concert

BYLINE: AMANDA REAVY STAFF WRITER

SECTION: CITY/STATE; Pg. 19

LENGTH: 378 words


A stint of severe weather Sunday may have discouraged visitors from stopping by
the state-sponsored Tornado Aid Benefit Concert at the Illinois State
Fairgrounds.

But organizers say the dozens who did arrive at the Orr Building did their part
to help the local branch of the American Red Cross recover from storm relief
efforts.

"The turnout was OK. The possibility for severe weather played a factor," said
Jennifer Waldinger, Department of Central Management Services program manager.

Thunderstorms moved through Sangamon County about 3:30 p.m. with reports of
penny-sized hail in Auburn and two miles east of Chatham, according to the
National Weather Service.

CMS worked with the Illinois Department of Agriculture and other state agencies
to put on the event, which raised money to help the Red Cross with its second
wave of storm relief efforts, said Chuck Hartke, Department of Agriculture
director.

"The first week was covered by insurance and (assistance from the Federal
Emergency Management System. The second wave of storms was not," he said. "Every
little bit helps."

The suggested minimum donation was $5 per person, with children younger than 12
admitted for free. Proceeds from food and drink sales also were donated to the
Red Cross, along with sales revenue from Tornado Aid T-shirts that were
available for purchase.

Hartke said the Department of Agriculture donated use of the building while six
bands donated their time to play. "Maybe we should have used a smaller
building," Hartke said with a laugh.

The event was held from noon to 10 p.m. and featured music acts including The
City Limits Band, River Ramblers, Ultraviolet, Inspected by 12, Thornhill and
Jolly Band of Cowboys.

Other activities included clowns, balloons, face painting and a "moon walk."

Waldinger said she didn't have a final count for how much money was raised  but
expected the event to raise several thousand dollars.

Chris and Mary Schofield of Rochester came to the concert for several hours with
their friends Thanh and Marque Melick of Pawnee to enjoy the drinks and live
music.

Mary Schofield, who works for CMS, said she wished the event had better
publicity.

"I wish there were more people," Chris Schofield said. "We came a long way to
support a good cause."

                 The State Journal- Register (Springfield, IL)

                            July 18, 2012 Wednesday

Official: More drought aid expected soon

BYLINE: Tim Landis; Business Editor, TIM.LANDIS@SJ-R.COM

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 262 words


Severe drought damage is spreading quickly throughout Illinois, the acting
director of the state Department of Agriculture said Tuesday.

Bob Flider said he expects the federal government to announce additional
emergency aid within days for a drought that shows no signs of easing.

"In fact, the forecast between now and the end of September is hotter and
drier," Flider said after announcing a new state marketing campaign for Illinois
products at the Schnucks supermarket in Sangamon Center North.

He said the department and Gov. Pat Quinn are in contact with the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, which has designated more than 1, 000 counties
nationwide as drought disaster areas, including 26 in southern Illinois.

The greatest damage has been done to the corn crop, but Flider said cattle
farmers also have been hurt by the loss of summer hay. He said the agency is
urging farmers to work with local Farm Service Agency offices to allow emergency
use of land normally set aside for conservation.

"It makes hay available to cattle that otherwise might not be available," Flider
said. "We're working with the Farm Bureau trying to get that message to the
local ag community, that they need to work with their FSA to make that case.

"Once they do, they can be declared a disaster area," Flider said.

Under USDA rules, a county qualifies if it has been in a severe drought for at
least eight weeks or has had an extreme drought during the growing season.

A national update from the U.S. Drought Monitor is scheduled for release
Thursday.

Tim Landis can be reached at 788-1536.

                              699 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                 July 8, 1988, Friday, Late City Final Edition

Illinois, No. 2 U.S. Corn Producer, Loses Half of Its Crop to Drought

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to the New York Times

SECTION: Section A; Page 9, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 866 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 7


Months of drought and weeks of blistering temperatures have destroyed half the
corn crop in Illinois, the nation's second-largest producer of corn, state
agriculture officials said today.

That assessment by Illinois was the first of what is almost certain to be a
string of reports of crop failures across the Middle West, although the northern
Great Plains states of Minnesota, Montana and the Dakotas reported as early as
last month that at least half their wheat, barley and oat crops had already been
destroyed.

The Illinois officials, in telephone interviews, said the hot, arid conditions
were reducing corn yields by 2 to 5 percent a day. If the state does not receive
any rain in the next week to 10 days, they said, its corn harvest may yield no
more than 400 million bushels, only a third of last year's harvest, which ran a
close second to Iowa's 1.3 billion bushels and was 17 percent of the national
total.

Records for Misery

''It's already the worst crop failure in our history,'' said Mike Williams, the
state's assistant director of agriculture. ''Every day we don't receive any
moisture it gets worse. The question is how much worse it's going to get.''

Across the nation, heat records for a July 7 were set today, as were records for
lack of moisture. International Falls, Minn., usually one of the nation's
coolest spots, registered 98 degrees, tying the record for the hottest it has
ever been there on any date. In Flint, Mich., it was 101 degrees. Havre, Mont.,
has had only 30-hundredths of an inch of rain since April 1, the lowest total of
precipitation for so long a period ever measured in that region.

In Washington, the Agriculture Department added 61 counties to its list of
drought disaster areas, bringing the list's total to 1,880 counties, in 37
states. Such designation makes an area's farmers eligible for a variety of
relief programs.

Meanwhile, drought relief committees formed by Congress, the Reagan
Administration and the National Governors' Association met here to discuss the
worsening conditions in the South, the northern Great Plains, the Middle West
and California. Gov. George Sinner of North Dakota, chairman of the committee
formed by the governors' association, said the state and Federal officials had
discussed ways to more quickly provide feed to livestock producers.

The committees also discussed legislation Congress is preparing to vastly expand
aid to farmers whose crops have been destroyed or damaged. Representative E.
(Kika) de la Garza, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Agriculture
Committee, said a comprehensive bill would be ready to be submitted to both
houses of Congress by the end of the month.

The money to pay for the aid would come from the $5 billion or more the
Agriculture Department expects to save on income support programs this year
because of the drought. Income support is based on the difference between market
prices and higher, Congressionally-set target prices. With market prices rising
as a result of the drought and thus more nearly approaching the targets, the
Government expects to pay farmers far less than usual in the fall.

Corn Threatened Elsewhere

One of the states most seriously affected by the drought is Ohio. The
temperature soared to 100 degrees today in Columbus, the capital, and state
officials banned open burning. Ohio has experienced massive fish kills on the
Great Miami River near Miamisburg in recent weeks, and the flow of the Maumee
River at Toledo is 2 percent of normal.

And according to Ohio agriculture analysts, 70 percent of the state's
500-million-bushel corn crop, the nation's sixth-largest, is under severe
stress. If it does not rain in the next week, officials said, much of the crop
will be destroyed.

Corn, the nation's largest and most important crop, is also imperiled in Kansas,
Minnesota, Indiana, Missouri, Michigan and Kentucky.

In Ohio, Minnesota and Wisconsin, dairy farmers have begun to slaughter their
better cows because feed has become either too scarce or too expensive.

In the South, the drought is proving particularly ruinous to crops in
Mississippi, Alabama and Arkansas. More than 60 percent of the $400 million
soybean crop in Arkansas is rated as poor or very poor by the Department of
Agriculture, as is a similar percentage of the soybean crop in Alabama. Most of
Mississippi's $300 million cotton crop is also in dire shape.

Dredging Near Natchez

Along the Mississippi River, dredge operators working for the Army Corps of
Engineers were trying today to clear a channel 20 miles south of Natchez, Miss.,
at Black Hills, where 1,200 barges were reported blocked.

And Roger Steakley, a spokesman for the Corps of Engineers in Vicksburg, Miss.,
said measurements at Memphis showed that the Mississippi there was three feet
below the lowest level ever previously recorded.

Representatives of the Coast Guard, the Corps of Engineers and the American
Waterways Operators Association, a Washington-based trade group representing
barge and towboat companies, are planning to meet in Memphis on Friday to
develop a coordinated program for keeping the Mississippi and other important
waterways open to traffic.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: photo of Gov. George Sinner (Paul Conklin)

                   Copyright 1988 The New York Times Company

                              The Washington Post

                     May 5, 1982, Wednesday, Final Edition

State Seeks To Curb Gypsy Moth Spread

BYLINE: By NANCY SCANNELL, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: Virginia Weekly; Va. 1

LENGTH: 793 words


Virginia agriculture officials expect to begin aerial and ground spraying in
isolated parts of Fairfax and Loudoun counties next week in an attempt to
control the spread of leaf-eating gypsy moths.

The gypsy moth, which devastated 13.1 million acres of forest in the Northeast
last year, is most dangerous in its caterpillar stage, which hatches in late
April or early May, agricultural officials said.

Egg masses laid by female gypsy moths can contain 200 to 1,000 eggs; when the
caterpillars hatch they feed voraciously on newly formed leaves, usually at
night. Repeated defoliations can kill some trees and weaken others, making them
more vulnerable to attacks by other pests and borers.

"We want to get a start on controlling these pests in Virginia instead of
waiting until it's too late," said Robert Bailey, an assistant supervisor in the
plant and pest control section of the Virginia Department of Agriculture and
Consumer Services.

Egg masses that produce the gypsy moth caterpillar have been found in six
locations in Fairfax County, one spot in both Loudoun and Fauquier counties and
in the southern counties of Lunenburg and Floyd.

No egg masses have been found yet in Arlington or Alexandria, Bailey said, "but
it is a general assumption that Northern Virginia is next in line as far as the
general southward spread from the northeastern states is concerned. We also
presume there are other infected sites in Northern Virginia, but we haven't
found them yet."

The gypsy moth spreads naturally with the aid of wind, and artificially with the
aid of people. The female, which does not fly, crawls into cracks on outdoor
objects such as trees, wood piles and window ledges and under the eaves of
houses to lay her eggs. She also hitchhikes on recreational vehicles, tents,
mobile homes and hauling-trailers--which is how state agriculture officials
suspect many of the moths migrated here from the Northeast. Recreational
vehicles are more suspect because they often are parked for several days in
woody areas or campsites that may be infested.

State Agricultural Commissioner Mason Carbaugh said a half-mile radius
surrounding the infested areas already discovered in Northern Virginia will be
quarantined later this summer, provided various oversight committees of the
state legislature do not object.

Once in effect, Carbaugh said, the quarantines would allow state inspectors to
block infested shipments of agricultural products such as firewood from leaving
the restricted areas and to require inspection of recreational vehicles leaving
the areas. Violation of the quarantine would constitute a misdemeanor.

Some areas will be treated next week, weather permitting, with chemicals
sanctioned by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency as safe for humans, pets
and plant life. The chemicals to be sprayed are Thuricide, Dimilin and Dylox,
none of which has long-term residual effects, agriculture officials said.

Aerial spraying will take place next Tuesday for 65 acres in the Loudoun County
town of Lucketts, 50 acres in the Southdown subdivison in Great Falls and 33
acres in Springfield. A two-acre section in the Annandale Acres subdivision is
scheduled for ground-spraying late next week or early the following week.

In other areas, officials will lay chemically treated traps to attract and
confuse male gypsy moths and disrupt breeding.

Egg masses found on a tree on Auburn Street in Annandale, on a tree on Red
Spruce Road in Fairfax City and on a tree in West Park, an industrial park in
McLean near Tysons Corner have been destroyed and traps will be set to monitor
any further infestation, agricultural officials said.

Residents living in the areas to be sprayed already have been notified,
officials said, and will be reminded again before the spraying starts.

"We've advised them to stay indoors and get their pets and any laundry indoors,"
said Ralph Donnell, Fairfax County's gypsy moth control supervisor. "It's not
that they have to, but it just makes common sense not to stand outside while a
helicopter is spraying overhead."

The privately owned helicopters hired for the job are expected to start spraying
the Great Falls section at 7 a.m. and the Springfield area around 9:15 a.m.,
officials said. They said those times were picked because minimum activity would
be expected outside--too early for school children to be out, they said, and
late enough that most adults would have gone to work.

The spray should dry within 20 minutes to an hour after it is applied, they
said.

The Fairfax County Board of Supervisors has appropriated $35,000 to help combat
the gypsy moths, which are particularly fond of the oak and hickory trees that
make up more than 78 percent of the county's forest area.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Picture, Ralph Donnell, supervisor of gypsy moth control for Fairfax
County, and Rusty Wendt of the state Agriculture Department, check for moth eggs
or catepillars on the bark of the hickory tree.  By CRAIG HERNDON--The
Washington Post

                              701 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The Washington Post

                   February 3, 2000, Thursday, Final Edition

White House Offers Farm Aid Proposal

Charles Babington, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A06

LENGTH: 427 words


The Clinton administration, saying many farmers continue to struggle despite the
nation's overall rosy economy, announced yesterday a two-year, $ 11.5 billion
plan to boost farm incomes, encourage conservation and help farmers buy crop and
livestock insurance.

Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman, who released the budget proposal, said the
goal is to make supplemental aid to farmers more predictable until the mammoth
1996 farm bill is rewritten in 2002. Even though that bill had envisioned a
market-driven policy with fewer subsidies for farmers, Congress has approved
about $ 15 billion in emergency aid over the past two years, acknowledging that
drought and low prices continue to take a toll.

The administration's new proposal, part of the fiscal 2001 budget that President
Clinton will unveil on Monday, is designed to let Congress consider supplemental
farm aid in a more timely and orderly fashion, Glickman said in an interview.

"We believe it will focus the debate early in Congress to avert costly, ad hoc
emergency bills," he said. "We've said on a number of occasions that the safety
net in that [1996] bill is not adequate."

A spokesman for the House Agriculture Committee said the panel will hold
hearings on the administration plan but that its leaders will withhold comment
until more details are known.

The administration plan would spend $ 3.1 billion over two years to boost the
incomes of eligible growers of wheat, feed grains, rice, upland cotton and
oilseeds. Payments would be triggered when a farmer's projected gross income
from the crop, which would include existing government subsidies, falls below 92
percent of the preceding five-year average.

"The program addresses a major shortcoming of the 1996 farm bill through
providing countercyclical support that reflects a farmer's current production
and market conditions," said a Department of Agriculture briefing paper. The new
payments would be capped at $ 30,000 per farmer, it said, in order "to target
the program to smaller farmers who typically have lower farm income."

To encourage environmental safeguards, the administration plan would allocate $
600 million to "provide annual payments to farmers and ranchers who implement
such conservation practices as nutrient management, prescribed grazing and
partial-field conservation practices," which include "grassed waterways and
windbreaks," the briefing paper said. It also would increase spending to
safeguard wildlife habitats and to buy easements to protect farmlands from
suburban sprawl.

                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                             August 6, 2006 Sunday
                                  City Edition

Grain industry giants get millions in Katrina aid

BYLINE: ALAN GUEBERT, FOR THE LINCOLN JOURNAL STAR

SECTION: F; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 739 words

DATELINE: LINCOLN, NE


While American taxpayers await an accounting on the billions of dollars sent to
the Gulf Coast to clean up Katrina's devastation, the U.S. Department of
Agriculture already knows the tab for four emergency programs hastily designed
"to further reduce stress on the grain transportation system" caused by the
storm.

The amount was $22.7 million.

And, according to published data at www.fsa.usda.gov/DACO/Katrina.htm, the USDA
also knows where most of the loot went.

A cool $19.7 million of the federal aid, or 87 percent, to assist grain
merchandisers and farmers along Katrina-slowed Midwestern waterways slipped into
the deep, soft pockets of Cargill, Archer Daniels Midland and Louis Dreyfus,
three of the world's largest grain merchandisers..

The program, announced by Secretary of Agriculture Mike Johanns on Sept. 20, had
four components to address the Katrina-crunched grain market. All were tied to
slowing or reversing the flow of grain along an already backed-up,
drought-pinched Mississippi River system.

The first was a "temporary incentive" - known elsewhere as cash - "to assist
immediate movement of some 140 barges of damaged corn out of New Orleans to
up-river locations." Once there, the barges would be unloaded to then "continue
up the river to load and begin moving new-crop commodities."

Under this part of the program, Cargill, the giant multinational that earned
$2.1 billion on 2005 sales of $71.1 billion, was paid $7.2 million to move 92
barges back upriver.

Louis Dreyfus, another $20 billion-plus-a-year global grain player, received
$2.03 million to, as Johanns hopefully noted Sept. 20, "relieve pressure on
farmers and related businesses" by moving 28 barges back whence they came.

The second part of the Katrina program, "barge unloading of damaged
commodities," delivered a second helping of cash to Cargill - $960,985.92,
according to USDA stats.

The emergency plan also included a "freight differential" -again, cash - "to
reduce stress on the central gulf transportation and handling system â?¦ to
cover the costs of moving grain to other river transportation modes and handling
and locations."

ADM leaped into that breach and picked up $1.03 million in freight costs to
divert shipments to other ports. Dreyfus, which also diverted grain away from
New Orleans, collected $436,261.

Part four of the USDA plan sought to keep grain off Midwestern rivers by paying
upstream merchandisers, cooperatives and elevators to temporarily store it -
mostly on the ground - until the Mississippi system once again could absorb it.

The temporary storage approach, at least theoretically, also would keep local
grain prices from collapsing because of the river backlog.

Nineteen grain handlers - ranging from tiny Western Illinois Grain in
Colchester, Ill., to massive ADM - bid 32 million bushels of grain into the
temporary storage program at a total cost of $7.85 million, or an average 24.5
cents per bushel.

The industry's lions, again, received the lion's share of the money. ADM
pocketed $4.6 million to store 16.4 million bushels; Cargill grabbed $1.3
million on 5.2 million bushels; and the Japanese-owned Consolidated Grain &
Barge, now renamed CGB Enterprises, garnered $826,864 to hold on to 3.65million
bushels.

That's not a bad chunk of change for what most were going to have to do anyway.

Given the millions the Grain Gang got from the short-lived program, did any
aspect of the Katrina-inspired action actually hit its intended target, farmers
who witnessed cash grain prices slump after the hurricane slammed the gulf?

"The theory was right," notes Richard Sauder, general manager of Tremont
Cooperative Grain in Tremont, Ill., "but it mostly put money in the pockets of
big agribusiness." (Tremont Grain received $25,000 in USDA cash to temporarily
store 200,000 bushels of corn under the program.)

"Did it help farmers directly?" Sauder continues. "No. Did it help them
indirectly? Well, it could have."

Then, after a long pause, he adds, "You can get a lot of money in Washington by
just saying, 'This will help farmers.'"

True, yet it's very doubtful the program helped farmers.

It is crystal clear, however, that USDA's quickly implemented
"help-your-local-transnational-grain-company" program fattened their bottom
lines.

Hey, disaster always has been a good business to be in.

Alan Guebert is a freelance agricultural journalist. He can be reached at
agcomm@sbcglobal.net or at 21673 Lago Drive, Delavan, IL 61734.

LOAD-DATE: November 17, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                           Greeley Tribune (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 5, 2009 Tuesday

EDITORIAL: Urgency needed in aid for farmers

BYLINE: Greeley Tribune, Colo.

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 366 words


May 5--Time is of the essence for farmers, dairy operators and ranchers who have
loans through New Frontier Bank.

That's why we appreciate Democratic senators Mark Udall and Michael Bennet, as
well as U.S. Rep. Betsy Markey, D-Fort Collins, jumping in last week to seek
help for area farmers affected by the closing of New Frontier.

We just hope it's not too late.

The delegation asked the U.S. Department of Agriculture to shift funds from its
guaranteed loan program to its direct operating loan program in the hopes some
area farmers could secure enough funds to continue operating.

Time is running out. New Frontier is scheduled to close Friday, and the Federal
Deposit Insurance Corp., which has taken over the bank, is working to resolve
loans held by the institution.

Other area banks also are trying to help out, but they don't have the loan
capacity to take all of New Frontier's debtors. It is estimated the closure of
New Frontier will leave $70 million in unmet loans for agriculture operators.

We hope the Department of Agriculture, through its Farm Service Agency, can act
quickly and give some hope to these farmers. This is a critical time. Because
their payoff doesn't come until harvest, most farmers need operating loans each
year to survive. Farmers need money to get their crops in the ground and have
enough to get them through the growing season and into harvest.

We don't have to remind anyone how important agriculture is to this county. As
Markey said, it is the "backbone of the local economy." We don't want to see
farms or other agriculture operations fail because of the closure of New
Frontier.

We urge our senators and representatives to continue their diligence and secure
help for our area agriculture producers quickly.

There simply isn't time to wait.

To see more of the Greeley Tribune, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.greeleytribune.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Greeley Tribune, Colo.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                    February 2, 1991, Saturday, City Edition

EPA moves to save Canyon views

SECTION: NATIONAL; WASHINGTON DIGEST; Pg. 9A

LENGTH: 543 words



The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) moved to protect the magnificent views
of the Grand Canyon by proposing on Friday a 70 percent cut in pollution from a
Southwestern power plant that blocks winter visibility. Acting on the last day
of a 1984 court order won by the Environmental Defense Fund, the EPA is
proposing reductions in allowed sulfur dioxide emissions from the northern
Arizona Navajo Generating Station, one of the largest coal-fired electric
utilities in the country. This is the first time a major regulatory action has
been proposed to improve visibility, the EPA said. Winter haze is significant
because of increasing wintertime visitors to the park almost 900,000 in 1989,
about 21 percent of the total annual visitors.
 ROTC programs to close or combine
 The Navy said Friday it plans to close Reserve Officer Training Corps (ROTC)
programs at five universities and combine 16 others into eight "consortia." The
five programs to be closed in 1996 are at Texas Tech University, the University
of Minnesota, the University of Missouri, the University of New Mexico and the
University of Utah. No new ROTC students will be enrolled in programs at those
schools after Sept. 30. The Navy said that in the budget year that begins next
Oct. 1 it will establish eight "geographic consortia" for ROTC students who
currently are enrolled in ROTC programs at 16 sites. For example, ROTC students
at University of California-Los Angeles and the University of Southern
California will be placed in a combined program. The Navy said the ROTC
reductions reflect a budget squeeze, plans for a smaller Navy and Marine Corps
and a need to reduce the number of new officers commissioned each year.  It said
the reductions will save the Navy $ 18.5-million a year.
 Imported French wines ruled safe
 Federal regulators said Friday that a fungicide widely used on grapes in Europe
was safe when consumed in very small amounts, ending a year-old dispute over
French wine exports to the United States. The Environmental Protection Agency
(EPA) said in a statement that it had concluded that procymidone, made by
Japan-based Sumitomo Chemical Co. Ltd., was safe when found on wine grapes grown
before Jan. 1, 1990, at levels of seven parts per million or less. "The EPA
action clears the way for uninterrupted importation of wines from a number of
countries including France, Italy and Spain," Sumitomo said in a statement
issued by its U.S.  arm, Sumitomo Chemical America Inc. The United States banned
imports of French wines for nine months last year after traces of the chemical
which is not used in the United States turned up in several wines.
 Briefly
 New Zealand would be able to ship avocados to the United States under a
proposal announced Friday by the Agriculture Department.  "We have determined
that New Zealand is free from high-risk pests, such as fruit flies and weevils,
that attack avocados," said James W.  Glosser, head of the department's Animal
and Plant Health Inspection Service.
 Cotton farmers soon will get about $ 185-million in payments for participating
in the 1990 program for upland cotton, the Agriculture Department said Friday.
Rice farmers will receive about $ 580-million from a similar plan.

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                    February 28, 2002 Thursday Metro Edition

More to qualify for food stamps

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DITS; Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 626 words


On Friday, more people in Indiana will qualify for food stamps.

The state is changing one of the rules. Owning a car worth more than $4,500
won't count against applicants anymore.

"This should have been changed years ago," said Charlotte Barrier, placing extra
emphasis on "years." She works with clients seeking poverty relief at the
Portage Township trustee's office in South Bend.

"This will particularly help families who've exhausted their savings but still
need to get to work," said John Hamilton, secretary of the state's Family and
Social Services Administration, who came to Elkhart to make the announcement.

He said the state knows of more than 600 households that were denied food stamps
because of the vehicle rule last year.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture finances the food stamp program and sets the
programs' restrictions. But, within the past year, the USDA allowed states to
change the vehicle rule.

Indiana officials seized the opportunity. Not only are they helping needy people
in tough economic times, but giving out more food stamps doesn't require a dime
of state money. Indiana Gov. Frank O'Bannon recently ordered a freeze on hiring
and wages for state employees and trimmed other programs for the elderly and
disabled.

The number of food stamp recipients in Indiana increased 20 percent in the past
year, Hamilton said. Most of the recipients are children. Hoosiers received
$32.7 million of the aid in December alone, said Cindy Collier, the FSSA's
policy director.

To qualify, a food stamp applicant must have no more than $2,000 in savings.
Until today, a car is permissible if it's used for household duties such as
going to work or going shopping -- not recreational vehicles. But, every dollar
of the vehicle's value that exceeds $4,500 is counted as assets against the
$2,000 limit.

So, an applicant whose car is worth more than $6,500 could not qualify.

Nor could a family that owns two cars, each worth $6,000. The excessive value of
each car would add up to $3,000 in assets.

Now welfare workers won't be concerned with the vehicles, unless, Hamilton said,
a family owns six cars, raising questions that the family is spending beyond its
means.

Applicants will still need to meet income requirements. For example, the income
for a family of four cannot exceed about $18,000, Hamilton said.

"The old rule was probably outdated," said Charles Smith, director of St. Joseph
County's welfare office.

Even in homes where both parents work, the adults need their cars to keep their
entry-level jobs, he said.

What happens to someone who's denied food stamps?

"They end up here more often," said Vonda Horst of Church Community Services in
Elkhart, where she counsels needy clients in finding help. She has seen several
clients disqualified from food stamps because of the vehicle rule.

Single men may have been the most vulnerable under the old rule, at least in the
eyes of Linda Jung-Zimmerman, director of the Advocacy Center in South Bend and
Mishawaka, two offices of the United Religious Community that connect the needy
with help.

Long-term help for the men is limited, while mothers and children can turn to a
variety of welfare aid for families, she said.

The change raised questions in the mind of Nyla Moore, the trustee for Elkhart's
Concord Township, who offers aid for the needy.

Maybe people will benefit in the long term. But, she asked, if more people apply
for food stamps, will this overload welfare caseworkers and create delays? She's
particularly concerned about O'Bannon's hiring freeze on welfare employees.

Smith said he has five vacancies that he can't fill in a staff of 200. He has
yet to hear about any other potential cuts.


LOAD-DATE: March 14, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: John Hamilton, secretary of Indiana's Family and Social Services
Administration, describes changes in food stamp rules in a talk Wednesday to the
Elkhart Chamber of Commerce. Starting Friday, owning a car worth more than
$4,500 no longer will count against applicants.  Tribune Photo/GENE KAISER

                 Copyright 2002 South Bend Tribune Corporation


                              708 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                  November 30, 2005, Wednesday, FINAL EDITION

French rally around farmers at WTO talks

BYLINE: Noelle Knox

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 1153 words

DATELINE: MONTALET-LE-BOIS, France

MONTALET-LE-BOIS, France -- In the late afternoon November sun, Philippe
Durand's small fields of young wheat are the picture of French country living.
There's only one problem with this picture. Durand's 500-acre farm wouldn't
survive without government subsidies and trade barriers.

"I'd be finished," said Durand, 39, who works alone, growing wheat, rapeseed
(the source of canola oil) and sugar beets on his farm about 35 miles west of
Paris.


And it's not just a problem for him. In fact, the international dispute over
farm subsidies and market access could shatter any hopes of reaching a global
trade agreement when the World Trade Organization meets in Hong Kong on Dec.
13-18.

This round of trade negotiations is turning out to be a showdown between the
United States, which is the world's largest agricultural producer, and France,
which is No.2 and the voice for European farmers. And there is a parallel battle
between rich countries and such emerging nations as Brazil, India and China. All
sides have put offers on the table that the others claim are not enough.

"We can't give everything without getting anything in return," says Christian
Ligeard, head of international relations for the French Ministry of Agriculture.
"We've said clearly to the (European trade) negotiator, if the package is only
agriculture, we will say, 'No.'"

For American farmers, who receive $23 billion in direct farm subsidies plus
indirect support, the pain will depend on how deep U.S. negotiators agree to
cut. But, in exchange, there could be deals for international services, such as
banking and insurance, as well as for manufacturing sectors such as computers
and cars.

Also at risk is the WTO's reputation, damaged after trade negotiations in Mexico
collapsed in 2003 following a failed trade summit in Seattle in 1999.

Ironically, many French farmers today criticize the subsidies, claiming they
make farmers less efficient by growing crops based on the financial assistance
they will receive, instead of rotating crops to help replenish the soil, Durand
says.

"It's the subsidy that determines whether a certain crop is worth growing or
not," he says.

On farms north of the Loire Valley, he says by way of an example, you almost
never see sunflowers anymore. That's because farmers are paid the same subsidy
for sunflowers and rapeseed, and sunflowers need more sun and attract more
hungry birds.

"The subsidy is set arbitrarily by (EU lawmakers in) Brussels, without
consideration to regional traditions. Because of that, the face of agriculture
in France has changed. Because of that, the sunflower is scratched from the
list, just like that," he says, flicking his hand.

Durand admits he also cultivates his land to maximize his revenue (he earns
$35,000 a year) and take advantage of subsidies. Because farmers are paid based
on what they produce, they produced gluts of butter and milk. In January, the
system will change and farmers will be paid a subsidy based on an average of
what they produced the last three years.

"It's absurd," Durand says. "In the fourth year, (the farmer) can work less and
take less and less responsibility. He will be paid off historical amounts, not
how he's working now."

Free trade ideas challenged

But free trade is getting a bad name in France, where unemployment is almost 10%
and double that in immigrant quarters (where rioters recently torched cars and
schools). Labor unions are being forced to give concessions in order to stop
companies from moving factories to Eastern and Central Europe, where wages and
benefits are lower.

In May, France voted against a constitution for the European Union, a political
and economic alliance of 25 countries, partly out of fear of competition from
cheaper labor in Eastern and Central Europe.

"If you work in a factory making textiles, you have to find another job, but
what job?" Ligeard explains. "They voted against the referendum because of a
concern that we're playing with the rest of the world but not by the same rules
so we're not going to gain. We're playing at a considerable handicap."

French President Jacques Chirac, whose approval ratings have skidded to 35%,
according to a survey by IFOP published this month in Le Journal du Dimanche, is
under severe pressure to protect French farmers, who, despite representing only
2.5% of the workforce, wield a lot of political power.

France, which will be represented in Hong Kong by the European Union, has agreed
to an EU proposal to eliminate subsidies for agricultural exports -- which
account for 8% of the EU's agricultural aid budget of $53 billion. Last week,
the Europeans also agreed to cut sugar subsidies by 36% over four years.
European governments pay their farmers three times the price of sugar on the
world market.

Now, France wants the U.S. to abolish its food-aid program for poor countries,
claiming it subsidizes farmers, and instead give cash aid so poor countries can
buy what food they need wherever they want.

"If you want us to eliminate our export subsidies, we want you to eliminate your
food-aid program and give aid in cash," Ligeard says.

In response, Neena Moorjani, spokeswoman for the U.S. Trade Representative,
said, "The U.S. has put forward proposals to put additional disciplines around
food aid that will prevent commercial displacement. We are concerned with
proposals by the EU that would allow food aid on a cash-only basis."

Moorjani said, "Research shows that when countries move to cash-only policies,
the amount of food aid they give declines."

The French also are demanding that developing countries, such as Brazil, India
and China, open their markets to French cars and other manufactured products, as
well as to banks and other service companies.

But developing countries, which are the majority of the WTO's 148 members, have
dug their trenches.

"They're saying to big countries, 'If you're serious about opening global
markets so we can benefit from international trade, you have to open your
markets to our food products. You promised us you would in (trade negotiations
from 1986 to 1994) Uruguay, and you didn't,'" says John Audley, a trade expert
at the German Marshall Fund, a trans-Atlantic think tank.

Many Europeans, however, remember the days after World War II, when people
starved because there wasn't enough food. That crisis was the genesis of
Europe's agricultural policies, which were designed to create and support a
self-sufficient food supply.

At Durand's farmhouse -- 6,100 miles from Hong Kong -- he knows French subsidies
are on the bargaining table. He knows Europe's agricultural policies will
change, if not in this trade round, in another.

"I already made my own revolution," he says. "I must be an opportunist in the
face of the system. If the system is absurd, I must be absurd."






LOAD-DATE: November 30, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                   USA TODAY

                      May 7, 1992, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

FOREIGN AID

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 4A

LENGTH: 229 words


Senators bluntly warned the Bush administration Wednesday that its aid package
for the former Soviet republics is in danger because it can be seen as a foreign
aid blank check. During a joint Agriculture Committee/Appropriations foreign aid
panel hearing, Sen. Robert Kasten, R- Wis., pointed out vague language in the
bill calling for ''such sums as may be necessary'' for various aid programs.
Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., said President Bush's package lacks ''theme, theory
or consistency.'' The aid bill includes new grain credits and agricultural and
economic technical assistance.

BANK RECORDS: Rep. Henry Gonzalez, D-Texas, was rejected when he made an
emergency request to Chief Justice William Rehnquist to temporarily halt special
counsel Malcolm Wilkey's review of records from the now-closed House bank
pending further court action. He said giving the records to Wilkey threatens
Congress' independence. House officials have complied with a Justice Department
subpoena and turned over the records to Wilkey.

REP. JAMES QUITS: Rep. Craig James, R-Fla., said he would not run for re-
election this November because he did not want his reputation tarnished by
congressional scandals. He raises the number of House members not returning to
Congress to 61. Forty-two are retiring, 13 are running for senator or governor
and six lost in party primaries.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Capital Line

                    Times-News (Burlington, North Carolina)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 11, 2014 Tuesday

Alamance Co. catches up on food aid applications

BYLINE: By Chris Lavender, Times-News, Burlington, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 288 words


Feb. 11--The Alamance County Department of Social Services successfully cleared
its backlogged food nutrition service applications before the Monday federal
deadline.

County DSS Economics Support Program Manager Michelle Poole said 246 backlogged
food nutrition service applications had been processed by Friday before the Feb.
10 deadline

As of Feb. 3, county DSS had 30 backlogged applications that needed processing,
narrowing the number to six applications that needed processing Friday.

Alamance County DSS wasn't the only social services department that was required
to meet the deadline of Feb.10 that the U.S. Department of Agriculture set last
month. Social services agencies in 24 counties, including Durham, Orange, Wake,
Mecklenburg, Guilford, Forsyth and Cumberland, faced it as well.

Eleven regional processing centers were established statewide last week for
social services staff with assistance from NC FAST -- N.C. Families Accessing
Services through Technology -- "over-the-shoulder" staff support to process
backlogged applications.

Alamance County DSS staff began processing backlogged applications Feb. 4 at a
regional processing center in Orange County. Social services departments from
Durham and Orange counties were present at the same regional center with
Alamance County DSS. The social service departments joined together to complete
the process.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture had threatened to cut federal funding
provided to the counties through the Food and Nutrition Service Program if the
deadline of Feb. 10 was not met to clear the backlogged applications.

www.thetimesnews.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                           August 29, 2007 Wednesday
                                  City Edition

Food brief

BYLINE: LINCOLN JOURNAL STAR

SECTION: D; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 97 words

DATELINE: Lincoln, NE


CHIPOTLE PROCEEDS TO BENEFIT FARM AID

As part of its ongoing commitment to helping family farms, Chipotle Mexican
Grill today will donate proceeds from sales of items made with naturally raised
pork, beef and chicken to Farm Aid, a nonprofit organization that supports and
promotes family farming and sustainable agriculture.

Chipotle will contribute up to $50,000 to Farm Aid.

Chipotle's naturally raised meat includes 100 percent of its pork, more than 70
percent of its chicken, and nearly half of its beef.

Chipotle has two Lincoln locations: 2801 Pine Lake Road and 232 N. 13th St.
