                              712 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     April 5, 1980, Saturday, Final Edition

U.S. Acts to Halt the Sale of Cattle Fattened With the Aid of Banned DES

BYLINE: By Joanne Omang, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A4

LENGTH: 559 words


The government moved yesterday to halt the sale of more than 70,000 cattle known
to have been implanted illegally with the banned growth stimulant DES, which
causes cancer in laboratory animals.

As many as 200,000 steers, or about two-days' normal slaughter, may be affected
in five states, primarily in Kansas and the Texas Panhandle, according to a
joint statement from the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the Food and Drug
Administration.

Some cattle illegally fattened with the aid of DES "unquestionably" already have
been sold, slaughtered and consumed, according to Tom Grumbly of USDA's Food,
Safety and Quality Service.  However, he said, the meat is "no worse than any
that was on the market prior to the ban," which went into effect last Nov. 1.

DES, or diethylstilbestrol, is a synthetic estrogen that was prescribed a
generation ago to control human pregnancy disorders.  however, some daughters of
the treated women developedvaginal or cervical cancer and some sons suffered
genital abnormalities.  Laboratory animals developed cancer when fed DES, which
has been used nationwide since 1954 to speed cattle fatteniing.

Livestock and feed industries and DES suppliers fought proposed bans for seven
years and have challenged the most recent one in court.  "An investigation by
FDA over the past two weeks has revealed widespread disregard for the ban," the
two agency heads said in the joint statement.

"These violations simply are not acceptable.  A drug associated with a long-term
health hazard has been deliberately introduced into the food system in violation
of the law."

Grumbly said two officials of Allied Mills Inc., a Chicago-based subsidiary of
Continental Grain Co., voluntarily disclosed to the FDA last March 14 that DES
was being used at two Allied feedlots in Kansas.

FDA investigators found that the DES pellets, which are implanted behind
animals' ears, has been distributed by Walco International Inc., of Porterville,
Calif., and Schmidt-allen of Greeley, Colo., after the July 13 cutoff date for
sales.  The two firms are voluntarily recalling any existing stocks, the
agencies said.

The pellets were then implanted in steers after the Nov. 1 deadline in 30
feedlots, the statement said.  Fifteen of those were in Kansas, eight in Texas,
four in Colorado, two in California and one in Nebraska.  In letters sent out
yesterday, the feedlot owners were ordered to remove all the implants and hold
the cattle until the DES has been eliminated from their systems.

That means the affected animals will be held for at least 35 days, 63 days if
the kidneys or livers are to be used for human food.

The National Cattlemen's Association immediately protested that the time
requirement was "impractical and will needlessly delay the marketing of cattle."

While noting that the organization "does not condone in any way the use of any
product which has been ruled illegal," spokesman Roger Berglund said a delay of
120 days after the pellet implantation had been the norm before the ban and
ought to be used now.

That period, he said, was sufficient previously to guarantee elimination of DES.
"There never have been any DES residues in edible tissue as a result of
commercial use of DES implants," he said.  "There is no cause for concern about
the wholesomeness and safety of beef."

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1980 The Washington Post


                              713 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                             January 7, 1996 Sunday

LENGTH: 221 words


DICKINSON -- Dickinson State University is offering a customized agronomy
application training class to meet the needs of agriculture businesses in
southwest North Dakota. Funded in part by a Work Force 2000 grant, the 16-week
course covers classroom training in first aid, transportation forms, records and
laws, interpersonal relationships and commercial applicator license training.
The course also includes the DSU driving course and on-the-job training. The
course is in response to industry needs and was spurred by the Southwest Farmers
Union Oil Company Managers Association. ""Ag-related businesses in the state are
finding it nearly impossible to locate trained employees to meet their
increasing employment needs,'' said Connie Kooren, general manager of the
Dickinson Cenex Land of Lakes Cooperative. ""More and more services are being
demanded by ... both large and small farmers.'' Kooren also said agri-business
employees are now required to hold several different certifications for
transporting and applying new chemicals. After completing the course, students
will have earned certifications in truck driving, chemical application, first
aid and CPR, plus their class A drivers license. To enroll, call DSU at
227-2175. For information, call DSU's department of agriculture and technical
studies at 227-2185.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                        York Daily Record (Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 18, 2011 Friday

EDITORIAL: Floods and drought at the same time?

BYLINE: York Daily Record, Pa.

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 429 words


Nov. 18--We must be nearing the end times here in Pennsylvania -- Penn State sex
scandals, heat waves, droughts, floods, all manner of Armageddonish things.

What's next -- a plague of locusts?

Oh right -- forgot about the national media swarming State College.

But seriously, you know things are bad when our area gets federal disaster
assistance for both flooding and drought.

Literally.

Tuesday's newspaper had stories about both.

--On page 2A, a wire piece noted that government aid to victims of Pennsylvania
summer flooding had totaled $187 million as of Monday.

Some 90,000 households registered for help and disaster assistance grants for
flooding associated with Hurricane Irene and Tropical Storm Lee in late August
and September, respectively.

Thank goodness for the aid to local people who suffered devastating losses from
flooding.

The deadline to apply for aid is Dec. 14.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture is also offering farmers assistance for crops
lost to late-summer flooding.

--On page 6B there was a brief story at the bottom of the Money & More page
noting that the USDA had declared York County a disaster area.

Flooding wiped out crops?

No -- drought.

The department said it was offering financial assistance to area farmers because
of "drought and excessive heat that occurred June 1-Aug. 30, 2011."

Heat? Yes. There were some pretty hot stretches this summer.

But drought?

Well, that's puzzling.

Even before the late-summer deluges, area rainfall numbers seemed OK.

At the York Airport, June was indeed below normal rainfall by 4.17 inches.

But both July and August were above normal at the airport -- July by 1.72 inches
and August by 2.49 inches.

Maybe not an ideal summer for agriculture, but not numbers that would seem to
indicate a disaster either.

This will almost certainly end up being among the wettest years on record
locally, and the Agriculture Department is offering drought relief to farmers --
as well as flooding relief?

Weird.

Oh well, some farmers could no doubt use the low-interest loans and such. They
are an important part of our local economy, and we would not deny them
assistance to stay economically viable.

Conservative taxpayers might have a different take on the situation, though.

Yes, it sure has been a strange weather year (Oct-snow-ber!). And climate
scientists say we can expect more of the same as global warming makes for wilder
weather patterns.

All we ask is, please, please, no snowmaggedons this winter!

___ (c)2011 York Daily Record (York, Pa.) Visit York Daily Record (York, Pa.) at
www.ydr.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

LOAD-DATE: November 18, 2011

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: YO

                       Vallejo Times Herald (California)

                           February 7, 2007 Wednesday

Solano begins process for disaster area status

BYLINE: By Erin Pursell, The Reporter staff, Vacaville

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 364 words


The Governor's Office of Emergency Services has requested that Solano County be
added to the list of 18 counties statewide that were declared disaster areas
after last month's cold snap.

The designation is needed in the wake of the freezing temperatures that extended
from Jan. 6 to Jan. 19 and left more than $45,000 - a preliminary estimate - in
damage to crops, according to Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger in a letter to the
U.S. Secretary of Agriculture.

"Though the full effect of the freezing temperatures may not be realized until a
later time, current estimates are reflecting a 90 percent loss to orange and
lemon crops," the letter reads.

Those figures result from a countywide survey of citrus growers that
demonstrated that that county meets federal standards requiring that 30 percent
of a crop must be lost to receive disaster status, according to Solano County
Agricultural Commissioner Jerry Howard, who described the freeze as dramatic and
devastating.

"Citrus is a small commercial crop in Solano County, but those growers who had
invested in it did have significant losses," he said. "Citrus is the crop that
qualifies us for the agricultural disaster but because of that others could
qualify for aid as well."

Receiving the disaster designation is a multi-agency, multi-step process - with
an unclear timeline - but once it is finalized, local farmers likely will have
an eight-month window to apply for aid, he explained.

"At this stage of the game it's as positive a step as we could hope for after a
disaster," Howard said regarding the process.

Robert Hansen, manager of Suisun Valley Fruit Growers, a local nonprofit
agriculture cooperative, is among local farmers who have commended the county's
effort to garner federal aid.

"In the Dixon and Winters areas the citrus got wiped out," he said, and noted
that the disaster designation will help as farmers continue to thaw their
businesses.

"The disaster relief only pays a portion of the cost of maintaining a tree," he
said regarding federal aid. "But it sure helps."

For more information including resources related to the 2007 freeze recovery,
visit www.oes.ca.gov.

Erin Pursell can be reached at county@thereporter.com.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                      Foster's Daily Democrat, Dover, N.H

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             March 6, 2012 Tuesday

State agency will provide one-time funding aid for vet diagnostic lab at UNH

BYLINE: Andrea Bulfinch, Foster's Daily Democrat, Dover, N.H.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 544 words


March 06--DURHAM-- A one-time funding source will help to maintain the New
Hampshire Veterinary Diagnostic Laboratory open for the next year and a half at
the University of New Hampshire campus.

After a reduction in funding for the laboratory was made for this year and next
following cuts to both the university and the state agriculture department, the
facility was at risk of being shut down, closing its programs and laying off its
instructors. A contribution from the state Department of Agriculture, Markets &
Food will now cover the anticipated shortfall for fiscal year 2013.

"It's something we've been working toward for several months," Lorraine Merril,
commissioner of agriculture markets and food, said. The the diagnostic
laboratory is a joint operation between the state Department of Agriculture
Markets and Food, the public, and the university, she said

She described the diagnostic lab as being hit by a perfect storm of
circumstances consisting of cuts to the budget for the department of agriculture
, the recession having affected the fees normally received for services of the
laboratory sought by veterinary and livestock communities, and the 48 percent
overall cut in funding to the university, she said.

"It just made a lot of reductions to the point of being pretty dire," Merril
said.

While students shared a lot of concern over the possibility of the laboratory
being shut down, its effects would have reached beyond campus, Merril explained,
saying it plays a crucial role to public health in addition to animals and the
students education. The laboratory is where animals can be tested for rabies,
EEE or West Nile virus, she said.

But the outpouring from students and parents was immense. Through phone calls
and emails she said they were very concerned about the possibility of the
laboratory being closed and really appreciative of the benefits they get from
being able to work in the facility and do research projects. She said students
also receive advising and some teaching from the veterinary pathologists who
staff the lab.

Merril said the funding should get the program through fiscal year 2013. Beyond
that, ways of increasing revenue and having state funding renewed are being
looked at for a more stable financial model.

In a statement from the university, the goal is for the lab to be able to
produce a balanced budget through steps to include an improved business model,
an increase in external funding through increased fees, expanded services and
private giving, and a continuation of the funding partnership from the state and
the UNH College of Life Sciences and Agriculture.

In the same statement, dean of the College of Life Sciences and Agriculture Jon
Wraith, said the response heard from students is what made those involved
determined to bridge the gap. He said with the commissioners office and the
laboratory staff, they've been able to identify and develop a good start on new
revenue streams.

As for this one-time contribution, Merril said it will help to bridge the gap
between then and now.

"We just knew we needed to find a way to make it work," she said.

___ (c)2012 the Foster's Daily Democrat (Dover, N.H.) Visit the Foster's Daily
Democrat (Dover, N.H.) at www.fosters.com Distributed by MCT Information
Services

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                      August 5, 1988, Friday, City Edition

Newly developed processor makes rice bran fit for humans

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 508 words

DATELINE: TORRANCE, Calif.; MINNEAPOLIS; ATLANTA



TORRANCE, Calif. - Rice bran, long consigned to feed for cattle and   pigs, can
now be rendered economically fit for human consumption   because of a new
technology developed by a company here. Brady   International, developer of the
technology, announced shipment to two   California mills Wednesday of its
rice-bran processor, which resulted   from a government program aimed at making
better use of the world's   present supply of rice. The development could also
improve nutrition in   this fiber-conscious country as well as abroad. Brady
developed the   processor in conjunction with the U.S. Department of
Agriculture. The   machines, which stabilize rancid-prone rice bran, are
produced under   contract by ASI Controls in Houston. Robin M. Saunders,
research leader   of the food quality research unit of USDA's Western Regional
Research   Center in Albany, Calif., said stabilizing rice bran has been a
high-priority research project for at least 25 years.

    Surgeon steps aside after story     MINNEAPOLIS - The University of
Minnesota's chief heart-lung surgeon   is temporarily stepping aside from two
positions amid a report that has   led a newspaper to acknowledge a "serious
lapse of journalistic   judgment," officials said Wednesday. The Star Tribune,
in a copyright   story Tuesday, reported that Dr. Stuart Jamieson was being
investigated   by the university for allegedly ordering an associate to perform
bypass   surgery on a patient considered dead before the operation began. But in

   a front-page statement in Thursday editions, Star Tribune executive   editor
Joel Kramer said the account of the operation should not have   been published
"because it was based on sources who did not have   first-hand information to
support the account. The surgeon who   performed the operation, Dr. Jolene
Kriett, has since denied that Dr.   Jamieson knew anything about the surgery
until several hours after it   was performed," Kramer said. "The Star Tribune's
efforts to reach Dr.   Kriett before publication of the first story were
unsuccessful, and Dr.   Jamieson had refused to comment."

    AIDS in military: 1 in 1,000    ATLANTA - The largest testing program yet in
a specific group of  Americans has found that just more than one in 1,000
active-duty  military personnel have been exposed to the AIDS virus, lower than

 among the general population, officials said Thursday. The U.S. Centers  for
Disease Control said 2,232 of 1,752,191 people on active duty on  April 24 had
tested positive for antibodies to the virus which causes  AIDS, a rate of 1.3
per 1,000. The Defense Department began screening  for AIDS exposure in January
1986. Federal health officials have  estimated that 1.5-million Americans are
infected with the AIDS virus;  that would be roughly five times the rate among
active-duty military   personnel.

                              721 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                              The Washington Post

                             June 6, 2002 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Funds Sought For Farmers Who Need To Rebuild;
Insurance, Current Aid Leave Gaps, Officials Say

BYLINE: a Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: SOUTHERN MARYLAND EXTRA; Pg. T03

LENGTH: 669 words


Maryland and Charles County officials told area farmers Monday night they would
ask the state legislature and Congress for additional tornado relief to fill in
where insurance and current government aid programs have fallen short.

The officials told a group of about 25 farmers that cash grants and
zero-interest loans may be available for those whose insurance will not cover
heavy losses.

Much of the possible funding will depend on a Maryland Department of Agriculture
effort to determine how much farmers lost and the costs of rebuilding. At least
47 farms were affected by the tornado, and those farmers are being asked to tell
state agriculture officials how much of a gap exists between their insurance
claims and their rebuilding estimates.

"It's going to give us a number that we can talk to people about," said Hagner
R. Mister, the Maryland secretary of agriculture and a former Calvert County
commissioner. "We don't want any farmers left behind."

Since a federal disaster area was declared in Charles, Calvert and Dorchester
counties a month ago, affected area farmers have said they feel left out of the
federal aid packages streaming into the area.

Most assistance available to farmers is in the form of low-interest loans. While
most aid being offered to all categories of property owners is in the form of
loans, taking on new debt can present special problems for farmers.

"I know that loans can get you in more trouble than they get you out of," said
Del. Samuel C. Linton (D-Charles).

To enable a farmer to obtain cash grants that do not have to be repaid, local
officials have looked to the General Assembly and Congress to set aside some
disaster relief.

State Sen. Thomas McLain Middleton (D-Charles) said the legislature's budget
committees would consider calling a special session to fund a relief package. He
said cash grants are a possibility -- especially for the poor, for people who do
not have access to current relief programs and for young farmers, who are rare
and valued.

"The purpose of it is to keep farmers farming," Middleton said.

Middleton also asked farmers if they would be interested in zero-interest loans,
a relief option that may be more feasible. Few farmers raised their hands.

"If you're going to make it zero percent, let's not make it a welfare program
where only the extremely poor can apply," said Bobby Stahl, 40, who lost his
house, several barns and two vehicles when the tornado struck his 10-acre cattle
farm on Oliver's Shop Road. "Let's make it eligible for all of us."

Like many other farmers, Stahl says he has been "flat-out denied" by several
federal agencies he asked for assistance.

The Charles County commissioners have asked Congress to budget $ 17 million in
additional disaster relief in the appropriations bills coming up for hearings
this summer.

"It seems to me that the federal government should be able to step up to the
plate and help our county," said Commissioner Allan R. Smith (R-Waldorf).

Aides to Sen. Barbara A. Mikulski (D-Md.) and Rep. Steny H. Hoyer (D-Md.), both
of whom sit on appropriations committees, said their offices had not received
the Charles County letter yet. Hoyer has said he is working on obtaining some
extra disaster assistance for Southern Maryland, which is in his district.

But many at the meeting acknowledged that government may not be able to fill all
the gaps. One Charles County farmer told of a $ 1.5 million estimate he received
just for removal of tree stumps. Others talked of hundreds of thousands of
dollars of loss, much of which will not be covered by insurance.

With or without government assistance, most farmers say they will rebuild, if
not everything, then what they can.

Steve Walter, who grows grain, hay and other crops on a 500-acre farm west of
Hughesville, lost 13 barns and several grain bins. He still doesn't know what he
will rebuild.

"Given the situation, who knows?" Walter said. "I don't know how long I've got
to be in the grain business in this county."

                       Grand Forks Herald (North Dakota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 4, 2014 Thursday

BRIEF: $50,000 in federal funds to aid low-income homeowners in Pembina County

BYLINE: Grand Forks Herald

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 133 words


Dec. 04--The Red River Regional Council will receive $50,000 in federal funds to
help 11 low-income homeowners in Pembina County make needed repairs to their
homes.

The funds for the Red River Regional Council are available through the U.S.
Department of Agriculture Rural Development's Housing Preservation Grant
Program.

U.S. Sen. Heidi Heitkamp, chairwoman of the Senate Agriculture Subcommittee that
oversees rural development, said in a press release issued Wednesday the funds
are "a much-needed investment for some of the least fortunate in our state to
help make sure they have safe homes in which to raise their families."

                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            February 2, 2007 Friday

EDITORIAL: More aid

BYLINE: The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: COMMENTARY

LENGTH: 359 words


Feb. 2--GOV. BILL Ritter has ordered the Colorado Department of Local Affairs to
distribute $635,000 to eight area counties to help them meet expenses resulting
from two major blizzards at the end of December.

Many counties in Southeastern Colorado already have exceeded their snow removal
budgets despite the fact that in December then-Gov. Bill Owens made $2 million
available to the region for snow plowing and other emergency costs. The latest
round of state aid will be distributed to the eight counties thusly:

- Baca, $100,000.

- Bent, $50,000.

- Crowley, $50,000.

- Huerfano, $60,000.

- Kiowa, $50,000.

- Las Animas, $100,000.

- Otero, $100,000.

- Prowers, $125,000.

In addition to state aid, the U.S. Department of Agriculture has approved
low-interest loans to be made available to area farmers and ranchers hardest hit
by the storms, which left up to 15-foot snowdrifts and an estimated 10,000 head
of cattle dead.

Gov. Ritter said he also is working with Colorado's congressional delegation to
find further federal grants and assistance. He met last week with Rep. John
Salazar to talk about financial relief for ranchers and farmers.

The storms and the continued ice-cold weather pose a serious threat to cattle
and the calves now being born. One area rancher, Rod Ricken, says this is the
hardest year he has ever had calving since he began his cow-calf operation in
1965.

The threat is indeed real. Mr. Ricken says if he is not there to help within 30
minutes of a cow giving birth, the calf will die. That's bottom line for those
whose livelihoods are in cattle ranching.

More aid may be needed. Some will be forthcoming when Michael Martin Murphy
gives a benefit concert March 18 at the State Fair Events Center. Keep an eye
out for ticket sales to begin and plan to attend.

Our neighbors in the Arkansas Valley need all the help they can get.

Copyright (c) 2007, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune
Business News. For reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call
800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The
Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                              725 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                 The Australian

                          September 22, 2010 Wednesday
                          2 - All-round First Edition

IT'S MORE EXPENSIVE TO IGNORE POVERTY

BYLINE: ARCHIE LAW

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 633 words


Kevin Rudd has a chance to show true leadership to the world

TOMORROW, Foreign Minister Kevin Rudd is representing Australia at a UN summit
in New York to review progress on the Millennium Development Goals for halving
extreme poverty and hunger by 2015.

For the first time since being ousted as prime minister, Rudd will rub shoulders
with the likes of French President Nicolas Sarkozy and German Chancellor Angela
Merkel. He has already met US President Barack Obama on this visit. The summit
will provide him with an opportunity to demonstrate true leadership to the
world.

Despite being a nation of generous individuals, Australia's record on foreign
aid leaves much to be desired. We languish towards the bottom of the league
table for the amount of foreign aid we provide as a percentage of our gross
national income.

Australia provides just three cents per $100 of income to overseas aid -- or
0.33 per cent of gross national income.

Under Rudd's prime ministership, Australia committed to increase this to 0.5 per
cent, but now the UN is calling on governments to contribute at least 0.7 per
cent of national income to reach the Millennium Development Goals by the target
date of 2015.

Many other developed countries have already reached this target. In fact, some
are contributing more than 1 per cent of national income to aid.

With nearly 4.5 million children dying each year before their fifth birthday,
largely because of malnutrition, the case for increasing our aid program is
obvious.

However, the problem of global poverty and hunger is not just a moral challenge.
For the financially minded, the good news is that addressing the problem is far
cheaper than ignoring it.

For example, let's take a closer look at Millennium Development Goal One, which
aims, among other things, to halve hunger by 2015. According to the UN, to reach
this goal, an extra $40 billion in aid is needed each year to support
agricultural and food security programs that increase self-sufficiency in food
production.

To put that in perspective, a recent ActionAid report found hunger was costing
poor nations more than $450bn annually through reduced worker productivity, poor
health and lost education. That means fighting hunger is now 10 times cheaper
than ignoring it.

It is thus particularly disappointing that the report found Australia was a
laggard in aid to agriculture -- contributing less than one-third of its fair
share.

In fact, underinvestment in agriculture globally over the past decade means 20
of the 28 poor nations measured are off track to halving hunger by 2015; 12 of
these are going backwards.

In sub-saharan Africa, just under a third of the population was chronically
malnourished last year. If trends continue, nearly 50 per cent of Africans could
be going without enough food by 2020.

And it isn't just the poorest, war-torn and disaster-struck countries of the
world that are not doing well. Some of the world's wealthier countries are
shockingly off track.

In India, one of the world's emerging global economic successes, one in five of
the population is hungry and close to half of all children are malnourished.

It's not all bad news, however. By investing more in local agriculture,
governments can feed their people and regenerate rural economies.

Recent research has pointed to the vital role that agriculture played in China's
initial take-off.

Agriculture was estimated to have contributed to poverty reduction four times
more than growth in the manufacturing or service sectors.

Meanwhile, many other countries have slashed hunger rates by increasing
investment in small-scale farmers -- in particular women farmers.

Safety nets are also important to help small farmers keep planing and harvesting
through tough times.

Archie Law is chief executive of anti-poverty agency Action Aid Australia

LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: AUS


                   Copyright 2010 Nationwide News Pty Limited
                              All Rights Reserved

                              727 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       St. Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                            October 19, 2007 Friday

Organizers of fund for organic farmers hurt by floods say aid is pouring in

BYLINE: BY TOM WEBB Pioneer Press

SECTION: MINNESOTA-TWIN CITIES; Wisconsin

LENGTH: 277 words


Natural-food lovers have donated $270,000 to help organic farmers in
southeastern Minnesota and western Wisconsin recover from August's floods,
organizers said Friday.

The first $50,000 has just been distributed to 11 farms, with more to come from
the Sew the Seeds Fund. The outpouring surprised the organizers, who credit the
personal connection natural-foods consumers share with area growers, some of
whom faced 17 inches of rain in a single day.

"It's stunning," said Mark Muller of the Institute for Agriculture and Trade
Policy, a Minneapolis policy group. "When we started talking about this in
mid-August, we thought $5,000 or $10,000 would be great to get out to a few
farmers. But the response by consumers, the co-ops, the restaurants, then Whole
Foods jumping on board has just been great."

Customers at Whole Foods Markets in six Midwestern states donated about $40,000,
which was then joined by a $35,000 donation from the company's Midwest region,
spokeswoman Kate Klotz said.

On a smaller scale, "There was a group of kids in the Prospect Park neighborhood
in Minneapolis that had a lemonade stand and raised $40 for the Sew the Seeds
Fund," Muller said.

State and federal disaster aid also will become available to some farms with
major losses, but that funding can take a while.

Due partly to its hilly terrain, the region of southeastern Minnesota, western
Wisconsin and northeastern Iowa has been one of the nation's hotspots for
organic agriculture. The August deluge was particularly hard on organic
vegetable growers, who farm the rich valley floors most susceptible to
floodwaters.

Tom Webb can be reached at twebb@pioneerpress.com or 651-228-5428.

LOAD-DATE: October 20, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2007 St. Paul Pioneer Press
                              All Rights Reserved


                              728 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                March 11, 1999, Thursday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

NATION

BYLINE: From News Services

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A6, NATION BRIEFS COLUMN

LENGTH: 1006 words



Farmers must wait for $ 2 billion in disaster aid

Farmers counting on $ 2 billion in congressionally approved disaster aid will
have to wait until June to get it, Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman says. In a
letter sent Tuesday night to Senate Agriculture Chairman Richard Lugar and House
Agriculture Chairman Larry Combest, Glickman said administering the aid is "far
more complex than past natural disaster assistance programs." And he said the
agency is inundated with aid disbursements during this tumultuous farm year,
including assistance packages of $ 50 million for hog farmers and $ 200 million
for dairy farmers. "Getting these payments out as expeditiously and as fairly as
possible is a top personal priority for me," Glickman wrote. Combest, R-Texas,
responded that the delay was "unacceptable. There are now billions of dollars
that should already be in the hands of farmers and ranchers." Combest said
farmers need the money as they go into the planting season.

U.S.-Italian review of training flights is announced

A soon-to-retire Navy admiral will lead a joint U.S.-Italian review of safety
rules for U.S. military training flights originating from bases in Italy, the
Pentagon announced Wednesday. The 30-day review is designed to prevent the kind
of mistakes that led to the Feb. 3, 1998, accident in which a Marine Corps jet
severed cables holding a ski gondola near Cavalese, Italy, killing 20 people.
The pilot of the EA-6B jet, Marine Capt. Richard Ashby, was acquitted last week
in a military court-martial on 20 counts of involuntary manslaughter and
negligent homicide. The Marines are likely to make a decision by the end of this
week on whether to go ahead with the court-martial of Ashby's navigator on that
flight, Capt. Joseph Schweitzer. He also faces a charge of obstruction of
justice.

Benefits of Cuba embargo are debated at hearing

Defenders of the 4-decade-old U.S. embargo against Cuba said Wednesday it has
helped decimate the once-powerful Cuban military and forced economic reforms
that otherwise would not have been undertaken. Sen. Robert Torricelli, D-N.J.,
said at a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing that the weakening of the
Cuban military was one of several "real, lasting and tangible benefits" of the
economic embargo in recent years. But Eloy Gutierrez Menoyo, a Cuban exile who
heads a Miami-based anti-embargo group, testified that 40 years of isolation of
the Cuban regime has brought misery to the Cuban people and served only to
please "discredited" Florida exile groups opposed to President Fidel Castro.
With committee Chairman Jesse Helms, R-N.C., seated a few feet away, Menoyo said
Helms' embargo-tightening legislation of 1996 is "an insult to Cubans, offends
the world" and serves to perpetuate the Castro government.

2 justices defend hiring of women, minority clerks

Two Supreme Court justices Wednesday defended the court's record of hiring women
and minorities as law clerks but added there's room for improvement. "I must
stand in defense of my colleagues," Justice Clarence Thomas, the second black to
serve on the nation's highest court, told a House Appropriations subcommittee.
"I do believe that they would love to see more minorities at the Supreme Court
in every capacity." Justice David H. Souter predicted new pressure at law
schools to see that more high-achieving minorities and women are among those
recommended for clerkships. Thomas and Souter appeared before the House
Appropriations subcommittee on commerce, justice, state and the judiciary to
outline the h igh court's budget request for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1.


Arizona governor is treated for kidney infection

Arizona Gov. Jane Hull was in the hospital Wednesday with a kidney infection she
first noticed on a weekend trip to Mexico. "She is uncomfortable, but alert and
working," spokeswoman Francie Noyes said. Hull, 63, checked into Good Samaritan
Regional Medical Center in Phoenix on Tuesday evening, Noyes said. The governor
and her husband, a doctor, became concerned because she was so nauseous she
couldn't take antibiotic pills without vomiting, Noyes said. Hull took office in
1997 after the bank fraud conviction of former Gov. Fife Symington. She fell ill
Saturday while in the Gulf of California port of Puerto Penasco.

NASA moves up Hubble repair mission to October

NASA will launch an emergency repair mission this fall to the Hubble Space
Telescope, which is in danger of shutting down. NASA decided Wednesday to move
up the next regularly scheduled Hubble visit to October so spacewalking
astronauts can fix the telescope's deteriorating pointing system. The mission
had been set for June 2000. Two of Hubble's six gyroscopes, needed for pointing
and stability, have failed since astronauts' last service call, in 1997. A third
gyroscope is partly broken and considered unreliable. Astronomers need at least
three perfect gyroscopes to conduct observations throughout the universe. "We
are one failure away from losing science," said Ed Weiler, head of NASA's space
science program.

Lawmakers again push for education tax breaks

Lawmakers from both parties renewed a push Wednesday for education tax
legislation that President Bill Clinton vetoed last year. The measure offers tax
breaks for parents who send their children to private schools and allows
tax-free withdrawals from education savings accounts for pre-college expenses.
Clinton vetoed the legislation last summer, saying it would have provided $ 3
billion to fund tax benefits for richer families while doing "virtually nothing
for average families." Congressional backers believe they have a "strong,
bipartisan coalition building here," said one sponsor, Rep. Kenny Hulshof, R-Mo.
The Democratic co-sponsors are Sen. Robert Torricelli of New Jersey and Rep.
William Lipinski of Il linois. The bill would expand the tax-free savings
accounts that Congress created in 1997, with Clinton's blessing, to provide for
college expenses.

LOAD-DATE: July 25, 1999

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: PHOTO Photo by ASSOCIATED PRESS -  A protester cries out as she is
restrained by a new York City police officer outside the Chinese Mission
Wednesday. The demonstrators were marking the anniversary of Tibet's revolt
against China in 1959. The Chinese crackdown led the Dalai Lama to flee to
India.

LOAD-DATE: February 24, 2017


                              730 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                            April 8, 2009 Wednesday

States to get funds to rebuild dams;

BYLINE: Lincoln Journal Star

SECTION: Pg. B2

LENGTH: 241 words


Eleven states, including Nebraska, will share nearly $45 million in aid from the
economic stimulus program to rehabilitate aging dams, the Agriculture Department
said Monday.

Oklahoma will receive $14 million for several projects across the state, while
Georgia will get more than $6 million. Texas will receive nearly $5 million,
while projects in Massachusetts, Virginia and West Virginia were awarded more
than $4 million.

In Nebraska, $1.17 million will go to the Papillion Creek watershed dam site
W-3, south of Blair.

Tim Haakenstad, with the federal Natural Resources Conservation Service, says
four other Nebraska projects are awaiting approval.

The Papio Creek dam classification went from low hazard to high hazard due to a
higher traffic count on Highway 30. With urbanization in that area, there is a
greater danger that there could be lives lost if the dam broke and the creek
flooded the road, Haakenstad said.

The federal aid is designed to revitalize rural communities and bolster
deteriorating dams that could fail and threaten lives and property.

"Many dams and other important flood control structures across the country are
in a race against time," said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. He estimated
the funds would create about 1,000 jobs.

Projects in Arkansas, Kansas, Missouri and New York also will receive funding
under the program, which requires state and local sponsors to provide 35 percent
of the funding for their projects.

LOAD-DATE: April 8, 2009 Wednesday

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

Coffees, Cutlery, Forks, Freezers, Greenhouses, and 19 other Product & Service
categories tracked by NetWise Data. Custom Coffee Plan does business in the
Aerospace, Agriculture, and Automotive Industries, as well as 20 other major
Manufacturing Industries. Custom Coffee Plan has at least 4 business locations.
The company describes itself via it's website thusly: "Save money on office
coffee and breakroom supplies with Custom Coffee Plan, a division of Farmer
Brothers."

                              732 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                             Arusha Times (Arusha)

                                 July 28, 2012

US Sponsors Agricultural Studies for 58 Locals

LENGTH: 482 words


On Monday, July 23 on the grounds of the U.S. Embassy, Ambassador Alfonso E.
Lenhardt hosted a farewell program for 58 Tanzanian students receiving grants to
study agriculture, nutrition, and related fields at universities in Tanzania and
abroad.

The scholarships are sponsored by the American People through the United States
Agency for International Development (USAID) under the Feed the Future
Initiative. Several distinguished guests delivered remarks, including the Deputy
Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture Mbogo Futakamba, and Vice
Chancellor of Sokoine University of Agriculture Professor Gerald Monela.

Over a five-year period, Feed the Future will sponsor 120 Tanzanians for
postgraduate studies in agricultural and nutrition sciences. Currently, there
are six Tanzanian students pursuing either Master's or Doctoral degrees in the
Unites States of America. Of the 58 students sponsored this year, 29 of them
will pursue Master's and PhD degrees in agricultural and nutritional sciences at
six American universities - Ohio State University, Michigan State University,
Virginia Tech, Tuskegee University, University of Florida, and Iowa State
University.

Nineteen trainees will pursue Bachelors and Master's degrees at Sokoine
University of Agriculture, and ten trainees will pursue Master's and PhD degrees
at African universities outside Tanzania.

In his remarks to the students, Ambassador Lenhardt stated, "The American People
are committed to helping Tanzania achieve its true potential as a bread basket
for Africa. In order to achieve this critically important objective we need
strong leadership, we need innovation, we need dedication, and most importantly
we need all of you to take this great educational opportunity and come back to
Tanzania to accelerate its agricultural revolution. The United States looks
forward to continuing our partnership with Tanzania in building the Tanzanian
leadership capacity to alleviate food insecurity, malnutrition, and poverty."

The Feed the Future Initiative was launched by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham
Clinton during her visit to Tanzania in June 2011. Feed the Future is the U.S.
Government's global hunger and food security initiative that supports Tanzanian
driven approaches to address the root causes of hunger and poverty, and is in
alignment with the Comprehensive Africa Agriculture Development Programme
(CAADP). One of the key elements of Feed the Future is research and development.
In addition, it provides funding to the Innovative Agriculture Research
Initiative (iAGRI) which is helping to train the next generation of agricultural
scientists and managers.

Founded in 1961 by President John F. Kennedy, the United States Agency for
International Development is the U.S. Governments primary agency for the
distribution of foreign aid. For more information on USAID's history and
programs, see www.usaid.gov.

LOAD-DATE: July 29, 2012

                              733 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                         Spokesman Review (Spokane, WA)

                           November 19, 2009 Thursday
                                  Main Edition

FOOD STAMPS GO UNTAPPED BY ELIGIBLE AMERICANS

SECTION: A; Pg. 15

LENGTH: 431 words


<b>EDITORIAL</b>

Accepting help can be difficult. You might have to swallow some pride.

But people need to eat, and  government aid is going unused. The U.S. Department
of Agriculture reports that 60 percent of eligible American families apply for
food stamps. This is considered good news, because  the national rate was 50
percent in 2004. Back then, only 38.7 percent of eligible Idaho households
applied. In Washington state, it was 50 percent.

The surge in applications is no doubt caused by the recession and the rise in
unemployment. Washington's rise in food stamp applications since August 2008 is
the second highest in the nation. Idaho's increase is the fourth highest. But
there is still a lot of untapped aid.

There can be a stigma attached to government aid, and the urge for independence
is commendable. But those rationales won't end a child's hunger pangs.

In recent years, several states have broadened eligibility requirements, so many
people may not be aware that they qualify for food stamps. Actually the term
"stamps" is outdated, because debit-style cards are now swiped at cash
registers. The average food aid recipient in June received $133. Poorer families
can get more.

You don't have to be out of work or destitute to get help feeding your family.
In Washington, the general income thresholds for eligibility, according to the
Department of Social and Health Services' Web site,  are: a monthly gross income
(before taxes and deductions) of $1,805 for one person; $2,429 for two people;
$3,052 for three; and $3,675 for four.

In other words, a high percentage of working families qualify for Basic Food,
which is what the state calls its program. The Web site food.wa.gov has the
details on eligibility and applications for Washington residents. Idahoans can
go to healthandwelfare.idaho.gov.

Though hunger has been spotlighted during the recession, widespread  childhood
poverty has achieved a distressing level of permanence. A study of 29 years of
data by the Archives of Pediatrics and Adolescent Medicine has found that half
of all children will benefit from food stamps at some point in their lives. And
that figure is conservative because of all the eligible households that don't
apply.

In 2008, about 49 million Americans (17 million of them children) lacked a
consistent supply of food. About 43 percent of children in Spokane County
qualify for free or reduced lunch at school.

The scope of childhood poverty is stunning and has lifelong consequences, but
society is not indifferent. There is help. Just ask.

<b>TYPE:</b> Column, Commentary, Editorial

LOAD-DATE: November 21, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                    Copyright 2009 Spokane Spokesman-Review


                              734 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       St. John's Telegram (Newfoundland)

                             August 29, 2004 Sunday

Making the case for cattle

BYLINE: CP

SECTION: INTERNATIONAL NEWS; Pg. A14

LENGTH: 502  words


Agriculture Minister Andy Mitchell came away empty-handed Saturday after arguing
the case for reopening the Canada-U.S. border to live cattle exports in a
meeting with his American counterpart.

Mitchell travelled to New York City specifically to meet U.S. Agriculture
Secretary Ann Veneman face to face for the first time and described her as very
businesslike as they discussed the mad cow crisis that has been crushing the
Canadian cattle industry for 16 months.

In a brief interview after the meeting, Mitchell said he argued the Canadian
case based on science, but it wasn't clear how well his position was received by
Veneman, in New York for this week's Republican convention.

She indicated to me she wanted to see the regulatory process moving forward in
the States, to speed up resolution of the situation, Mitchell said.

The fact that Washington is moving so slowly toward reopening the border makes a
made-in-Canada solution all the more important, he added.

It's clear there's no specific end dates to the American review process.

The United States and other countries closed their borders to Canadian beef
exports after a single case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or BSE, was
discovered in May 2003 on a farm in northern Alberta.

The U.S. started allowing some cuts of beef across the border last September,
but continues to ban imports of live Canadian cattle, creating a backlog of beef
and driving down prices.

Another case of BSE was found last December in a cow in Washington State, which
has complicated matters for American ranchers threatened with the loss of some
of their own markets, such as Japan.

But some Canadian producers suspect part of the reason the U.S. seems to be
dragging its heels on resolving the border issue is to protect its own beef
industry. Industry groups such as the Canadian Cattlemen's Association have
developed long-term plans for coping with the mad cow crisis, which include
emergency cash aid from governments as well as initiatives for boosting
slaughter capacity, loan guarantees and market expansion to reduce reliance on
the U.S.

Some of those have captured Mitchell's imagination as a way to help cope with
the border closure. Ottawa has started to drop broad hints that as the crisis
drags on, more emergency aid could be coming for the cash-strapped industry.

Ralph Goodale, the federal finance minister from southern Saskatchewan, has been
suggesting recently that he might shake open Ottawa's piggy bank.

In March, at the time of the last federal budget, Ottawa announced a $1-billion
farm aid package that included $680 million in relief for cattle producers. That
also included a pledge from Goodale of more help if the border remained closed
for a protracted period.

Goodale has recently repeated that pledge to help cope with mad cow - a serious
issue not just for producers but a serious issue for the country.

However, he hasn't said just how much aid might be made available.

I'm not in a position now to put a dollar figure on the situation, said Goodale.

LOAD-DATE: September 3, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              735 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           January 2, 1992, Thursday

US AND PRIVATE DONORS TO SHIP SUPPLIES TO FORMER SOVIET UNION

BYLINE: JOHN DAVIES; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: TRANSPORTATION, Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 866 words


Roger Runningen was inside a bread store near St. Petersburg when a state
official announced to several hundred waiting people a message that is heard
more and more this winter in the republics that once were the Soviet Union: No
more bread.

"It was almost unbelievable - the people didn't get angry, or shout out or
protest the way Americans might have," Mr. Runningen said. "They just dashed for
the exits in the direction of another store where they heard there might be
read."

The Russians hurried past a private store with plenty of bread for those willing
to pay the equivalent of half a month's pay for a loaf, he said.

Mr. Runningen is press chief for Edward Madigan, U.S. secretary of agriculture.
After a trip filled with vivid images like this, Mr. Madigan returned to the
United States to head up a $ 165 million effort to ship emergency food to the
former Soviet republics, Mr. Runningen said.

The first shipment - $ 15 million of wheat stored in Texas and cheese and butter
from Pennsylvania - is due to go to Armenia later in January, Mr. Runningen
said. "The U.S. Department of Agriculture knows the grain is needed immediately
but said it is simply too heavy to move except in bulk ships," he said.

The U.S. government still would like to move the dairy products there by air but
so far has been unable to line up air freighters to carry the relief supplies,
he said.

"We're working with the Armenians to try to get it airlifted," Mr. Runningen
said.

Shipping lines, air carriers and the ports to be used have not yet been
identified, Mr. Runningen said. Several additional shipments of food will be
made to other parts of the Soviet Union later in the year, he said.

In addition, the Department of Agriculture already has three other Soviet relief
projects planned - development of a full-scale demonstration farm near St.
Petersburg, dispatching of teams of agricultural extension agents in the Soviet
Union and establishment of a panel of top U.S. business leaders to find ways to
reduce waste, spoilage and diversion in the Soviet distribution system.

Beyond that, the U.S. government is considering "two or three" other aid
packages for the Soviet Union, Mr. Runningen said.

On Tuesday, Mr. Madigan said the U.S. government had received no requests from
any of the former republics to speed up the remainder of the $ 1.25 billion in
U.S. agricultural credit guarantees they are due to receive.

Asked whether the USDA might accelerate the credits that are due to be granted
next Feb. 1, March 1 and April 1, Mr. Madigan told reporters that he had
received no such request.

He then pointed out that the USDA in the past has speeded up the timetable on
already-announced credits whenever the Soviet Union made such a request.

Mr. Madigan said U.S. farm exports to the former Soviet Union "can only get
better" as those republics move toward "adoption of democratic principles and
free markets."

Meanwhile, in the Pacific Northwest, companies and individuals seeking to
establish stronger ties with the former Soviets said they realize that providing
food aid this winter may be a practical way to help cement relationships.

Last year, the state of Alaska and Aeroflot worked together to send shipments of
surplus canned salmon to the Soviet Union.

Last month, the Oregon state Department of Agriculture worked with Oregon Potato
Co., Boardman, Ore., to ship a container packed with 10 tons of dehydrated
potatoes to Khabarovsk in the Soviet Far East.

"K" Line, which transported the container to Tokyo, established a special
humanitarian aid cargo rate for the shipment. From Tokyo, the box was shuttled
to a Soviet port, then moved by rail to Khabarovsk.

David Landon, president of Oregon Potato, said he arranged for the donation
mainly because of the Soviet food shortages, but he added that the shipment also
allows the Soviets to know what's available.

"The food shortage is very real," he said, "but there's no denying the gesture
could open the door to future markets for Oregon potatoes."

Mr. Landon took part in an Oregon trade mission to Khabarovsk last month. He
personally showed cooks there how to best turn the flakes into mashed potatoes.

Shipping costs for the container of potatoes were paid by the Oregon Potato
Commission, Northwest Medical Teams, Rotary chapters in Portland and Lake
Oswego, Ore., and sister city organizations for Portland and Khabarovsk.

This month, a Seattle transportation executive is planning a similar relief
effort, with the shipment of 20 tons of flour to Vladivostok, for distribution
to bakeries in the Primorski region. The flour will produce 60,000 loaves of
bread.

Managers at other West Coast ports said they were unaware of any Soviet relief
shipments from their venues but added that private relief organizations don't
always tell the ports when a container or air shipment may contain relief
supplies.

The Port of Oakland, for example, noted that the Oakland-Nakhodka Sister Cities
organization has been particularly active in finding ways to help Russians in
the Nakhodka area. But the group has not gone into detail about relief materials
shipped, the port said.

LOAD-DATE: December 16, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              736 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                    February 25, 1994, Friday, FINAL EDITION

FDA to be asked to OK irradiation of red meat

BYLINE: Sandra Sanchez

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 986 words


The Agriculture Department will seek approval to use low doses of radiation on
beef and other red meat to kill harmful bacteria, Secretary Mike Espy said
Thursday.

Espy said the department decided last week to ask the Food and Drug
Administration for approval. Cited: Irradiation can kill virtually all harmful
bacteria that escape inspection, including E. coli O157: H7. That rare strain
was blamed for three deaths last year. Michael Jacobson of the Center for
Science in the Public Interest calls the proposal "a quick fix that doesn't
solve the fundamental problem of sick cows and filthy packing houses." The FDA
approved irradiation of poultry in 1990.

AIDS WAIVER: Attorney General Janet Reno said the State Department jumped the
gun in telling U.S. embassies around the world she had issued a waiver that
would allow foreigners with the AIDS virus to attend the Gay Games IV and
Cultural Festival June 18-25 in New York. "I'm not even aware of the issue,"
Reno said. Foreigners with the AIDS virus or any other "communicable disease of
public health significance" are barred from the USA. The State Department said
its cable was premature, announcing a "blanket waiver" for visas up to 30 days
to attend the gay event.

DEMJANJUK RULING: A Cincinnati federal appeals court refused to reconsider its
ruling that the U.S. government committed fraud by withholding information that
could have been used to fight John Demjanjuk's 1986 extradition to Israel.
Demjanjuk, 73, returned to Cleveland in September after Israel reversed his
conviction of being Nazi death-camp guard "Ivan the Terrible."

RECORD SNOW: Washington state broke its 24-hour snowfall record after 65 inches
fell from Wednesday to Thursday, canceling schools in eastern regions.
Elsewhere, a snowstorm that dropped 12 inches on Chicago Wednesday hit the Great
Lakes and New England. Freezing rain and ice coated parts of Connecticut and was
blamed for 126 traffic accidents. In Massachusetts, the education commissioner
warned that schools will have to stay in session for 180 days this year,
including vacation days and weekends, to make up snow days.

LATE PORN BILL: David Wingate Sr., a Grand Haven, Mich., video store owner
cleared of obscenity charges, is billing police about $ 8,000 in late fees for
two X-rated videos they used as evidence against him. "Business is business," he
says of the $ 2-per-day late charge on tapes rented in 1991 by undercover police
and held as evidence. Officials say they'll return the tapes, but call the bill
"totally ridiculous."

COMEDIAN SHOT: Former Saturday Night Live performer Garrett Morris, 57, was shot
and seriously wounded in south central Los Angeles during an attempted robbery.
Police spokeswoman Sandra Castello said Morris' assailants confronted him as he
walked toward his car. "The victim said he had no money. The assailants fired
two rounds," Castello said. Morris, who underwent surgery, was hit once in the
chest and once in the arm. No arrests have been made.

MAKEUP FLAP: Several Washington, D.C., council members were outraged that Mayor
Sharon Pratt Kelly used city cable TV fees to pay $ 65-an-hour makeup sessions,
The Washington Times reported. Contracts awarded makeup artist Julie
Rodgers-Edwards $ 5,000 from February to September 1993, $ 9,000 more through
December. Kelly said the services were used for her and guests of cable shows.

SLEEPY PILOT: James Rich dozed after putting his plane on auto-pilot from
Springfield, Ky., to Crossville, Tenn., last week, waking six hours later to an
empty fuel gauge and the Gulf of Mexico below. Rich had no flotation device and
can't swim. The Coast Guard rescued him, but his $ 70,000 plane sank. He could
be fined and lose his pilot's license.

MOMENTARY MILLIONS: James Smith, 72, had only a day to enjoy the news that he'd
won part of a $ 6.4 million Virginia Lotto jackpot. The Chilhowie, Va., man died
of a heart attack Feb. 17 - a day after his caretaker, Reba Poling, learned she
held a winning Feb. 16 ticket, according to news reports. Poling had said she
was planning to split the winnings with Smith and his two daughters. But lottery
officials said Poling claimed the winnings Tuesday alone.

SNORE RULING: The Davis, Calif., City Council ruled snoring is not a violation
of the city's noise ordinance. Some council members apologized to a woman who
had been cited for snoring too loudly. Sari Zayed, 30, pleaded innocent to the
charge after duplex neighbor Chris Doherty complained to police. The district
attorney's office still hasn't announced whether Zayed will be prosecuted. She
is scheduled to appear in local court March 25.

ALSO THURSDAY . . .

TRAIN DERAILMENT: Amtrak rail service is expected to remain rerouted through
parts of Iowa today, as cleanup of a derailed coal train continues. Fifty-two of
the train's 117 cars derailed. The cause is under investigation.

VIOLENCE CONFERENCE: About 1,000 social workers, teachers, police and
health-care workers attended a Charleston, S.C., conference on violence and the
black family. The summit is an idea-sharing forum for policy-makers.

Farrakhan seeks Congress hearing

Nation of Islam leader Louis Farrakhan said he wants to testify before Congress
to clarify the views of his Muslim sect. The request follows a resolution passed
by the U.S. House Wednesday condemning a November speech by Farrakhan aide
Khallid Abdul Muhammad for anti-Semitic remarks. The Senate unanimously adopted
a similar resolution Feb. 2.

"I would hope . . . that whatever the House and the Senate has said about
Brother Khallid and myself indirectly, and the Nation of Islam may be
challenged" so future generations could have "our testimony to read, weigh and
judge for themselves," Farrakhan said. Farrakhan dismissed Muhammad this month.

With: Paul Leavitt, Gary Fields, Jane Schmucker, Cathy Chestnut, Desda Moss

LOAD-DATE: June 11, 1994June 11, 1994June 11, 1994June 11, 1994June 11, 1994June
11, 1994

TYPE: Nationline

                              737 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                            May 13, 1987, Wednesday

FREIGHTER CARRYING FOOD AID MAROONED

BYLINE: Fort Lauderdale News & Sun-Sentinel (AP)

SECTION: MARITIME, Pg. 3B

LENGTH: 625 words

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.


A rusty freighter carrying about 8,000 tons of foodstuffs bound for famine
victims in Africa and Jordan is marooned at Port Everglades, Fla., the victim of
mechanical failure and a financial dispute.

The 416-foot Porto Coroni broke down about 25 miles off the coast of Cuba and
was towed into Port Everglades April 3, crewmembers and port officials aid.

The port said the ship's owners, based in Athens, Greece, apparently have
abandoned the vessel and its 18-man crew.

"What's unusual about this is the owner threw up his hands and gave up," said
Robert Richards, the port's harbor master.

About one-half of the foodstuffs onboard consists of pinto beans, cornmeal and
soybean oil bound for Mozambique. Provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture
, the food will be distributed by World Vision, a humanitarian relief
organization based in Monrovia, Calif.

The rest of the cargo is flour donated by a United Nations relief organization,
which is destined for Palestinian refugees in Jordan.

"We're trying to move this aid out," said Graham Bott, president of Tampa-based
Afram Lines. "We will not spare any expense to get this moving."

The cargo is worth $ 1.7 million to $ 1.8 million, Mr. Bott said.

Afram chartered the Porto Coroni from a Panamanian company, Defender Bay
Shipping, which op erates out of Athens. He said Afram Lines, which is trying to
buy the ship, has reached an impasse with the company's owners and Athens- based
lenders who financed operations of the 17-year-old ship.

The ship's owners could not be contacted for comment.

In the meantime, Afram has dispatched engineers to Port Everglades to repair the
broken-down generators and correct other mechanical problems. Mr. Bott said
repairs, which will cost about $ 500,000, could be completed in 10 days.

The foodstuffs, wrapped in bags and large drums, have not spoiled, Mr. Bott
said.

The ship, which left New Orleans in March, was headed for the port of Quelimani
in Mozambique, where part of the cargo would be taken to the country's coastal
region, said Jerry Kitchel, spokesman for World Vision. From there, he said the
rest of the World Vision cargo would be dropped off at Durban, South Africa, and
transported by truck to southern Mozambique.

"Considering that the situation in Mozambique is very grave, we want to see the
food get there as quickly as possible," Mr. Kitchel said. "We are very
uncomfortable with the delay."

World Vision's aid program in Mozambique is targeted at 1.5 million famine
victims, he said.

Tom Bell, a U.S. Department of Agriculture official in Kansas City, Mo., said
this was the first time he could recall a relief shipment being held up so long
at a port.

The delay has frustrated and angered the crewmembers, who are from Greece and
the Philippines.

Most are owed wages for the past two months, said Howard Botts, director of the
Christian Seaman's Service, a Fort Lauderdale religious group that has helped
the men.

Aboard the ship on Monday afternoon, Angel Pesce, the cook, prepared rice and
chicken. Sweltering in the cramped galley, he said the refrigerator had broken
down.

"The conditions are very bad," Mr. Pesce said. "It's rained inside the cabins
and (the ship) is full of cockroaches and rats. We have been abandoned."

Arthur Levine, a Fort Lauderdale attorney who represents Afram, said if the ship
sale is successful, the crew will be paid and sent home.

For now, crewmembers said they are relying on the Christian Seaman's Service.

"It's a sad situation trying to get food to Africa, and now the crew needs
food," port spokesman Tim Lewis said Monday.

In addition, port charges accumulate daily. Mr. Lewis said the ship owes $
22,425 in wharfage and other fees.

LOAD-DATE: January 8, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                  Copyright 1987 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              738 of 999 DOCUMENTS


              The Times and Democrat (Orangeburg, South Carolina)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                          September 7, 2016 Wednesday

Farmers await flood help

BYLINE: Gene Zaleski, The Times and Democrat, Orangeburg, S.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 490 words


Sept. 07--Farmers and agriculture officials say the application process for
state assistance following the October 2015 floods went smoothly.

Now the waiting begins for growers to receive payments for their crop losses.

Orangeburg County farmer Harry Wimberly lost his entire corn crop last year due
to the floods.

He successfully filled out his farm aid application and has been told he
qualified for assistance. He has been told payments will begin Oct. 1.

"That is all I know," he said, adding the application process went smoothly.

State lawmakers agreed in May to provide $40 million to help farmers after last
October's torrential rains.

The S.C. Department of Agriculture says flooding wiped out $330 million worth of
crops at harvest time, and farmers lost an additional $45 million because they
couldn't plant winter crops in bogs.

Wimberly thought payments would arrive a little sooner, as corn has already been
harvested and cotton and peanuts are quickly approaching.

"But I am happy it will come Oct. 1," Wimberly said. "When it comes, it will be
well used."

South Carolina Farm Bureau President Harry Ott said on a scale of 1 to 10, the
farm aid application process has been a 10.

"I have not gotten any complaints from farmers with any difficulty with the
application process," Ott said. "The application process went smoothly."

It appears the process "worked as it was designed to work," he said.

"I have not gotten anybody calling me and saying they thought they should have
qualified and they did not," Ott said.

Ott expressed his appreciation to the S.C. Department of Agriculture, Clemson
Extension and the S.C. Department of Revenue for working together to make the
process function well.

"We are looking forward to the completion of the application process and are
hoping farmers will be getting financial assistance soon," he said.

Calhoun County Clemson Extension Agent Charles Davis said he did not have any
hard numbers on applications, but echoed Ott about the process.

"The ones who may have had the most problems are small vegetable producers or
those who did not have a farm number as required by legislation," he said.

Farmers had until Aug. 15 to apply for the aid. The deadline to apply for
assistance for Cherokee, Pickens and Oconee counties was Sept. 6.

The aid can cover up to 20 percent of losses, but no farmer can get more than
$100,000.

To be eligible for the grant, farmers must have experienced a verifiable loss of
agricultural commodities of at least 40 percent as a result of the October 2015
flooding.

A number of training sessions, including one in Orangeburg, were held throughout
the state for farmers to help them with the application process.

Contact the writer: gzaleski@timesanddemocrat.com or 803-533-5551. Check out
Zaleski on Twitter at @ZaleskiTD.

                          The Anniston Star (Alabama)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           January 18, 2017 Wednesday

Deadline Jan. 30 for farmers to apply for federal forage aid

BYLINE: Zach Tyler, The Anniston Star, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 254 words


Jan. 18--Farmers feeling the far-reaching effect of a summerlong drought have
until the end of this month to apply for federal assistance in feeding
livestock, a Farm Service Agency official said Wednesday.

More than 300 livestock farmers in the area have already applied for such aid
through the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Livestock Forage Program, according
to Bill Browning. Executive director of the USDA's Farm Service Agency in
Calhoun, Cleburne, Talladega and Shelby counties, Browning said Wednesday that
the long-running drought has made feeding cowherds and other livestock tough.

The biggest obstacle, he said, is a limited supply of hay for winter feeding.

"If you didn't raise hay and have hay yourself, you're going to have to do some
soul-searching," Browning said. "You may be leaving the cattle business."

The USDA's forage program offers to subsidize the drought-related losses
experienced by farmers of many kinds of animals -- from "alpacas, beef cattle,
buffalo, beefalo, dairy cattle, deer, elk, emus, equine, goats, llamas, poultry,
reindeer, sheep or swine," according to a release on the program from Browning's
office.

The program had paid $534,711 to Calhoun County farmers in November, according
to a Farm Service Agency spokeswoman. Statewide, some $8.5 million had been
paid.

Staff writer Zach Tyler: 256-235-3564. On Twitter @ZTyler_Star.

                              741 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                         September 21, 1994, Wednesday

NORTHWESTERN LEADERS SEEK MARKETING POLICY FOR FARM GOODS

BYLINE: WILLIAM DiBENEDETTO; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FOREIGN TRADE, Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 340 words

DATELINE: SEATTLE


Pacific Northwest business and government leaders have banded together in a call
for more aggressive marketing of the region's agricultural products.

The Citizens Network for Foreign Affairs drafted a list of six recommendations,
the result of a round-table discussion among 75 U.S. and Canadian leaders, last
month during the Washington Agricultural Showcase in akima, Wash.

"If the Pacific Northwest intends to capitalize on the many growing global
markets for agricultural goods, then a regional strategy is necessary," said Pat
Berndt, mayor of Yakima. "These policy recommendations represent a clear and
positive move in that direction."

One recommendation urges the Pacific Northwest Economic Region, a regional
economic development group, to establish an agriculture working group that will
focus on building international markets for Northwest agricultural producers and
processors. The group has eight working groups that cover transportation and
environmental issues.

"Agricultural producers and other parties within the agricultural sector need to
develop a nonpartisan, sustainable, cooperative program to boost agricultural
exports from the Pacific Northwest," said the first recommendation.

The list also emphasizes a "regional approach" to marketing and says that the
agricultural showcase, one of the largest of its kind in the nation, is a
successful model of what the private sector can do for the state and the Pacific
Northwest.

Another recommendation said Northwest interests "should encourage the
establishment of a regional U.S.-Mexico Chamber of Commerce, given the large and
growing importance of the Mexican market for Pacific Northwest agriculture."

Economic development in emerging markets is essential, but assistance ''should
not consist solely of disaster and food aid, but should consist primarily of aid
that builds local economies," said the policy group.

The Citizens Network for Foreign Affairs is a nonprofit public policy, education
and international development organization.

                              743 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   February 18, 1995, Saturday, Final Edition

Panel Proposes Child Nutrition Block Grants

Judith Havemann, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: A Section; Pg. A11

LENGTH: 479 words


The House Economic and Educational Opportunity Committee announced plans
yesterday to combine the Agriculture Department's $ 5.5 billion breakfast and
lunch programs for schoolchildren into a single nutrition cash payment to the
states.

The action, if passed by Congress and signed by the president, would end the
guarantee that all eligible children would receive free or low-cost meals at
federal government expense.

Instead, states would receive a set amount of money each year to spend on
nutritional programs for low-income children. The amount of money would be
allowed to increase by 4.5 percent each year. The Congressional Budget Office
has estimated that, without committee action, costs would go up 5.2 percent each
year.

A Ways and Means subcommittee last week approved turning the main welfare
program, Aid to Families with Dependent Children, into a similar block grant to
the states, and to end the guarantee that all eligible poor people would receive
benefits under that program. Both are designed to fulfill the promises in the
Republican "Contract With America."

The opportunity committee is following a similar pattern in proposing the school
nutrition block grant and a separate family nutrition block grant for low-income
women and children.

The block grants are supposed to increase the flexibility of the states to
design programs tailored to local needs and to enable the states to increase
administrative efficiency by setting similar eligibility standards and rules for
all programs.

The committee would prohibit payments to immigrants who are not citizens, as
proposed for other block grants.

Although the school breakfast programs serve 796,000 children annually, and 4.7
million children receive free or low-cost school lunches, both are dwarfed by
the food stamp program, which serves more than 27 million Americans a month at a
cost of more than $ 25.6 billion. That program is under the jurisdiction of the
Agriculture Committee, which has not revealed its plan for food stamps.

Gerry Miller, director of social services in Michigan, said Republican governors
had been negotiating with the Agriculture Committee in an effort to win the same
block grant status for food stamps as for other forms of public assistance.

"AFDC, food stamps and Medicaid are a complementary package in our minds," he
said. "We need flexibility in all of them to make the system work."

Medicaid negotiations with the Republican governors also are underway. The
governors have asked Republican chairmen of the congressional budget and finance
committees to allow the program, whose costs have been skyrocketing, to grow by
8.8 percent a year.

"This is the best-case scenario," said Cyndy Brucato, spokesman for Minnesota
Gov. Arne Carlson (R). "Now we are hoping we will get about a 7 percent annual
increase, but we don't know."

LOAD-DATE: February 18, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
