                       Sydney Morning Herald (Australia)

                            August 1, 1998 Saturday
                                  Late Edition

US plans wheat aid buffer

BYLINE: DIANE STOTT

SECTION: NEWS AND FEATURES; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 479 words


The United States has promised to investigate ways of quarantining Australian
farmers from the effects of US wheat aid to Indonesia, after tensions rose
yesterday during high-level talks.

The US Secretary of State, Dr Madeleine Albright, said a meeting between
officials of both countries would be held in Washington soon to find ways of
containing the commercial effects of the aid program.

The Prime Minister, Mr Howard, and the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Fischer, both
raised the issue with Dr Albright during her visit to Australia for AUSMIN talks
on defence and trade issues.

Mr Fischer had earlier in the week attacked the US Administration, accusing the
President, Mr Clinton, of breaching the spirit of commitments he had made
previously not to interfere in Australia's traditional agricultural markets.

He claimed the Americans were donating the wheat under the guise of
"humanitarian aid" when the US Secretary of Agriculture, Mr Dan Glickman, had
stated that the aims of the program were also to expand US export markets and
boost prices for US grain growers.

Dr Albright, alluding to Australia's strong representations on the issue, said
yesterday she now understood the depth of anger about the issue here.

But she stressed that the hunger in Indonesia needed to be addressed to allow
economic reforms to progress and a smooth transition to democracy.

Tensions had escalated between the two countries earlier yesterday after Mr
Glickman attacked Mr Fischer for his stand against the US aid plans.

Responding to Mr Fischer's claims that the wheat aid was directed at opening
Indonesia as a new export market, Mr Glickman said: "The United States has
always engaged in humanitarian assistance to those countries in the world which
need our help. "[It] is not intended to displace commercial sales, period. We're
not doing anything insidious."

The US plans to give 500,000 tonnes of wheat to the Indonesians, with the
prospect of a further million tonnes, in a market where US sales tally just
200,000 tonnes a year.

Indonesia is a lucrative market for Australia, where sales reach about $600
million a year, or about 3 million tonnes.

Mr Fischer, who is also Minister for Trade, said on ABC radio yesterday that
Australia's concerns were "legitimate". Australia was being caught in the
crossfire between America's fight against European farm subsidies. "We want to
work with the USA on that, but equally Australia's sovereign and legitimate
rights - we'll be in there defending that," he said.

Mr Howard had also raised the issue with Dr Albright at a dinner on Thursday
night, where Dr Albright assured him the US did not want to interfere in
Australia's commercial trade with Indonesia.

"Quite rightly, we're expressing concern on behalf of Australian primary
producers because, unlike American primary producers, Australian farmers don't
get government subsidies," he said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              745 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               February 15, 1995, Wednesday, Late Edition - Final

METRO DIGEST

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 517 words



GIULIANI SEEKS DEEPEST CUT SINCE 1930'S

Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a financial blueprint for New York City that
included the largest percentage reduction in overall spending since the Great
Depression and that would drastically reshape municipal government and slash its
services to the poor. A1.

Despite all the attention devoted to budget cuts, the plan presented by the
Mayor includes a variety of new measures to raise money, including several ideas
-- like selling advertising in parks or increasing the number of taxi medallions
-- that seem likely to provoke a fight. B4.

The Mayor's proposed cuts would affect education, hospitals, child welfare, the
police, youth, the arts and sanitation. B5.

The release of the Mayor's preliminary spending plan is the beginning of a long
process by which the city's budget is determined. B5.

IN FISCAL CRISIS, GIULIANI IS TRANSFORMED

Four months ago, when Mayor Giuliani crossed party lines to endorse Mario M.
Cuomo in the race for governor, he excoriated George E. Pataki. But now, with
Mr. Pataki in the Governor's mansion, the Republican Mayor has made a
turnaround. At the heart of it is the fact that to close a $2.7 billion deficit,
one way or another, he desperately needs state help to balance his budget. News
analysis, A1.

ALBANY RE-EXAMINES THE DEATH PENALTY

Coaxed by Governor Pataki, the State Senate backed off a plan to pass
legislation that would have given New York one of the most extensive
death-penalty laws in the country. A1.

NEW YORK CITY

AIDS SERVICES FAULTED IN FEDERAL LAWSUIT

The city agency in charge of providing services for people with AIDS is in such
disarray that many recipients are effectively being denied benefits that they
are entitled to, said a class-action suit filed in Federal court. B4.

CORTINES RENEWS ATTACK ON CITY HALL

After tensions between the two men had appeared to subside, Schools Chancellor
Ramon C. Cortines harshly criticized Mayor Giuliani's proposal to gain greater
control over how the Board of Education spends its money. B5.

A plan to transform Yankee Stadium into a garage-surrounded preserve drew sharp
criticism from community leaders. B3.

The commissioner of the city's community assistance unit resigned. B3.

REGION

COURT REVIEWS CHILD SUPPORT

Like many divorced fathers, James Pascale pays child support. And like a growing
number, he helps care for his children a few days a week. Mr. Pascale's lawyer
went before the New Jersey Supreme Court to argue that because such
"nontraditional" arrangements are becoming more common, it is time for the state
to re-examine the guidelines that determine child-support payments. Mr. Pascale
wants the court to allow him to retain some of the money he now pays in child
support to spend on his children as he sees fit. B6.

COLLEGE SECURITY GUARD HELD IN SLAYING

A campus security guard was arrested and charged with murdering a professor's
widow while she was cleaning out her late husband's office on Sunday. B6.

Neediest Cases B2

About New York by Michael T. Kaufman B3

                              747 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               March 18, 1982, Thursday, Late City Final Edition

ERODING EROSION

BYLINE: By Ken Cook

SECTION: Section A; Page 27, Column 2; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 830 words

DATELINE: SHEPHERDSTO WN, W. Va.


Dust storms darkening the sun in Washington, D.C., with topsoil blown from the
Great Plains, an anxious farmer knee-deep in a newly carved gully - today, after
a half-century and $20 billion worth of Federal programs, these memories still
shape national policy aimed at combating soil erosion. But Government findings
in recent years have substantially changed experts' ideas about erosion
problems, and public debate over how to solve them must take those findings into
account.

One legacy of the Dust Bowl is that we continue to think of erosion as a threat
to all farmland. Actually, most erosion occurs on a relatively small amount of
land. Analysis of data collected by the Agriculture Department in 1977 shows
that only 6 percent of American cropland (24 million acres) accounted for a
staggering 43 percent of the two major types of erosion: sheet erosion, in which
rain washes a thin layer of soil from a field, and rill erosion, in which soil
is carried away in small water-etched channels. Similarly, over half the
cropland erosion caused by wind occurred on 9 percent of the nation's acreage.

Though often invisible to the naked eye, the loss of soil from sheet and rill
erosion can be stupendous. Slightly more than nine million acres of crop-land -
2 percent of the national total - lost 518 million tons of soil through sheet
and rill erosion in 1977. (By comparison, all of the gullying in America moved
57 percent of that amount.) On average, this cropland lost an inch of soil to
sheet and rill erosion every three years - a rate 10 times greater than the
national average.

Federal programs have failed dismally in getting conservation treatment to this
small amount of highly erodible land. A monumental but largely unnoticed
Agriculture Department study published in 1981 indicated that between 1975 and
1978, as many as half the erosioncontrol practices introduced with Federal
financial and, in some cases, technical assistance have been confined to land
with only minor erosion problems. The study concluded that soil savings in the
agricultural conservation program could be tripled, at no increase in cost, by
''targeting erosion control funds according to the potential for erosion.''

So in the debate over the conservation program Secretary of Agriculture John R.
Block proposed in October, ''targeting'' is the watchword. He wants to shift 25
percent of his department's $700 million annual conservation effort to
as-yet-undesignated ''critical areas'' of erosion and flooding. County
committees that administer Federal cost-sharing have been encouraged to seek out
farmers with serious erosion problems instead of parceling out money on the
traditional first-come first-served basis. A pilot program offers farmers
financial aid in proportion to the amount of soil that the aid will save.

To fully implement targeting would be to fundamentally alter - and improve -
nearly 50 years of Federal conservation policy and programs. With level or
declining budgets for these programs, any buildup in target areas will reduce
conservation services elsewhere.  That will produce political problems, because
all farmers, regardless of the extent of their conservation problems, have been
able to benefit from these programs since their inception.

Targeting presents scientific problems, too. In general, erosion makes soil less
productive. Yet certain extremely thick soils seem to withstand very high rates
of erosion without great loss of productivity. Conversely, a small amount of
erosion may seriously impair crop production on shallow soils. In either case,
erosion may introduce into bodies of water damaging amounts of sediment,
fertilizer, and pesticides. The Agriculture Department, aware of these
considerations, has indicated that high rates of erosion will not be the sole
criterion for selecting target areas.

While targeting, in its infancy, points the way to improved conservation, after
five decades of research and experience we do not fully know where erosion hurts
us most. But I think current research will verify that a fairly small amount of
land accounts for much of the threat erosion poses to agricultural productivity
and water quality. Such advances will be forfeited if research funds are lopped
from the budget, as President Reagan has proposed.

Conservation is desirable everywhere. But the Government has limited resources,
and so have farmers. Thus, we cannot afford to permit outdated policies and
self-defeating budget cuts to impede the scientific tasks of soil conservation
that lie ahead.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
Ken Cook, a journalist, contributes regularly to the Journal of Soil and Water
Conservation, a magazine.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Illustrations: drawing

TYPE: OP-ED

                   Copyright 1982 The New York Times Company


                              748 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                            January 3, 2012 Tuesday
                                  Main Edition

IN YOUR COMMUNITY Metro & Obituaries;
Deluged nonprofits help needy get food stamps

BYLINE: April Hunt; Staff

SECTION: METRO NEWS; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 1042 words



HIGHLIGHT: Strapped food banks can't meet demand. A record 1.8 million Georgians
received aid through federal program.


Teresa Ashe took a break from looking for work on a recent rainy morning to fill
out the necessary paperwork that would get her a week's worth of food from a
food pantry.

But the laid-off housekeeper didn't rush home to tuck into the offerings of
tinned stew or boxes of mac and cheese from the Christian Aid Mission
Partnership food pantry in Austell. She waited in the office so she could meet
with an expert to help her apply online for food stamps.

"I don't know what's going to come next," said Ashe, whose unemployment benefits
ran out the week before Christmas. "It's going to be thin until I can find a
job. I can use the help."

Ashe is hardly alone. Faced with a record number of hungry Georgians, food-bank
operators and state officials have teamed up to find more potential recipients
of the food stamp program, officially known as the Supplemental Nutrition
Assistance Program.

Nearly one in five people in the state rely on food stamps, a record 1.8 million
people through September, according to U.S. Department of Agriculture figures.
Georgia has seen an 87 percent jump in the program since the recession began in
2007. The cost to taxpayers has grown considerably. Americans will pay $65
billion to fund the food stamp program this year, more than double what it cost
in 2005.

A big reason for the program's expansion is that many workers have slipped from
the middle class during the ongoing economic downturn, creating a need for more
regular help than food banks can provide. Food stamps offer that boost.

"It's a perfect match for the state to find the population that needs this
program," Lucy Smith, manager of the Food & Nutrition Unit in the state
Department of Human Resources. "Right now, it appears that need is only going to
grow."

Opponents of the expansion argue food stamps are beyond the original mission of
the agriculture department. In an essay written for the libertarian-leaning
Georgia Public Policy Foundation, University of Georgia Professor Emeritus
Harold Brown argues that shift bloats the department's budget.

"In times of great controversy over the cost of government, it is time to
question USDA's straying from its traditional mandates," Brown writes. "Remove
nutrition programs from USDA and let it concentrate on what made it great."

However, the foundation has not taken an official stance against food stamps or
advocated for any changes.

Food bank operators would like the see the number of food stamp recipients grow
through the partnership between the state and nonprofits. It's not that donors
don't make feeding needy people a priority. Charities like the Atlanta Community
Food Bank consistently rank among the top 10 recipients of financial and food
aid.

But even with more donations, the nonprofits can't keep up with demand for their
help, said the food bank's chief operating officer Rob Johnson. And food banks
are designed for emergency aid, not to provide regular assistance.

"Quite frankly, we are not the most efficient way of getting food to people,"
Johnson said. "People being able to go to the store and buy what they need with
their card is certainly more efficient than we are."

Funding for food assistance also has been spared from budget controversies on
the federal level.

Still, despite its relative budget safety, the program only serves about 70
percent of people who qualify for food stamps, Smith said.

One factor is the lack of computer literacy --- or of a computer itself --- to
file an application. That is where food pantries like the Christian Aid Mission
Partnership, or CAMP, center play a key role.

Little technical savvy is needed for the food stamps, which years ago shifted
from coupons to a Electronic Benefits Transfer card that functions much like any
debit card. The cards can be used only for food, with checkout machines at
stores configured to determine what products qualify for purchase.

Still, workers on the front lines say there remains a stigma of applying for
aid, especially among senior citizens who never before needed help.

Vera Carrillo, an intake counselor at CAMP, said there is also a growing number
of people of all ages who never before needed assistance. Many have some money
coming in, but food is a distant third to priorities like housing and
transportation.

"People say, 'I didn't think I would qualify,' or they think for years they
didn't need it, so now they don't want it," Carrillo said.

Joan Martin, who also recently received food from CAMP, applied years ago for
food stamps but was $15 over the weekly limit. General recipients qualify if
they are 130 percent over the federal poverty line, which is $22,350 for a
family of four.

Now a retired day care worker, the 70-year-old Lithia Springs woman is more
likely to qualify --- most senior citizens do --- but isn't sure she'll bother.

"One month I had 37 cents left over," Martin said of paying bills and medicine
with her Social Security income. "But I don't fool with food stamps. I'll get
by."

Even those who receive food stamps will likely need some help. CAMP's executive
director Darlene Duke said the food pantry this year changed its rules, allowing
needy people to receive food every month. They had been limited to assistance
six times a year.

That effectively doubles their distribution, with each of the 12,000 families
served getting about 95 pounds of food each time they visit.

"We have to hook people up with every food program we can," Duke said.

Who qualifies

What makes someone eligible for food stamp benefits.

*Financial factors such as income and household expenses. Eighty-five percent of
food stamp recipients are at or below the federal poverty line, which is $22,350
for a family of four.

*Only citizens and legal immigrants are eligible, most of whom must wait 5 years
in legal status before qualifying for benefits.

*Able-bodied adults between 16 and 60 (with some exceptions) are required to
register for work, to take part in employment/training programs referred by the
Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program office, and to accept or continue
suitable employment.

*Benefits come to the household via electronic debit cards, known as electronic
benefit transfer cards which can be used in more than 216,000 approved retail
stores in the U.S. to purchase unprepared food.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspapers


                Copyright 2012 The Atlanta Journal-Constitution


                              749 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   November 05, 1998, Thursday, Final Edition

U.S. Offers Tons of Food To Russians; Shipments to Combat Wintertime Shortages

Thomas W. Lippman, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A49; THE 1998 ELECTION

LENGTH: 716 words


The United States has agreed in principle to send 3.1 million metric tons of
wheat and other food to Russia to "help sustain Russians through a serious food
shortage this winter," President Clinton announced yesterday.

In a statement issued at the White House, Clinton said the emergency shipments
were contingent on assurances that the food would be distributed to the truly
needy and would be exempted from Russian taxes and import duties.

The large consignment of food -- more than 10 times the amount the Clinton
administration announced in September it would send to famine-stricken North
Korea -- is a reflection of Russia's dire economic situation. Agriculture
Secretary Dan Glickman said it is a "minimum" amount and that the administration
"is prepared to provide additional assistance as necessary."

But U.S. officials said the aid also reflects the United States' desire to
maintain good relations with Russia despite Washington's criticism of economic
policies Russia is adopting now that unfettered capitalism and free-market
reforms have been set aside.

The U.S. strategy is to maintain bilateral cooperation on a broad range of
scientific, environmental and health issues while letting the government of
Premier Yevgeny Primakov make its own economic decisions. Yesterday, the Energy
Department announced completion of security upgrades at two storage sites in
Russia for bomb-grade uranium.

Glickman said this year's grain harvest in Russia is projected at "just 52
million metric tons -- the country's worst harvest in 50 years. The problems in
Russian agriculture have been compounded by the devaluation of the ruble and the
crisis in Russia's banking system," which have left Russia without the cash to
purchase food on the open market.

In Moscow yesterday, Deputy Prime Minister Yuri Maslyukov said that money set
aside to provide food and fuel to Russia's far north, where winter is especially
long and harsh, had been "used for some other purposes. . . . We will have to
take a number of difficult steps to provide the population with fuel and food."

According to the Agriculture Department, the U.S. aid will be in three packages:
1.5 million metric tons of wheat in the form of an outright grant; 1.5 million
tons of wheat, sorghum and other commodities to be made available through a
low-interest loan; and 100,000 tons of various commodities to be contributed to
volunteer relief agencies for direct distribution to needy Russians. The overall
value of the package was estimated at $ 500 million.

In addition to helping the Russians, Clinton and Glickman said, the aid will
benefit U.S. farmers, who they both said "have been hit hard by an agricultural
crisis here." Agriculture department officials said this is the third time the
United States has provided food to Moscow since the breakup of the Soviet Union
early this decade. U.S. food was shipped to the Caucasus region of southern
Russia after the 1994-96 war in Chechnya, and a small amount of grain was
provided earlier this year, they said.

In the case of Chechnya, however, the aid was sent in response to a onetime
crisis. Yesterday's announcement, and the commitment to provide more aid as
needed, reflect a systemic crisis in Russia that could go on for years,
officials said.

The stabilization program announced by Russia on Saturday, Maslyukov said, was
spurred by the realization that "the banking system was in a state of collapse
and could not breathe. The industrial sector has, as a result, come to a
standstill, and there was a threat that the whole economy would stop."

U.S. officials have made no secret of their disapproval of key points of the
Russian program, including subsidies to ailing industries and the issuance of
new bank notes to pay salaries of workers and soldiers. After nearly six years
of commitment to free-market reform in Russia, Clinton administration officials
have resigned themselves to the fact that the reformers have been eclipsed, but
they continue to warn that the choices Russia is making are inflationary.

Maslyukov said the government intends to hold the printing of rubles to what he
called "a permissible amount" but added that, in any case, "I think that we are
in such a state that it is impossible to scare us anymore."

LOAD-DATE: November 05, 1998

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Washington Post

                     June 11, 1992, Thursday, Final Edition

VOLUNTEERS

Anne Chase

SECTION: MARYLAND WEEKLY (MONTGOMERY); PAGE M5

LENGTH: 589 words


Looking for volunteer opportunities? Following are groups in your area in need
of volunteer help for a day or a week or on a regular basis. This column is
published every other week. Nonprofit groups in need of volunteers should send
notices to Volunteers, The Washington Post, 1150 15th St. NW, Washington, D.C.
20071.

Work With Children

Teenagers and adults interested in working with disabled children are needed at
the Cedar Lane Special Education Summer School program from June 22 to July 31.
People are needed to work in the therapeutic swim program, in physical
education, arts, crafts and music. Volunteers will need to adhere to a regular
schedule. There will be an orientation session June 18 from 9 to 11 a.m. at the
school, 5451 Beaverkill Rd., Columbia. Call Pam Vollmerhausen at 410-313-6977
for an application.

Environmental Workers

The Howard County office of the Soil Conservation Service of the U.S. Department
of Agriculture is looking for people 17 and older to take water and soil
samples, create wildlife habitats, lead conservation education programs and
interpret satellite maps. Call Jack Helm at 410-465-3180.

Volunteer Teens Needed

United Way of Central Maryland has a list of hundreds of summer opportunities
for teenage volunteers. Young people are needed to work at hospitals, homeless
shelters, libraries, schools and museums. The list includes organizations in
Baltimore City and the five counties surrounding the city, including Howard.
Call the United Way's volunteer referral line at 410-659-0050.

Volunteer Center

The Columbia Volunteer Corps has listings of organizations in Howard County that
need volunteers.

Meals on Wheels needs drivers to deliver meals to homebound and elderly people.
The hours are 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Monday through Friday. Volunteers are asked to
work once a week or every other week.

The National Federation of the Blind needs drivers to take blind people to
monthly support group meetings and to meetings with state officials in Baltimore
and Annapolis.

Developmental Services Group is looking for a therapeutic assistant to work
individually during the day with an adult with a brain injury who works on a
computer. Training will be provided.

For more information, call Sandra Fields at 410-381-0980.

Travelers Aid

The Travelers Aid Society needs volunteers to staff its booth at Union Station
in the District. Travelers Aid gives information on sightseeing, lodging and
transportation, and also helps travelers stranded by events. The booth is open
from 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. seven days a week, and workers are expected to work
one four-hour shift per week. Parking is provided. Call Ann Ingram at
202-546-3120.

Community Symphony

The Takoma Park Symphony Orchestra and choral group is looking for violinists
and people to help with public relations. Call Nora Boskoff at 301-589-4049.

Folklife Festival

The Smithsonian Institution needs volunteers to work on its Festival of American
Folklife that will be held on the Mall in the District from June 25-29 and July
2-5. Helpers assist the craftspeople, musicians and cooks, watch equipment, help
the stage crews and bring refreshments for the performers. The festival needs
bilingual volunteers who speak English and one of the following languages:
Spanish, French, Dutch, Navajo, Jamaican creole or Sranan, a language spoken in
Suriname and French Guiana. A volunteer orientation session will be held on June
20 from 10 a.m. to noon on the Mall. Call the Smithsonian at 202-287-3445.

                              751 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                November 23, 2005 Wednesday Penn/Elkhart Edition

NIPSCO: Resolve bill-paying woes now;
Aid, budget plans, other alternatives may be available.

BYLINE: By JOSHUA STOWE; Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: NATION; Pg. A1; COLD REALITIES: PAYING HEATING BILL

LENGTH: 662 words


SOUTH BEND -- She expects the story to have a happy ending when her heat comes
on today, but Debra Bonds said last week was a chilling chapter in her struggle
to stay warm.

Meanwhile, NIPSCO wants her recent heating woes to serve as a cautionary tale
for others -- a reminder to resolve any bill issues now, before Michiana's
weather, so far mild, turns far colder.

Higher heating bills are coming, along with biting winter winds, said NIPSCO
spokesman Tom Cuddy. And that, he said, means that now is the time to tackle any
bill-paying concerns.

"With gas costs as high as they are, we know some people will have problems
paying their bills," Cuddy said. "What we have always encouraged our customers
to do -- but more so now -- is to contact NIPSCO before the bill comes due."

One customer's story

Starting today, Bonds said, she won't have to worry about heating the Twyckenham
Drive home she shares with her 8-year-old grandson.

She won't have to rely on electric heaters or her fireplace to provide warmth,
she said, and won't have to boil water to wash her dishes or fill her bathtub.

The reason, she said, is that she has paid off the balance that kept her gas off
for about a week. It all started Nov. 16. At about 7:30 p.m., Bonds noticed she
had no heat, despite having recently mailed payment for her latest bill.

After contacting NIPSCO, she learned the only thing between her and a warm house
was a payment of more than $550 -- more than four times what she had sent in
because of a combination of past due money, a deposit and a reconnection fee.

The total caught her off-guard and initially left her wondering how she'd muster
the cash. She thought there shouldn't be any problem.

After receiving a disconnection notice, she mailed in a payment she thought
would reach NIPSCO by Nov. 15, in time to keep her heat.

But the payment didn't post in time, and as a result, NIPSCO cut off her natural
gas at 8:26 a.m. Nov. 16, Cuddy said. He consulted her customer record at The
Tribune's request after Bonds signed a release form allowing him to do so.

Bonds' past record showed she had received disconnection notices in 2003 and
2004 as well, Cuddy said, and that she hadn't been able to meet the terms of a
payment plan she worked out with NIPSCO in December 2004.

Bonds said a health condition has hampered her ability to pay bills. She said
she suffers from congestive heart failure and consequently must often miss a day
or two of work during each pay period.

But as it turns out, Bonds might be eligible for NIPSCO's Winter Warmth program
for needy customers, although she said she had not applied for help through it.

When he learned of her medical condition, Cuddy said that while he didn't know
the specifics, "I would be hard-pressed to see how she would not qualify" for
Winter Warmth assistance.

Seek aid, payment plans

Cuddy said Bonds' experience can help others.

"The moral of the story is, customers need to contact us before they miss a
payment," he said.

Whether a person has had past difficulty paying or is encountering his or her
first problem bill, the key is to try to work something out ahead of time, he
said.

For one thing, he said, customers can apply for help through NIPSCO or through
agencies that help those in need.

For another, Cuddy said, customers may be able to set up a payment plan,
depending on their income, past payment history and any extenuating
circumstances.

In addition, customers who are worried about large bill fluctuations from month
to month or season to season can enroll in NIPSCO's budget plan.

The plan allows customers to pay the same amount each month, using their past
energy use and estimated future prices to provide an average monthly bill.

"Regardless of your situation, regardless of your income," Cuddy said, "the
number one thing for customers to do is call us before they miss a payment."

Staff writer Joshua Stowe:

jstowe@sbtinfo.com

(574) 235-6359


LOAD-DATE: December 9, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

didn't post in time. She expects her heat to be restored today, but NIPSCO
officials say her story should encourage customers to pay bills early and to
contact the company as soon as they encounter financial difficulty.   Tribune

aid for those people with low income. Save yourself some hassle by calling on
them in the following order.  1) Energy Assistance Program.  This is at REAL
Services. Your income must be no more than 150 percent of the federal poverty
level.  Call (574) 232-6501 in St. Joseph County and (800) 225-3367 in Elkhart,
Marshall, Kosciusko and Fulton counties.  2) Your township trustee.  Helps with
unpaid bills but not deposits.  3) Winter Warmth  program. This aid is only for
natural gas provided by the Northern Indiana Public Service Co.  The program can
help only with deposits for now. That's because there's a limited amount of aid
left, and NIPSCO officials, who created the program, said they want to focus on
deposits. You must have a shutoff notice from NIPSCO to receive help with
deposits.  Aid for previously unpaid bills may return Dec. 16 if NIPSCO receives
permission from state regulators to renew the program.  Contact these social
service agencies for Winter Warmth:  In St. Joseph County   Family & Children's
Center Counseling and Development Services, 105 E. Jefferson Blvd., Suite 700,

County   Salvation Army, 209 State St., LaPorte; (219) 326-5342.  Those in
Coolspring and Michigan townships should go to the agency in Michigan City.
Salvation Army, 1201 S. Franklin, Michigan City; (219) 874-6885.  * * *  Rural
weatherization loans.   Loans are available to help repair or weatherize rural
homes for those with low income. The interest rate is 1 percent. These are
available from the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Rural Development.  Call
(219) 324-6303, ext. 4, if you live in St. Joseph, Jasper, Lake, LaPorte or
Porter counties. Call (574) 936-2024, ext. 4, if you live in Elkhart, Fulton,
Kosciusko, Marshall, Pulaski or Starke counties.

                              752 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            September 3, 1999 Friday

LENGTH: 147 words


FARGO (AP) -- Five North Dakota counties will get more than $1 million each in
federal aid as a result of 1998 farm flooding. County offices started setting
checks Tuesday for farmers and ranchers, said Scott Stofferahn, state director
for the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency. Of $42 million
approved nationwide, $22 million goes to North Dakota. The program was funded by
last year's emergency farm aid legislation. The top five North Dakota counties
in the Flood Compensation Program were Richland with $2.04 million in aid,
Cavalier with $1.69 million, Bottineau with $1.38 million, Traill with $1.06
million and Dickey with $1.02 million. Payments are based on rental rates for
land, so the per-farmer amounts are generally greatest in the Red River Valley.
Statewide, payments averaged $1,821 per applicant, with 12,070 of the state's
31,000 farmers applying.

                              753 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                   The News Virginian (Waynesboro, Virginia)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 4, 2008 Thursday

Gubernatorial hopefuls pledge agriculture aid

BYLINE: Jimmy LaRoue, The News Virginian, Waynesboro, Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 736 words


Dec. 4--HOT SPRINGS -- Two of the three Democrats running for governor made
their case Wednesday that they would be best suited to support Virginia's
agricultural interests.

Sen. Creigh Deeds, who grew up on a Bath County farm, told a breakfast gathering
at the Virginia Farm Bureau Federation convention at The Homestead that he has
an intimate understanding of agricultural issues, noting that he's the only one
to have been born in Virginia and born on a farm.

"Now is the time to stand with Virginia's farmers," Deeds said.

Del. Brian Moran, of Alexandria, told the group later in the morning that he has
championed the federation's issues in the House of Delegates, even going against
his own party to support ending the estate tax. America, Moran said, "was born
on a Virginia farm."

He said current challenges are related to one another.

"Strong agriculture policy can lead to healthier kids and less money spent on
health care," Moran said. "Better land use planning can mean protecting
generations of farmers. And our environmental policies can have a huge impact on
our economic development plans."

Deeds pointed to his sponsorship of the Agricultural Stewardship Act and said he
was "proud to write the most progressive, incentive-based land conservation law
in the nation, creating tax incentives, tax credits to encourage people to put
their land into conservation easements."

Both candidates talked up the need for expanded energy opportunities --
including biofuels -- while pushing for increasing broadband opportunities in
rural areas and improving transportation infrastructure. They both touted their
ties to U.S. Sen.-elect Mark Warner and Gov. Timothy M. Kaine.

Deeds called for an "energy research triangle" similar to the Research Triangle
in North Carolina established in 1960 by then-North Carolina Gov. Luther Hodges.
He also wants to retool the state's community college system.

"We've got to compete for the smart jobs," Deeds said.

Moran said more people in Virginia should understand agriculture's economic
impact, and its economic reach should be expanded globally. He touted a trade
mission to India with Kaine that he said resulted in $100 million in investments
in the state.

At the same time, Moran said more needs to be done to encourage Virginians to
buy locally.

"We've spent so much time figuring out how to get Virginia produce to market on
the other side of the country that sometimes we forget that it's easier to sell
it on the other side of the county," Moran said.

He also wants to invest in agricultural education through the Virginia
Cooperative Extension and expand university research. Moran said the state
should continue its commitment toward land preservation and conservation.

"The fact is, our challenges are interconnected more than ever before," Moran
said.

Deeds, quoting Scripture several times during his address, said biblically,
farmers are natural conservationists at heart. If elected, he said his focus
would be on three things -- "the economy, the economy, the economy."

Moran said he would continue to be a strong supporter of Farm Bureau interests.
He said he feels "strong" about his message, having spent time in every region
of the state "for years."

"From Fairfax to Galax, we are far more alike than different," Moran said.

Deeds, despite a financial disadvantage against his two Northern Virginia rivals
for the Democratic nomination, said he believes his message is resonating around
the state. His advantage, Deeds said, is that he's been on the ballot in every
state precinct, receiving nearly 1 million votes in his close loss for attorney
general three years ago to Republican gubernatorial candidate Bob McDonnell, who
addressed the convention Monday.

"I've got serious challenges ahead of me," Deeds said. "I'm running against
these two guys from Northern Virginia that have access to a lot more cash than I
do, and campaigns, to a large extent, are about the money you raise and that
affects your ability to get your message out."

To see more of The News Virginian or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.newsvirginian.com. Copyright (c) 2008, The News Virginian,
Waynesboro, Va. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For
reprints, email tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or
847-635-6550, send a fax to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group
Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave., Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                    July 5, 1993, MONDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

CLINTON PLANS $1.2 BILLION FLOOD AID; PRESIDENT VISITS IOWA COMMUNITY HIT BY
DISASTER

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 704 words

DATELINE: ELDRIDGE, IOWA


President Bill Clinton pledged Sunday night to make as much as $1.2 billion in
federal money available to help flood victims along the Mississippi River.
Visiting a farm near Davenport, Iowa, Clinton put the overall damage estimate of
the past week's floods in Iowa, Illinois and Missouri at close to $1 billion.
He said too little money was available at this time to cover all the losses. But
he announced that farmers, farm businesses and individuals would get the same
treatment given to victims of Hurricane Andrew in Florida last year.  This means
businesses and individuals will be eligible to have the federal government pay
as much as 50 percent of their total losses.  On his way to the farm, Clinton
had his motorcade stop on a long, high bridge across the Mississippi River,
surveyed the damage and walked into Davenport - the hardest-hit community along
the river - to shake hands with residents. At one point he waded through water
on the street, shook his head and said, "It's bad." In the city, the Mississippi
had risen to more than 7 feet above flood stage, and even higher levels were
expected with additional heavy rain upstream.  Mayor Pat Gibbs has estimated
damage to Davenport at $100 million.  Clinton explained that he had already
signed an order releasing $100 million to help those in the flood area.
Administration officials said the government would move to make an additional
$297 million, in a federal disaster fund, available for flood victims, bringing
the total to $397 million. And Agriculture Secretary Mike Espy, who accompanied
the president on the trip, said the administration would ask Congress to approve
an additional $850 million in aid. That would bring the total to roughly $1.24
billion.  Clinton engaged in a testy exchange with a farmer who demanded to know
where the president would find the money to pay for the aid - and whether it
would mean higher taxes.  Steve Loussaret, 23, of Long Grove, Iowa, complained
to Clinton, "I remember someone saying, 'No new taxes,' about six months ago."
"It wasn't me," Clinton said.  The president then gave a pitch for his $500
billion deficit reduction program and said he didn't know exactly where the
money would come from to pay for the disaster aid, saying it was up to Congress
to find other areas to cut.  The president said the farm aid would not add to
the deficit.  "If you don't believe that you should have any tax increase at
all, you're entitled to that opinion," he told the farmer. "But I think you'll
make more money in lower interest rates than you'll pay in more taxes." Clinton
also ordered changes in the eligibility rules for farmers seeking relief so it
will be easier for more to apply for federal help, including farmers who have
not been able to plant their crops because of prolonged rain.  He said he was
waiving relief rules to make farmers who have been unable to plant crops
eligible for disaster aid.  A growing number of Midwestern farmers have voiced
fear that they would not be able to seek federal aid because the storms that
have been battering the region for months have prevented crop planting. Federal
aid usually is based on damage to crops.  In Iowa alone, farm economists
estimate that the late planting of corn and soybeans has cost the state at least
$750 million. The overall damage to the state has been put at more than $1
billion.  Other states damaged by the rains include Illinois, Wisconsin,
Minnesota, Missouri and South Dakota.  Clinton, wearing a green long-sleeved
shirt, jeans and leather boots, greeted residents a block away from the most
heavily flood sections of downport Davenport.  The president's jumbo jet had
flown low over the Mississippi River so Clinton could look from the window at
rain-swollen waters that have inundated low-lying farms and homes.  Rain was in
the forecast for each of the next several days, and officials were warning it
could prolong the flooding for weeks.  In western Minnesota, 5.9 inches of rain
fell overnight at Morris. In Marshall, having its third round of flooding in two
months, the Redwood River crested Saturday 2.6 feet above flood stage. That
river feeds the Minnesota River, a major contributor to the Mississippi.

                                US Official News

                            August 3, 2016 Wednesday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri)
Issues Solicitation for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S.
International Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 453  words

DATELINE: New York


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International
Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: AG-INFG-S-16-0057

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: August 2, 2016

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AG-INFG-S-16-0057 (2000004245) for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after August 2, 2016, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near August 10, 2016.



To be eligible to submit offers, potential contractors must meet KCCO's vendor
qualification requirements established in accordance with FAR Subpart 9.2.
Details of these requirements and contact information are available online at:
http://www.fsa.usda.gov/FSA/webapp?area=home&subject=coop&topic=pas-vr. KCCO's
main contact for vendor qualification requirements is Betty Kunkel who can be
reached by phone at 816-926-3295 or by email at Betty.Kunkel@kcc.usda.gov
Once qualification requirements have been met, access to WBSCM will be provided.
Bids, modifications, withdrawals of bids, and price adjustments shall be
submitted using this system. Submission of the above by any means other than
WBSCM will be determined nonresponsive. Complete details of the contract
requirements and terms are available in KCCO's master solicitation for commodity
procurements and USDA's commodity requirements documents available through the
attached document packages. KCCO's solicitation (when published) will specify
the commodities, tonnage, and required shipping schedules.

Set Aside: N/A

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 311

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205 Mail Stop 8698 Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s): Janet Cleveland, Grain Marketing Specialist
janet.cleveland@kcc.usda.gov Phone: 816-926-2540

                   Tonawanda News (North Tonawanda, New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           December 21, 2010 Tuesday

Bad weather in 2010 leads to disaster aid

BYLINE: Tonawanda News, North Tonawanda, N.Y.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 379 words


Dec. 21--Two weather events during 2010 placed Erie and Niagara counties on
natural disaster area lists, allowing farmers to qualify for federal assistance.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture last week designated 19 counties in New York
as natural disaster areas due to losses caused by frost, freezing, high winds,
hail, excessive snow, excessive rain and cold temperatures that occurred Feb. 15
-- May 12. Erie County was among the 19 counties listed, and Niagara County was
among 31 additional counties placed on the list because of its proximity to the
disaster area.

In addition, Niagara County qualifies for disaster assistance because of
excessive rain, flooding, flash flooding, hail and high winds that occurred
between June 2 and July 21. Franklin, Orleans and Suffolk counties were named
natural disaster areas. Niagara qualified as one of Orleans County's neighbors.

"President Obama and I understand these conditions caused severe damage to a
wide variety of crops including fruit and vegetable crops, and we want to help,"
said Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack. "This action will provide help to
farmers who suffered significant production losses."

Three other weather events were considered severe enough to qualify parts of New
York state as natural disaster areas, including two for excessive rain and one
for excessive drought.

All five events were designated natural disasters on Friday, which qualifies
farm operators in the designated areas eligible for low interest emergency (EM)
loans from USDA's Farm Service Agency (FSA), provided eligibility requirements
are met.

Farmers in eligible counties have until June 17, 2011 to apply for loans to help
cover part of their actual losses. FSA will consider each loan application on
its own merits, taking into account the extent of losses, security available and
repayment ability. Additional information is available online at
http://disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

To see more of the Tonawanda News or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.tonawanda-news.com/. Copyright (c) 2010, Tonawanda News, North
Tonawanda, N.Y. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more
information about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information
Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com.

                              758 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

                           September 10, 2010, Friday

STATE Briefs

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P5A

LENGTH: 597 words


I-64 bridge opening ties up morning traffic

The new Interstate 64 bridge between South Charleston and Dunbar opened Thursday
morning, tying up traffic in the process.

Road workers shut down the eastbound lanes of the interstate about 7 a.m. to
shift traffic to the new bridge, said a Kanawha County Metro 911 dispatcher.

The lanes going over the new bridge opened about 7:30 a.m., the dispatcher said.
In the meantime, morning rush-hour traffic was backed up for several miles, into
Putnam County.

Coal train derails in Wayne County

A train derailed in Wayne County early Thursday, according to Wayne County 911
dispatcher.

The accident happened at the intersection of W.Va. 37 near Morris Funeral Home
in the town of Wayne about 12:30 a.m., the dispatcher said. No one was injured,
he said.

The Norfolk Southern train was carrying coal from a mine near East Lynn, the
dispatcher said.

The road was reopened Thursday morning. Officials were still unclear Thursday
afternoon what caused the derailment.

State to seek drought aid for panhandle

MARTINSBURG - The West Virginia Department of Agriculture plans to request
federal aid for the drought-stricken Eastern Panhandle.

Agriculture spokesman Buddy Davidson told The Journal that the department will
request a disaster declaration from the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Davidson
said the state is awaiting damage assessments from the federal department's Farm
Service Agency.

Jefferson County homeland security and emergency management director Barbara
Miller said a disaster declaration would make farmers eligible for emergency
loans.

Festival seeks film award nominees

SUTTON - The West Virginia Filmmakers Festival wants nominees for the state's
best movie maker.

The organization says it awards the West Virginia Filmmaker of the Year Award
based on recent or lifetime work that has had the most impact on the state's
movie industry. Nominees can be involved in any aspect of making films,
including production, direction, writing and acting, and they should have strong
ties to the state, such as making a movie in West Virginia or living here.

The winner will be announced during the 11th annual West Virginia Filmmakers
Festival.

Harrison issues first smoking ban citation

CLARKSBURG - An Eagles lodge is the first establishment to be cited under the
Harrison-Clarksburg Health Department's Clean Indoor Air regulation.

The Exponent Telegram reports that the county's sanitation supervisor cited
Fraternal Order of Eagles No. 2353's trustee, William Bunnell, for an alleged
smoking violation last week.

The regulation bans smoking at most public places, including bars, restaurants
and video lottery establishments. It went into effect June 1.

Health department administrator Chad Bundy told the newspaper the misdemeanor
complaint is the first to be filed under the regulation.

Bunnell says he will ask for a jury trial.

A lawsuit filed by a group of fraternal organizations challenging the regulation
is pending.

West Virginia whistle to be heard in Colorado

STEAMBOAT SPRINGS, Colo. - The noon whistle is coming back to Steamboat Springs
- just a bit softer.

The ski resort's city council decided Tuesday to revive the city's traditional
noon whistle blasts reminiscent of a steamboat. The noon whistles were stopped
in 2008 because of structural concerns caused by the sirenlike 150 decibel
whistle blasts downtown.

The new whistle is stainless steel and made by MD Whistles in Fairmont, W.Va.
The owner of the company, Mike Daugherty, says the new whistle will have a more
comfortable noise level of about 100 decibels.

- from staff, wire reports

                              The Washington Post

                     May 23, 1992, Saturday, Final Edition

Lugar Seeks Record of Prewar Farm Aid to Iraq

George Lardner Jr., Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A21

LENGTH: 588 words


The Senate Agriculture Committee's ranking Republican, Sen. Richard G. Lugar
(Ind.), joined his Democratic chairman yesterday in calling on the Bush
administration for a huge number of documents concerning prewar agricultural aid
to Iraq.

The decision by Lugar added a significant bipartisan flavor to the spreading
number of congressional investigations into the administration's courtship of
Iraq before the Persian Gulf War.

Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick J. Leahy (D-Vt.) said he intended
to pursue his investigation of Commodity Credit Corp. (CCC) guarantees and other
U.S. support for Iraq before Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait, "no matter how high
up I have to go."

Leahy and Lugar sent letters to the secretaries of Agriculture, Treasury and
State and the head of the Federal Reserve demanding production of thousands of
pertinent records and calling for the submission of lists within a few days.
Leahy said in a statement that the document request was necessary because the
Bush administration was refusing to provide the General Accounting Office with
records for an inquiry it started more than two years ago.

"Refusal by the administration to cooperate suggests the possibility of a
coverup," Leahy said.

One of the most startling documents that has come to light thus far is an Oct.
13, 1989, memorandum written by a State Department official, Frank Lemay, after
a meeting with four Agriculture Department officials about a bank scandal in
Atlanta that indicated the CCC program with Iraq was riddled with fraud.

Lemay reported to State Department higher-ups that the USDA was "looking at
possible diversion of CCC-guaranteed commodities during transit, illegal
payments required by Iraq of exporters," and demands for kickbacks in the form
of after-sales services.

The memo also quoted one Agriculture Department lawyer, Kevin Brosch, as saying
federal prosecutors in Atlanta had "some indication diverted funds (and possibly
direct bank-lent funds) were used to procure nuclear-related equipment."

"USDA expectations are that the [bank] investigation could 'blow the roof off
the CCC,' " Lemay reported. ". . . We should proceed carefully in urging the
immediate provision of loan guarantees to Iraq. If smoke indicates fire, we may
be facing a four-alarm blaze in the near future."

At a hearing late Thursday before the House Banking Committee, Brosch and
another Agriculture Department official, Lawrence T. McElvain, repudiated the
memo. McElvain said he had no recollection of saying anything about "a
possibility of any of these commodities being diverted . . . for military
equipment" and said the memo "misrepresented very badly" the actual discussions.

Lemay could not be reached for comment yesterday.

The dispute over prewar policy toward Iraq also has extended to the Senate
Foreign Relations Committee where Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.) has asked for
indefinite postponement of a hearing on the nomination of James P. "Jock" Covey
to head a new State Department bureau for South Asia.

The hearing for Covey, a deputy assistant secretary of state for the Near East,
was held up, sources said, because of questions about his involvement in prewar
Iraqi policy. Some Democrats on the committee also supported the delay, the
sources said.

Foreign Relations Committee members, one source said, are wondering what Covey
and his bureau did when they were told of possible diversion of CCC-guaranteed
food shipments. Covey was one of the recipients of the Lemay memo.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, SEN. RICHARD G. LUGAR.

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS, FOREIGN NEWS

                       Copyright 1992 The Washington Post


                              760 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                    SEPTEMBER 1, 2000 Friday CNORTH EDITION

NEWS IN BRIEF

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B06

LENGTH: 356 words


Driver killed in accident

on DeKalb Pike in Whitpain

WHITPAIN - A motorist, whose identity police have not yet disclosed, was killed
about 8 a.m. yesterday after the 1984 Oldsmobile he was driving collided with a
flatbed truck on DeKalb Pike (Route 202) just north of Route 73.

Police said the car was traveling north on DeKalb Pike, and the truck was
traveling south. The driver of the Oldsmobile was pronounced dead at Mercy
Suburban Hospital.

The accident, which forced DeKalb Pike to be shut down in both directions for
two hours, remains under investigation, police said.

Cheese franks are recalled

over possible metal shards

READING - The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection
Service has announced the recall of 6,588 pounds of cheese franks that could be
contaminated with metal fragments.

Berks Packaging Co. of Reading recalled Weis Quality Our Deluxe Cheese Franks
after a consumer from Pennsylvania reported finding two metal fragments in the
product, company officials said. The recalled package has "EST. 8782" in the
USDA seal, and a sell-by date of Oct. 17. The contaminated product is believed
to have been sold in Pennsylvania, Maryland, New York and New Jersey grocery
stores within two weeks of production.

Anyone with food-safety questions may call the USDA Meat and Poultry Hotline at
1-800-535-4555.

Two events to be added

to annual 12K AIDS Walk

Organizers of the annual AIDS Walk announced yesterday that they would add two
events - a 12-kilometer run and a one-mile stroller walk for families with small
children - to the traditional 12K walk at this year's event on Oct 15.

Also for the first time, participants will be able to register or obtain a
sponsor form online at www.aidswalkphilly.org Anyone interested also can
register by calling the AIDS Fund at 215-731-9255. There is no registration fee
and no minimum pledge requirement.

Last year, more than 30,000 people participated, raising nearly $1 million for
44 area organizations that provide care, education and other services for people
with HIV and AIDS and others affected by the disease.

                              761 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                           January 15, 2015 Thursday
                                 METRO EDITION

USDA grants aid 3 state projects

BYLINE: JOSEPHINE MARCOTTY; STAFF WRITER, STAR TRIBUNE (Mpls.-St. Paul)

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 522 words



HIGHLIGHT: $26 million targets flood control, water quality and songbird
protection.


The Red River, the imperiled golden-winged warbler and environmentally minded
Minnesota farmers all will benefit from $26 million in new federal funding
designed to boost conservation and clean up agricultural water pollution in the
state.

The three projects, which all must provide significant matching funds from other
sources over the next five years, are part of a revamped $370 million program
announced Wednesday by the U.S. Department of Agriculture's conservation arm.

Calling it a "new era of conservation," U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack
said the 115 "high impact" projects across 50 states represent the latest
strategies in how to protect water quality and wildlife. It is the first time
the agriculture department has joined forces with state and local governments
and other groups to increase the scope and financing for projects designed to
protect the environment.

"These partnerships are forging a new path for getting conservation on the
ground and are providing opportunities for communities to have a voice and
ownership in protecting and improving our natural resources," Vilsack said.

In Minnesota, the largest grant - $12 million - will go to flood prevention
projects in the Red River Valley. Nearly 30 federal, state and local government
agencies will work to build water retention systems and ponds on agricultural
lands that will work to slow the flow of water into the river while also
reducing phosphorus and nitrogen pollution levels. The Red River is a major
source of nutrient contamination in Canada's Lake Winnipeg. Once completed, six
to eight different sites will store approximately 50,000 acre-feet of
floodwater.

It is small piece of a $1.8 billion diversion and flood control project underway
to protect Fargo, N.D., and other towns along the river, and it will need a
total of $21 million over the next five years.

Minnesota's three-year-old Agricultural Water Quality Certification Program for
farmers was awarded $9 million to expand statewide. It provides farmers with
expert help and financial assistance in adopting ways to stop soil erosion and
water pollution. That could include things like new drainage systems and other
water management tactics to prevent runoff. The total cost for the next five
years will be $21 million. State agriculture officials said they expect to get
the remaining funds by tapping the state's Legacy funds.

The American Bird Conservancy, a national conservation group, and three states
joined forces to protect the golden-winged warbler by improving forest habitat
on 64,000 acres around the Great Lakes.

The bird has suffered one of the steepest population declines of any songbird
species, primarily because of the disappearance of young forests, its preferred
habitat.

"Michigan, Minnesota and Wisconsin have the largest remaining breeding
population, and habitat management actions there are considered critical to
rebuilding populations rapidly," said Dr. George Fenwick, president of the
American Bird Conservancy.

The project will cost a total of $10 million, and Minnesota has contributed some
of it through Legacy funds.

Josephine Marcotty · 612-673-7394

LOAD-DATE: January 15, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                          Copyright 2015 Star Tribune
                              All Rights Reserved


                              762 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              September 23, 1984, Sunday, Late City Final Edition

PRESIDENT DEFENDS SPURNING STEEL AID AS HELP TO FARMERS

BYLINE: UPI

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1; Page 32, Column 6; National Desk

LENGTH: 343 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 22


President Reagan said today that he decided last week to aid debt-ridden farmers
but declined to impose import quotas on steel to aid that industry because they
were a ''quick fix'' that might backfire on agricultural America.

In his weekly paid political address on radio, Mr. Reagan said such quotas could
spur inflation and prompt other nations to retaliate against American exports,
including farm products.

He said steel and agriculture ''have not shared fully'' in the economic recovery
because declining land values made it hard for farmers to repay high- interest
loans and foreign ''dumping'' of government-subsidized steel in the United
States made it hard for domestic makers to compete.

Last Tuesday, Mr. Reagan ordered the Farmers Home Administration to defer up to
25 percent of loan recipients' payments for five years and made available $630
million in private loan guarantees to farmers.

He then rejected the steel industry request for the quotas, ordering instead a
program of seeking voluntary restraints from foreign producers while promising
tough new action if they did not comply. ''One thing I'm not doing, for it would
damage our economy more than it would help, is imposing import quotas,'' he said
today.

In the radio broadcast, four days before Mr. Reagan's planned campaign trip to
steel-producing areas in Ohio, the President criticized Walter F. Mondale, the
Democratic Presidential nominee, as favoring the quotas.

''That kind of protectionism is my opponent's policy,'' Mr. Reagan said, ''and
just like his tax increase, it's the wrong policy.''

''The lessons of history are clear,'' the President added. ''The costs of
protectionism for one group would automatically be passed on to another.
Inflation would be reignited, jobs would be destroyed, not saved, and foreign
countries would retaliate against our exporters like our farmers.''

''By resisting quick fixes,'' he said, ''and helping those in steel and farming
help themselves, we'll make sure all of us can and will go forward together.''

                    Appeal-Democrat (Marysville, California)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                            February 14, 2016 Sunday

Education Briefs: Feb. 14, 2016

BYLINE: Appeal-Democrat, Marysville, Calif.

SECTION: LIFESTYLE

LENGTH: 519 words


Feb. 14--Yuba City

College hosts grant application workshop

Cambridge Junior College is hosting a workshop to help future college students
complete their 2016 Cal Grant applications.

The workshop is at 5:30 p.m. Feb. 23 at the campus, 990-A Klamath Lane, Yuba
City.

Cal Grant applications are due by March 2. The financial aid program is
administrated by the California Student Aid Commission and is the largest source
of California state funded student financial aid.

Call Cambridge Junior College at 674-9199 for more information.

Chico

Continuing education scholarship available

Scholarships are available for students whose studies were interrupted for at
least five years by circumstances beyond their control and who now want to
resume their undergraduate studies at California State University, Chico.

The Bernard Osher Foundation, headquartered in San Francisco, is offering
$60,000 in scholarships.

Applications are due by 5 p.m. Feb. 29. An application and more information are
available online at rce.csuchico.edu/osherscholarship.

For more information, visit rce.csuchico.edu or call Regional and Continuing
Education at 898-6105.

CSU Chico Continuing Education has administered and distributed $470,898 in
Bernard Osher Foundation Reentry Scholarships to 90 CSU, Chico students in the
past nine years.

Yuba-Sutter

Scholarship for those interested in business

Students who demonstrate potential entrepreneurial business interest and
rationale are eligible for the Entrepreneurial Scholarship available through the
Employer Advisory Council.

The $1,000 scholarship is provided by the Yuba, Sutter, Colusa, Butte EAC.

To qualify, applicants must be at least 16 years old, need not be students and
must show Local Labor Market Information for the industry.

The planned business must be within the local area.

Applications, due by March 1, must be delivered or mailed to EAC, 950 Tharp
Road, suite 1000, Yuba City, CA 95993.

For more information, contact Toni Costales-Servin at
tcostales-servin@sutter.k12.ca.us or 822-5852.

Farm Bureau offers agriculture scholarship

The Yuba-Sutter Farm Bureau is offering scholarships to graduating high school
students who have long-term career interests in agriculture.

Open to students from Yuba and Sutter counties, the program awards one-time
gifts of $500 or more to at least four students annually.

Applicants must be a senior currently enrolled in a public or private high
school with an average to above-average academic record, and plan to enroll as a
full-time student at an accredited school.

The student or his or her parents or guardians must be a current member of YSFB
for at least one year before the student's application.

The 2015 scholarship applications must be postmarked or returned -- no
electronic submissions -- by 5 p.m. April 24 to the Yuba-Sutter Farm Bureau
office, 475 N. Palora Ave., suite A, Yuba City CA 95991.

For an application, visit yubasutter.cfbf.com/Scholarships.aspx or call 673-6550
.

(Marysville, Calif.) at www.appeal-democrat.com Distributed by Tribune Content
Agency, LLC.

                              764 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     Charleston Daily Mail (West Virginia)

                             April 3, 2015, Friday

State briefs

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P5D

LENGTH: 618 words


Builder sues W.Va. property owners

BECKLEY- More than 100 property owners in West Virginia are being sued by the
developer of a proposed natural gas pipeline.

Mountain Valley Pipeline LLC's lawsuit seeks access to the properties to conduct
a survey for a possible pipeline route.

The lawsuit said the property owners have rejected the company's request to
enter their properties. The lawsuit names 103 individuals and three corporations
in 10 counties as defendants.

The Register-Herald reported that Mountain Valley Pipeline filed the lawsuit
last week in U.S. District Court in Beckley.

Earlier this month, families in Summers and Monroe counties filed a lawsuit
against the company seeking to prevent its agents from entering their
properties.

The pipeline would stretch about 300 miles from northwestern West Virginia to
Pittsylvania County in Virginia.

Attorney general shares fund totals

In a possible bid for governor, state Attorney General Patrick Morrisey says he
raised more than $310,000 over two months and has about $546,000 in cash.

In a news release Thursday, Morrisey said the totals account for a late January
fundraising start and a new $250,000 self-loan.

Morrisey's campaign said he may use the cash for re-election or the open
governor's race next year.

Democratic Gov. Earl Ray Tomblin can't run again because of limits.

Morrisey, Senate President Bill Cole and Congressman David McKinley are the
major Republicans who have expressed interest in the governor's race.

Democratic U.S. Sen. Joe Manchin is considering running for his old job as
governor.

Democratic state Senate Minority Leader Jeff Kessler has a campaign account for
governor with $60,800 transferred from an old committee.

WVU awarded $453,000 agriculture grant

MORGANTOWN - West Virginia University has been awarded $453,000 grant from the
U.S. Department of Agriculture.

The grant is from the USDA's National Institute of Food and Agriculture. Nearly
$19 million is being awarded to universities around the U.S. to ensure a safe
and nutritious food supply and as well as the development of antimicrobial
resistance strategies.

The WVU grant is aimed at developing what the USDA says is innovative protein
sources for a growing population.

Four forests added to federal registry

GLEN JEAN. - Four West Virginia forests are being added to the Old Growth Forest
Network.

The first West Virginia forest to be added to the network of ancient forests is
one located in the federally protected New River Gorge National River. That will
occur on April 15.

The other old growth forests being dedicated by the network are Cathedral State
Park, Pierson Hollow of Carnifex Ferry Battlefield State Park and Gaudineer
Scenic Area in Monongahela National Forest.

West Virginia is joining a number of states that have forests in the Old Growth
Forest Network. They include New York, Massachusetts, Maryland, Pennsylvania and
Virginia, among others.

Deadline looms for college aid grants

The clock is ticking for West Virginia high school seniors to be considered for
a higher education grant to attend a state college or university.

The West Virginia Higher Education Policy Commission said seniors and college
students have an April 15 deadline to apply.

Chancellor Paul Hill said the grant program is the largest need-based financial
aid program in the state.

In the 2013-14 academic year, the Higher Education Grant Program awarded nearly
$41 million to more than 19,000 students across West Virginia.

Awards are based on financial need. The grant may be renewed for up to three
academic years beyond the initial award.

For more information on the Higher Education Grant, visit the College Foundation
of West Virginia at www.cfwv.com.

                              765 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                  March 12, 1999, Friday, CONSTITUTION EDITION

HEALTH NEWS & NOTES;
Food-borne illnesses decline

SECTION: FEATURES; Pg. 10F

LENGTH: 368 words


Diseases caused by two food-borne infections, salmonella and campylobacter,
dropped between 1996 and 1998, preliminary data from the Centers for Disease
Control and Prevention suggest. Salmonella infections fell 13 percent and
campylobacter infections were 15 percent lower, according to data from the
Foodborne Diseases Active Surveillance Network, or FoodNet. The incidence of E.
coli, the bacterial infection usually spread through contaminated, undercooked
beef products, went from 2.7 cases per 100,000 population in 1996 to 2.3 in 1997
to 2.8 in 1998, which could be a normal fluctuation. CDC researchers do not
fully understand the reasons for the decline in illnesses but think prevention
efforts by the U.S. Department of Agriculture and the Food and Drug
Administration may be working. Influenza deaths higher: Death rates this flu
season are running slightly higher than expected, the CDC said Thursday. The flu
season, which runs from late October through early May, got off to a slow start
but has heated up, with 43 states reporting outbreaks, the CDC said. For the
week ending Feb. 27, pneumonia- and influenza-related deaths accounted for 8.1
percent of the total deaths reported in 122 U.S. cities, the CDC said. The
agency had expected a rate of 7.5 percent or less. For the last three weeks in
February, in fact, the rate has run higher than CDC expectations. Officials said
flu season may not have peaked yet. Inherited genes and AIDS: Scientists have
found inherited genes that may explain why some people infected with HIV quickly
develop AIDS while others with the virus live for years in relatively good
health. The discovery has no immediate benefit for HIV patients, but it
increases understanding about how the virus attacks the body, said Mary
Carrington, one of the researchers involved in the study. In a genetic study of
about 500 people infected with HIV, Carrington and fellow researchers at the
National Cancer Institute found that differences in the inherited pattern of
what are called HLA Class I genes determined who became sickest the soonest and
who was able to hold off the disease progression. A report on the study appears
today in the journal Science.
