                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                            November 2, 2007 Friday
                             First Replate Edition

FOOD RELIEF: From Georgia to Ethiopia, farm bill counts

BYLINE: WILTON D. GREGORY, J. KEVIN BOLAND; For the Journal-Constitution

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 15A

LENGTH: 836 words


Georgians and Georgia farmers have some experience with drought. And although
we've had some relief lately, lack of rain can be a serious problem for our
state.

But in eastern Ethiopia, drought and deforestation often spell agricultural
disaster for farmers and herders trying to earn a meager living from the land.
During the short rainy seasons, water that should bring sustenance rushes down
the steep hillsides, carrying precious topsoil with it. As a result, crops fail
and villagers suffer from hunger. This problem illustrates the crisis of
Ethiopia's perpetual battle against chronic food shortages.

In the village of Legedini, however, a gift of the American people is helping
the community to escape the cycle of hunger. The village residents built by hand
the low stone walls that climb the terraced hillsides. These terraces catch soil
as it washes from the tops of the hills, providing fertile ground to grow crops
and animal feed. The villagers were paid for their labor with U.S.-donated food
in this unique, self-help program.

Food aid, the provision of commodities like wheat, rice and vegetable oil to
communities in need, has served as the backbone of U.S. humanitarian relief for
over 50 years. It prevented starvation in Europe after World War II. It has held
at bay the recurrent threat of famine in Africa and South Asia. It has
undergirded contemporary relief after the Indian Ocean tsunami, the earthquakes
in Pakistan and catastrophic flooding in Central America.

However, food aid doesn't only save lives in natural disasters and emergencies.
American humanitarian organizations use food aid and other resources to address
chronic hunger and foster long-term development through a wide range of
programs. Food aid commodities combined with cash can advance education, health
and agricultural development, which help communities cope with disasters down
the road.

Current law directs that 75 percent of food aid must be used for development, or
long-term programs that help communities address entrenched problems, such as
hunger or a lack of clean water. But the law also allows this rule to be waived
--- and it is waived every year. Currently, just 25 percent of food aid is used
for long-term development programs. The rest is used during natural disasters
and other emergencies. Make no mistake; we must not let people starve. But there
are other ways to meet unexpected needs, such as supplemental budget requests or
tapping a grain reserve known as the Bill Emerson Humanitarian Trust.

What we can't do is cut out programs such as the Legedini Food Security Project
in Ethiopia. It stops the cycle of recurring hunger dead in its tracks.

There is a sensible solution to this dilemma through the farm bill currently
under consideration in Congress. You don't have to tell anyone in rural America
that this legislation deals with issues of great importance to our farmers. But
it is not well known that a key provision of the farm bill is the main vehicle
governing U.S. food aid programs. Catholic Relief Services and more than a dozen
other humanitarian agencies are urging Congress to mandate in the farm bill that
at least half of the U.S. food aid budget --- a minimum of $600 million --- be
set aside in a "safebox" to be used exclusively for development programs, such
as Legedini, that fight chronic hunger.

This type of designated funding would guarantee that we don't lose the fight
against chronic hunger by diverting almost all food aid to emergencies, such as
droughts or disasters. The $600 million safebox was included in the version of
the farm bill passed last month by the U.S. Senate Agriculture Committee. We
urge the full Senate, and ultimately the House-Senate conference committee, to
preserve this provision in the final version of the farm bill.

The farm bill is extremely important to Georgia's farmers, who rely on it to
enable them to compete in the global marketplace. We understand and support our
fellow Georgians who depend on agriculture for their families. Congress must
provide the right tools to help them compete.

Georgians have big hearts and a long tradition of helping our neighbors in need.
Passing a farm bill with a safebox for food aid targeted for long-term
development will help our neighbors overseas, including the poor in Legedini and
the 70 million other impoverished people who each year benefit from food aid.
The food aid program funded through the farm bill provides the opportunity to
make real and lasting advances in the fight against hunger.

* Archbishop Wilton D. Gregory (left) leads the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of
Atlanta. Bishop J. Kevin Boland leads the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Savannah
and is a member of the board of directors of Catholic Relief Services.

HOW TO SUBMIT AN OPINION COLUMN: Submissions should be 750 words or less. E-mail
columns to dbeasley@ajc.com; fax them to 404-526-5610. Columns submitted to the
AJC may be published, republished and made available in the AJC or other
databases and electronic formats.

                              Journal of Commerce

                             April 8, 1997, Tuesday

Contamination scare is shriveling sales of fresh as well as frozen strawberries

BYLINE: BY JOHN MAGGS

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 705 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


A hepatitis outbreak traced to frozen Mexican strawberries is leading some
consumers to forgo purchases of all strawberries, including those grown in the
United States, according to a major U.S. strawberry processor.

""I know of three U.S. growers whose customers are cutting back purchases, ''
said Arthur Price, owner and chief executive of Global Trading Inc., of
Greenville, S.C., the largest U.S. processor of frozen Mexican strawberries.

Another processor, Andrews & Williamson Sales Co. of San Diego, sold some 2
million pounds of frozen strawberries from Mexico blamed for an outbreak of
hepatitis A that infected 175 people in Michigan.

In addition to the consumer safety issues, the scare plays into the hands of
U.S. farm groups and those opposed to free trade initiatives with Mexico.

In a related development, meanwhile, an executive at the U.S. plant that
processed the imported strawberries apparently had direct links to the Mexican
farm industry.

While federal authorities are still trying to determine the source of the
contamination, U.S. strawberry growers have seen a dip in fresh strawberry
demand, even though only frozen varieties have been implicated.

In addition, an official with the Ralphs grocery store chain in California said
the company had halted all sales of fresh Mexican strawberries, which accounted
for 30 percent of its strawberry sales.

Mr. Price said a U.S. Food and Drug Administration official told him the agency
should have the results of its first tests on the infected strawberries today or
Wednesday, and that these will likely rule out contamination before the fruit
reached A&W's plant.

DISTINCTION NOT MADE

Nevertheless, consumers may not make the distinction.

""It's like this with every food scare, '' Mr. Price said. ""The shopper will
continue to skip strawberries and pick up a cantaloupe.''

Mr. Price, who says he's been in the strawberry processing business for 30
years, says the U.S. executive at the center of the hepatitis scare - Fred
Williamson has owned and operated strawberry farms in the Mexican state of Baja
California .

Mr. Williamson resigned as president of San Diego-based Andrews & Williamson
Sales Co. last week after the company was accused of falsely labeling
Mexican-grown strawberries as being from California.

Mr. Williamson has been a longtime player in the strawberry business, with
interests in the United States and Mexico, according to growers and importers in
the Southwest. He also has been a major importer of cherry tomatoes from Mexico.

While scientists still don't know whether the strawberry contamination took
place in Mexico or in the United States, supporters of domestic growers continue
to use the food scare to push U.S.-raised fruits and vegetables.

""These strawberries from California are absolutely safe to eat,'' said state
Agriculture Secretary Ann Veneman last week, wolfing down some fruit to prove
her point.

AIDS KIT MAKER

Andrews and Williamson is owned by Beaverton, Oregon-based Epitope Inc., a
company best known for a pioneering oral test kit for AIDS.

But the company's second-most important line of work is in genetic plant
engineering, particularly tomatoes and grapevines. People involved with the
Mexican tomato industry say Mr. Williamson is known to be an important player in
that business, in addition to his investments in Mexican strawberry plantations.

Andrews and Williamson referred all inquiries to Epitope, and Epitope officials
did not respond to questions about tomato or strawberry investments in Mexico.

It also is not clear whether Epitope's involvement in genetically engineered
tomatoes is linked in any way to Mr. Williamson's role in the Mexican industry.
Mexico has grabbed a larger share of the U.S. tomato market recently partly
because of its aggressive experiments with different strains of vine-ripened
tomatoes that have longer shelf lives than U.S.-grown varieties.

Andrews & Williamson spent some $36,000 last week to inoculate school children
exposed to hepatitis from the company's canned strawberries.

Mexican officials and some U.S. officials said it was unlikely that Mexican
growers were to blame for the contamination.

                              769 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                   April 10, 2004 Saturday Mishawaka Edition

Rural aid available for fixing, buying homes;
Low-, moderate-income levels qualify.

BYLINE: Tribune Staff Report

SECTION: NATION; Pg. A5

LENGTH: 332 words


Extra help is available for those with moderate and low income who want to buy
or repair their homes in the rural parts of St. Joseph, LaPorte, Lake, Porter
and Jasper counties.

It's not a new program, but the U.S. Department of Agriculture has recently
passed along some extra funds.

To qualify, the house you are fixing or buying must be within certain boundaries
as determined by the USDA. In St. Joseph County, it is roughly to the south of
Roosevelt Road and west of Rush Road, but the line wiggles to include a chunk of
Crumstown.

Here are the various types of aid:

Home repair loans will be given for emergency needs since funds are limited,
said Steven Ballard, manager for Rural Development, a USDA program based out of
LaPorte.

If you are age 62 or older and cannot repay a loan, you can seek a repair grant,
but only to remove health or safety hazards or to make the home accessible.

To qualify for either the grant or loan in St. Joseph and LaPorte counties, your
annual income must be less than $20,100 for a single person and $28,700 for a
family of four. The income requirements are different in the other counties.

Rural Development is also offering loans to buy, build or repair a home, though
folks with higher income can apply for these.

To qualify in St. Joseph and LaPorte counties, your annual income must be less
than $32,150 for a single person and $45,900 for a family of four. The income
limit varies in other counties.

The loan's interest rate is 6 1/8 percent, but a subsidy can lower it to 1
percent depending on the person's income and other factors.

The home must have a price of less than $144,500, Ballard said.

The USDA provided an additional $4.4 million statewide for this program.

For more information or to see if you qualify for any of this aid, contact Rural
Development at (219) 324-6303, ext. 4, or e-mail at Steven.Ballard@in.usda.gov.
Or write to the office at 100 Legacy Plaza West, LaPorte, IN 46350.

                              The Bismarck Tribune

                           January 14, 2006 Saturday

Sunflowers might help in the fight against AIDS

SECTION: NEWS/STATE

LENGTH: 393 words


N

By DAVE KOLPACK

Associated Press Writer

FARGO, N.D. (AP) - Local agriculture officials are upbeat about a German study
showing that a sunflower plant could be used in new drugs to fight the disease
that causes AIDS.

Scientists at the University of Bonn discovered the link while they were looking
at antifungal properties the sunflower uses to fight off sclerotinia, a disease
commonly known as white mold.

Brady Vick, a chemist for the USDA's sunflower research unit in Fargo, said the
results come from reputable scientists who have a tradition of finding natural
chemicals to treat diseases.

"It's exciting for the Germans, they're the ones who discovered it," Vick said
Monday. "It's kind of a surprise announcement. I don't know how they made the
connection."

The findings could help promote further research and marketing for the crop,
said Larry Kleingartner, executive director of the National Sunflower
Association in Bismarck.

"It's very preliminary, quite frankly," Kleingartner said. "We are checking
within different levels of Washington to see if there's potential for some
accelerated research on this."

Sunflower groups spend about $500,000 a year on research to fight white mold, he
said. It also affects soybeans, canola and edible beans.

"It's interesting to see this very complex plant disease as a potential source
of medicine for a very difficult human disease," Kleingartner said.

White mold cost farmers more than $100 million in 1999 and 2004, Kleingartner
said. It can show up in the roots during growing season or infect the head
during cool and wet weather in late summer.

"It can wipe out a whole field within a couple of days," Vick said.

The antifungal substance used in the AIDS drugs is also found in the artichoke
and wild chicory. Researchers said it would be cheaper to make the drug from the
sunflower plant.

"It's important to note that the apparent HIV antiviral compounds identified in
the Bonn study occur within the sunflower plant, not the edible seed or oil of
sunflower," Kleingartner said. "However, we already know that sunflower seed and
oil have proven nutritional and health benefits unrelated to the defense
chemicals within the plant that it uses to defend itself against fungal
diseases."

Officials at the National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases in
Bethesda, Md., were not immediately available for comment.

LOAD-DATE: April 19, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     July 14, 1988, Thursday, City Edition

Drought-relief effort bogged in Congress

SOURCE: Compiled from Wire Reports

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 437 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON



WASHINGTON - The congressional effort to write a drought-relief    package was
swept off track Wednesday by a flood of special-interest    amendments, as
President Reagan, about to embark on a visit to    America's farmlands, warned
he would not accept wholesale revisions of    current farm law.

     What began Monday as a bipartisan approach to helping farmers
disintegrated Wednesday into a noisy bazaar, with lobbyists lining the
hallways and lawmakers pitting home regions and favorite commodities    against
each other.

     House Agriculture Committee members churned out at least 53    amendments
to the basic draft bill; there were 31 in the Senate    Agriculture Committee,
with more likely.

     Sen. David H. Pryor, D-Ark., said the pressures were mounting along    with
reports of crop losses. "As the drought gets worse," he said,    "the intensity
of expectation increases."

     During a White House meeting Wednesday with American Farm Bureau
Federation officials, Reagan cautioned that he did not want Congress to    use
the drought as a pretext for revising current farm law.

     "Extraneous matters, such as rewriting the existing farm bill,    would
only deter our efforts to provide this much-needed aid," Reagan    said as he
repeated his support for "taking whatever actions are    necessary" to help
farmers through one of the century's worst    droughts.

     Reagan said he would insist that relief go "to those who need it    most,"
that farmers who purchased federal crop insurance be given the    same aid as
those who did not, that the relief bill not require farmers    to do
"unreasonable things" such as plowing under crops and that it    "must not bust
the budget."

         Meanwhile, agriculture experts insist that recent rain - up to    4
inches over some of the flatland region - won't help much of the    already
damaged corn crop. But the Reagan visit, they say, is a good    gesture on the
president's part and should help get federal aid for    farmers who have
substantial crop loss.

     Reagan is scheduled for stops in Moline, Ill., and neighboring
Davenport, Iowa, before he returns to Washington.

     "Even though it has rained, when the president looks at the crops,    he's
going to see a bad situation," said Steve Newman of the Illinois    Farm Bureau.
"As you know there's nothing like looking at the problem    square in the face
and making some decisions."



LOAD-DATE: November 11, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                            Times Publishing Company

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                          November 21, 1991, Thursday

U.S. pledges $ 1.4 billion aid package for Soviets

BYLINE: By T. Elaine Carey and Marcia Kunstel STAFF CORRESPONDENTSagricultural;
food; officials; soviet; organizations; negotiations

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; SECTION A; PAGE 01

LENGTH: 284 words


Washington - Amid growing concern about the possibility of hunger and civil
unrest in the Soviet Union this winter, the White House on Wednesday announced a
$ 1.4 billion aid agreement made with the 12 Soviet republics.

Only $ 164 million will be in the form of direct emergency aid, said
presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater. The remaining $ 1.25 billion will be
credits for the purchase of U.S. farm commodities.

Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan said at a briefing that all 12 Soviet
republics, through an inter-republic committee, agreed to be responsible for the
debt and will jointly decide the mix of commodities purchased and how much goes
to each republic.

The $ 1.25 billion will guarantee commercial bank loans for the purchase of U.S.
grain, and $ 165 million of free food will be provided, mainly through private
organizations.

The Agriculture Department is negotiating with the United Way, CARE, World
Vision Relief and the Seventh-day Adventist Church to distribute the food, a
department official told The New York Times.

A much smaller but still undetermined amount of money will be used to build a
model farm in the St. Petersburg area; to construct model wholesale food markets
near Moscow and Kiev; to send American agricultural extension workers; and to
provide credit guarantees for loans to private Soviet-American ventures in
Soviet food processing and distribution, Mr. Madigan said.

The aid plan is far below the $ 3.5 billion the Soviets requested from the
United States to get through the winter, but Mr. Madigan said more may be
available by spring. The $ 1.25 billion in credits will be freed in four
installments between now and April.

LOAD-DATE: February 10, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                    Copyright 1991 The Atlanta Constitution


                              774 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                 The Australian

                          September 22, 2010 Wednesday
                         1 - All-round Country Edition

IT'S MORE EXPENSIVE TO IGNORE POVERTY

BYLINE: ARCHIE LAW

SECTION: WORLD; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 629 words


Kevin Rudd has a chance to show true leadership to the world

TOMORROW,, Foreign Minister Kevin Rudd is representing Australia at a UN summit
in New York to review progress on the Millennium Development Goals for halving
extreme poverty and hunger by 2015.

For the first time since being ousted as prime minister, Rudd will rub shoulders
with the likes of US President Barack Obama, French President Nicolas Sarkozy
and German Chancellor Angela Merkel.

The summit will provide him with an opportunity to demonstrate true leadership
to the world.

Despite being a nation of generous individuals, Australia's record on foreign
aid leaves much to be desired. We languish towards the bottom of the league
table for the amount of foreign aid we provide as a percentage of our gross
national income.

Australia provides just three cents per $100 of income to overseas aid -- or
0.33 per cent of gross national income.

Under Rudd's prime ministership, Australia committed to increase this to 0.5 per
cent, but now the UN is calling on governments to contribute at least 0.7 per
cent of national income to reach the Millennium Development Goals by the target
date of 2015.

Many other developed countries have already reached this target. In fact, some
are contributing more than 1 per cent of national income to aid.

With nearly 4.5 million children dying each year before their fifth birthday,
largely because of malnutrition, the case for increasing our aid program is
obvious.

However, the problem of global poverty and hunger is not just a moral challenge.
For the financially minded, the good news is that addressing the problem is far
cheaper than ignoring it.

For example, let's take a closer look at Millennium Development Goal One, which
aims, among other things, to halve hunger by 2015. According to the UN, to reach
this goal, an extra $40 billion in aid is needed each year to support
agricultural and food security programs that increase self-sufficiency in food
production.

To put that in perspective, a recent ActionAid report found hunger was costing
poor nations more than $450 billion annually through reduced worker
productivity, poor health and lost education. That means fighting hunger is now
10 times cheaper than ignoring it.

It is thus particularly disappointing that the report found Australia was a
laggard in aid to agriculture -- contributing less than one-third of its fair
share.

In fact, underinvestment in agriculture globally over the past decade means 20
of the 28 poor nations measured are off track to halving hunger by 2015; 12 of
these are going backwards.

In sub-saharan Africa, just under a third of the population was chronically
malnourished last year. If trends continue, nearly 50 per cent of Africans could
be going without enough food by 2020.

And it isn't just the poorest, war-torn and disaster-struck countries of the
world that are not doing well. Some of the world's wealthier countries are
shockingly off track.

In India, one of the world's emerging global economic successes, one in five of
the population is hungry and close to half of all children are malnourished.

It's not all bad news, however. By investing more in local agriculture,
governments can feed their people and regenerate rural economies.

Recent research has pointed to the vital role that agriculture played in China's
initial take-off.

Agriculture was estimated to have contributed to poverty reduction four times
more than growth in the manufacturing or service sectors.

Meanwhile, many other countries have slashed hunger rates by increasing
investment in small-scale farmers -- in particular women farmers.

Safety nets are also important to help small farmers keep planing and harvesting
through tough times.

Archie Law is chief executive of anti-poverty agency Action Aid Australia

LOAD-DATE: September 21, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                    Messenger-Inquirer (Owensboro, Kentucky)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 5, 2010 Friday

BRIEF: Area farmers are eligible for federal drought disaster aid

BYLINE: Messenger-Inquirer, Owensboro, Ky.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 264 words


Nov. 05--U.S. Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack has granted Gov. Steve Beshear's
request for disaster assistance to Kentucky farm families in 91 counties --
including Daviess, Hancock, McLean, Muhlenberg and Ohio -- because of the severe
drought conditions that began Aug. 1.

"The current drought has critically impacted our agriculture sector, including
early harvests with reduced yields and loss of water supply for livestock," the
governor said.

A secretarial disaster designation provides farm families, meeting eligibility
requirements, the opportunity to be considered for disaster assistance from Farm
Service Agency, including emergency loans and Supplemental Revenue Assistance
Payments.

Farmers in eligible counties have until July 3 to apply for emergency loan
assistance. SURE Program applications for 2010 crop losses will be accepted in
2011, when the 2010 farm revenue data becomes available.

Information about USDA's Disaster Assistance Programs and the secretarial
disaster designation process are available at www.fsa.usda.gov by clicking on
the Disaster Assistance Program link in the left-hand column.

To see more of the Messenger-Inquirer, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.messenger-inquirer.com. Copyright (c) 2010, Messenger-Inquirer,
Owensboro, Ky. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more
information about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information
Services (MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com, e-mail
services@mctinfoservices.com, or call 866-280-5210 (outside the United States,
call +1 312-222-4544).

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                    April 6, 1990, FRIDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

STATE FARM-ADVOCACY OFFICIALS OFFER DIM VIEW BEFORE AID CONCERT

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 187 words


ST. LOUIS: U.S. agriculture remains in crisis, even though federal officials say
things are looking up down on the farm, the head of the Missouri Rural Crisis
Center said Thursday. Bill Christison, president of the farm group based in
Columbia, Mo., passed through St. Louis on his way to the Farm Aid concert this
weekend in Indianapolis. Christison, who lives near Chillicothe, Mo., was
accompanying six other farmers.  Roger Allison, the center's executive director,
said Farm Aid had donated $280,335 to Missouri farmers since 1985. Much of the
money provided food, payments for utility bills or propane fuel, Allison said.
Christison says the nation needs a farm policy that helps farmers and consumers,
not food corporations.

Thursday.  With him (from left) are farmer Al Reger from Newtown, Mo., and
activist Jim Carson of the People's Coalition of Missouri.

                              777 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                        Western Morning News (Plymouth)

                               September 15, 1999

Lessons we can learn from abroad

BYLINE: This Week Nick Brown Has Been Discussing With European Commission
Officials The Possibilities Of Emergency Aid For Britain'S Farmers. But As
Farming Editor Carol Trewin Reveals, Other Governments Seem Able To React To
Agricultural Crises With More Speed And Determination To Solve The Problems

SECTION: Supplement: Farming

LENGTH: 1405 words


While the farming industry staggers from one crisis to the next, the region's
farmers have been hoping for positive signals indicating where their future lies
and how they will arrive there. So far they have been disappointed.

Two major meetings between Agriculture Minister Nick Brown and the farming
unions, and between the Welsh Agriculture Secretary, Christine Gwyther, Northern
Ireland Minister Lord Dubs, and Scottish Parliament's Rural Affairs Minister
Ross Finnie have both ended inconclusively.

All farmers have as an indicator of how the Government is thinking is another
consultation document on the interpretation of the Agenda 2000 Common
Agricultural Policy reforms, the possibility of a cull ewe scheme and a review
of the burden of regulation.

Even though farming leaders had anticipated that CAP reform would be difficult
and painful, most would privately admit that they could not have forecast that
the industry's problems would have come, as Hamlet put it, in battalions rather
than as single spies.

What it desperately needs now is a feeling that the Government is batting on its
side, rather than in thrall to political ideals, largely dominated by the
Americans. (Think genetically modified foods, liberalised world markets and so
on.)

However a quick glance across the Atlantic and the English Channel reveals a
very different political approach to dealing with some of the problems created
by a world glut of some commodities - including milk, pork and lamb - and the
collapse of key markets in Russia and the Far East.

It is no wonder the French President, Jacques Chirac, famously said "non" at the
EU summit in Berlin last March, thus almost singlehandedly overturning the
radical CAP reform proposals, leaving the British, Danish and Swedish
delegations spluttering into their steins of beer.

The French both revere and fear their farmers. Unlike in Britain, the rural vote
is still a significant factor in French politics, and French farmers have never
been afraid to start protesting at the drop of a "chapeau". Only last week
tonnes of imported apples were unceremoniously dumped in the centre of Avignon,
and from Deauville to Marseilles farmers are staging a series of demonstrations
against the "injustice" of recently imposed American import tariffs on - among
other things - Roquefort cheese. Never mind that only 440 tonnes of Roquefort's
total annual production of 18,000 are exported to the USA.

So it would seem that despite their best intentions, few French politicians
choose to be seen supporting any political decisions that could give their
farmers any further encouragement to block roads and disrupt commerce.

It is no surprise to learn that struggling pig farmers have received 300 million
French francs in direct state aids to help them through their difficulties.
European Union officials have declared this to be an illegal subsidy, but
observers in France say the French Government has discovered a "long forgotten"
EU regulation to avoid repayment to Brussels. And to ensure the industry's
future, rather than allow it to go into free fall with the collapse of many
businesses, the government has forbidden any further expansion of the national
pig herd until the world market improves - having discovered that the number of
sows declared and the actual number farmed failed to tally.

The losses caused by the stringent requirement to cull entire cattle herds
following an outbreak of BSE would make British farmers weep, particularly with
cull cow values now around GBP 300. No problem in France. On average the
compensation paid for every potentially BSE-infected animal is between 12,000 -
13,000 French francs. The French government has also decided, independently of
Brussels, to maintain the calf processing aid scheme.

Unlike in Britain, where young farmers are struggling to get a foothold on the
farming ladder, or are so disenchanted with future prospects that they are
turning their back on the industry in droves, the French believe passionately in
keeping young blood coming into the industry.

So there are incentive schemes ranging from a 50% tax rebate in the first five
trading years, to reduced social security payments and subsidised loans - with
interest rates between two and 3.5% - of up to 940,000 Fr Fs for farm
improvements and modernisation.Then there is a wide selection of local authority
grants and incentives, again to encourage young entrants and certain types of
farming, depending on the region. For instance in Burgundy, newcomers can apply
for a 50,000 franc "mobility" grant, which is never repaid, if they have
travelled over 50 kilometres to start farming.

If French farmers benefit from positive support from their Government, the story
in the USA is even more remarkable. In the last year Britain's farmers have been
watching events across the Atlantic with a mixture of envy, admiration and
incredulity.

Following the 1996 Freedom to Farm bill, the US was held up in many quarters as
the model the UK should eventually emulate. Production quotas disappeared,
export tariffs were to be abolished, farmers paid a lump sum of money depending
on their size and enterprises, and left to get on with producing whatever
commodity they liked, to meet market demands and conditions.

Preparing for the World Trade Organisation talks, which begin in Seattle in
November, the Americans have been sending out a clear message - that they are
not to be messed with and that free trade, at world market prices, is where they
are going and that they intend to lead from the front.

So it is strange to hear, three years after the bill that was supposed to
liberalise American agriculture, that the US Senate is about to sign off $7.6
billion of "disaster relief", to add to previous state hand outs to the nation's
farmers, that include $200 million aids to pig producers, $20 million grants to
help seasonal and migrant farm workers, $337 million in emergency loans and $42
million for flood damage.

Despite US Agriculture Secretary, Dan Glickman's view that this aid does not
compromise the country's position in the forthcoming WTO round because it is
"disaster relief" rather than direct aid payments, observers elsewhere are
asking "what price the Freedom to Farm bill now?"

The Americans' recent actions over the so-called beef wars, imposing 100% import
tariffs on selected European products, including Roquefort cheese, were a clear
indicator of the US mood where trade affecting their products is concerned. This
is seen as mere sabre rattling warming up for the bigger issues between the USA
and the Europeans when the EU moratorium on the bovine growth hormone BST runs
out at the end of this year, and as more GM crops are grown. The US clearly will
not be messed with if their exports are threatened.

So it was surprising - or was it - to hear that the US government recently
slapped 100% import tariffs on Australian and New Zealand lamb. Why? To protect
domestic production which is apparently in a slump. The Aussies and the Kiwis,
two of the USA's partner countries in the so-called Cairns Group which has been
formed to give a coherent voice in the WTO talks, are furious.

Back on this side of the Atlantic, farmers say this confirms their view that the
US Government is not to be trusted and is clearly happy to change the rules when
it suits its own circumstances. Dan Glickman may be hawkish in public when
setting out the country's position for future negotiations, but on the domestic
scene transmogrifies into a dove.

What is clear is that anything is possible, if the political will is there, to
keep farmers farming - but it requires a willingness to be adaptable, or even
imaginative with the terms used to describe aid packages. While acknowledging
that a short-term financial aid package would keep a few businesses from
bankruptcy, most British farmers know that a small sticking plaster will not
stop the lifeblood haemorrhaging from the industry.

What they want is a long term structure, a structure that is determined by a
positive and supportive political attitude rather than one that appears to be in
permanent opposition. And although the "level playing field" is a concept many
farmers, and indeed the British Government, believe in, it is clear that even
that is only as level as individual nations wish it to be. Sadly the UK
Government still seems a long way from achieving either.

LOAD-DATE: September 20, 1999

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: NEW FREEDOM: For farmers in the USA production quotas have disappeared
and they are free to produce whatever they like to meet market demand French
farmers unload apples into the street in protest against US sanctions on French
products Tractors and trailers block a French road as farmers demonstrate
against negotiations in Brussels to reform the European CAP policy Tonnes of
fruit and vegetables lie on the streets of Aix en Provence in southern France -
the farmers' method of demonstrating their claim that supermarkets chains were
crushing their profits

                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                     FEBRUARY 29, 1996 Thursday SF EDITION

HOUSE NARROWLY REJECTS PROPOSALS TO END SUGAR AND PEANUT SUBSIDIES < WORK BEGAN
ON THE REFORM OF FARM POLICIES ADOPTED< DURING THE DEPRESSION. A FINAL VOTE IS
LIKELY TODAY.

BYLINE: Robert Greene, ASSOCIATED PRESS, This article contains information from
Reuters.

SECTION: NATIONAL; Pg. A04

LENGTH: 575 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Southerners and their farm-state allies narrowly defeated moves yesterday to
kill federal sugar and peanut subsidy programs as they began work on a bill that
would make the greatest change in farm policy in 60 years.

After hearing threats that sugar from Cuba might find its way to U.S. shores,
the House voted 217-208 to continue quotas on sugar imports and maintain price
supports for domestically grown cane and beet sugar.

By a similar 212-209 margin, it voted to continue a Depression-era peanut
program that limits who can grow the crop and, according to foes, guarantees
producers a price that is twice the world market price.

The General Accounting Office, a congressional watchdog agency, estimates that
the sugar program inflates what Americans pay for food by $1.4 billion and says
the peanut program adds $500 million to their shopping bills.

The votes were the first floor skirmishes as the House began acting on a major
overhaul of farm programs that would end decades-old subsidies for corn, cotton,
wheat and other major crops. A final vote on the bill is expected today.

The measure ends the system of near limitless spending for major crop subsidies
accompanied by government controls on planting. To ease the switch and its
impact on land values, the bill guarantees farmers fixed, declining payments
over seven years independent of crop prices.

Once the House bill is passed, House and Senate negotiators must work out
differences. The Senate passed its version on Feb. 7.

Core proposals are the same for both bills because they were passed by Congress
in the balanced-budget legislation that President Clinton vetoed last year.
Since then, the Senate added conservation, nutrition, rural development and
other segments that raised the cost of the bill but were needed to win
Democratic support.

Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman has recommended a veto in part because the
bill ends the old safety net that pays farmers when crop prices fall but not
when prices rise.

MEDICAID AND WELFARE. The White House could not accept bipartisan Medicaid and
welfare reform proposals crafted by U.S. governors in their current form, Health
Secretary Donna E. Shalala said yesterday.

Laying out the administration's position in detail for the first time, Shalala
told the Senate Finance Committee the administration urged a number of major
changes to the plans, adopted unanimously by the governors Feb. 6.

But she said if Congress and the administration worked on a bipartisan basis to
strengthen protections for children, guarantee benefits to the poor, and require
states to put up more of their own money, a broad compromise was possible.

On welfare, the administration believes the governors' proposal giving states
control of welfare and limiting aid to five years does not provide enough
protections for children and may allow states to cut their own welfare spending.

Shalala wants Congress to provide vouchers to aid children whose parents lose
benefits, require states to spend 100 percent of what they spent on welfare in
1994 in order to tap into a federal emergency fund, provide extra federal aid in
case of recession, and eliminate a provision in the governors' plan letting
states take over foster care programs.

Republican leaders want to attach the governors' proposals to a must-pass bill
to increase the nation's $4.9 trillion debt limit, to be debated early next
month.

LOAD-DATE: October 28, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              The Washington Post

                     October 4, 1991, Friday, Final Edition

Soviet Economic Treaty Called 'Vital' for Aid;
U.S. Envoy Urges Republics to Sign Accord

Margaret Shapiro, Washington Post Foreign Service

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A19

LENGTH: 816 words

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 3, 1991


U.S. Ambassador Robert Strauss said today that an economic accord among
republics of the Soviet Union is "vital" to persuade Western countries to
provide the large infusion of aid that Soviet officials say they need to make it
through the winter.

U.S. Agriculture Secretary Edward Madigan, on tour here to assess the food
situation, said Washington also wants detailed explanations of actual economic
needs to support a Soviet request for $ 10.2 billion in assistance.

Soviet leaders here no longer are predicting famine this winter, Madigan said,
but they stress that without significant aid, severe shortages will occur,
leading to even greater social and political instability as the country
continues to unravel.

New Soviet statistics released today confirm that the harvest is below past
years, in part because of poor planning, poor weather and lack of transportation
or fuel, the Tass news agency reported. It said 151.7 million tons of grain had
been harvested throughout the country, in contrast to 211.5 million tons last
year, raising the possibility of bread shortages soon. The sugar beet, cotton
and potato harvests also are below expectations, Tass reported.

Strauss said in an interview that the new economic accord approved in principle
by a majority of Soviet republics, but not yet signed by most of them, is "the
most significant thing that could happen for the Soviet economy." A failure to
sign it in the coming days, he said, would be "a terrible setback" as leaders of
the Group of Seven leading industrialized democracies prepare to meet in Bangkok
to decide how much aid to give this moribund economy.

"It's not for us to say what should or shouldn't be in it," Strauss said, "but
signing an economic treaty is . . . going to have a significant impact on the
[Group of Seven] when they meet in Bangkok. It is very, very vital."

On Tuesday, 12 republics agreed in principle to a new economic confederation, or
commonwealth, to replace the centralized economic structure of the Soviet Union.

The agreement left many important issues to be worked out later, however, and it
is far from clear how such a confederation would work, or even whether the
legislatures of the various republics will go along with the plan. So far only
Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and Byelorussia have formally adopted it.

Madigan said the chaotic economic situation has been evident as U.S. officials
try to pin down Soviet officials on details of the $ 10.2 billion in aid that
Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev told officials of Europe's Economic Community
this week that his country needs.

That amount "is not a figure that we have yet been able to make coincide with
what we know," Madigan said after meetings with top Soviet agriculture and
economic officials.

The agriculture secretary said Soviet officials told him that, in addition to
problems with the wheat harvest, they expect shortages of 1.5 million tons of
meat, 5.7 million tons of milk and 3.7 billion eggs this winter. But, he said,
"They do not expect there will be something as dramatic as famine. There will be
shortages that could result in some social unrest."

The chaotic situation in the country was also apparent in political matters
today. Gorbachev announced a delay in the start of the new Supreme Soviet
legislature because many republics have either not yet decided to participate or
have not selected delegations. The session was supposed to begin Oct. 8 but now
is slated to open Oct. 21.

Splits among the republics over military matters were also apparent today. The
Ukrainian defense minister said his republic needs armed forces "as a guarantor
of democracy and independence," and the Byelorussian prime minister suggested
that his republic might not be willing to give up the nuclear weapons stationed
on its territory.

"We do not want nuclear weapons," Prime Minister Vyacheslav Kebic said. "But
let's be honest and recognize that the NATO alliance still exists, and it does
possess armed forces -- which means that the first line of defense in Western
countries' path is in Byelorussia and the Ukraine."

In the Ukraine, Defense Minister Vladimir Grinev said his republic too should
keep its nuclear weapons: "I don't especially like what [Russian President]
Boris Yeltsin said, that Russia would grab all the nuclear weapons. That causes
tension."

The Reuter news agency reported from Moscow:

Rebel national guardsmen started pulling out of the capital of Soviet Georgia
today after a month of armed confrontation with supporters of President Zviad
Gamsakhurdia.

The withdrawal seemed to play into the hands of Gamsakhurdia, who has maintained
that the opposition in the southern republic was trying to mount a coup. But
rebel commander Tengiz Kitovani, who says he has 7,000 men under his command,
told a crowd of about 1,500 people that the retreat was just a change of
tactics.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

GRAPHIC: PHOTO, U.S. AMBASSADOR ROBERT STRAUSS.

TYPE: NATIONAL NEWS, FOREIGN NEWS

                       Copyright 1991 The Washington Post


                              781 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                    March 11, 1999, Thursday, Final Edition

WASHINGTON IN BRIEF

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A05; WASHINGTON IN BRIEF

LENGTH: 438 words


A New Role for Criminal Division?

The public interest lobby group Common Cause yesterday proposed shifting
responsibility for investigating high-level government corruption from
independent counsels to the Justice Department's criminal division, which would
get new powers.

The group opposed letting the independent counsel law expire on June 30 without
enacting new procedures to ensure thorough investigations of top federal
officials suspected of misconduct. To do so, it said in a letter to the Senate
Governmental Affairs Committee, would leave investigations of the president and
his administration open to public suspicion.

Common Cause proposed giving the assistant attorney general in charge of the
criminal division power to investigate allegations of crimes by high-level
officials. That official's decisions could not be overruled by more senior
Justice Department officials unless the reasons were spelled out in a public
memorandum.

GOP to 'Explore' Clinton's Tax Plans

Congressional Republicans yesterday signaled a willingness to consider President
Clinton's proposals to close corporate tax shelters, but they derided most of
the president's $ 89.7 billion in net tax increases.

House Ways and Means Committee Chairman Bill Archer (R-Tex.) told Treasury
Department officials at a hearing that the GOP will "explore" the 11 proposals,
which would raise an estimated $ 11.7 billion in revenue over the next 10 years.

The Ways and Means panel was not so receptive to 75 other revenue-raising
proposals included in Clinton's budget for fiscal 2000.

Farmers Must Wait Until June for Aid

Farmers counting on $ 2 billion in congressionally approved disaster aid will
have to wait until June to get it, according to Agriculture Secretary Dan
Glickman.

In a letter to Senate Agriculture Committee Chairman Richard G. Lugar (R-Ind.)
and House Agriculture Committee Chairman Larry Combest (R-Tex.), Glickman said
administering the aid is "far more complex than past natural disaster assistance
programs."

And he said the department is inundated with aid disbursements during this
tumultuous farm year, including assistance packages of $ 50 million for hog
farmers and $ 200 million for dairy farmers.

Combest said the delay was "unacceptable."

Many in Congress have complained that USDA is moving too slowly in administering
aid to farmers. Congress approved the money as part of a $ 6 billion emergency
package late last year as commodity prices were in a free fall. Prices have done
little to rebound since then, making some members of Congress angry at the slow
dispersal process.

                              784 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         The Evening Sun (Hanover, PA)

                            April 27, 2002 Saturday

John Heilman, Falls Church, Va.

SECTION: OBITUARIES

LENGTH: 233 words


John Heilman, 83, of Falls Church, Va., and formerly of Hanover, died April 11,
2002. He was the husband of Margara Heilman, his wife of 25 years.

Born July 8, 1918, in Hanover, he was the son of the late Harry F. Heilman and
Anna Mae Peterman Heilman.

He was a graduate of Hanover High School's class of 1935. After graduating from
Penn State College in 1939, where he studied agricultural engineering, economics
and rural sociology, he joined the U.S. Department of Agriculture. There, he
held various positions with the Farmers Home Administration, and was later
appointed Chief of Farm Management/Agricultural Economics in Washington.

He worked in Venezuela for the American International Association from 1948 to
1959, and for the Venezuelan government on several industrial and agricultural
projects until he was named deputy regional director for Latin America with the
Agency for International Development [AID]. He held several managerial positions
with AID in Korea [1960-1962], Pakistan [1962-1964] and Washington.

In 1964, he was named head of the economic section of the U.S. Embassy [with the
rank of minister] and director of USAID in Argentina; and in 1974, he was
appointed associate director in Vietnam.

Surviving also are a daughter, Ellen Shatzer of Laurel, Md.; a sister, Julia J.
Heilman of Hanover; three grandchildren and four great-grandchildren.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              785 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Lima News (Ohio)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 1, 2011 Thursday

Grant to aid with Hardin County plan

BYLINE: Bart Mills, The Lima News, Ohio

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 350 words


Sept. 01--KENTON -- A grant from the U.S. Department of Agriculture could help
one of the state's hardest hit counties climb out of an economic rut.

Officials for Ohio's Rural Community Assistance Program and the USDA Rural
Development office were in Kenton Thursday to announce a $175,105 grant that
will be split between Hardin, Jefferson and Morgan counties. The money will help
the communities develop long-range strategic plans as a way to deal with the
decades of job loss and economic deficiencies they have been dealing with.

John Hohn, director of Economic Development for the Hardin County Chamber and
Business Alliance, said the money will help them move ahead with the planning.

"CEDS -- which stands for Comprehensive Economic Development Strategy -- is
designed to bring together the public and private sectors in the creation of an
economic road map to establish goals and objectives." Hohn said.

The Hardin County chamber partnered up for the grant with the WSOS Community
Action Commission representing Wood, Seneca, Ottawa and Sandusky counties. The
funds will help them draft a road map for developing some much-needed programs
for the community, said Barb Wingfield, director of the Hardin County Chamber.

"These strategic planning tools are much needed, and with the help of WSOS, many
projects we've dreamed and talked about for several years finally will become a
reality," Wingfield said.

The three counties were chosen for the grant because they are among the hardest
hit by Ohio's economic troubles.

Hardin County has experienced economic distress through the years beginning in
the mid-1970s when one of the largest employers began layoffs. The county has
never fully recovered from this loss, and unemployment in Hardin County in
October was measured at nearly 11 percent, representing 1,600 people out of
work, out of a labor force of 15,000. Average unemployment in 2009 was 12
percent, significantly higher than the Ohio average of 10.2 percent.

www.limaohio.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                     The Post-Star (Glens Falls, New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            December 14, 2009 Monday

Farm subsidies smaller for Washington County

BYLINE: Nick Reisman, The Post-Star, Glens Falls, N.Y.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 664 words


Dec. 14--EASTON -- Wisps of white steam escaped from the young heifers at Sean
and Sandy Quinn's farm in Easton.

As people passed by on a cold Friday morning, the cattle lifted their heads from
the feed they were munching on moments before, their black eyes bulging in
surprise.

The Quinns' farm received about $32,000 in direct payments from the U.S.
Department of Agriculture, according to a database compiled by the Washington,
D.C.-based Environmental Working Group.

The money was the most given to any farm in Washington County in 2007, the last
available year of the data.

But the amount pales in comparison to what farms in other parts of the state --
mostly western New York near the Finger Lakes region -- receive in aid from the
federal government.

Washington County is one of the largest dairy-producing counties in state,
ranking sixth overall. But in terms of federal aid and support in the form of
direct payments, the county ranked 16th within New York, according to USDA data.

Counties like Cayuga, Livingston and Ontario -- where farms tend to be fewer in
number but larger in scale than in Washington County -- benefited the most from
the money.

Cayuga in western New York has nearly the same amount of farms as Washington
County but received $1.8 million in direct aid, making it the largest recipient
of federal money in the state.

Livingston County, which has 801 farms, 44 fewer than Washington County,
received $1.7 million, according to the agriculture census.

Part of what is at issue is that many of these farms and counties benefit from
being close to the Finger Lakes, said Sandy Buxton, a business educator at the
Washington County Cornell Cooperative Extension.

"That's identified as a watershed and as a key location," Buxton said, adding
that some of the payments are awarded for efforts to mitigate environmental
runoff.

Farmers are essentially told not to use certain areas due to the environmental
hazards and impacts of agriculture.

"It's basically conservation reserve money to not farm ground or maintain it for
filter fields or preserve habitat," she said.

At the same time, dairy payments alone aren't as generous when compared to
diversified farming.

"If dairy is your primary thing, you're not going rise that high on the list,"
Buxton said. "If you have a more mixed agriculture community doing some grain
and doing some other types of crops, that may receive some level of substitute
payment, or be considered a high risk location."

U.S. Rep. Scott Murphy, D-Glens Falls, however, cautioned that not all direct
payments are the same.

"I think looking at it in the aggregate, you probably miss a lot of the
nuances," Murphy said in a phone interview last week.

Many of the subsidy programs vary in nature and different farms vary in need, he
said.

"That's the result of a lot of different programs," Murphy said. "I haven't
heard anybody complaining about this aggregate issue."

Murphy added that right now, he and other representatives of agriculture-reliant
districts are focused on helping the flagging dairy industry, which continues to
deal with low wholesale prices. Sean Quinn, the Easton farmer, said he takes the
funding in stride.

"Sometimes it seems very fair and sometimes it seems so far-fetched and out of
whack," he said.

Quinn prefers allowing the free market to sort out the travails of the
agriculture industry, and said the political support -- from lawmakers to the
local farm bureau -- the area receives is excellent.

"If you're having trouble, they throw you some help," Quinn said. "We have
excellent representation in this area."

To see more of The Post-Star, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.poststar.com Copyright (c) 2009, The Post-Star, Glens Falls, N.Y.

tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                              787 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        The Pueblo Chieftain (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              May 9, 2013 Thursday

Five counties eligible for federal aid

BYLINE: Chris Woodka, The Pueblo Chieftain, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 268 words


May 09--Five Southern Colorado counties received federal drought designation
Wednesday.

Alamosa, Conejos, Costilla, Huerfano and Las Animas counties received the
designation from Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack, according to a letter to
Gov.

John Hickenlooper. The counties will be added to other counties on the Eastern
Plains that already have had drought declarations.

The designation allows farmers to apply for emergency loans and other assistance
from the Farm Service Agency. Colorado's U.S. senators hailed the decision.
"Colorado and the West are experiencing one of the most severe droughts on
record. This ongoing drought threatens farm jobs and our agricultural economy
throughout the state," said Sen. Mark Udall, D-Colo. "We need to act -- and soon
-- on a new Farm Bill that strengthens farmers' and ranchers' hands as they
confront this ongoing drought."

"While areas of Colorado received late-season snow that brought some much-needed
moisture to our state, the drought over the past several years has tortured
crops and pastures around the state -- and dry conditions continue to persist in
many counties," said Sen. Michael Bennet, DColo. "These disaster designations
will provide critical assistance to farmers and ranchers to help offset their
losses due to the recent drought."

Snowpack in the Rio Grande and Arkansas River basins remains well below peak
levels and irrigated farms typically use 85 percent of the water.
cwoodka@chieftain.com

___ (c)2013 The Pueblo Chieftain (Pueblo, Colo.) Visit The Pueblo Chieftain
(Pueblo, Colo.) at www.chieftain.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2013

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20130509-PB-Five-counties-eligible-for-federal-aid-0509-20130509

                              788 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                            October 29, 1999, Friday

US red meat trade expected to run big trade deficit

BYLINE: BY RICHARD LAWRENCE

SECTION: SPECIAL REPORT; Pg. 11

LENGTH: 858 words


The United States is moving towards a substantial deficit in red meat trade next
year, at least in tonnage terms, agriculture analysts forecast.

U.S. beef, veal and pork exports will decline about 4 percent to 5 percent in
volume from record 1999 levels, according to latest U.S. Agriculture Department
estimates. Meanwhile, beef imports are expected to rise sharply, perhaps by 7.5
percent, to a new all-time high as pork imports fall slightly.

This year, analysts estimate, the United States will export about one ton of
beef, veal and pork for every ton it imports. But not so next year, they
predict. Imports of these meats, expected to total about 1.73 million tons, will
outpace exports by more than 150,000 tons, the first substantial deficit since
the mid-l990s. Nonetheless, they note, exports will remain at close to record
levels.

Moreover, their estimates may understate U.S. pork and beef export prospects,
since they do not factor in possibly large new U.S. food aid shipments to
Russia.

Also helping mitigate the latest export forecast is the fact that traders should
earn more for every ton they sell, given that U.S. prices are expected to rise.

Prices lie behind much of the Agriculture Department's trade forecast. As U. S.
beef supplies tighten and prices increase, some consumers may turn from beef to
cheaper meats, cutting back beef exports. At the same time, higher U. S. prices
may attract more imports.

A major factor in this year's strong export showing is the East Asian economic
recovery. Japan alone buys about one-half of all U.S. beef, veal and pork sold
abroad. Falling trade barriers are helping export sales. And in the months
ahead, a possible depreciation of the U.S. dollar, which many economists expect,
would help make U.S. meat more competitive.

The importance of exports for U.S. meat producers was underlined by a recent
National Pork Producers Council report showing that U.S. pork exports have risen
80 percent in value since 1995. The industry, it said, soon expects to eclipse
Denmark as the world's No. 1 pork exporter.

Exports are also becoming much more vital to U.S. beef producers. About 8
percent of U.S. beef output now goes for export, compared to 1.5 percent in
1985, notes Chuck Lambert, chief economist for the Denver-headquartered National
Cattlemen's Beef Association.

Both the Cattlemen's Beef Association and the Des Moines-based Pork Council are
among the U.S. agricultural community's strongest advocates of a new round of
World Trade Organization market access negotiations. They seek to further
reduce, if not eliminate, foreign tariffs, import quotas and subsidies, to clear
the way for a greatly expanded meat trade.

U.S. pork is sold to 115 countries, many of them granting only minimal market
access, while other countries completely bar pork, the pork council said. Even
sales to Japan, by far the biggest foreign buyer of U.S. pork, could ""explode''
if Japan opened its market wider, the council contends.

The cattlemen's association foresees especially large export gains if the
European Union could be persuaded to ""unlock'' its beef market and China joins
the WTO, sharply paring its tariffs and taking other trade liberalizing steps.

For more immediate help, beef and pork producers are pressing the Clinton
administration to provide more food aid to cash-starved Russia.

This year the Agriculture Department is financing exports of 50,000 tons of U.S.
pork and about the same amount of beef for Russia. Producers now urge a second
food aid package of up to 150,000 tons of pork, which, they argue, could help
prevent a repeat of last year's disastrous decline in hog prices. Beef producers
hope that any new aid package would include at least as much beef, in particular
variety meats, as was provided this year.

In general, however, pork exports next year look relatively flat, given the
Agriculture Department forecast of a 5 percent drop in tonnage next year to
544,000 tons. But if the government steps up its food aid to Russia, total
exports might rise slightly, analysts say.

Sales to Japan and Mexico, the two largest foreign markets, are expected to stay
at this year's levels. Exports to South Korea, another big market, may keep
rising, though more slowly than this year's exceptionally torrid pace. Sales to
Taiwan and Hong Kong also look promising. Large European Union export subsidies
may limit U.S. gains, however.

U.S. imports of pork, up almost 20 percent this year, may fall about 3 percent
next year, Agriculture Department analysts say. Canada, which supplies over half
of all U.S. pork imports, may concentrate more next year on other markets,
particularly Asia.

Private analysts appear more optimistic than Agriculture Department forecasters
about the beef industry's export prospects. Next year, said Lambert of the beef
association, exports will probably rise, but at a slower pace than this year.
(Through August, they were up about 8 percent in value from a year earlier.)
Sales to Japan will keep growing, he said, especially if, as anticipated,
Japan's economy improves and the yen stays strong.

LOAD-DATE: October 29, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo - Cattle grazing in a field in Kansas. U.S. exports of beef are
expected to decline next year while imports will grow, widening the trade
deficit in this sector.;

                         The Age (Melbourne, Australia)

                           November 12, 1998 Thursday
                                  Late Edition

Wheat board warns US on food aid;
Commodities

BYLINE: BEN MITCHELL: Regional Reporter

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 253 words


The chairman of the Australian Wheat Board, Mr Trevor Flugge, has cautioned the
United States Government not to use its surplus wheat as food aid for Indonesia.

Mr Flugge told the Rural Press Club yesterday that any plans to use wheat in
food aid would undermine Australia's multi-million-dollar trade with Indonesia
and trigger a strong response from the AWB.

Mr Flugge said the AWB expected the wheat trade with Indonesia to return to
normal within 12 months.

Mr Flugge also urged the Agriculture Minister, Mr Mark Vaile, to sign off on the
AWB's new constitution as soon as possible.

A new constitution is needed before the AWB can be privatised in July under the
timetable established in legislation that has already passed through Federal
Parliament.

The new grower-controlled company has to have in place a multi-billion-dollar
borrowing program to fund next year's harvest payments.

The new constitution has been the source of division within the industry, with
many growers reluctant to make the AWB fully commercial.

Many growers believe they will lose control of AWB policy after the $550million
privatisation.

Mr Flugge moved to allay their fears yesterday, saying that all wheat producers
would have a veto over what happened.

Mr Flugge also moved to mollify the Grains Council of Australia, which wants a
$150million cap on the amount of capital the AWB can buy outside its normal
business operations once it is privately owned.

He said the AWB would have a conservative acquisition program after it was
privatised.

LOAD-DATE: July 25, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

aid would trigger a strong response from the AWB.

                              794 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            January 24, 1997 Friday

BYLINE: John MacDonald

LENGTH: 389 words


FARGO -- Senators from North Dakota and South Dakota urged the federal
Agriculture Department Thursday to extend emergency aid to ranchers hit hard by
a recent rash of blizzards. And Sen. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., said he is upset the
USDA reneged on a promise to provide long-term aid to the ranchers as well.

Across the Plains, tens of thousands of cattle are dead or in danger of dying
because of the weather. Some have frozen in recent blizzards, while others
starved because they cannot find feed, or because their snowed-in owners have
been unable to get it to them. The USDA approved an emergency program last week
to help farmers and ranchers who are having difficulty feeding their animals
because of blizzards. It includes cash reimbursements to cover feed costs, cash
assistance for snow removal and direct grain donations from the Commodity Credit
Corp. Dorgan said while the aid is ""welcome and helpful,'' the feed assistance
is set to expire Saturday. Dorgan and Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D., met Thursday
afternoon with USDA officials to request that the expiration date be extended
indefinitely and that the reimbursements be expanded to cover other hardships
ranchers may encounter from the storms. ""It is clear to us that this crisis in
North Dakota as a result of the subsequent winter storms is going to be a crisis
that is going to last for quite some time,'' Dorgan said. For that reason, he
said the aid should be extended as well. The North Dakota office of the federal
Farm Service Agency has received reports of nearly 13,000 cattle deaths in the
state so far this winter. The number is expected to be even higher in South
Dakota. Dorgan said he is confident the USDA will consider the request and he
hopes to have an answer by today. But at the same time, Dorgan said he is upset
at the agency for failing to keep a promise to provide long-term aid to the
ranchers. The USDA, according to Dorgan, agreed to a program in which it would
share the cost of buying animal feed in future months for ranchers who need it
because of the storms. ""They announced a program that I learned today they are
not providing,'' Dorgan said. USDA officials told him they were unaware at the
time that rules prevent the agency from issuing such a program unless farmers
suffered at least 40 percent loss of their hay or feed grain crop.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


       Copyright 1997 The Bismarck Tribune, a division of Lee Enterprises
                              All Rights Reserved


                              795 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                The Toronto Star

                   November 25, 1993, Thursday, METRO EDITION

High anxiety can boost men's blood pressure

SECTION: LIFE; Pg. C1

LENGTH: 355 words


   CHICAGO (Medical Tribune) - High anxiety can lead to high blood pressure in
men, according to a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association.
Middle-aged men who feel very tense and anxious are twice as likely to develop
high blood pressure in the next 20 years as those who are calm, the study found.

The results suggest doctors should begin treating middle- aged men who are very
anxious with relaxation training, biofeedback and other psychological therapies
aimed at preventing the development of high blood pressure, wrote the main
author of the study, Dr. Jerome Markovitz of the University of Alabama in
Birmingham.

Fido's fleas may be

cause of allergy

Some people are allergic to other people's cats and dogs but not their own,
creating a long-standing medical puzzle that may now be solved, the Chicago
Tribune reports. People who sneeze and wheeze around other people's pets may be
allergic to the pets' fleas and not animal dander, says entomologist Richard
Brenner of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. Researchers found proteins in
flea feces, shells, skin and other debris can cause allergic reactions.

Estrogen cuts risk

of heart disease

Besides easing menopausal symptoms, estrogen replacement therapy may reduce
women's risk of heart disease and stroke, according to a study of nearly 3,000
women aged 65 years and older. "These findings suggest that postmenopausal
estrogen use may be associated with lower risk of cardiovascular disease in
women well into the eighth decade of life," Dr. Teri Manolio of the U.S.
National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute says in the Chicago Tribune.

AIDS vaccine

tests are delayed

Plans to test possible AIDS vaccines in large numbers of U.S. volunteers will be
delayed at least until the end of 1994, because of deeply disappointing results
in recent small-scale tests, New York Newsday reports. The potential vaccines
had seemed to work against special strains of the AIDS virus cultivated in the
laboratory. But in tests, all but one of the vaccines failed to stimulate immune
responses against real-life strains of the virus.

LOAD-DATE: May 12, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              796 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                             The Guardian (London)

                                August 23, 1989

India angry over US 'cancer corn'

BYLINE: By MARTIN WALKER in Washington

LENGTH: 325 words


INDIA has complained to the US Department of Agriculture that corn delivered
under a US food aid programme has been contaminated with a carcinogenic fungus,
aflatoxin.

The fungus has proliferated in the drought that has gripped the Mid-west corn
belt for the last two years, and has now spread to Texas.


Federal inspectors have already confirmed that so far this year they have
blocked the export of four million bushels of US corn infected with aflatoxin,
but varying levels of the fungus have been detected in 24 million bushels.

The shipment to India was checked and approved when it left the US in June. It
appears that the fungus, which is not easy to detect, may have developed on the
journey. The aflatoxin was discovered in a 100,000-tonne shipment loaded in
Seattle and New Orleans, which are at opposite ends of the US.

Corn is the mainstay of the US food aid programme, and the contamination batters
the image of generosity the US tries to win through its aid. The detection of
aflatoxin in corn sent for a school meals project in Guatemala earlier this year
has been the target of propaganda by anti-government guerrillas.

The growing international alarm over aflatoxin is beginning to threaten
America's food exports, its most valuable single export industry.

Mexico has begun strict border checks to monitor US corn imports, and the
discovery of aflatoxin on corn being loaded onto ships bound for Spain, Saudi
Arabia, and Japan has raised the alarm among US customers worldwide.

Traditionally, corn has only been checked at seaports when export contracts
require that each cargo be checked for moisture and foreign matter.

Mexico established its own border controls when state officials in Texas sealed
silos and elevators to prevent locally-grown corn from being sent to food
processing plants after it was found to contain 'many times the level of
aflatoxin considered safe for consumption.'

LOAD-DATE: June 13, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1989 Guardian Newspapers Limited

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                            August 24, 2006 Thursday
                                  City Edition

Henry asks Bush for agriculture aid ;
State farmers and ranchers would get help for drought

BYLINE: Michael McNutt, Capitol Bureau

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 5A

LENGTH: 414 words


Gov. Brad Henry is asking President Bush to push for reauthorizing two programs
in which state farmers and ranchers would be partially reimbursed for losses
caused by the drought.

"Oklahoma is facing its most serious drought in history," Henry wrote in a
letter to Bush and U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns.

Henry wants the Agriculture Department's crop disaster and livestock assistance
programs activated.

"Despite the recent rain in parts of the state, the drought has taken a massive
toll on Oklahoma farms and ranches. Our producers are in desperate need of help
during this difficult period," the governor wrote.

Jim Reese, state executive director for the Agriculture Department's Farm
Service Agency in Stillwater, said the programs would provide aid to partially
compensate for losses.

"It's not just line up and get money, you have to prove that you had a loss and
we have to be able to document it, and then we pay a reduced percentage," Reese
said.

Farmers and ranchers would not have to pay back the money, he said.

"It doesn't cover the whole loss," Reese said. "In the past ... if you have 100
percent loss, you might get compensated for somewhere between 30 to 40 percent
of the loss. If you lose the whole crop, it might give you some assistance to
put your next crop back in or in the case of cattle producers if they don't have
any grass it would allow them to be compensated for hay or feed that they were
forced to buy."

Wheat farmer Myron Bradt of Alva said the programs would help.

"We had a pretty shy wheat crop this year in the state of Oklahoma, lots of
abandoned acres that never made it to harvest that were intended for harvest,"
he said. "The problem was if you drilled early enough and got wheat pasture and
you put cattle on your wheat, there just wasn't enough moisture to support both
cattle and the wheat crop."

Previous aid was approved Reese said Congress granted the crop disaster and
livestock assistance programs in 2005 for state farmers who suffered losses
during 2003 and 2004 and also approved the programs in 2003 for losses during
2001 and 2002.

"It's not like it's a program sitting out there that we can access anytime," he
said. "It has to be passed by Congress."

Because of the drought, the state has received three natural disaster
declarations dating to Jan. 1, 2005. The designations allow state producers to
be considered for low interest loans from the Farm Service Agency.

"I'm not sure farmers need more debt," Bradt said.

LOAD-DATE: August 25, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              800 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                           February 02, 2001, Friday

State cuts off food bank's supplies

SECTION: PASCO TIMES; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 314 words

DATELINE: DADE CITY



(ran PC edition)

Officials have no investigation or evidence of wrongdoing against the Circle of
Seven Ministries, they just want questions answered.

A state agency said Thursday it has suspended a food bank's supply of government
food - although the state has made no allegations of wrongdoing - until an agent
can discuss the operation with its leaders.

Gloria Van Treese of the state Department of Agriculture's Bureau of Food
Distribution said the state has filed no complaints and made no findings against
the Circle of Seven Ministries' food bank and has not been investigating it. The
state suspended the food supply after a newspaper reporter called the Department
of Agriculture with questions about the ministry, she said.

Van Treese said the state must obey federal rules governing distribution of food
to the needy. If anyone complains about a food bank, that bank's leaders are
questioned so the state doesn't risk losing federal funds.

"If we just need to go in there and educate them, then we can do that," she
said.

The U.S. government supplies food to regional distribution centers. In turn,
those centers supply food to local groups, Van Treese said.

The rules require food banks to ask recipients if they qualify for government
aid, Van Treese said.

Food centers also can't require payment or request donations from recipients,
Van Treese said.

Pastor Betsy Holt said Thursday her ministry will be scrambling to come up with
about $ 400 for food boxes given to 60 to 70 needy families.

Holt said there is a donation box but no one has been pressured to give.

She said the food bank is run correctly and she plans to cooperate with the
state to renew the food supply.

"My motto is you never give up and you never give in when you're serving the
Lord," she said.

Van Treese said she expects an agent will meet with the ministry next week.


LOAD-DATE: February 7, 2001

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
