                               The New York Times

                             July 7, 2011 Thursday
                              Late Edition - Final

Former Agriculture Official Named in Corruption Case

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Metropolitan Desk; Pg. 20

LENGTH: 536 words


ALBANY -- A former top agriculture regulator used his position to steer $100,000
in aid to a nonprofit group that employed his wife as a consultant, according to
an investigation report obtained by The New York Times.

The office of Inspector General Ellen N. Biben, which wrote the report, is
referring the case to the state ethics commission and to the Albany County
district attorney.

The regulator, Jerry Cosgrove, who was deputy commissioner of the state
Department of Agriculture and Markets until he was fired last year because of
the investigation, denied the allegations made in the report, according to his
lawyer.

Department staff members had initially rejected an aid application from the
group, the New York Agricultural Land Trust, which paid Mr. Cosgrove's wife,
Judy Anderson, $150,000 over three years. But according to the report, Mr.
Cosgrove demanded that the land trust receive money; one employee testified that
Mr. Cosgrove said, ''If they don't receive funding, heads are going to roll.''

Mr. Cosgrove is also accused of inflating the aid program used to finance the
land trust, boosting it to $1 million annually from $500,000, though the program
was ultimately suspended amid the investigation; of signing off on tens of
thousands of dollars' worth of legislative grants that went to the trust; and of
approving a $50,000 consulting contract for his former employer, the American
Farmland Trust, even though he had initiated negotiations over the contract
before he left his previous job.

Mr. Cosgrove's lawyer, Jonathan B. Fellows, denied any wrongdoing by his client.

''The reason Jerry was put into this position was his experience in farmland
preservation and protection,'' said Mr. Fellows, who had not seen the report.
''Everyone knew that he worked for American Farmland Trust for 15 years and his
wife worked in the same field.''

Mr. Fellows said Mr. Cosgrove had disclosed his potential conflicts of interest
to three top officials in the Department of Agriculture and Markets, including
the commissioner and the agency's counsel. He also sought an opinion from the
Commission on Public Integrity, which regulates compliance with state ethics
laws.

John Milgrim, a spokesman for Ms. Biben, declined to comment.

The inspector general's office contends in its report, which is expected to be
officially released on Thursday, that Mr. Cosgrove misled the integrity
commission when he sought its opinion. Among other things, he did not disclose
that his wife did consulting work for the specific grant program that led to the
$100,000 grant.

Investigators also asked Mr. Cosgrove if he had told subordinates that ''heads
are going to roll.''

''You know, should I have said that? No,'' he replied. ''But looking at the
facts, being frustrated by the, you know, the situation at the time, there was
probably something that could have been construed to that, but I don't think I
would ever use the phrase 'heads will roll.' ''

The agricultural agency exonerated Mr. Cosgrove in its own investigation in
2009. Several weeks ago, The Times submitted a state Freedom of Information Law
request seeking records of that investigation, but received only two pages of
scrawled notes related to the grant process.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: July 7, 2011

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                   Copyright 2011 The New York Times Company


                              830 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                           The Philadelphia Inquirer

                          February 27, 2008 Wednesday
                                JERSEY-D Edition

Cuts strike at heart of the Garden State

BYLINE: By Jacqueline L. Urgo and Kristen A. Graham; Inquirer Staff Writers

SECTION: SOUTH JERSEY; Inq South Jersey; Pg. B01

LENGTH: 932 words


HAMMONTON, N.J. - In this heart of South Jersey farming, the self-proclaimed
"Blueberry Capital of the World," residents had one question yesterday:

Isn't this the Garden State?

That question arose after Gov. Corzine, in his annual budget address, proposed
eliminating the state Department of Agriculture - an agency farmers see as a
vital source of information and advocacy.

"It's a real slap in the face to anyone involved in the agriculture industry,"
said Evelyn Penza, whose family has been farming for generations.

"It's very difficult for any of us to comprehend how we can be called the Garden
State, and yet will lack a Department of Agriculture," said Penza, who operates
the Red Barn Farm Market and Café. "We now have so much competition from
international markets that we need all the support we can get in retaining the
family farms."

Peter Bylone, manager of the Vineland Produce Auction, one of the oldest
farmer-operated cooperatives in the nation, said farming would become more
challenging.

"From an advocacy perspective, we are going to be on the losing end," Bylone
said. "From a practical perspective, it could become a bureaucratic nightmare
for us."

"Instead of one-stop shopping, farmers will now have to deal with an alphabet
soup of government agencies, he said, referring to the proposal to incorporate
some of the functions of the agriculture department into other state
departments.

Ed Wengryn, a spokesman for the New Jersey Farm Bureau, an advocacy group for
farmers, said his agency is urging its members to challenge Corzine's plan.

"Looking at it strictly from a numbers perspective, we don't see where any
savings is going to come from," Wengryn said. "All the programs and permitting
would still have to be done."

Also set to take a hit under the governor's proposed budget are hospitals. The
governor called for cutting charity-care payments - which help hospitals pay for
those who are uninsured and underinsured - to $608 million, down from $716
million.

Rich Miller, president and chief executive officer of Virtua Health, which runs
hospitals and health services across South Jersey, said Virtua provided $15
million of charity care at Medicaid rates, which are below cost, in 2007, but
was reimbursed for $2.6 million.

Virtua's charity work "is continuing to grow and our reimbursements are
dwindling," said Miller.

This is nothing new. He said the problem, which has been around for 15 years, is
shutting down hospitals.

"Now what you're seeing is a hospital crisis. We can't do it anymore," he said.

Although he said he understood Corzine faced tough choices, Miller called on the
state "to come forward and take care of this social issue and provide coverage
for the underinsured and uninsured in New Jersey."

Corzine's budget also meant bad news for municipalities. His proposed $1.8
billion in aid to towns represents a decrease of about $190 million.

In Cherry Hill, officials are tired of the "shell game," said Dan Keashen,
spokesman for Mayor Bernie Platt.

"The township is disappointed in the governor's decision to cut municipal aid,
and believes this budget adds up to passing the buck onto the dining-room table
of our residents," Keashen said.

Chris Tassi is mayor of Audubon, a town of just under 10,000. Corzine's plan is
to target towns of that size and smaller, which will be given priority in grants
for consolidation and shared services.

Tassi said he had heard whispers of what was coming down from Trenton, but the
job of finding places to cut will be tough.

"We're in the middle of doing our budget now, and there's going to have to be a
tightening of everything. Every line item," he said.

One group that will see a significant increase in aid, not a cut, is New
Jersey's public schools.

Under Corzine's proposed budget, school aid would increase by about $532
million. The increase is the result of a formula for school funding that the
governor championed and that narrowly won state legislative approval last month.

Under the formula, which will require state Supreme Court approval, education
aid would be spread more evenly across districts with poor youngsters - as
opposed to concentrating the funds on the so-called Abbott districts, largely
disadvantaged urban districts.

Actual district-by-district aid figures will not be released until tomorrow,
according to education spokesman Jon Zlock. However, based on earlier figures,
all districts would get some aid increase - at least 2 percent and no more than
20 percent.

Camden, an Abbott district, was projected to get the minimum increase. Black
Horse Pike Regional, a needy district that is not an Abbott, could receive the
maximum aid boost. Cherry Hill, a relatively affluent suburban district, was
looking at a 10 percent increase. But because it spends more per student than
what the state deems adequate, under the new formula, the district could have to
use some of its aid to provide property-tax relief.

Despite some misgivings about the impact of the new funding formula, the New
Jersey School Boards Association commended the proposed budget.

"Against the backdrop of state budget cutbacks, the increase in education
funding will relieve or stabilize property-tax burdens in a significant number
of communities," said executive director Marie E. Bilik. "The recommended
appropriation will also provide a needed infusion of aid to many programs that
have been flat-funded for six years."

Contact staff writer Kristen Graham at 856-779-3970 or kgraham@phillynews.com.

Inquirer staff writers Cynthia Burton and Rita Giordano contributed to this
article.

LOAD-DATE: February 27, 2008

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                            March 21, 1998, Saturday

Weather-weary farmers eligible for assistance

SECTION: HERNANDO TIMES; BRIEFLY; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 157 words



Hernando County, which has been designated a disaster area by President  Clinton
as a result of recent severe storms, is eligible to receive assistance  from the
U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency.

Eligible family farmers may qualify for emergency loan assistance for  repairing
or restoring damaged farm property, reimbursement of expenses  already incurred,
reimbursement of production expenses for damaged or  destroyed crop and
livestock enterprises and producing new crops.

Loans are limited to family-size farm operators and $ 500,000 total
indebtedness, 80 percent of the calculated actual production loss and 100
percent of the actual physical loss.

Payment terms depend on the purpose of the loan and the applicant's ability  to
repay the loan. Applications may be obtained from the Pasco/Hernando FSA
office, One Pasco Center, 30407 Commerce Drive, San Antonio, or call (352)
588-5211.

                                US Official News

                            December 23, 2016 Friday

Memorandum: Require food service employees to obtain first aid training in CPR
and the Heimlich maneuver

LENGTH: 506  words

DATELINE: New York



 Harrisburg: Pennsylvania House of Representatives has issued the following
Memorandum:



  From:     Representative Stephen Kinsey

 To:     All House members

 Subject:     Require food service employees to obtain first aid training in CPR
and the Heimlich maneuver



 Colleagues, when the House returns for the upcoming legislative session, I will
introduce free-standing legislation intended to require food service employees
of retail food establishments to obtain first aid training in CPR and the
Heimlich maneuver. The term "retail food establishment" would be defined to mean
"any public eating or drinking place which serves food or beverages, with
charge, to the public for on-premises consumption and which is required to
register with the Department of Agriculture in accordance with 3 Pa.C.S. §5734."




 Briefly, my legislation would require employees of food establishments where
food is served for on-premises consumption to secure training and certification
in emergency first aid.

Such first aid training would include instruction in the Heimlich maneuver,
pursuant to a training program approved by the Department of Health as described
in the Red Cross Manual 32-1138 and CPR pursuant to a training program provided
by the Red Cross or a similar organization, as approved by the Department of
Health. The Department of Health would be required to consult with the
Department of Agriculture to determine whether any or all employees of retail
food facilities under 3 Pa.C.S. §5703 should be exempt from the first aid
training and certification requirement.



 As provided in the proposal, a proprietor of a food establishment could
designate at least one food service employee who holds a valid first aid
training certificate to be present at all hours during which food or beverages
are sold or offered for sale. In such cases, training and certification could be
waived for all other food service employees. The training and certification
requirement could also be waived in cases of undue hardship, and when a local
health authority would determine that a food service employee's work assignment
renders first aid training impracticable or unnecessary. As stipulated in the
legislation, no food establishment, proprietor of a food establishment or food
service employee would be civil or criminally liable for a good faith
application of emergency first aid by a trained and certified food service
employee.



 Furthermore, the legislation would require proprietors of retail food
establishments to post graphic displays of the Heimlich maneuver in conspicuous
areas of the food establishment. The posting would depict, in both words and
pictures, the signs to look for to determine if an individual is choking and the
method for performing the anti-choking procedure. Other provisions of the
legislation enumerate the powers and duties of the Department of Health and
local health authorities.

Hunger in the News: Food Aid, Food Stamp Committee, Ferguson, School Lunch

LENGTH: 265  words

"Potentially damaging food aid reform cut from Coast Guard bill," by Tom Murphy,
Humanosphere.  "Advocates for international food aid claimed victory this week
after the Senate cut a provision that they say would have hurt efforts to
deliver food effectively to people in need around the world. The new version of
the bill passed both the Senate and House on Wednesday."

"UN resumes food aid for Syrian refugees," Al Jazeera.  "The UN World Food
Programme will restart its food aid for 1.7 million refugees in Jordan, Lebanon,
Turkey, Iraq and Egypt after it received enough donations to fund the suspended
programme."

Tracy, The Wall Street Journal.  "Rep. Mike Conaway (R., Texas), the newly
appointed chair of the House Agriculture Committee, is pledging to undertake a
"thoughtful" review of food stamps."

Ferguson is less about passing more anti-discrimination laws than about
rekindling economic growth and spreading the proceeds."

Lydia Wheeler, The Hill. "The bill known as "cromnibus," contains language that
would allow states to exempt struggling districts from having to offer all whole
grain products and eases requirements for schools to reduce sodium levels.

                              836 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                            January 15, 2013 Tuesday
                                 THIRD EDITION

NATION DIGEST

BYLINE: From news services

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A15

LENGTH: 573 words


Agriculture chief returning to Cabinet

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack will keep his job in President Barack Obama's
second term.

USDA communications director Matt Paul said Monday that Obama asked Vilsack to
stay in his post and Vilsack accepted. Vilsack is the former Democratic governor
of Iowa.

The farm economy has thrived under Vilsack's tenure, but his job hasn't been as
easy in Washington. He is expected to spend the next several months lobbying
Congress to pass a farm bill that would extend agriculture subsidies and
domestic food aid.

Farm-state lawmakers' efforts to pass that bill failed in the last Congress.

Meanwhile, Obama is considering two women for senior economic positions,
weighing Ruth Porat, chief financial officer at Morgan Stanley, for deputy
Treasury secretary and Wal-Mart Foundation President Sylvia Mathews Burwell for
budget director, according to people familiar with the matter.

Scrutiny has been mounting over the number of women and minorities that will
surround the nation's first black president in his second term. Cabinet members
who are departing at the end of his first term are being replaced largely by
white men. But Obama said critics should wait until the remaining vacancies have
been filled.

Clinton to testify o Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton will testify Jan.
23 before the House Foreign Affairs Committee about the deadly Sept. 11 assault
on the U.S. mission in Libya.

That's the word from Rep. Ed Royce, R-Calif., chairman of the panel. He said in
a statement late Monday that Clinton will answer questions about the raid that
killed U.S. Ambassador Chris Stevens and three other Americans in Benghazi.

Clinton had been scheduled to testify last month but she suffered a concussion
when she fell during an illness. She was later hospitalized with a blood clot in
her head.

Bush released from hospital o Former President George Bush, 88, has left a
Houston hospital where he spent nearly two months recovering from an illness
that began with a bronchitis-related cough.

Arizona OKs Medicaid expansion o Arizona Gov. Jan Brewer said Monday that she
plans to push for an expansion of the state's Medicaid program under the federal
health care law, a surprising decision that could have an impact on other
Republican governors weighing a similar decision. Brewer has opposed the federal
health care law known as the Affordable Care Act, citing worries over a
potential overreliance on federal funding.

Sandy aid package o House conservatives opposed to more deficit spending tried
Monday to chip away at the $50.7 billion Superstorm Sandy aid package by
requiring offsetting spending cuts to pay for recovery efforts and by stripping
money for projects they say are unrelated to the Oct. 29 storm or not urgently
needed.

The push by budget hawks for amendments sets up a fight with Northeast lawmakers
in both parties eager to provide recovery aid for one of the worst storms ever
to strike the region.

Cold grips West o As an unusual cold spell gripped parts of the West for a fifth
day, some California citrus growers reported damage to crops and an agriculture
official said national prices on lettuce have started to rise because of lost
produce in Arizona.

In California's San Joaquin Valley, where farmers are fighting to protect about
$1.5 billion worth of citrus fruit on their trees, Sunday temperatures dropped
to 25 degrees in some areas and stayed low longer than previous nights.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                            July 25, 2001 Wednesday

Environmental groups: Shift farm money to conservation programs; Federal aid:
Data show that most of the subsidies go to grain and cotton farmers in a small
number of states

BYLINE: ASSOCIATED PRESS

SECTION: Pg. a9

LENGTH: 388 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Congress should shift half of all federal farm spending into conservation
programs, away from payments that subsidize crop production, a coalition of
environmental groups said Tuesday.

That would help reduce the runoff from farms and livestock operations that fouls
rivers and streams and also benefit areas of the country that receive relatively
little money from federal farm programs, the groups said.

"Less than 10 percent of the money Congress spends now helps farmers help the
environment," said Tim Searchinger, a lawyer for Environment Defense, one of the
groups making the recommendation to Congress.

On Thursday, the House Agriculture Committee is set to begin writing legislation
that will govern farm and nutrition programs for the next 10 years.

A $$ @168 billion plan proposed by the committee's Republican chairman and
senior Democrat would steer much of the money into subsidies for grain, cotton
and soybean farmers. About $$ @15 billion would go into conservation programs,
primarily the Environmental Quality Incentives Program, which helps crops
farmers and livestock producers pay for improvements.

Under existing farm programs, too much of the money goes to grain and cotton
farmers in a relatively small number of states, according to data compiled by
the environmental groups.

North Dakota, for example, receives 27 cents in federal subsidies for every
dollar of agricultural production, a bigger share than any other state, followed
by Montana at 24 cents, and Illinois and Louisiana, at 18 cents each.

California and Pennsylvania, by contrast, each receive about two cents in
federal aid for every dollar of their agricultural production, and Florida
receives one cent. Fruits, vegetables and livestock, which are major commodities
in those states, received relatively little federal aid.

"Traditional programs are inequitable in part because they are limited to the
production of wheat, feed grains and cotton, which actually generate only
one-fifth of the value of the country's agriculture," according to a report by
the groups.

In addition to Environmental Defense, other groups involved in writing the
report were American Farmland Trust, Center for Science in the Public Interest,
Defenders of Wildlife, the Environmental Working Group and Trout Unlimited.

                              839 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      Saint Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                             March 2, 2000 Thursday

STUDY: U.S. AID A BOON TO FARMERS

BYLINE: Lee Egerstrom Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 1C

LENGTH: 731 words


A state attempt to help Minnesota farmers survive last year's low prices
probably didn't do much to keep financially strapped farm families out of
bankruptcy. But federal aid appears to have played a more significant role,
according to University of Minnesota economists who have studied farm relief
data.

The amount of state aid averaged $1,473 per farm, and that was too little to
make much difference to farms in financial trouble, said economist Steve Taff.
At the same time, a significant share of the state money ended up in the hands
of farmers and farmland owners who had no financial problems.

Separately, evidence is building that 1999 federal farm aid bailed out Minnesota
farmers for the second year in a row.

Kent Olson, economist and coordinator of farm management studies for
southwestern and southeastern Minnesota, said preliminary data show that
government payments provided the bulk of net farm income on most farms surveyed.

Federal government programs provided about $2 billion to Minnesota farmers last
year, based on USDA records in St. Paul.

In Southwest Minnesota, farmers participating in University of Minnesota farm
management programs had net farm income of $43,853 last year; the average farm
in the study received $44,728 in federal payments.

The previous year, southwestern Minnesota farmers averaged net farm income of
only $8,616 after received federal government payments of $30,021 per farm.

Southeastern Minnesota, supported by a stronger dairy industry, produced better
results last year with average net farm income of $68,561 that was helped by
average government payments of $52,050 per farm, Olson said. In 1998, farmers in
the southeastern counties averaged net income of $65,739 with average government
payments of $23,322 per farm.

"What this says is that our farmers depended on the federal government payments,
but it is harder to draw conclusions about the state help," he said.

Taff agrees. The amount of state aid wouldn't help the really needy, he said,
and it wasn't needed by a lot of people who ended up with the state government
check. He said the state money would be "welcome, but probably not critical" for
the people who received it.

For instance, Taff and colleague Paul Glewwe found that 100 Ramsey County
"farmers" shared $65,421 in state farm aid payments, or an average of $654 per
recipient. The Minnesota Department of Revenue can identify only 15 farms in the
county.

This means urban dwellers who own farmland elsewhere in the state and don't rely
on agriculture to make a living received aid nonetheless.

"All we know is where the checks were sent; not where the farm is located," Taff
said.

Larger Hennepin County, which does have rural areas west of Minneapolis, had 421
farms qualify for $305,810 in state aid, or $726 per farm. The only targeting
attempt the Minnesota Legislature made last year was to restrict benefits for
very small farms and horse farms, Taff said. As a result, about half of Hennepin
County's farms didn't qualify for state aid.

Washington County has about 1,200 legally recognized farms, but the 187 farms
that qualified for state benefits received $1,100 in aid - more in line with the
state average.

About 20 percent of the state payments went to groups organized as farm
partnerships, limited partnerships, family farm corporations, farm management
companies or nonfarm corporations.

Of the 49,000 recipients of state aid last year, 1,562 people living in other
states received $1.5 million in aid for their Minnesota farm holdings.

Federal farm aid has a similar mix of recipients as people who own farms and
their renters decide who will receive government payments, the economists said.
The money often ends up in silk-stocking suburbs, Phoenix and San Diego because
the payments may be used to pay land rents.

While that means taxpayer money often ends up in the hands of wealthy property
owners, that isn't all bad for agriculture, said Olson. The federal dollars
helped keep land prices from collapsing as they did during the 1981-1987 farm
financial crisis, and renting land allows young farmers and new farmers to enter
the business, he said.

Lee Egerstrom, who covers agribusiness and food companies, can be reached at
legerstrom@pioneerpress.com or (651) 228-5437.

                              841 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     May 25, 1991, Saturday, Final Edition

A Program That Wasn't Broken

SECTION: OPINION EDITORIAL; PAGE A30

LENGTH: 422 words


WHAT COULD have possessed farm-state legislators and the U.S. Department of
Agriculture to hamstring a federal credit program that was working well enough
and had helped farmers to sell more than $ 30 billion in agricultural
commodities to high-risk foreign purchasers over the past 12 years?

Until enactment of the 1990 farm bill, Congress thought it a swell idea for the
U.S. taxpayer to cosign loans to countries that wanted to buy U.S. agricultural
products but were not good credit risks. Otherwise, banks wouldn't lend them
grocery shopping money. But last year the Senate Agriculture Committee,
unwilling to let well enough alone, decided that to qualify for these loan
guarantees, foreign buyers had to be, of all things, credit-worthy (and never
mind that if they were credit-worthy they might not need the guarantees). The
agriculture secretary was thus forbidding credit guarantees to countries that
"cannot adequately service the debt." Congress also restricted the use of the
program for foreign policy or aid purposes.

The sponsor, Agriculture Committee Chairman Patrick Leahy (D-Vt.), thought that
by stressing credit-worthiness and laying on restrictions, the export credit
program would be shielded from noncommercial considerations such as grain
embargoes and bilateral disputes. Other members who noticed the new provision
accepted it as consistent with the frugal temper of the times: The old program
had lost $ 5.3 billion since its inception. The Agriculture Department, fighting
other brush fires in the farm bill, didn't think much about the change at all.

But then the Soviet Union, already a recipient of $ 1 billion in credit
guarantees, asked President Bush for $ 1.5 billion more to buy U.S. wheat, feed
and soybeans. Under the old rules, it could have been easily done;
credit-worthiness was but one factor in deciding export credits, not the
controlling factor. But now, given the judgment of the CIA, the International
Monetary Fund and others that the Soviet economy is in perilous condition, the
White House is hard-pressed to say yes. The result? Suddenly Bob Dole (R-Kan.)
and other farm-state senators who supported last year's change are saying they
mean for the Soviet Union to get the wheat too.

In fact, the old program wasn't broken. It had some ambiguities, including
whether every loan would be repaid, but this is implicit in having a special
program for uncertain buyers in the first place. The best course would still be
to revert to the old, muddy way of doing business.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

SERIES: Occasional

TYPE: EDITORIAL

                       Copyright 1991 The Washington Post


                              842 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           February 10, 1989, Friday

USDA MAY OPEN BIDDING FOR FOOD AID TRANSPORT

BYLINE: ROSE A. HOROWITZ; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 774 words


The U.S. Agriculture Department is moving toward an open bidding system for
transporting U.S. food aid cargoes, said shipping sources who attended a closed
meeting on the government aid program.

According to these sources, Marvin Lehrer, director of the PL-480 (Food for
Peace) Operations Division of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, said at the
meeting that the USDA was in the process of drafting regulations that would llow
for an open bidding system.

The current bidding system, which covers hundreds of millions of dollars worth
of freight costs, is now closed. None of the winning and losing transportation
offers are disclosed to the public. The winning bid is chosen behind closed
doors. The transportation system has been criticized by government audits and by
brokers and shipowners, but no substantial changes have been passed in years.

Mr. Lehrer was one of the speakers addressing about 200 people at a seminar on
Wednesday held in Rosslyn, Va. The meeting was sponsored by the International
Trade and Development Foundation, a non-profit group based in Arlington, Va.

The foundation, which aims to educate the American public about U.S. trade and
development activities, barred the press from attending the seminar on food aid
programs. Attendees at the conference paid $ 30 to attend the all-day program.

The U.S. Agency for International Development will pay $ 9,000 to the foundation
for a report on the findings of the seminar held Wednesday, said Doug Eldred, an
AID spokesman. The agency issued the payment under a purchase order, he said. If
an AID payment to an outside contractor is authorized for more than $ 10,000,
AID has to conduct an open bidding process, he said.

"AID is not sponsoring the seminar, but it did contract for a report from the
foundation to report the findings," said Mr. Eldred.

Daniel E. Shaughnessy, president of the foundation, said Thursday that AID
wanted to buy the report.

He said the group would prepare a report on the seminar that would be available
to the public.

Responding to questions Tuesday, Mr. Shaughnessy said the foundation never
intended to include the press and that the conference was overbooked. He also
said the foundation wanted an open exchange among participants.

"We feel it was extremely successful because of the exchange of information and
audience participation," Mr. Shaughnessy said when contacted Thursday.

Some shipping brokers said the topics discussed were fairly routine and that
there wasn't enough time to ask questions of the panel members. Another broker
said it was productive. "It gives us the opportunity to listen to people in
government and industry exchanging views," said one source.

A senior government official said speakers at the seminar didn't include any
government officials or others that have criticized the way the transportation
system works.

Private groups holding meetings like this often have "head doctors talking to
head doctors" and don't bring in "toe doctors," with another perspective, he
said. Such meetings allow government agencies to issue ''reports that seem near
consensus," according to the source, who declined to be identified. "This seems
to maintain the status quo," he said.

For years, there has been pressure within the agencies to keep things as they
are, he said, echoing views expressed by some in the shipping industry.
Moreover, agents for countries participating in the food aid programs and the
countries themselves are resistant to change because they fear it will hurt
their operations.

A number of country agents/brokers said that an open bidding system would help
resolve charges of favoritism among shipowners and country agents and brokers.
They also said an open system might help resolve criticisms of conflict of
interest in the way the system is run. Others said conflict of interest problems
would still remain unless a more fundamental overhaul is achieved.

According to one source, someone at the conference asked if the regulations that
USDA was considering would prohibit a country shipping agent from also acting as
a ship broker in the food aid programs. Mr. Lehrer responded that an open tender
system should address that conflict of interest issue, said the source.

Mr. Lehrer also reportedly said the USDA was looking at standardizing all
country tenders for freight transportation. Now each country submits its own
tender for approval by USDA.

Freight services to transport food aid to recipient countries are valued in
excess of $ 400 million, according to the foundation, in a letter it sent
inviting participants to the conference.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE:  Food For Peace? - Food For Profit?

GRAPHIC: ILLUSTRATION: GRAPHIC

                  Copyright 1989 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              843 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 December 27, 1990, THURSDAY, FIVE STAR Edition

SUBSIDIES FOR TOBACCO BUT NOT FOR THE ARTS

BYLINE: Clarence Page Column

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 3C

LENGTH: 800 words


CHICAGO Just when it seemed as though enough had been said about government
funding for the arts, fiction writer Vince Passaro weighs in with a new spin.
Call it the ''guilty artist'' approach.  In an essay in the December Harper's,
Passaro, who once received a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts,
does not advise others to stop dipping into the public arts barrel. Dip if you
must, he says, but be careful how you rationalize it.  ''The necessary
selfishness of being an artist means, when it comes to money, getting one's
snout into whatever trough makes itself available,'' Passaro writes. ''But the
moment we pass from merely cashing in to actually believing that government
money is necessary and deserved is a dangerous moment indeed, when we put at
risk the independence and authority that make art something more than stirring
decoration for the halls of fashion and power.'' By claiming the works of
Mapplethorpe and other controversial artists have a social impact too dangerous
to be deserving of public support, Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., and his accomplices
like Rep. Dana Rohrabacher, R-Calif., have forced artists to argue back that,
no, the arts really are not that big of a deal. Don't worry. Be happy. Gimme the
money. Still, Passaro suggests that artists would do well to use the debate as
an opportunity to ''recollect the source of our true power.'' ''The real and
terrifying freedom of art doesn't come from legislators, and it doesn't come
from committees. It comes from the limitless chaos of our hearts.'' Bravo. Three
cheers for the limitless chaos of the heart.  But I am troubled that Passaro
seems to be offering an elegant new spin to the old and treacherous argument
that government help undermines individual initiative. If so, he only skims the
surface of an issue more fundamental than the NEA debate.  After all, if we're
going to talk about public troughs, how about some debate over a controversial
feedbag nearer and dearer to Helms' heart: government aid to tobacco farmers?
''There's no question that tobacco has no redeeming value whatsoever,'' Health
and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan declared in Chicago recently.  But,
while Sullivan's branch of government wages a vigorous war against smoking,
another branch, the Department of Agriculture, continues to subsidize it, thanks
to tobacco-state politicians like Helms.  Maybe artists have the wrong approach.
Maybe instead of asking for grants, they should demand ''price supports.'' Or
maybe they should demand that the government pay them not to produce art, like
some farmers are paid not to grow crops. Or maybe they should demand that the
government buy up surplus art they have been unable to sell, like the feds buy
surplus farm production.  Helms has yet to show us any art that is as hazardous
to one's health as research shows tobacco to be. Maybe the real debate has less
to do with morality than with a more fundamental question of pork-barrel
politics: ''Where's mine?'' SOURCE: Copyright 1990 The Chicago Tribune

LOAD-DATE: October 18, 1993

LANGUAGE: English

                  Copyright 1990 St. Louis Post-Dispatch, Inc.


                              844 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                   November 23, 1989, Thursday, Final Edition

Sharing the Nation's Bounty

BYLINE: MARY McGRORY

SECTION: FIRST SECTION; PAGE A1; MARY MCGRORY

LENGTH: 789 words


Food for Peace is one of the programs by which we have defined ourselves for 35
years. We are proud of it, and with reason.

It is Thanksgiving written into law. It represents us at our best -- idealistic,
generous, practical. We share the endless bounty from our 350 million planted
acres with the rest of the world. We loan money to poor countries to buy the
food they need or we give it to them. It's good for the world's hungry and good
for our farmers, too.

Food for Peace has saved millions of lives. It could save more, perhaps, if the
law did not forbid helping communist countries, although the law is often
circumvented.

Senate Agriculture, Nutrition and Forestry Committee Chairman Patrick J. Leahy
(D-Vt.) was a teenager when Hubert H. Humphrey was exhorting the country on the
wonders of the program he so passionately espoused. Leahy thinks it's time to
overhaul the program, time to streamline it.

A five-person group from Agriculture, State, Treasury, the Agency for
International Development (AID) and the Office of Management and Budget, called
the Development Coordinating Committee, meets weekly to consider requests for
food aid. It has been known to dither for months. In the current issue of the
Food for Peace newsletter by former senator John Melcher (D-Mont.), a lifelong
friend of needy people, it is noted that the committee waited so long to ship
rice to the Philippines that Manila canceled the request.

Leahy also wants to broaden the mission of PL 480. He wants to de-politicize it
completely, rule out all foreign policy or diplomatic considerations -- and just
feed the world.

"We should be thinking of our food aid for moral and humanitarian reasons,
rather than the self-interest of the U.S.," he says.

The chairman of the House Select Committee on Hunger, Rep. Tony P. Hall
(D-Ohio), is in complete agreement. Says Hall, who succeeded Mickey Leland, "We
can end hunger in the world. We have the capacity to do it."

Both chairmen hope to incorporate that goal of feeding the hungry, whoever they
are, into the revision of the agriculture bill that comes up next year. They
will attempt to get State, OMB and Treasury out of the food-aid picture, so that
diplomatic and financial considerations will not dominate discussions of human
need. Agriculture, which knows where the food is, and AID, which knows where it
should go, could handle the program unassisted.

There have always been ways of getting around the ban on sending food to "any
country or area dominated or controlled . . . by a world communist movement," as
the law reads.

Even before the recent legislation that whizzed through Congress in time for
Lech Walesa's visit, Poland was getting PL 480 food. It was not sent to the
government but routed through Catholic Relief Services. Strictly speaking,
Poland is still under communist control, but nothing would have stopped Congress
from getting help to Warsaw.

In another case, Mozambique, which until recently had 3,000 Soviet advisers, got
food it desperately needed through the private voluntary agencies, like CRS and
CARE. Melcher thinks that our food aid had much to do with Mozambique's change
of heart. He points out that regular meals from the United States do much to
open minds to the charms of democracy and that malnourished people simply do not
have the energy and the vigor to work toward freedom.

In Marxist Ethiopia, where there is, ironically, enough food grown in the north
to feed the entire country, the help that Mickey Leland died to get in was being
channeled through the private agencies.

No one doubts that if Mikhail Gorbachev applied for food aid this winter, we
could do it, even though the Soviet Union has obviously no religious service
organizations or private charity groups to do the distributing.

Food for Peace has been used to enormous effect, but it has been abused for
political reasons, too, most notably in El Salvador, where it became food for
war. El Salvador, where the food supply is adequate, got $ 39 million. Starving
Ethiopia was getting only $ 38 million. The food was given to the Salvadoran
Army -- no one knows how much it kept or sold for cash -- even though the rules
say food should not be used for military advantage. Rep. Byron L. Dorgan
(D-N.D.) charged that the administration had "grotesquely distorted the program
for it own economic and military goals."

The Wall Street Journal reported Oct. 26 that 1.6 million pounds of U.S. food
was found rotting in a government warehouse and had to be burned.

It's time that this old and generally honorable program got a facelift, not just
so its humanitarianism can shine through, but because now that we can do it, we
should eliminate hunger from the world.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: COLUMN

                       Copyright 1989 The Washington Post

                         Cape Gazette (Lewes, Delaware)

  This content, including derivations, may not be stored or distributed in any
  manner, disseminated, published, broadcast, rewritten or reproduced without
                      express, written consent from STPNS

                               February 23, 2010

Plenty of fat can be cut out of Delawares upcoming budget;
COMMENTARY

BYLINE: Christian Hudson

LENGTH: 566  words


While our state legislators are working on the Delaware budget for the upcoming
year, I thought it might be helpful to look at some of the highlights from the
previous year's budget: budget.delaware.gov/fy2010/hb2 90.pdf.

The governor has publicly asked for ideas in ways that the state can save money,
so I thought I'd give it a try. Besides, it's our money after all.

After just a brief look at the budget, I was absolutely startled to find so much
waste lying right in plain sight. Don't believe me? Let me give you just a few
of the many examples of Delaware's reoccurring expenses. You can then decide for
yourself if your tax dollars should fund these items every single year.

Office of Management and Budget: Delaware Surplus Services. We pay almost
$390,000 per year to auction off our surplus equipment. Does that mean that our
state is so inefficient that we can't even sell our equipment without having to
pay people to buy it?

Department of Correction: Prisons: Other Items: Prison Arts. I am hopeful that
the $82,500 we spend every year on "Prison Arts" is at least therapy, and not
simply macaroni-art with a splash of glitter. At worst it could be a class on
how to make prison weapons out of paintbrushes. Can anyone else think of a
better way to spend $82,500 per year of your taxes?

Department of Health and Social Services: Public Health: AIDS Needle Exchange
Pilot Program. We spend $230,000 per year on exchanging dirty needles from drug
addicts who are infected with AIDS? Do we know if the needle bandit used our
taxes to fund his recent reign of terror on local businesses?

Department of Agriculture: Other Items: Fingerprints: We pay $76,000 per year
for this one. More importantly, why exactly does the Department of Agriculture
have a Fingerprints Division? Other Items: Fingerprinting: $75,000 per year. You
read that correctly, we have both a Fingerprints Division and a Fingerprinting
Division, both within the Department of Agriculture. On the state budget these
are officially listed as two separate divisions of the Department of Agriculture
. I'm still trying to figure out why the Department of Agriculture deals with
fingerprints in the first place though. Are these guys fingerprinting Delaware
farmers, or chickens?

Department of State: Office of the Secretary: World Trade Center. $120,000 per
year. This is supposed to be a nonprofit that helps Delaware businesses do
business overseas. Unfortunately, they also help allow member businesses from
neighboring states.

Isn't it nice to know diat Delaware tax money is going to subsidize businesses
in Pennsylvania? Internal Program: Government Information Center. If you go to
the website gic.delaware.gov/you can see what tiiey get paid to do. This mainly
involves creating Twitter accounts and YoiiTube videos for state agencies, all
for just under $800,000 per year. Sounds productive, doesn't it?

Please note that this is only a very partial list. A thorough, line-by-line,
evaluation should be performed by every department to eliminate wasteful
spending of taxpayer dollars.

Recommendation: There is plenty of room for budget cuts within die state of
Delaware, without resorting to budget cuts for necessary services like police,
fire, emergency medical technicians, maintaining roads, etc.

Christian Hudson of Lewes is a real estate entrepreneur, a member of the
Governor's Advisory Council on Manufactured Housing.

LOAD-DATE: March 19, 2010

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          South Bend Tribune (Indiana)

                  February 28, 2002 Thursday Marshall Edition

Food stamp rules change on Friday

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DITS; Tribune Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. D1

LENGTH: 609 words


On Friday, more people in Indiana will qualify for food stamps.

The state is changing one of the rules. Owning a car worth more than $4,500
won't count against applicants anymore.

"This should have been changed years ago," said Charlotte Barrier, placing extra
emphasis on "years." She works with clients seeking poverty relief at the
Portage Township trustee's office in South Bend.

"This will particularly help families who've exhausted their savings but still
need to get to work," said John Hamilton, secretary of the state's Family and
Social Services Administration, who came to Elkhart to make the announcement.

He said the state knows of more than 600 households that were denied food stamps
because of the vehicle rule last year.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture finances the food stamp program and sets the
programs' restrictions. But, within the past year, the USDA allowed states to
change the vehicle rule.

Indiana officials seized the opportunity. Not only are they helping needy people
in tough economic times, but giving out more food stamps doesn't require a dime
of state money. Indiana Gov. Frank O'Bannon recently ordered a freeze on hiring
and wages for state employees and trimmed other programs for the elderly and
disabled.

The number of food stamp recipients in Indiana increased 20 percent in the past
year, Hamilton said. Most of the recipients are children. Hoosiers received
$32.7 million of the aid in December alone, said Cindy Collier, the FSSA's
policy director.

To qualify, a food stamp applicant must have no more than $2,000 in savings.
Until today, a car is permissible if it's used for household duties such as
going to work or going shopping -- not recreational vehicles. But, every dollar
of the vehicle's value that exceeds $4,500 is counted as assets against the
$2,000 limit.

So, an applicant whose car is worth more than $6,500 could not qualify.

Nor could a family that owns two cars, each worth $6,000. The excessive value of
each car would add up to $3,000 in assets.

Now welfare workers won't be concerned with the vehicles, unless, Hamilton said,
a family owns six cars, raising questions that the family is spending beyond its
means.

Applicants will still need to meet income requirements. For example, the income
for a family of four cannot exceed about $18,000, Hamilton said.

"The old rule was probably outdated," said Charles Smith, director of St. Joseph
County's welfare office.

Even in homes where both parents work, the adults need their cars to keep their
entry-level jobs, he said.

What happens to someone who's denied food stamps?

"They end up here more often," said Vonda Horst of Church Community Services in
Elkhart, where she counsels needy clients in finding help. She has seen several
clients disqualified from food stamps because of the vehicle rule.

Single men may have been the most vulnerable under the old rule, at least in the
eyes of Linda Jung-Zimmerman, director of the Advocacy Center in South Bend and
Mishawaka, two offices of the United Religious Community that connect the needy
with help.

Long-term help for the men is limited, while mothers and children can turn to a
variety of welfare aid for families, she said.

The change raised questions in the mind of Nyla Moore, the trustee for Elkhart's
Concord Township, who offers aid for the needy.

But, she asked, if more people apply for food stamps, will this overload welfare
caseworkers and create delays?

Hamilton said he doesn't expect too much of a problem. He foresees an increase
of fewer than 1,000 on the food stamp caseload in the next year.

LOAD-DATE: March 14, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: John Hamilton, secretary of Indiana's Family and Social Services
Administration, describes changes in food stamp rules in a talk Wednesday to the
Elkhart Chamber of Commerce.  Tribune Photo/GENE KAISER

                 Copyright 2002 South Bend Tribune Corporation


                              847 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                             August 5, 2007 Sunday
                                 Metro Edition

Drought-relief request takes on urgency;
USDA's State Emergency Board recommends disaster assistance be available in 25
Minnesota counties.

BYLINE: Jackie Crosby, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 553 words


Morrison County farmer Ken Primus hasn't seen an inch of rain at one time since
he planted in early May. He's not yet in panic mode, but he's starting to get
worried.

"If we got half of a normal crop, I'd be happy," said Primus, whose 75-acre farm
is about 7 miles southwest of Little Falls. "My corn is still green yet, but
there's some fields around here that are brown all the way to the top."

Gov. Tim Pawlenty hopes federal aid will soon be on its way.

In a letter sent to U.S. Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns on Friday, Pawlenty
asked the USDA to declare 25 Minnesota counties as agricultural disasters, which
would allow farmers and ranchers access to low-interest federal loans. A final
decision is made by the secretary of agriculture or the president.

The emergency loans, administered by the Farm Service Agency, can be used to
restore or replace property, pay production costs associated with the drought,
supplement living expenses, reorganize farming operations and refinance certain
debts.

Pawlenty said farmers in northern Minnesota are experiencing significant losses
to their hay and pasture, leaving many to worry about not having feed for
livestock over the winter.

"Corn and soybean crops are also losing value daily as the warm, dry weather
continues across the state," Pawlenty wrote in the letter.

Pawlenty included Roseau County in his request for aid because of an extensive
winter-kill of the county's perennial rye grass.

Last Tuesday, Pawlenty took a tour of distressed farms in central Minnesota and
asked the U.S. Department of Agriculture to assess the drought damage across
Minnesota. The department's emergency board recommended disaster assistance.

As an example of meager rainfall, Pawlenty last week pointed out the Little
Falls area had received 71 percent of its normal rainfall in May, 41 percent in
June and only 17 percent in July.

In late July, the National Drought Mitigation Center reported that a wide swath
of the state, running from the southwest to northeast, was suffering from
"severe" drought.

"When corn is shoulder high on up, it needs a third of an inch of water a day on
an 85-degree day," said Primus, who has about 60 acres of corn and 10 acres of
barley. "So with weather like we have now, that corn is using over 2 inches a
week. When you don't get any rain, that hurts."

Minnesota has two loan programs for farmers hit hard by the drought. The
Disaster Assistance Loan Program is for farmers in counties that receive the
disaster declaration and helps with the costs of watering, irrigation and other
drought mitigation systems.

The state's Loan Restructuring Program can help farmers pay their bills,
regardless of whether they live in a federally designated disaster area.

Primus said he has mixed feelings about the federal government stepping in.

"I've been here since 1978, and I've never had a government loan yet," he said.
"When you have a drought, it's kind of the checks and balances of the system. It
sounds kind of cruel, but that's part of the risk you take in agriculture."

Jackie Crosby - 612-673-7335

FEDERAL AID SOUGHT FOR THE FOLLOWING COUNTIES:

Aitkin, Anoka, Benton, Brown, Carlton, Cass, Cook, Crow Wing, Douglas, Hennepin,
Hubbard, Itasca, Kanabec, Lake, Mille Lacs, Morrison, Pipestone, Pope, Roseau,
St. Louis, Sherburne, Swift, Todd, Wadena, Wright.

LOAD-DATE: August 8, 2007

                              848 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

                March 8, 1983, Tuesday, Late City Final Edition

NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;
Aid for Kosher Kitchens

BYLINE: By Laurie Johnston and Robin Herman

SECTION: Section B; Page 3, Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 175 words


Saying that 33 percent of the Bronx's 90,000 Jews are ''at or near the poverty
line,'' Representative Mario Biaggi was concerned that none of the 930,000
pounds of Government-surplus cheese awaiting distribution from a Bronx warehouse
was kosher.

''It troubles me,'' he wrote recently to the Federal Department of Agriculture,
that Jewish residents ''will not benefit from surplus cheese or butter.''
Furthermore, with more lower-income families in particular becoming Orthodox, he
said, ''it presents a conflict when these families are forced to use the
nonkosher foods out of sheer desperation and need.''

Accordingly, the Agriculture Department has agreed to buy enough surplus kosher
cheese to fill orders from the city, determined by the state's Bureau of
Government Donated Foods. Kosher cheese is processed in special plants inspected
by rabbis.

Mr. Biaggi learned of the situation from several Jewish charities in his
district. One of them, he wrote, ''distributed 1,200 food packages during
Passover to hard core poor individuals.''

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company

                                US Official News

                           February 4, 2016 Thursday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri)
Issues Solicitation for "Purchase of Empty Bags for U.S. Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 271  words

DATELINE: Lahore


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Purchase of Empty Bags for U.S. Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: AG-INAE-S-16-0023

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: February 3, 2016

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AG-INAE-S-16-0023 (2000003852) for 50kg empty
woven polypropylene bags to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Delivery basis is FAS Vessel at U.S. Gulf.


The solicitation is expected to be available on or after February1, 2016, and
will be available electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain
Management (WBSCM) system located at
https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a link to the
aforementioned website in the document package attached to the solicitation
notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website (http://www.fbo.gov).
A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for the acquisition. All
future information regarding this acquisition, including solicitation amendments
and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM and FBO. Interested
parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the most up-to-date
information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of receipt for offers
will be on or near February 4, 2016.

Set Aside: N/A

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 314

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205 Mail Stop 8698 Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s): Julie Stephen, Agricultural Marketing Specialist
julie.stephen@kcc.usda.gov Phone: 816-926-6524

                              851 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                            Legal Monitor Worldwide

                            August 19, 2014 Tuesday

Lawyers file civil rights complaint over Ohio's food stamp requirements

LENGTH: 428  words


Legal advocates for the poor have filed a civil rights complaint with the
federal government over the state's move to enforce work requirements for food
stamp beneficiaries in most counties, saying the decision has disproportionately
impacted minorities in urban areas.


Ohio previously had not enforced the federal welfare-to-work requirements. But
officials at the Ohio Department of Job and Family Services reinstated the rules
last year in most Ohio counties citing an improved economy.
The state sought a waiver from the U.S. Department of Agriculture to exempt 16
high-unemployment counties from the work requirements, which the federal agency
approved.
The rules require able-bodied adults age 18 to 50 without dependent children to
spend at least 20 hours working, job training or volunteering each week to get
food stamps. The exempted counties are: Adams, Brown, Clinton, Coshocton,
Highland, Huron, Jefferson, Meigs, Monroe, Morgan, Muskingum, Noble, Ottawa,
Perry, Pike and Scioto.
But advocates say the decision has had a disparate impact on minorities in the
state's urban counties, while mostly white recipients in exempted rural areas
have benefited.
The Legal Aid Society of Columbus, the Ohio Poverty Law Center and others filed
the administrative complaint Friday with the USDA against Republican Gov. John
Kasich's administration.
Statewide, about 1.75 million people get food stamps. About a third are
minorities, according to the groups. Most live in urban areas not included in
the waiver.
Advocates said in the waiver counties, the food stamp program serves about 94
percent white recipients and nearly 6 percent minority individuals.
"This decision has unfairly made access to nutrition assistance more difficult
for many minority Ohioans," the groups' attorney wrote in their compliant.
Angela Terez, a spokeswoman for the state's job and family services department,
said Ohio's intent was not to single out any particular group. "Our intent was
to help those who needed help."
Ohio has provided resources to counties to help implement employment and
training programs for those who need to meet the work requirements, she said.
"Lots of things can count toward this requirement - even searching for a job can
count toward the requirement," Terez said.
Kate McGarvey, an attorney for the Legal Aid Society of Columbus, said it's up
to the agriculture department to determine whether to investigate the complaint.
The agency is not required to hold a hearing.  The groups want the waiver
extended to all 88 counties.
 2014 Legal Monitor Worldwide.

LOAD-DATE: August 19, 2014
