                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                            April 20, 2000 Thursday
                                  City Edition

Letters to the editor

SECTION: B; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 616 words


PERFECT RECIPE

History will look back on this generation and wonder why supposedly intelligent
people recommended condoms to prevent pregnancy and disease, in particular HIV/
AIDS. The Physician Desk Reference for 2000, page 2169 lists the failure rate of
male condoms to prevent pregnancy is 14 percent. Fertility at its broadest
stretch is 20 percent of the typical menstrual cycle. By extrapolation, the
failure rate of male condoms to prevent HIV/AIDS must be more than 50 percent
(male to female transmission only).  As a family physician I cannot in good
conscience recommend condoms, male or female, for anything. I can hear those
pro-condom advocates whining now "We have to do something." To finish their
phrase for them "so we can have sex with whomever we want, whenever we want, as
much as we want." Now, in the previous sentence replace the word "we" with
"children" and the word "sex" with "toys, candy, fun, alcohol, drugs" or just
leave it at "sex." This, my friends, is the perfect recipe for raising a brat.

Dr. Timothy H. Fischer, Lincoln

A FEW QUESTIONS

I sat down to watch my favorite program, "60 Minutes" on April 9 and lo and
behold, Mike Wallace was asking the right questions of the American Farm Bureau.
The Farm Bureau does not know nor has it ever represented the interests of the
American farmer. While thousands of family farmers struggle to survive in a
hostile environment of low commodity prices, high input costs and a misguided
federal farm program (costing taxpayers billions), the Farm Bureau leadership is
issued stock options, lobbies the Iowa Legislature for bailout of a failing
airline and systematically aids and abets the demise of American agriculture. I
have two questions to ask. If you are a farming member of the American Farm
Bureau, what have they done for you lately? My second question arises from the
front page article on "60 Minutes" and the Farm Bureau (LJS, April 10). Bryce
Neidig, president of the Nebraska Farm Bureau, states he does not know the value
of his stock options. I question whether the power of the presidency should rest
in the hands of a man who is "unaware" of the value of his stock. Perhaps he is
"unaware" of what is happening in production agriculture, or perhaps he just
doesn't care. The American Farm Bureau is the undisputed master of smoke and
mirrors.

Linda C. Schroeder, Lincoln

NEGLECT AT UNL

In eastern Nebraska, there is a School of Music in which the organ department
has been sadly neglected. In spite of excellent instructors, students struggle
with equipment long in need of attention. The practice organs are in need of
much work and repair, the result of deferred maintenance. The organ bench in the
teaching studio is broken and needs two people to adjust the height, an
adjustment which should only require the turning of a knob. Organ classes
studying and playing hymns use outdated hymnals, when nearly every major
denomination has issued new editions in the past several years. Where is the
school in which this department is in such a sorry shape? It is located in
downtown Lincoln, Neb., known as the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

It is no secret that the sports program at UNL dominates the university. One
might even say that sports control the university. Winning is everything, even
if it means firing a basketball coach and paying him a king's ransom. No
problem; the Athletic Department has plenty of money and gets whatever it wants.
Didn't they just "buy" a new basketball coach?  Are there other departments as
underequipped and poorly maintained as the organ department? Has education taken
a back seat to the "god" of sports? What are the marks of a good university?

Marcia Worchester, Lincoln

LOAD-DATE: July 8, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 2000 Lincoln Journal Star,
                              All Rights Reserved


                              853 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

              November 8, 1984, Thursday, Late City Final Edition
                              Correction Appended

WHO'S HOT AND WHO'S NOT ABOUT A SECOND TERM;
STATE DEPT. IN A DITHER OVER HELMS



BYLINE:
By BERNARD GWERTZMAN

SECTION: Section B; Page 16, Column 5; National Desk

LENGTH: 1315 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 7


The State Department has no embassy in Raleigh, N.C., but it was more interested
today in the post-election political scene in North Carolina than in most of the
reports it was receiving from its nearly 200 missions overseas.

Department officials, hoping that the answer would be ''no,'' were discreetly
asking reporters and politicians if they thought it likely that Senator Jesse
Helms, the senior Republican from North Carolina who survived a fight for
re-election, would chose to become the next chairman of the Senate Foreign
Relations Committee.

''It would be a 'koshmar,' '' one Soviet watcher said, using the Russian word
for ''nightmare'' as he speculated on the problems that might arise if Mr. Helms
took over the committee, through which all State Department dealings with the
Senate have to pass.

Mr. Helms, as the second-ranking Republican on the committee, has shown an
uncanny ability to put obstacles in the path of the State Department through the
years. He has delayed Senate confirmation of ambassadors and senior department
officials, held up action on key foreign policy legislation and shown himself to
be free of any adoration for Foggy Bottom as an institution.

Now, because of Senate seniority rules, Mr. Helms has the option of becoming the
next chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee or remaining as chairman of the
Agriculture Committee. This is because Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois, who
has been chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee since 1981, and who was on
close relations with the department, lost his re-election bid at the same time
that Mr. Helms was winning his.

Will He or Won't He?


At an Election Day party at the Madison Hotel Tuesday night that drew many
foreign diplomats and Reagan Administration officials, a principal subject of
conversation was whether Mr. Helms would take the Foreign Relations slot.

Throughout his campaign against Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., Mr. Helms was
categorical in saying he would not give up the Agriculture chairmanship for the
Foreign Relations chairmanship.

Campaigning last Saturday in Greenville, the heart of North Carolina's
flue-cured tobacco belt, Mr. Helms told a cheering crowd at a tobacco warehouse:
''This Senator is going to continue to be the chairman of the Senate Agriculture
Committee, not the Foreign Relations Committee.'' Mr. Helms has almost single-
handedly protected the Federal tobacco program against those in Congress and the
Administration who would like to do away with it.

''I know what Jesse has said,'' a senior State Department official said this
morning. ''But he is going to come under tremendous pressure from conservatives
outside of North Carolina to replace Percy.''

A Special Kind of Place


Mr. Percy was defeated by Representative Paul Simon. The spot he occupied on the
Foreign Relations Committee is a special kind of place. The chairman enjoys
tremendous prestige because of his regular high-level consultations with the
President and the Secretary of State. Senator J. William Fulbright, for one,
became a household name in the 1960's and early 1970's because of his eloquent
speeches and his well-prepared and often confrontational hearings that
questioned the wisdom of policies followed by the Kennedy, Johnson and Nixon
Administrations.

The chairman has access to the most sensitive information, and his advice is
sought on all manner of foreign policy decisions, including the appointment of
ambassadors and other high officials. He has the ability to move foreign policy
legislation ahead, or block progress. He can let ambassadorial appointments
wither by not scheduling confirmation hearings.

If and when President Reagan pledges to seek new arms control agreements in his
second term, the chairman could become a major obstacle to progress if he did
not support such agreements. And Mr. Helms, more than any other Senator on the
Foreign Relations Committee, is unhappy about agreements with the Soviet Union
and has been known to oppose confirmation of State Department officials who
favor dealing with the Communists.

An Endorsement, 'a Bad Idea'


His influence is such that 22 ambassadors, all political appointees, gave him
their endorsement in his re-election campaign. The move, made against the advice
of Secretary of State George P. Schultz, was criticized by a group of former
ambassadors who said envoys should stay out of partisan politics. One of the
ambassadors who gave the Helms endorsement said today, ''I know it was a bad
idea, but I felt it would help the State Department in the long run.''

But as Senate aides explained today, the question of whether Mr. Helms remains
as Agriculture chairman or moves to Foreign Relations is complicated by a number
of matters.

Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana is next in seniority to Mr. Helms on both
the Agriculture and Foreign Relations committees.

Since a senator can be chairman of only one committee, Mr. Lugar would become
Agriculture chairman if Mr. Helms took the Foreign Relations post. Mr. Helms has
indicated that keeping Mr. Lugar from heading the Agriculture Committee is one
reason for his staying there. For Mr. Lugar, who is from the Middle West, does
not support Federal aid for tobacco farmers, and if he became Agriculture
chairman, that might mean the end of the program.

The Race for Majority Leader


Mr. Lugar, who has worked closely with the Reagan White House and has a foreign
affairs background through teaching and as a Rhodes Scholar, would be the State
Department's choice to replace Mr. Percy as chairman of the Foreign Relations
Committee. But Mr. Lugar has set his sights on replacing Senator Howard H. Baker
Jr. of Tennessee as the Senate majority leader. Mr. Baker is retiring.

Mr. Lugar is competing with Senators Bob Dole of Kansas, Ted Stevens of Alaska,
James A. McClure of Idaho and Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico for majority
leader. The balloting is scheduled Nov. 28.

According to Senate aides, if Mr. Lugar loses that race, Mr. Helms will probably
stay with Agriculture and Mr. Lugar will replace Mr. Percy.

But if Mr. Lugar is chosen majority leader, and therefore can hold no committee
chairmanships, and if Mr. Helms then stayed with Agriculture, the next
Republican in line to become chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee would
be Charles McC. Mathias Jr. of Maryland. Senator Mathias, a supporter of arms
control and of improved relations with Moscow, would be as much anathema to some
conservatives as Mr. Percy had been.

To prevent that, there might be considerable pressure on Mr. Helms to renege on
his pledge and to take over Foreign Relations. In that case, with Mr. Lugar as
majority leader, the next in line at Agriculture is Senator Thad Cochran,
Republican of Mississippi, who might be more sympathetic to the North Carolina
tobacco interests than Mr. Lugar.

Another Turnaround


Less dramatic than the question of who will be the new Foreign Relations
Committee chairman is the situation caused in the House of Representatives by
the apparent defeat of Representative Clarence D. Long, Democrat of Maryland,
the longtime chairman of the Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations.

Mr. Long, widely known in Washington as ''Doc,'' has been one of Israel's most
influential supporters in Congress. He was also an occasional thorn in the side
of the Administration by his periodic questioning of the value of any foreign
aid except for Israel and a few other close allies.

In his subcommittee post he was able to intimidate many State Department
witnesses and to hold up aid appropriations until he was satisfied. He will be
replaced in that slot by Representative David R. Obey, Republican of Wisconsin,
whom the State Department regards as less contentious but likely to be more
questioning of Israel's continuing requests for aid.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

CORRECTION-DATE: November 10, 1984, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

CORRECTION:
Because of a technical error, an article on the Washington Talk page in some
editions on Thursday about Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina,
omitted a line. The passage should have said that Representative David R. Obey,
Democrat of Wisconsin, would replace Representative Clarence D. Long, Democrat
of Maryland, as chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign
Operations.

                   Copyright 1984 The New York Times Company


                              854 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            April 29, 1993, Thursday

New law lets farmers sue for product defamation

BYLINE: By Mark Sherman STAFF WRITERlegislation; law; government; Georgia;
agriculture; finances; business; lawsuits; courts

SECTION: STATE NEWS; Section D; Page 2

LENGTH: 375 words


Farmers may sue anyone who defames their products, under a bill signed into law
Wednesday by Gov. Zell Miller.

Sponsored by House Agriculture Committee Chairman Henry Reaves (D- Quitman), the
measure had overwhelming support in the General Assembly.

But it was opposed by the Georgia Press Association, which fears it may be used
to stifle news reports and public relations campaigns critical of agricultural
products.

The bill creates the potential for liability if statements are made that are not
based on "reasonable and reliable scientific inquiry, facts or data."

Said David Hudson, attorney for the press association, "It's a bad piece of
legislation, full of constitutional defects."

He predicted it would be overturned in a court challenge. A similar bill won
approval in Colorado in 1991 but was vetoed by the governor.

Chuck Reece, spokesman for Mr. Miller, said there is no connection between the
governor's approval of the measure and his angry remarks to reporters Tuesday
over recent news stories concerning contracts awarded by the Georgia lottery.

Also Wednesday, Mr. Miller signed:

The $ 8.9 billion budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1, and unlike last
year, the governor found no objectionable spending inserted by legislators. A
budgeting procedure law, which also contains a provision banning secret budget
funds. Mr. Miller last year vetoed an unexplained item in the state budget,
which turned out to be a $ 479,000 appropriation controlled by House leaders.

A package of child abuse bills requiring quicker police and court involvement in
suspected cases of abuse and allowing Mr. Miller, Lt. Gov Pierre Howard - the
original sponsor of the bills - and other top officials access to previously
closed child abuse files.

A measure requiring the Commissioner of Corrections to notify crime victims when
their assailants are released.

Legislation that authorizes the funding for a resort in Mr. Miller's native
Towns County.

Two bills that give purchasers of equipment for the disabled the right to return
defective merchandise. One applies only to motorized wheelchairs and scooters;
the other includes other devices. By signing both bills, Mr. Miller raised the
question of which would take effect.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH931290196

                    Copyright 1993 The Atlanta Constitution


                              855 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                          December 17, 2008 Wednesday

US to extend $ 115 million to Pakistan under Food Aid Programme

LENGTH: 278 words


ISLAMABAD: Pakistan and United States of America here on Wednesday inked US $
115 million agreement under Food Aid Programme.  An agreement for the provision
of 50,000 MT of soft white wheat to Pakistan worth US $ 18 million was signed
here at Economic Affairs Division (EAD) this afternoon.

The transportation charges of the donated wheat would also be borne by the US
government.  Farrakh Qayyaum, Secretary EAD and Ms.Anne W.  Patterson Ambassador
of the USA to Pakistan signed the agreement on behalf of their respective
governments.  The donation has been made under the US Department of Agriculture
food for Progress Act administered by the Foreign Agriculture Services.

The fund generated under this program would be used to support private sector,
development of agriculture such as improvement of agricultural techniques,
marketing  system,  farmers education and development of agriculture related
business.

Secretary Ministry of Food and Agriculture Zia ur Rehman was also present on the
occasion.  Speaking on the occasion, Secretary EAD Farrukh Qayyum thanked the
government of the USA for providing assistance in cash and kind.

He also disclosed that under the Credit Guarantee Program (GSM), US government
would also provide a soft loan of US $ 100 million and negotiation in this
regard have been almost finalized.

He added this is a two and half year program and in the first phase US $ 50
million would be available to Pakistan. Zia ur Rehman said that the commodity
would be monetized and sold on Rs.750  per 40 kg in the local market. He added
that the funds of the wheat would be utilized for the development of agriculture
sector in the country.

LOAD-DATE: January 8, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                      Copyright 2008 The Balochistan Times
                              All Rights Reserved


                              856 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)

Federal aid to farmers, poor

SECTION: News; A12

LENGTH: 118 words


President Bill Clinton released $55 million in U.S. aid to help residents of
nine states cope with the heat. The money, provided under a program that is used
more often to help low-income people pay for heat during the winter, may be used
to buy air conditioners, fans and other relief. In West Virginia, U.S.
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman issued the declaration of aid for 89 counties
in Kentucky, Maryland, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia and West Virginia -
including some of the states receiving air-conditioning relief. The order, which
likely will be expanded in the coming days, makes farmers who have lost at least
30 per cent of a crop eligible for low- interest federal loans.


LOAD-DATE: August 4, 1999

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: P Photo: TOM MIHALEK, AFP / John Rigolizzo, a third-generation farmer
in Berlin, N.J., stands in a field of drought-stunted corn yesterday. He
estimated that the lack of rain this year in the eastern United States has
destroyed 75 per cent of his farm's corn crop.

                              857 of 999 DOCUMENTS



                                US Official News

                           December 3, 2016 Saturday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri)
Issues Solicitation for "Purchase of Empty Bags for U.S. Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 271  words

DATELINE: New York


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Purchase of Empty Bags for U.S. Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: 12-1NFE-17-S-0007

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: December 2, 2016

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation 12-1NFE-17-S-0007 (2000004445) for 50kg empty
woven polypropylene bags to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Delivery basis is FAS Vessel at U.S. Gulf.


The solicitation is expected to be available on or after December 2, 2016, and
will be available electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain
Management (WBSCM) system located at
https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a link to the
aforementioned website in the document package attached to the solicitation
notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website (http://www.fbo.gov).
A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for the acquisition. All
future information regarding this acquisition, including solicitation amendments
and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM and FBO. Interested
parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the most up-to-date
information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of receipt for offers
will be on or near December 6, 2016.

Set Aside: N/A

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 314

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205 Mail Stop 8698 Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s): Julie Stephen, Agricultural Marketing Specialist
julie.stephen@kcc.usda.gov Phone: 816-926-6524


LOAD-DATE: December 4, 2016

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newswire

https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a link to the
aforementioned website in the document package attached to the solicitation
notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website (http://www.fbo.gov).

future information regarding this acquisition, including solicitation amendments
and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM and FBO. Interested
parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the most up-to-date
information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of receipt for offers
will be on or near December 22, 2015.

LOAD-DATE: February 24, 2017


                              869 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                           January 25, 1997 Saturday

LENGTH: 194 words


FARGO (AP) -- The federal government has extended the deadline for ranchers who
have lost cattle to apply for emergency aid, Sen. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D., said
Friday night. The Agriculture Department approved a special emergency aid
package last week that includes reimbursements to cover feed costs. But the
program is still set to expire today, Dorgan said. Dorgan and Sen. Tom Daschle,
D-S.D., talked by phone Friday with Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman and urged
him to approve additional aid to farmers and ranchers in the Midwest. ""He has
decided that late filed requests for emergency feed assistance will be
accepted,'' Dorgan said. ""That's helpful, but we're asking for more than that.
We're asking that they extend the event period.'' Dorgan said no specific
application deadline has been set, but the USDA wants ranchers to file them in a
timely manner. A rash of blizzards has left thousands of cattle dead in the
Midwest, and even more in danger of dying because ranchers can't get feed to
their animals or have run out of feed. Dorgan said he and Daschle asked Glickman
to expand the aid to include other hardships farmers and ranchers might face.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2006

                                US Official News

                           February 18, 2016 Thursday

Head Line: US Federal Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture (Missouri)
Issues Solicitation for "Purchase of Empty Bags for U.S. Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 273 words

DATELINE: Lahore


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Purchase of Empty Bags for U.S. Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: AG-INAE-S-16-0028

Notice Type: Solicitation / Cancelled
Posted Date: February 17, 2016

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AAG-INAE-S-16-0028 (2000003892) for 50kg empty
woven polypropylene bags to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Delivery basis is FAS Vessel at U.S. Gulf.


The solicitation is expected to be available on or after February 12, 2016, and
will be available electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain
Management (WBSCM) system located at
https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a link to the
aforementioned website in the document package attached to the solicitation
notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website (http://www.fbo.gov).
A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for the acquisition. All
future information regarding this acquisition, including solicitation amendments
and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM and FBO. Interested
parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the most up-to-date
information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of receipt for offers
will be on or near February 16, 2016.

Set Aside: N/A

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 314

United States

                              872 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The Washington Post

                      May 4, 2000, Thursday, Final Edition

Md. Farmers to Receive Federal Aid; Money to Compensate for Low Prices, Drought
Damage Could Total $70 Million

Lori Montgomery; Jennifer Lenhart , Washington Post Staff Writers

SECTION: WEEKLY - MD; Pg. M01

LENGTH: 531 words



Maryland farmers could receive an estimated $ 70 million in federal aid--more
than three times the amount paid two years ago--to compensate for low prices and
damage done by last year's drought, the worst Maryland has seen in a century,
federal agriculture officials said.

Much of the money has yet to reach the state's more than 12,000 farmers, most of
whom are expecting some form of federal assistance to help them recover from a
double calamity in 1999--when the worst year in a five-year dry spell slashed
crop production in Maryland while good yields in the Midwest kept crop prices
low.

"Our farmers are hurting badly," said Tom Shockley, executive director of the
Maryland office of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency.

Federal officials could not say how much they expect to pay out in Virginia this
year. To date, Virginia farmers have received $ 14.6 million for crops that
failed in 1999, almost all of which went to farmers whose crops were damaged by
the drought, said Donald Davis, executive director of the Farm Service Agency in
Virginia.

Payments also were distributed to farmers who lost crops to flooding, with
farmers in southeast Virginia filing the bulk of those claims.

In August, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman declared much of Maryland and
Virginia and all of West Virginia disaster areas because of prolonged heat and
drought. Every one of Maryland's 23 counties reported damage to crops and
livestock, while nearly all of the 84 Virginia counties that have farming
activity suffered losses.

"Not everybody did terrible last year. For grain growers, if you got a
thunderstorm at the right time it wasn't so bad," said Kevin McNew, an
agricultural economist at the University of Maryland. Soybean growers, for
example, were hit hard early, but they recovered when hurricanes dumped rain on
the state in September.

"But it was really terrible in Howard [County] and on west," McNew said. "Dairy
guys had to buy hay. And the livestock guys found it was cheaper to send beef to
market than to buy the hay to feed them."

Federal officials could not say exactly how many Maryland farmers would receive
payments as a result of the drought. But 11,200 of the state's more than 12,000
farmers have applied for payments under a USDA program that helps them pay back
loans when low crop prices slash their incomes.

Meanwhile, more than 1,000 farmers have applied for grants under a program that
helps farmers whose livestock died or whose production was reduced by drought.
More than 200 have applied for help reseeding ruined pastures. And nearly 3,700
have applied for crop disaster relief.

To qualify for disaster relief, farmers must show that their fields or livestock
yielded less than 65 percent of the amount expected for the year. The USDA will
cover about 70 percent of proven losses on the 1999 crop.

In Maryland, corn yields dropped from 109 to 93 bushels an acre statewide last
year, with nearly 50 precent reductions in some counties, according to state
agriculture officials. Soybean production fell as low as 30 bushels an acre,
state officials said; milk production was also down.


LOAD-DATE: May 04, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              874 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       St. Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                           August 30, 2006 Wednesday

Drought relief called stingy;
Little aid headed for Minnesota, Wisconsin despite dry cropland

BYLINE: TOM WEBB, Pioneer Press

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 1C

LENGTH: 427 words


The Bush administration offered $79 million of new drought aid for farmers
across 27 states, a proposal that left Minnesota critics angry at its
stinginess, and prompted even allies to call for more help.

"It's like spitting in a blast furnace and calling it a big deal," fumed Doug
Peterson, president of the Minnesota Farmers Union. "How dumb do people think we
are?"

The centerpiece of the administration's drought-aid program, announced Tuesday
by Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns, is advancing by several weeks $700
million in previously promised federal subsidies for cotton, peanut and sorghum
farmers. Yet Minnesota grows virtually no cotton, peanuts or even grain sorghum,
so hardly a dime of that early money would come here, despite a severe summer
drought in central and northern Minnesota. Wisconsin would be in an identical
situation.

Republican Gov. Tim Pawlenty applauded the announcement, citing in a statement
the package's $50 million for livestock producers. But Pawlenty added, "We will
continue to work with the federal government to provide additional relief."

The $50 million in livestock block grants would be split among the hardest-hit
areas, including Texas, Oklahoma, Nebraska and South Dakota, all major livestock
states.

Farm-state lawmakers in Congress and the Bush administration are at odds over $4
billion sought for disaster aid this year, and President Bush already promised
to veto an emergency spending bill that contained drought relief. That battle
will be rejoined when Congress returns from August recess.

Tom Buis, president of the National Farmers Union, saw one glimmer of hope.
"We're really appreciative that the secretary recognized that the disaster
victims need some assistance out there, but we're a little concerned that what
he had to offer was not much."

Johanns, on a drought tour of South Dakota, said Tuesday, "Today's actions
emphasize USDA's commitment to use every resource available to help farmers and
ranchers who are impacted by drought."

Meanwhile, many parts of Minnesota still are experiencing extreme drought
conditions despite recent rainfall.

State forecasters continue to put much of northwestern, north central and
central Minnesota in "extreme drought" classification.

Some surrounding areas are in the slightly lower "severe drought" category,
while northeastern Minnesota is classified as being in a moderate drought. The
southern quarter of Minnesota has no drought designation.

Associated Press reports were used in this story. Tom Webb can be reached at
twebb@pioneerpress.com or 651-228-5428.

LOAD-DATE: August 30, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                     Copyright 2006 St. Paul Pioneer Press
                              All Rights Reserved


                              875 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The Washington Post

                      May 4, 2000, Thursday, Final Edition

Drought Aid Could Reach $70 Million; Most of Md.'s Farmers Still Waiting for
Funds

Lori Montgomery; Jennifer Lenhart , Washington Post Staff Writers

SECTION: SOUTHERN MARYLAND EXTRA; Pg. M03

LENGTH: 531 words


Maryland farmers could receive an estimated $ 70 million in federal aid--more
than three times the amount paid two years ago--to compensate for both low
market prices and damage done by last year's drought, Maryland's worst in a
century, federal agriculture officials said.

Much of the money has yet to reach the state's more than 12,000 farmers, most of
whom are expecting some form of federal assistance to help them recover from a
double calamity in 1999--when the worst year in a five-year dry spell slashed
crop production in Maryland while good yields in the Midwest kept crop prices
low.

"Our farmers are hurting badly," said Tom Shockley, executive director of the
Maryland office of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency.

Federal officials could not say how much they expect to pay out in Virginia this
year. To date, Virginia farmers have received $ 14.6 million for crops that
failed in 1999, almost all of which went to farmers whose crops were damaged by
the drought, said Donald Davis, executive director of the Farm Service Agency in
Virginia.

Payments also were distributed to farmers who lost crops to flooding, with
farmers in southeastern Virginia filing the bulk of those claims.

In August, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman declared much of Maryland and
Virginia and all of West Virginia disaster areas because of prolonged heat and
drought. Every one of Maryland's 23 counties reported damage to crops and
livestock, while nearly all of the 84 Virginia counties that have farming
activity suffered losses.

"Not everybody did terrible last year. For grain growers, if you got a
thunderstorm at the right time it wasn't so bad," said Kevin McNew, an
agricultural economist at the University of Maryland. Soybean growers, for
example, were hit hard early, but they recovered when hurricanes dumped rain on
the state in September.

"But it was really terrible in Howard [County] and on west," McNew said. "Dairy
guys had to buy hay. And the livestock guys found it was cheaper to send beef to
market than to buy the hay to feed them."

Federal officials could not say exactly how many Maryland farmers would receive
payments as a result of the drought. But 11,200 of the state's more than 12,000
farmers have applied for payments under a USDA program that helps them pay back
loans when low crop prices reduce their incomes.

Meanwhile, more than 1,000 farmers have applied for grants under a program that
helps farmers whose livestock died or whose production was reduced by drought.
More than 200 have applied for help reseeding ruined pastures. And nearly 3,700
have applied for crop disaster relief.

To qualify for disaster relief, farmers must show that their fields or livestock
yielded less than 65 percent of the amount expected for the year. The USDA will
cover about 70 percent of proven losses on the 1999 crop.

In Maryland, corn yields dropped from 109 bushels to 93 an acre statewide last
year, with nearly 50 percent reductions in some counties, according to state
agriculture officials. Soybean production fell as low as 30 bushels an acre,
state officials said; milk production was also down.


LOAD-DATE: May 04, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2000 The Washington Post


                              876 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                               The New York Times

               August 20, 1983, Saturday, Late City Final Edition

STATES IN MIDWEST SEEKD DROUGHT AID



BYLINE:
By The Associated Press

SECTION: Section 1; Page 6, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 522 words


Missouri's Governor asked yesterday to have his state declared a disaster area
because of drought damage, joining Indiana in seeking Federal aid as experts
warned that the 1983 harvest of corn and soybeans in the parched Middle West
could be among the worst on record.

''Due to the extreme temperatures and drought conditions which Missouri has
experienced, the agricultural situation over the entire state has reached
disastrous proportions,'' Gov. Christopher S. Bond of Missouri said in a
telegram to Secretary of Agriculture John R. Block.

Gov. Robert D. Orr of Indiana earlier sought a disaster declaration to qualify
Hoosier farmers for special loans and other assistance.

''I think it's a crisis as of today with the continuation of this weather,''
Robert Lounsberry, the Agriculture Secretary of Iowa, said about the prolonged
heat wave and drought.

Corn Crop Held Endangered

''We have all the makings of a very serious disaster out there,'' said Gov.
Terry Branstad of Iowa, predicting sharp reductions in corn yields. ''Every day
we go without rain there's a substantial loss out there.''

''It's bad, real bad,'' said D. J. Merideth, a farmer in southeast Missouri.  He
predicted that only one-third of his 1,700 acres of soybeans would survive.

Secretary Block said he would spend part of the weekend assessing the losses on
his 3,000-acre farm in Illinois, where state officials were considering making a
request for a declaration of agricultural disaster. ''It probably won't be a
happy thing to see,'' Mr. Block said.

Harold Parrett, a farmer in Mohomet, Ill., had to count 56 consecutive corn
brown and barren plants before he found one with an ear. It was tiny and had few
kernels.

Corn Plants Fail to Produce

''There's just nothing on 80 percent of the corn,'' Mr. Parrett said. ''It won't
justify running the combine over it. We'll be lucky to average 10 bushels an
acre.''

In New York, Robert Loewy, a grain analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities
Inc., said that by harvest time ''the combination of heat and the lack of
moisture will have proven to be the worst of the century.''

Part of the drop in corn output will be a result of a Government production
control program called under which farmers were compensated with grain from
Government storage for taking about 20 million acres of corn out of production.

Water Emergency Declared

In Kentucky, Gov. John Y. Brown Jr. declared a state of emergency because of
drought and ordered Kentucky communities with water shortages to begin
conservation measures.

Governor Brown said the increased demand for water and lack of rain had combined
to create critical shortages.

He gave the state's adjutant general, Billy Wellman, the authority to call up
National Guardsmen and to use emergency funds.

Eight guardsmen will report Saturday for two days to help officials in the city
of Cynthiana, Ky., install pipe and a pump provided by the state to help deal
with a water shortage caused by low river levels.

Governor Brown also directed state officials to to provide local governments
with technical assistance and aid.


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: photo of cattle being kept cool in Nebraska

                   Copyright 1983 The New York Times Company


                              877 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                        Topeka Capital-Journal (Kansas)

                             August 9, 2011 Tuesday

Roberts: Additional drought relief on its way

BYLINE: The Capital-Journal

LENGTH: 332 words


U.S. Sen. Pat Roberts, R-Kan., called for additional aid to farmers dealing with
drought, and the U.S. Department of Agriculture listened, Roberts' office said
in a statement Monday.

Roberts, ranking member of the Senate Committee on Agriculture, Nutrition and
Forestry, called on the USDA to consider additional options to provide aid to
producers struggling from prolonged drought conditions.

As a result of discussions with the USDA, U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom
Vilsack announced Monday that the Farm Service Agency will modify Conservation
Reserve Program policies to provide further help to those affected by the
drought.

"I am pleased to have worked with USDA to act immediately to bring additional
relief to farmers and ranchers across the country battling drought," Roberts
said. "Given the extreme conditions out there, the changes in policy just make
sense."

According to USDA, the policy changes are as follows:

FSA is permitting farmers and ranchers in drought-stricken areas of Colorado,
Kansas, New Mexico, Oklahoma and Texas to extend the emergency grazing period
from Sept. 30 to Oct. 31 without an additional payment reduction. Producers
wishing to participate in emergency grazing must first request permission from
the FSA county office by indicating the acreage to be grazed.

As a second condition designed to help producers, FSA will allow producers
nationwide to utilize harvested hay from expiring CRP acres when those acres are
being prepared for fall seeded crops. Before this modification, all mechanically
harvested hay was required to be destroyed. This change enables producers to
feed the hay that is mechanically harvested to their own livestock or to sell or
donate hay. Rental payments will be reduced by 25 percent for those utilizing
this option, consistent with existing policy for managed or emergency haying and
grazing of eligible CRP acres.

"I will continue to work with USDA and FSA to ensure every resource is available
to those in need," Roberts said.

                              878 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                             Daily News (New York)

                            January 26, 2003, Sunday

NEWS FROM HOME

SECTION: SUBURBAN; Pg. 11 RUSSIAN BEAT

LENGTH: 359 words

Signs of slowdown

MOSCOW - Russian companies' investment in productive capacity last year was less
than a third of the 2001 rate, indicating the country's economy may slow this
year for the third straight year.

Investment grew 2.6% last year to 1.66 trillion rubles ($52 billion), the State
Statistics Committee said in a report. In 2001, investment rose 8.7%.

"Russia is certainly slowing down, and demand for investment is slowing down as
well," said Alexei Zabotkine, chief economist at United Financial Group.

Frost damage

MOSCOW - Russia's grain harvest may fall 25% this year because severe frosts
damaged some plants sown in September and October for the spring crop, Interfax
reported, citing Agriculture Minister Alexei Gordeyev.

The harvest may fall to as low as 65 million metric tons this year, down from a
record 86.5 million tons in 2002, the news service said.

AIDS prognosis

WASHINGTON - The spread of AIDS in Russia threatens to cut as much as 10% from
the country's economy by 2020, and the Russian government is underestimating the
problem, the World Bank said.

"There is a problem of the AIDS epidemic emerging in Russia, but there has been
a reluctance to discuss it," said Christof Ruehl, the bank's chief economist for
Russia, which has the world's fastest-growing AIDS epidemic. The bank said
between 5 million and 14 million people there will be infected with the virus
over the next two decades.

Race winners

ANTERSELVA, Italy - Russia beat Germany by more than 30 seconds for its third
victory in six races in a women's 24-kilometer World Cup biathlon competition
Friday.

Belarus finished third, 52 seconds behind the winner.

Stocks on uptick

MOSCOW - Russian stocks rose Friday, led by AO Yukos Oil Co., as investors
gauged recent declines in the country's second-largest oil producer were not
justified by the company's earnings outlook, traders said.

The Russian Trading System index advanced 0.6% to 343.31, rising for the first
time in six days. The RTX Index, which tracks the eight biggest stocks on the
RTS, gained 0.2% to 565.15, with three stocks rising, four falling and one
unchanged.

                               The Washington Post

                     May 11, 2000, Thursday, Final Edition

Md. Farmers to Get $70 Million in Aid

Lori Montgomery; Jennifer Lenhart , Washington Post Staff Writers

SECTION: PG EXTRA; Pg. M11

LENGTH: 531 words


Maryland farmers could receive an estimated $ 70 million in federal aid--more
than three times the amount paid two years ago--to compensate for low prices and
damage done by last year's drought, the worst Maryland has seen in a century,
federal agriculture officials said.

Much of the money has yet to reach the state's more than 12,000 farmers, most of
whom are expecting some form of federal assistance to help them recover from a
double calamity in 1999--when the worst year in a five-year dry spell slashed
crop production in Maryland while good yields in the Midwest kept crop prices
low.

"Our farmers are hurting badly," said Tom Shockley, executive director of the
Maryland office of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Farm Service Agency.

Federal officials could not say how much they expect to pay out in Virginia this
year. To date, Virginia farmers have received $ 14.6 million for crops that
failed in 1999, almost all of which went to farmers whose crops were damaged by
the drought, said Donald Davis, executive director of the Farm Service Agency in
Virginia.

Payments also were distributed to farmers who lost crops to flooding, with
farmers in southeast Virginia filing the bulk of those claims.

In August, U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman declared much of Maryland and
Virginia and all of West Virginia disaster areas because of prolonged heat and
drought. Every one of Maryland's 23 counties reported damage to crops and
livestock, while nearly all of the 84 Virginia counties that have farming
activity suffered losses.

"Not everybody did terrible last year. For grain growers, if you got a
thunderstorm at the right time, it wasn't so bad," said Kevin McNew, an
agricultural economist at the University of Maryland. Soybean growers, for
example, were hit hard early, but they recovered when hurricanes dumped rain on
the state in September.

"But it was really terrible in Howard [County] and on west," McNew said. "Dairy
guys had to buy hay. And the livestock guys found it was cheaper to send beef to
market than to buy the hay to feed them."

Federal officials could not say exactly how many Maryland farmers would receive
payments as a result of the drought.

But 11,200 of the state's more than 12,000 farmers have applied for payments
under a USDA program that helps them pay back loans when low crop prices slash
their incomes.

Meanwhile, more than 1,000 farmers have applied for grants under a program that
helps farmers whose livestock died or whose production was reduced by drought.
More than 200 have applied for help reseeding ruined pastures. And nearly 3,700
have applied for crop disaster relief.

To qualify for disaster relief, farmers must show that their fields or livestock
yielded less than 65 percent of the amount expected for the year. The USDA will
cover about 70 percent of proven losses on the 1999 crop.

year, with nearly 50 precent reductions in some counties, according to state
agriculture officials. Soybean production fell as low as 30 bushels an acre,
state officials said; milk production was also down.


LOAD-DATE: May 11, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 2000 The Washington Post


                              880 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     August 15, 1999, Sunday, Final Edition

More Debt Won't Help Farmers Hit By Drought

Marcella Bombardieri, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: SOUTHERN MARYLAND EXTRA; Pg. M01

LENGTH: 871 words



With Southern Maryland farmers expecting to lose 30 to 70 percent of their crops
this year, the disaster assistance loans made available last week by U.S.
Secretary of Agriculture Dan Glickman will be of little use to the region, said
farmers and state and federal agricultural officials.

The farmers most in need of drought aid are already so heavily indebted that the
U.S. Department of Agriculture's emergency loans are unappealing despite their
low interest rates, said Tom Shockley, state executive director of the Farm
Service Agency (FSA), the USDA branch that will administer the loans through its
county offices.

"As one man told me, if you're drowning in 10 feet of water, what is pouring two
more feet of water over your head going to do?" Shockley said. "To borrow more
money to get deeper in debt is not the answer to the problem."

Southern Maryland farmers instead need grants--not loans--from Congress, or else
some will be forced to sell their land to developers, said many in the
agricultural community.

Farmers in Charles and St. Mary's counties expect to lose a sizable chunk of
normal crop yields--45 percent to 50 percent of the corn crop, 50 percent of
soybeans, 70 percent of hay, 30 percent of tobacco and 40 percent of vegetables,
according to FSA projections. Expectations are a bit less dim in Calvert County,
where farmers anticipate losing 20 percent of corn, 30 percent of soybeans and
30 percent of the hay yield.

Most likely, only a handful of Southern Maryland farmers will apply for the
low-interest loans released last week by Glickman's disaster area declaration
for almost all of Maryland, said Amelia Farrell, acting director for the FSA
offices in Calvert and St. Mary's counties.

The loans are restricted to family farm operators who have been turned down by
commercial creditors, so only the most severely strapped farmers would be
eligible. And many of those would be loath to plunge themselves deeper in debt,
said Emily Wilson, assistant director of government relations for the Maryland
Farm Bureau, a farm industry group.

"These low-interest loans are by no means the saving grace," Wilson said. "It's
not going to pull the state's farmers out of the economic disaster they're
facing by any stretch of the imagination."

Another requirement for the emergency loans is that farmers must have suffered a
loss of at least 30 percent of an essential crop. The loans, currently at a 3.75
percent interest rate, are available at up to 80 percent of actual losses, with
a maximum of $ 500,000 of indebtedness. Farmers have eight months to apply, and
many will not know how much help they need until the fall or next spring,
Shockley said.

Grants from Congress are what would really boost Southern Maryland farmers, said
Maryland Department of Agriculture spokesman Don Vandrey. Last year, Congress
appropriated almost $ 2.4 billion for farmers who fell victim to drought and
other natural disasters. Vandrey hopes the federal government will consider
similar measures this year for the mid-Atlantic region.

In the meantime, the FSA has an array of other, smaller programs to aid farmers,
and Maryland Gov. Parris N. Glendening (D) is putting together a $ 3 million
state package to provide assistance with erosion-preventive crops, small grains,
water and livestock feed, Vandrey said.

State and federal aid, however, may not be enough to keep all of Southern
Maryland's farmers in business. Continuing drought and "devastatingly low"
commodity prices have created "a vicious cycle" of loss that could drive some
families to sell their land to developers, Wilson said.

Many farmers agree that this summer's nightmarish weather creates a temptation
to bow out of farming altogether.

"The developers are parked at the gates, ready to move in," said Charles County
farmer B.B. Kemp. "If farmers can't pay their taxes and can't pay their bank
loans, they're going to say, 'The hell with it.' "

Calvert County farmers Phyllis and Richard Horsmon have decided to sell 20 acres
of their 100-acre farm in St. Leonard. They would be even more desperate for
cash if they hadn't diversified their crops to emphasize such nontraditional
items as chrysanthemums, or if Richard Horsmon had not sought an outside
job--two steps that more and more farmers are taking to stay afloat.

"It's sad, but we have no choice," Phyllis Horsmon said about the sale. "The
farmer loves his land and wants to save it, but he also has to take care of
himself, his kids and his retirement."

Not everyone agrees that this year's drought will spell the end of local
farmers, or even that federal aid is a good idea. According to Richard Horsmon,
government programs can do farmers more harm than good by allowing them to sink
into too much debt and avoid hard choices about how to save money.

Horsmon's opinion is echoed by St. Mary's farmer Donnie Tennyson, who adds that
while farmers may like to complain, they know how to survive tough times.

"We're going to have to dip into our nest eggs [this year], but that's normal in
agriculture," Tennyson said. "Overall, I don't think we're going to see a big
exit from farming here locally. We're very durable people."

DATELINE: Lahore


WASHINGTON: Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency officer has issued
requirement for "Purchase of Empty Bags for U.S. Food Aid Programs"

Solicitation No: AG-INAE-S-16-0011

Notice Type: Solicitation
Posted Date: December 7, 2015

Description: The solicitation is expected to be available on or after December
7, 2015, and will be available electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply
Chain Management (WBSCM) system located at
https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a link to the
aforementioned website in the document package attached to the solicitation
notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website (http://www.fbo.gov).
A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for the acquisition. All
future information regarding this acquisition, including solicitation amendments
and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM and FBO. Interested
parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the most up-to-date
information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of receipt for offers
will be on or near December 9, 2015.

                              882 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       San Jose Mercury News (California)

               September 16, 1998 Wednesday MORNING FINAL EDITION

AID FOR FARMERS LOOKS STRONG IN HOUSE

BYLINE: Mercury News Wire Services

SECTION: FRONT; Pg. 8A

LENGTH: 175 words


The House signaled strong bipartisan support Tuesday for rescuing farmers from
their worst financial crisis in at least a decade. President Clinton, meanwhile,
warned that "thousands and thousands" of producers could go out of business
without government help. In a non-binding procedural move, the House voted
331-66 to use the budget surplus for the farm aid rather than requiring
politically impossible cuts in other government programs. The administration has
endorsed measures totaling $7 billion.

Farm income is expected to be down 15 percent nationwide and far more in some
states because of plunging grain prices, drought in the South and crop disease
in the Midwest. Wheat prices are down 30 percent from the average for the last
five years. How much aid Congress will provide this year and in what form are
still being debated. The Senate approved $500 million in July, but prices have
continued to fall and the Agriculture Department says that will not be nearly
enough. Monday, the Senate rejected an administration plan.

LOAD-DATE: October 18, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                            September 1, 1989 Friday

Comment on Polish aid spurs pork belly futures

BYLINE: REUT

LENGTH: 281 words

DATELINE: Chicago IL


Reuter
  CHICAGO
   Pork bellies rose after U.S. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said
a request from Poland for U.S. bacon was receiving prompt attention.

Chicago Board of Trade soybean futures also rallied after a private
forecaster predicted that an earlier-than-normal frost would cut into
yields.

Traders at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange scurried to buy pork belly
contracts - which they sold Wednesday for want of news on the aid plan -
when Mr. Yeutter said talks were ongoing.

"Nothing has been decided. It's on the front burner," he said,
confirming speculation that the issue of sending food help was under
review.

Poland has asked the United States and other nations for 700,000 tonnes
of food, including meat and grains.

Analysts said meat aid for Poland may not benefit everyone in the
United States. Shipping frozen meat to Europe would be costly, noted one
analyst: "Someone will have to pay for it. Either the consumer with higher
prices or the taxpayer."

Soybeans also posted reduced gains on conflicting talk at the Chicago
Board of Trade about a forecast for an early frost.

Traders said one analyst had predicted cold weather for the U.S.
Midwest, sparking a rally that fizzled when rival forecasters said frost
next week was unlikely.

"Our long-term outlooks don't show a big cold mass . . . strong enough
to produce frost," one meteorologist said.

In precious metal trading, unusually high stocks and negative sentiment
weighed on silver prices, pushing them toward the $5 (U.S.) an ounce
level.

The weakness in silver spilled over into the gold pit.

A strong U.S. dollar also depressed gold but it rebounded from a new
contract low as traders squared books before the Labor Day weekend.

LOAD-DATE: January 10, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              Journal of Commerce

                          September 9, 1987, Wednesday

CHEMICAL BRIEFS

BYLINE: From Wire and Staff Reports

SECTION: CHEMICALS/PLASTICS, Pg. 13B

LENGTH: 634 words


Cyanamid to Purchase

Revlon Lens Unit

WAYNE, N.J. - American Cyanamid Co. has agreed to purchase Revlon's intraocular
lens business, currently operating as the Coburn Professional Products Division,
for an undisclosed price.

The acquisition will broaden Cyanamid's participation in the ophthalmic segment
of the medical device market and will operate as part of the Storz Instrument
business, acquired by Cyanamid in 1986.

Revlon's intraocular lens business is headquartered in Clearwater, Fla., and
operates in the United States and a number of overseas markets.

Cyanamid is a research-based biotechnology and chemical company that develops
proprietary medical, agricultural, chemical and consumer products and
manufactures and markets them worldwide.

j Du Pont, CIC Canadian

Sign Explosives Deal

WILMINGTON, Del. - E.I. Du Pont de Nemours & Co. announced that CIC Canadian
Investment Capital Ltd., through its subsidiary, ETI Explosives Technologies
International, has signed a definitive agreement to purchase Du Pont's
commercial explosives business in the United States.

CIC also signed a similar definitive agreement to purchase the Canadian
explosives business of Du Pont Canada Inc. Du Pont Canada is a 73 percent owned
subsidiary of the Du Pont Co. Completion of the sales is expected during the
fourth quarter. Terms were not disclosed.

j Ga. Asks Hartz to Halt

Shipments of Blockade

ATLANTA - The Georgia Department of of Agriculture will ask Hartz Mountain Corp.
to voluntarily discontinue shipment into the state of their pet flea and tick
repellent, Blockade, and consider adding precautionary language to the label
following reports of pet deaths and illnesses in Georgia.

Commissioner of Agriculture Tommy Irvin said a certified letter will be sent to
the company asking that a representative meet with department officials to
discuss labeling on the product. "It is our hope they would voluntarily meet
with us to find precautionary language which could be added to the Blockade
label in hopes of eliminating the alleged problems with this product."

EPA officials told state Agriculture Department officials that next week they
probably will direct Hartz to provide additional research data, and likely will
require supplemental label warnings to be placed on Blockade containers while
EPA reviews the new data.

j Six Groups Get Grants

For AIDS Projects

NEW HAVEN, Conn. - Yale University has been awarded a $ 1 million grant from the
National Institute of Health for research in developing a drug to combat AIDS.

The Yale research group is one of six being financed by the federal institute.
Others are the University of California at San Francisco and at Los Angeles,
Harvard University, Agouron Pharmaceuticals Inc. and SmithKline & French
Laboratories Inc.

The Yale project will focus on subcellular research to understand the chemical
structure ofAIDS virus proteins in order to develop drugs to block the protein
from either infecting or growing within healthy human cells.

j NJ Residents Oppose

Hazardous Waste Plant

TRENTON, N.J. - More than half of New Jersey's residents would oppose the
construction of a toxic waste treatment plant in their communities, and
one-fourth said they would move if the plant were built in their town, according
to a local newspaper poll.

The Star-Ledger-Eagleton Poll showed that more than one in three New Jersey
residents would either contribute to a legal defense fund or take part in a
peaceful protest to stop construction of such a facility.

The state is looking for sites to build one above-ground hazardous waste storage
plant and one or two hazardous waste incinerators.

Forty percent of the respondents said they would help pay court and attorney
fees to halt such a project.

LOAD-DATE: January 8, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE: CHEMICAL BRIEFS

                  Copyright 1987 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              886 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     The Leader-Post (Regina, Saskatchewan)

                             August 30, 2004 Monday
                                 Final Edition

Mitchell argues case in U.S.

BYLINE: Canadian Press

SECTION: BUSINESS & AGRICULTURE; Pg. B4

LENGTH: 691  words

DATELINE: NEW YORK


NEW YORK (CP) -- Canadian Agriculture Minister Andy Mitchell came away
empty-handed Saturday after arguing the case for reopening the Canada-U.S.
border to live cattle exports in a meeting with his American counterpart.

Mitchell travelled to New York City specifically to meet U.S. Agriculture
Secretary Ann Veneman face to face for the first time and described her as "very
businesslike" as they discussed the mad cow crisis that has been crushing the
Canadian cattle industry for 16 months.

In a brief interview after the meeting, Mitchell said he argued the Canadian
case based on science, but it wasn't clear how well his position was received by
Veneman, in New York for this week's Republican convention.

"She indicated to me she wanted to see the regulatory process moving forward in
the States," to speed up resolution of the situation, Mitchell said.

The fact that Washington is moving so slowly toward reopening the border makes a
"made-in-Canada" solution all the more important, he added.

"It's clear there's no specific end dates to the American review process."

The United States and other countries closed their borders to Canadian beef
exports after a single case of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or BSE, was
discovered in May 2003 on a farm in northern Alberta.

The U.S. started allowing some cuts of beef across the border last September,
but continues to ban imports of live Canadian cattle, creating a backlog of beef
and driving down prices.

Another case of BSE was found last December in a cow in Washington State, which
has complicated matters for American ranchers threatened with the loss of some
of their own markets, such as Japan.

But some Canadian producers suspect part of the reason the U.S. seems to be
dragging its heels on resolving the border issue is to protect its own beef
industry.

Industry groups such as the Canadian Cattlemen's Association have developed
long-term plans for coping with the mad cow crisis, which include emergency cash
aid from governments as well as initiatives for boosting slaughter capacity,
loan guarantees and market expansion to reduce reliance on the U.S.

Some of those have captured Mitchell's imagination as a way to help cope with
the border closure.

In Saturday's meeting, Mitchell said he underscored the importance of moving the
rule to readmit live cattle beyond the review process, where it has been stuck
since April, as the delay is causing "significant disruption" to Canadian
producers.

"She (Veneman) basically said that she wanted to make sure that the decisions
they undertook would not be challenged," Mitchell said.

"I said I understood that, but stressed the importance of that taking place
quickly."

Dennis Laycraft, executive vice-president of the Canadian Cattlemen's
Association, says the U.S. Department of Agriculture has had plenty of time to
test the immunity of the proposed rule against legal challenges.

Laycraft said the department should file the rule with the Office of Management
and Budget.

"At least that moves it to the second level and the clock starts ticking there,"
he said, noting the agency will have either 60 or 90 days to make a decision,
depending on what designation it gives the rule.

Ottawa has started to drop broad hints that as the crisis drags on, more
emergency aid could be coming for the cash-strapped industry.

Ralph Goodale, the federal finance minister from Regina, has been suggesting
recently that he might shake open Ottawa's piggy bank.

In March, at the time of the last federal budget, Ottawa announced a $1-billion
farm-aid package that included $680 million in relief for cattle producers.

That also included a pledge from Goodale of more help if the border remained
closed "for a protracted period."

Goodale has recently repeated that pledge to help cope with mad cow -- "a
serious issue not just for producers but a serious issue for the country."

However, he hasn't said just how much aid might be made available.

"I'm not in a position now to put a dollar figure on the situation," said
Goodale.

"But we've got to be prepared to stand by our producers through this incredibly
difficult period which is not at all of their making."

LOAD-DATE: August 30, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DOCUMENT-TYPE: Business

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


Copyright 2004 CanWest Interactive, a division of CanWest Global Communications
                                     Corp.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              887 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                 March 12, 1999, Friday, FIVE STAR LIFT EDITION

DRY WINTER RAISES FEARS ABOUT DROUGHT IN TEXAS;
BUSH DECLARES EMERGENCIES IN MOST OF STATE IN ORDER TO GAIN FEDERAL AID

BYLINE: The Associated Press

SECTION: NEWS, Pg. A5

LENGTH: 357 words

DATELINE: AUSTIN, TEXAS


Gov. George W. Bush declared an emergency in two-thirds of the state Thursday
amid worries that the unusually dry winter may give way to a summertime drought
more ruinous than last year's.

The emergency declaration in 167 of the state's 254 counties makes Texas
eligible for federal aid, which Bush said is needed to pay for the movement of
firefighting equipment to areas that may soon need it.

"I think we ought to pray for rain," Bush said.

Last year, bone-dry weather turned the Texas landscape into a tinderbox,
sparking more than 10,000 wildfires. The drought devastated the state's major
crops. More than one-fourth of the corn crop was lost, two-thirds of the cotton
and hay shriveled up and close to half of the sorghum, used primarily as animal
feed, died.

This year is looking like it could be worse.

The state has had way below-normal rainfall since the first of the year,
according to Carl Anderson, agricultural extension economist at Texas A&M
University. Last year, the drought began in early March.

"Agriculture is truly in peril," said Texas Agriculture Commissioner Susan
Combs. "They simply cannot make it when you have drought coupled with low and
falling prices."

She added: "I hope that weather forecasts for continued dry and warm weather in
Texas are proven wrong."

The Texas Forest Service said fire danger is increasing across Central and West
Texas, much of which never recovered from last year. The wildfire potential
already is greater in parts of West Texas and the Panhandle than it was in May
1998, the service said. In addition, spring winds are further drying out grazing
lands.

If a drought materializes, it will be the third in four years for the nation's
second-largest state.

"We're at the same point today that we were in May and June last year," said
Forest Service Director Jim Hull, who described conditions as "desperate."

Farmers and ranchers, still struggling from last year, are reporting problems.
Boll weevils, beetles that destroy cotton, are proliferating because farmers
cannot pay for eradication. And hay for livestock feed is in short supply.

LOAD-DATE: July 8, 1999

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: PHOTO Photo from the ASSOCIATED PRESS - A farmer near Veribest, Texas,
prepares his land for winter planting. Gov. George W. Bush declared an emergency
in 167 of the Texas' 254 counties because of an abnormally dry winter.

                         Star Tribune (Minneapolis, MN)

                            September 1, 2006 Friday
                                 Metro Edition

Ranchers hurt by drought may get aid;
The state could hear today how much of a $50 million federal relief fund that
affected livestock farmers can expect to see.

BYLINE: Matt McKinney, Staff Writer

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 1D

LENGTH: 503 words


Minnesota's drought-stricken livestock farmers may get a bit of federal rain
today: The state is expecting to learn how much of a $50 million pot of U.S.
Department of Agriculture (USDA) relief will come to cattle ranchers who have
seen some of the hottest, driest weather on record.

The hot weather had some ranchers selling their cattle prematurely, or even
selling entire herds, as hay and water supplies dried up, said Chuck Feikema,
president of the Minnesota State Cattlemen's Association.

"Up in the northern part of the state it's going to be a benefit to them, but is
it going to recoup all of their losses? Probably not," Feikema said.

The USDA is expected to send a letter to Gov. Tim Pawlenty today outlining how
much money will come to Minnesota and the conditions for distributing it to
livestock farmers.

The aid comes as part of a broader $780 million package made up of accelerated
payments and new and unused funds announced this week by U.S. Agriculture
Secretary Mike Johanns.

About $700 million of the package comes from a government hedge against bad
weather and low market prices that would have gone to the farmers anyway, but at
a later date.

The package drew fire from Democrats and from some farm groups who called it too
little to help farmers.

"I don't think this is going to do a thing in my district," said U.S. Rep.
Collin Peterson, D-Minn. He said the state's farmers are still waiting for help
for crop losses last year because of flooding.

"The administration has been against it, and that's been our problem," he said.
Now, he said, "they're trying to make it look like they're doing something, but
the majority of the money is just an accelerated payment."

A USDA spokesman said the government will accelerate its counter-cyclical
payments to cotton, sorghum and peanut farmers, crops that are largely not grown
in Minnesota.

The office of U.S. Rep. Mark Kennedy, R-Minn., meanwhile, said the USDA will
accelerate payments to drought-stricken soybean farmers as well, but that could
not be confirmed by the agency or by a spokesman for the state office of the
USDA's Farm Service Agency.

Package `rings hollow'

"I hate to say it, this year is an election year," said Doug Peterson, president
of the Minnesota Farmers Union. The aid package "kind of rings hollow for me and
a lot of farmers," he said.

A dozen members of his group plan to travel to Washington this month to push for
more relief, he said.

It's an election-year problem that may not be resolved before the end of the
corn and soybean harvests, meaning after the polls close, state Agriculture
Commissioner Gene Hugoson said.

"That's one of the dilemmas right now: Nobody is sure how severe this is," he
said.

The state has asked that 36 counties be declared disaster areas, making them
eligible for low-interest loans for farmers and ranchers.

A few counties may be added, Hugoson said.

The drought has covered as much as two-thirds of Minnesota, primarily in the
northwest and central portions of the state.

Matt McKinney - 612-673-7329

LOAD-DATE: September 1, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                          Copyright 2006 Star Tribune
                              All Rights Reserved


                              890 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   Irish News

                                October 11, 2005

Business - Gordon Brown demands EU deliver fair trade at Catholic aid
conference;

SECTION:  Pg. 47

LENGTH: 339 words


Chancellor Gordon Brown has demanded action to "tackle the waste" of the EU
Common Agricultural Policy (Cap) as part of global efforts to deliver fairer
trade to the world's poorest countries.

Speaking last week, Mr Brown said achievements on increased aid and debt relief
following July's G8 summit would be undermined without progress on trade when
leaders from the world's richest nations meet in Hong Kong in December.

"As we prepare for and then resume the talks on world trade, our job, Europe's
job, America's job, is to be on the side of opening the markets of the rich to
the poorest of the world," Mr Brown told an audience in Edinburgh.

In the 40th anniversary lecture for the Scottish Catholic International Aid Fund
(SCIAF) at St Mary's Cathedral, he hailed the agreement to double aid to Africa
and the recent launch of the International Finance Facility for Immunisation,
which he said should save 10 million lives.

Mr Brown also pointed to progress on debt relief, in particular the multilateral
debt write-off for the world's poorest countries.

But he insisted that the "debacle" and "disappointments" of previous World Trade
Organisation (WTO) summits in Seattle and Cancun must be avoided in nine weeks'
time.

"The key to progress is progress on agriculture, for most of the world's poor
still depend for their livelihoods on farming," Mr Brown said.

"We must address the trade rules that not only prevent poor people from throwing
off the shackles of poverty, but shackle poor communities still further, and so
we must put an end to what people in the poorest countries rightly see as our
hypocrisy of developed country protectionism."

The Chancellor pledged to press for the conclusion of a trade deal that would
"completely open markets to exports from poorer countries".

"We must expose and tackle the waste of the EU Common Agricultural Policy and
our test at Hong Kong will be setting a timetable - 2010 - to end agricultural
export subsidies," Mr Brown said.

LOAD-DATE: October 11, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Marine
Cargo Discharge/Delivery Survey Services"

LENGTH: 208  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Marine Cargo Discharge/Delivery Survey Services."

Solicitation no.  AG-INTS-S-13-0003                   Posted on: September 29,
2014

Notice Type:  Combined Synopsis/Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 488

Description: The USDA requests proposals from responsible sources to provide
marine cargo discharge/delivery survey services in various countries. The
service will include surveys of containerized, and/or breakbulk, and/or bulk
food aid cargoes. Separate firm, fixed-price requirements contracts to provide
survey services for food aid shipments to Bangladesh, Benin, India, Ivory Coast,
and South Sudan are contemplated.

Set Aside: N/A

Deadline for All responses: Feb 11, 2014 10:00 am Central

United States

                              May 1, 2014 Thursday

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Marine
Cargo Discharge/Delivery Survey Services"

LENGTH: 207  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Marine Cargo Discharge/Delivery Survey Services."

Solicitation no.  AG-INTS-S-13-0003                   Posted on: May 01, 2014

Notice Type:  Combined Synopsis/Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 488

Description: The USDA requests proposals from responsible sources to provide
marine cargo discharge/delivery survey services in various countries. The
service will include surveys of containerized, and/or breakbulk, and/or bulk
food aid cargoes. Separate firm, fixed-price requirements contracts to provide
survey services for food aid shipments to Bangladesh, Benin, India, Ivory Coast,
and South Sudan are contemplated.

Set Aside: N/A

Deadline for All responses: Feb 11, 2013 10:00 am Central

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205
Mail Stop 8698
Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s):
Steve Yancey,
Commodity Program Specialist
steve.yancey@kcc.usda.gov
Phone: 816-926-1460
