                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                  AUGUST 12, 1999 Thursday CNEW JERSEY EDITION

N.J. FARMS: RECOVERY IS YEARS AWAY NOT ONLY IS THE DROUGHT'S TOLL ON CROPS
EXTENSIVE, BUT U.S. LOANS ARE DEPLETED.

BYLINE: Suzette Parmley and Melody McDonald, INQUIRER STAFF WRITERS

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 996 words


Anthony Grasso, a 36-year-old peach farmer in Elm in Camden County, has very
little to show for his labor in this year's harvest. With the drought and heat,
he expects to gather maybe only 5 percent to 10 percent of the crop.

Grasso's wife, Lori, 35, is encouraging the couple's two children, ages 11 and
4, to seek higher education so they will have something to fall back on should
they choose their father's shaky profession.

"It's a tough career," said Lori Grasso, who keeps the books for the
family-owned farm, which of late has had nothing but mounting expenses, such as
$125,000 for fertilizers and chemicals. "My husband doesn't feel like there is
much of a future in farming."

More than extensive crop damage is at stake as the drought continues its drain
on the state's nearly $1 billion-a-year agriculture industry. With New Jersey
declared a farm disaster area Tuesday by U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan
Glickman, state officials said yesterday that it would take years to recover
from the drought's economic impact.

Another setback is that farm-loan programs in Washington have been depleted
because of the number of states that have applied for emergency assistance, due
to last year's drought in some areas and this year's.

All of Connecticut was declared a farm disaster area yesterday, along with 19
counties in Maryland, six in New York, five in Virginia, and one in New Mexico.
West Virginia was designated a farm disaster area last week, as were 87 counties
in Ohio on Tuesday.

In Pennsylvania yesterday, Gov. Ridge again appealed to Glickman to declare his
state a farm disaster area. Because 34 counties in New York were designated
disaster areas Tuesday along with 19 in New Jersey, 10 adjacent Pennsylvania
counties became eligible for federal low-interest loans.

Politicians in New Jersey and Pennsylvania asked Congress this week to
distribute grants and direct cash payments in addition to federal low-interest
loans to drought-stricken farmers. Grants and such payments would not have to be
paid back.

But officials at the U.S. Department of Agriculture said yesterday that the
back-to-back drought years had depleted their coffers. The agency spent its
entire fiscal 1999 budget of $287 million for emergency loans by June.

"Right now, we have no emergency loan money to distribute," said Carolyn
Cooksie, department administrator for farm-loan programs at the Farm Service
Agency. "We fund on a first-come, first-serve basis, and because of
weather-related disasters in '98 and '99, there's not a penny left."

Cooksie said her agency would appeal to Congress for additional funding because
it still has a backlog of applications from last year's drought, which wiped out
farmers in several Western and Southwestern states.

While there are no dollar figures on this year's crop damage in Pennsylvania,
the National Agricultural Statistics Service of the USDA has estimated that only
12 percent of the state's corn crop and only 1 percent of its pasture land are
in good condition.

In New Jersey, farmers are enduring financial hardships not seen 20 years. State
officials are estimating that damage to the state could reach $500 million
before the drought is over.

"Every day that this goes on, the losses grow exponentially," said a somber John
Rigolizzo Jr., president of the State Farm Bureau. "It's really stark. You see
burned-up fields up and down the state, just like toast."

Hay and field crops have nearly been destroyed by the dry spell and heat,
Rigolizzo said.

Fruit and vegetable growers have lost 25 percent to 50 percent of their crops,
he said, while grain and forage farmers have lost about half of their acreage to
the drought.

Rigolizzo said the conditions were so bad that it could take five or six years
before new peach and apple trees start producing fruit.

Farmers are already knee-deep in debt from last year's dry conditions, and
Rigolizzo said many had approached him about possibly asking lending
institutions to adjust their policies to take natural disasters into
consideration.

"Government works very slow," he said. "With [federal] assistance programs, it's
like a slow death. We need different forms of help. There are guys out there who
haven't received last year's aid. Now is the time to be looking for grants."

Virgil Eachus, a grain and dairy farmer who runs Wellacrest Farms Inc. in
Mullica Hill, will need at least $150,000 to break even this year. He is
ineligible to apply for federal loans, saying he is maxed out. "You can only
borrow so much," he said.

Eachus, 61, is counting on disaster-aid grants to get him through the year. The
fourth-generation farmer milks 300 cows and farms 1,500 acres of corn and
alfalfa, used mainly to feed the cows. This year, he won't have enough grain to
feed the cows and will have to buy corn to sustain his herd.

"We plant 930 acres of corn, and it is all burned up," he said. "It was too hot
to pollinate, and it didn't make any grain."

Severe weather and mounting debt have left Paul Hlubik, 39, disillusioned. He
farms more than 1,000 acres of grain and hay in Burlington, Monmouth, Mercer and
Ocean Counties. He said that 350 acres of crops were dead and that the rest were
producing about a third of what they normally would. He estimates he has lost
$100,000 to $200,000.

Making matters worse, Hlubik has found himself at an "unfair disadvantage" in
qualifying for federal assistance. He must be denied by his regular lender
before he can apply for federal low-interest loans. His good credit is working
against him.

"I'm not saying that I'm not grateful for the loans, because I am," he said.
"But a low-interest loan is not for everyone. It's for those who have been
denied by their regular lender."

Hlubik is grateful for one thing: He doesn't have children.

"If I had kids, I wouldn't want them to farm," he said. "And now I know why my
mom always pushed me away from it."

LOAD-DATE: October 22, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              900 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                      June 24, 1994, Friday, Tampa Edition

Feeding minds, bodies

BYLINE: KARI K. RIDGE

SECTION: TAMPA TODAY; EDUCATION; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 648 words

DATELINE: TAMPA



Just because school is out for the summer, parents in Hillsborough County  don't
have to worry that their children will be eating non-nutritious snacks  or
nothing at all.

For the first time, this year many of the county's schools are providing  free
lunch and breakfast to summer school students as well as to children 18  and
younger who are not attending summer school. Parents whose children are  not
attending summer school registered their children last month.

"During the school year, many of these children receive free or  reduced-price
meals, but during the summer months, who feeds the children?"  said Bernadine
King, manager of the  social services department's summer food  program for
children. "If a child doesn't have the basic foods to thrive,  there's going to
be bigger social problems down the road."

The school program is funded by a grant from the U.S. Department of  Agriculture
with money funneled through the Department of Education. It is  available to all
children at 81 schools participating in Hillsborough this  year. For a school to
qualify, at least 50 percent of the student body must be  eligible for free or
reduced-price meals during the school year.

Three junior highs, one high school and 77 elementary schools are providing  two
meals throughout the summer months - and jobs for 250 school cafeteria
employees. There are hot lunches such as pizza, chicken sandwiches and hot
dogs.

"The point is to make sure these kids are eating," said Mary Kate  Harrison,
director of food service for the county School Board. "If they  weren't getting
this service, many children would buy prepackaged foods with  empty calories on
their way home from school. We're providing nutrients and  reaching out to a lot
of kids who would normally be hungry."

Adriana Torres, a Town 'N Country mother, has brought her three children to
Dickenson Elementary School several times for breakfast and lunch since the
program began last week.

"With three children, I don't have time to cook hot meals all the time,"  Torres
said, while cutting up 2-year-old Adam's pizza. "The meals here are  great. They
get something from all the food groups. And I feel good knowing  they're eating
right. It's definitely better than nothing or fast food."

Lou Diaz, assistant principal at Adams Junior High, said he often can  detect
children who show up for school who have not eaten breakfast.

"These are growing teenagers so they always appear hungry," Diaz said.  "This
program helps those kids that haven't eaten - or don't have the money  to eat at
school - to remain anonymous. At this age, a lot of students are  very
embarrassed to pull out a free meal card, and often they won't eat at all
because they don't want anyone to know. This makes all the kids equal."

Although the program is available to all children under 18 throughout the
county, the majority of participants so far are summer school students. These
students, along with five to 10 children at each school who are not enrolled,
consume about 30,000 lunches each day.

Lea Hernandez, a summer science/math teacher at Dickenson Elementary, said  it
is important for her students to eat in preparation for the daily lessons.

"This class focuses on experiments, hands-on lessons that students have to  be
up and around to do," Hernandez said. "By lunchtime they have exhausted  all
their energies from breakfast, and they need this extra boost. Without  this
program, most kids would just grab a bag of chips and a soda."

For more information about the summer food service program, call the school
nearest you or Hillsborough Co. Schools Food Service at 272-4126. In addition,
the Hillsborough County department of social services provides a free summer
food service for children at local recreation centers and parks. Call  276-2092.

                          The Monitor (McAllen, Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           September 3, 2009 Thursday

Farmers finally getting drought assistance

BYLINE: Jared Janes, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 494 words


Sep. 3--MISSION -- Chuck McDonald said it's the worst year he has had in three
decades of farming.

Hurricane Dolly swamped the Monte Alto farmer's land last year when he was
already reeling from dry conditions.

Right after he recovered from Dolly, this year's drought and high temperatures
combined to devastate his cotton and grain crops.

"You never can get the right weather at the right time," said McDonald, the
chair of Hidalgo County's Farm Service Agency committee. "You're dealing with
disaster after disaster."

Aid to the agricultural producers hurt by last year's hurricanes and this year's
drought has been slow to come despite the implementation of a standing disaster
trust fund in the 2008 Farm Bill.

The new program --the Supplemental Revenue Assistance Payments Program, or SURE
for short -- replaces disaster relief aid that was distributed on a case-by-case
basis, said Juan Garcia, the Farm Service Agency's state director.

Aid distributed in the old manner was often unreliable, but the U.S. Department
of Agriculture has been slow to implement the new programs the bill established.

U.S. Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Laredo, said assistance to farmers through SURE will
be available beginning in November.

Hidalgo and Webb counties have formal disaster declarations from the drought.
Starr, Zapata and Jim Hogg counties have pending declarations.

"The drought didn't start yesterday," Cuellar said. "It's been a while. The
assistance for farmers and producers needs to happen now."

In the Rio Grande Valley, the devastating drought has killed a fifth of the
acreage, with dryland crops faring the worst.

Valley crop losses alone are estimated at $10.4 million through the end of July.

Total losses for ranchers and farmers across the state are pegged at $3.6
billion.

The crop damage in the Valley has dealt a heavy blow to farmers who were already
hurting from Hurricane Dolly losses estimated at $20 million.

Tommy Guerra, who runs cattle on 5,500 acres of land near Roma, said the drought
is affecting ranchers as well.

Next week is a deadline to submit applications for assistance with
livestock-related losses attributed to the drought.

Guerra, one of about a dozen ag producers who met Wednesday with the state's FSA
director to get details on aid programs, said the drought has killed much of his
grass -- a rancher's main resource.

"It will be 100 (degrees) again next week," he said. "Grass can't grow at 100
degrees."

Jared Janes covers Hidalgo County government, Edinburg and general assignments
for The Monitor. He can be reached at (956) 683-4424.

To see more of The Monitor, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.themonitor.com. Copyright (c) 2009, The Monitor, McAllen, Texas
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                              902 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            August 7, 1993 Saturday

LENGTH: 516 words


WASHINGTON (AP) Ä Congress passed and sent to the White House on Friday a $5.7
billion spending bill to repair damage from months of flooding and heavy rain in
the Midwest. The measure also provides aid to farmers suffering crop losses this
year from the Southeastern drought and weather problems elsewhere. Approving the
measure by a voice vote, the House made only minor changes in the bill passed
Wednesday by the Senate.

The Senate accepted the House measure Friday on a voice vote without debate or
dissent. President Clinton was expected to sign it quickly. Clinton requested or
endorsed all the items in the aid package, which totaled only $2.5 billion when
he introduced it July 14 in waterlogged Des Moines, Iowa. The amount of aid has
steadily grown with the scope of the disaster, and will continue to rise as the
flood waters recede, exposing more damage to communities, homes, farms, highways
and livelihoods. Damage has been estimated at $12 billion. The loss to farm
production will become clearer next Wednesday when the Agriculture Department
issues its first corn and soybean production estimates based on field surveys
conducted this weekend. ""We've scattered money all over the world,'' said Rep.
William H. Natcher, D-Ky., chairman of the House Appropriations Committee,
urging the House to move quickly. ""These are our people and they're
suffering.'' Besides approving $2.3 billion in payments for crop losses, the
bill gives $2 billion for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the
front-line agency for aiding individuals and families. The bill provides funds
for repair of levees, highways and rail lines; temporary jobs in flood cleanup;
individual loans of up to $1.5 million for small businesses; and grants for
communities to rebuild. It offers a variety of other aid aimed at protecting
water supplies, safeguarding against epidemics and helping individuals repair
their homes and farms. Some of the spending that was approved will service
nearly $600 million in loans, bringing the total value of the aid to $6.2
billion. Because of the crop-loss provision added by the Senate, growers should
be able to collect the full amount of disaster payment under a formula contained
in the 1990 farm bill. The formula enables growers to collect about 42 cents on
each dollar of loss. Disaster spending bills since then, however, have limited
payments to farmers at 21 cents on the dollar. The $900 million in crop-disaster
payments will be borrowed from the Agriculture Department's Commodity Credit
Corp., rather than directly from the Treasury. The CCC continuously takes in and
pays out money, and Congress yearly appropriates more to cover shortfalls.
Supporters of the increased crop-loss payments say that higher corn prices
because of lost production will result in lower price support payments,
offsetting the cost of paying for crop losses. None of the spending will be
charged against the federal deficit because of the emergency. Still, lawmakers
complained that the bill begins to undo the $496 billion deficit reduction bill
the Congress approved this week.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       The Oklahoman (Oklahoma City, OK)

                             July 15, 2008 Tuesday
                                  City Edition

Despite visit, Panhandle aid in doubt

BYLINE: John David Sutter, Staff Writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 12A

LENGTH: 147 words


Gov. Brad Henry announced Monday he will visit the Panhandle on Wednesday.

But confusion remains as to what actually is being done to help those affected
most by the drought, which has drawn comparisons to the devastating Dust Bowl of
the 1930s.

In late May, local county officials sent letters to Henry asking him to request
a federal disaster declaration, which would bring low-interest loans and aid for
farmers. Many of them harvested dust instead of wheat this year or had to sell
off cattle because there was no grass for them to eat.

Since then, a number of politicians have advocated a disaster declaration and
the federal aid that would follow.

Oklahoma Agriculture Secretary Terry Peach said by phone that farmers and
ranchers in Cimarron and Texas counties are eligible for aid because they border
counties in the state of Texas that fall under a recent disaster declaration.

                              904 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                          The Herald-Sun (Durham, NC)

                            August 5, 1999 Thursday
                                 Final Edition

Senate approves $7.4 billion to aid farmers hurt by low prices;
Adding of money to Agriculture Department spending bill sets stage for
negotiations with House

BYLINE: By PHILIP BRASHER Associated Press

SECTION: INSIDE FRONT; Pg. A10

LENGTH: 658 words


WASHINGTON - The Senate on Wednesday approved $7.4 billion in assistance for
farmers hurt by depressed crop prices, setting the stage for negotiations with
the House.

Democrats and some farm-state Republicans wanted more money, including special
assistance for Eastern growers who are suffering through one of the region's
worst droughts this century.

GOP leaders beat back several attempts to fatten the package, but signaled their
willingness to consider adding money later during talks with the House.

"We think this is a very strong program. ... It's a strong commitment," said
Sen. Thad Cochran, R-Miss.

Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, said the Senate action should be a "clear signal"
to farmers and their bankers that help will be on the way this fall.

Gaylen Affield, who grows corn, soybeans and wheat near Fergus Falls, Minn., was
cheered by the Senate action. "The government has to do something here because
we can't produce at these prices."

On a 89-8 vote, the $7.4 billion money was added to an Agriculture Department
spending bill for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

The House didn't put any such assistance in its version of the bill, but Speaker
Dennis Hastert, R-Ill., said recently the House is "committed to taking decisive
action."

A House-Senate conference committee will negotiate the final shape of the
assistance package, with negotiations starting in September after Congress
returns from a monthlong recess.

Prices for corn, soybeans, wheat and other crops have slumped to lows not seen
by farmers in years, even decades in some cases, because of huge crops
worldwide. Federal farm subsidies already were expected to reach a near record
$16.7 billion even without the additional assistance Congress is considering.

Democrats unsuccessfully sought $500 million in disaster aid for
drought-stricken growers on the East Coast and Midwest farmers whose land is
flooded.

"We're going to have to have some money for disaster assistance," said Mary Kay
Thatcher, a lobbyist for the American Farm Bureau Federation.

The Senate's aid package includes $5.5 billion in direct payments to most
growers, a separate $475 million for soybean growers, $400 million in subsidies
for crop insurance, $328 million for tobacco growers and $325 million in
livestock assistance.

The measure also would double the cap on crop subsidies that an individual
farmer can receive from $75,000 to $150,000, a change sought by Southern
growers.

Earlier this week, Democrats had proposed a total of $11 billion in assistance
but conceded defeat after losing battles Wednesday afternoon over several
smaller packages.

"Throwing a short rope to someone who is drowning in deep water is a nice
gesture, but it's not a lifesaving gesture," said Sen. Byron Dorgan, D-N.D. "One
of the facts of life for us is that we don't control the Senate."

The debate became something of a referendum on the 1996 farm law, popularly
known as "Freedom to Farm," which scaled back production-based crop subsidies.
Democrats wanted to put the bulk of the disaster aid into raising crop
subsidies, but Republicans said that would appear to be undoing the 1996 law.

The eight senators who voted against the aid package were Republicans Phil Gramm
of Texas, Judd Gregg and Bob Smith of New Hampshire, George Voinovich of Ohio
and Connie Mack of Florida, and Democrats Russ Feingold of Wisconsin, Bob Graham
of Florida and Robert Torricelli of New Jersey.

In a separate move intended to boost farm exports, the Senate added a provision
to the spending bill requiring the president to get congressional approval
before including food or medicine in a trade embargo. The only exceptions would
be for governments deemed to be sponsoring terrorism, including Cuba, Iraq and
Libya.

"When the U.S. uses food as a diplomatic weapon, by imposing unilateral
agricultural embargoes against foreign leaders, it takes away from our farmers
their ability to sell their product," said Sen. John Ashcroft, R-Mo.

LOAD-DATE: August 20, 2004

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                      Copyright 1999 The Durham Herald Co.


                              905 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              The Washington Post

                     August 11, 1986, Monday, Final Edition

Talking Points;
$1 Billion In Drought Aid Spreads Thin

BYLINE: By Marjorie Williams

SECTION: First Section; A13

LENGTH: 956 words


The largest single item in the administration's drought relief package,
announced recently by Agriculture Secretary Richard E. Lyng, was $1 billion in
"advance deficiency payments" -- which represented a 10 percent boost in the
income subsidies sent farmers in advance under federal farm programs. In
announcing the package, Lyng said he was raising the payments in response to the
drought "because many of these farmers need payments now."

What Lyng didn't say, the Democratic-controlled House Agriculture Committee did:
that of the $1 billion, only $32 million, or less than 4 percent, will go to
farmers in the eight states that include counties designated as drought disaster
areas.

The largest chunk, $143 million, will go to farmers in Iowa, where it's been
raining billy-ho and farmers are near harvesting a bumper corn crop. Illinois,
with $96 million, is the next big winner.

There's nothing new here: the numbers just reflect the usual distribution of
farm subsidies, which are based on volume of production. The Southeast is a
relatively small producer of the major subsidized crops such as wheat, corn,
cotton and rice.

But some Democratic members of Congress felt that the Reagan administration was,
at the very least, disingenuous in the way it announced the drought aid.

"They're using it as filler to make it look like they're doing something," said
Rep. Glenn English (D-Okla.). "It's just not honest."

Daniel Amstutz, undersecretary of agriculture for international affairs and
commodity programs, said the aid had specifically been requested by officials of
drought states and denied that there was any intent to make it appear targeted
strictly to those areas.

"I can understand the confusion," Amstutz said. But "there's been no intent" to
confuse the issue.

A fatter drought aid package was approved Wednesday by the House, and a similar
measure has been approved by the Senate as an amendment to an unrelated bill.

Pecking Order . . .

Death and taxes are always with us, and parking controversies run a close third.

The latest fuss was touched off when the Space and Naval Warfare Systems Command
(SPAWAR, to its intimates), located in cramped Crystal City, decided on a new
plan for assigning parking spots. Henceforth, it announced, parking privileges
would be based on rank rather than tenure.

One problem raised by the new rule was that, with the exception of a very few
senior managers, the caste system sends civilians to the bottom of the heap.
When Rep. Patricia Schroeder (D-Colo.) began receiving complaints from longtime
employes who risked losing coveted parking spaces, she fired off an angry letter
to Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr.

"Why are military personnel more deserving of parking spaces than civilian
secretaries with young children who have been on the job for years?" she asked.

"It is my understanding," Schroeder continued, "that car pools are now
advertised by rank. With this new competitive policy, one would be crazy to
invite a lower grade employe to join a car pool."

Schroeder received a letter Wednesday from Chase Untermeyer, the Navy's
assistant secretary for manpower and reserve affairs, explaining:

"The principal objective of the revised instruction was to develop reasonable
criteria with which to balance the legitimate needs of both executive personnel
and carpools and to provide the necessary management controls to ensure
equitable distribution of the limited number of available parking spaces."

If only they'd said so in the first place.

Catch a Wave . . .

Following President Reagan's announcement last week of a major initiative
against drugs, Rep. Dan Burton (R-Ind.) decided to institute drug testing of his
staff.

Burton is apparently the third member of Congress start testing: Rep. E. Clay
Shaw Jr. (R-Fla.) volunteered his staff for testing in March, and Sen. Paula
Hawkins (R-Fla.) did the same in April. One member of Hawkins' staff reportedly
quit in protest, but Burton's test will be voluntary.

What if someone declines? "Well," said Burton, "I'd have a confidential talk
with them and ask them why, and take it from there. I don't think that I can
give you a clear-cut answer. But I'm not going to be using their employment as a
reprisal." He promises to keep results confidential.

Why test now? "I've thought about it for a long time," Burton said. "When the
president came out with a proposal to have himself and his Cabinet tested, I
said to myself, 'This must be the right time.' "

Burton said he has six or seven staffers in Washington, and the same number in
his home office in Indiana. He expects that all will cooperate, and plans to pay
for the tests himself.

The point, he said, is that "people who are admired by children have a
responsibility to set an example."

Lighten Up . . .

The August Award for Rhetorical Opportunism goes to the Center for Peace and
Freedom, a conservative organization that is lobbying in favor of the
president's Strategic Defense Initiative (SDI).

In a release advertising a rally on the anniversary last week of the atomic
bombing of Hiroshima, the group offered the following parallels:

In the first paragraph, SDI was urged in order "to protect America from an
accidental launch of Soviet nuclear missiles -- a possible 'military Chernobyl.'
"

In the second paragraph, the group promised to give a "Hiroshima award to
members of Congress who have been outspoken critics of the Strategic Defense
Initiative . . . 'in recognition of continual support for the policy of mutually
assured destruction, and the defenselessness of the American people.' " And in
the fifth graph, the release noted that the demonstrators "fear a nuclear 'Pearl
Harbor.' "

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                       Copyright 1986 The Washington Post


                              906 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                              July 23, 2006 Sunday

Headlines highlight wasteful programs;
Reports detail political silliness

BYLINE: ALAN GUEBERT

SECTION: AGRICULTURE; Pg. b4

LENGTH: 707 words


July has been a tough month for farmers and ranchers in the Washington Post. On
July 2 and again on July 18, the Post published lengthy investigative pieces on
the enormous cost, wanton waste and built-in silliness of today's federal farm
programs.

The Page One headlines of each related the worst-kept secrets of Capitol Hill
policy-makers and U.S. food producers alike: "Farm Program Pays $1.3 Billion to
People Who Don't Farm," announced the July 2 piece; "No Drought Required For
Federal Drought Aid," blared the later story.

Each then went on to document how the 1996 Farm Bill, often referred to as
Freedom to Farm, and the 2002 Livestock Compensation Act, or drought bill, sent
farm program billions to non-farming farmers, non-ranching ranchers and
non-drought-suffering "victims."

(The Post published another Page One expose on July 19 on the U.S. Department of
Agriculture's poor oversight of the 2003 drought aid program.)

Each also contained quotes from happy-to-get-the-cash surgeons, lawyers, widows
and rain-soaked producers who received the windfalls mostly because they knew of
the programs and were breathing.

"The livestock program was a joke. We had no losses," said a Texas dairyman in
the July 18 story. "I don't know what Congress is thinking sometimes." (We do
know what the Texan was thinking; he took the maximum $40,000 program benefit
because "You would be a fool not to.")

The USDA's explanation of the cost and waste is the essential, bureaucratic
truth: We didn't write the goofy laws, Congress did. We only write the goofy
checks.

Congress did, indeed, write Freedom to Farm and the 2002 drought-relief bills,
and shortly thereafter expanded both to aid not only those who farm and ranch
but also those who shape, till and harvest the political landscape.

Or, in a phrase, Congress itself. For example, when GOP bosses - mainly Karl
Rove - saw a chance in 2002 to unseat Tim Johnson, South Dakota's Democratic
senator, President Bush jetted west to use Mount Rushmore as a backdrop to
inform drought-suffering ranchers to cinch their belts "another notch" tighter
because no emergency aid would be forthcoming.

Congress, Rove and the state's ranchers were aghast. Shortly thereafter,
Congress reversed the presidential prediction and approved emergency drought
aid.

Ranchers, however, did not forget. Johnson was re-elected over Republican
challenger John Thune by just 400 votes.

It was a mistake not repeated when the White House set its sights on South
Dakota's other Democratic senator, Majority Leader Tom Daschle, up for
re-election in 2004. The farm-aid rules were loosened and the floodgates opened
as the Republican Congress began to irrigate - with your money - key
congressional districts and states where the GOP hoped to make political hay.

And did they ever.

In November 2004, Senate boss Daschle was dethroned by Thune. The GOP also
tightened its grip on many Great Plains House seats. In Texas, Dems were
"droughted out" - redistricted - by now-disgraced House fixer Tom DeLay. One of
the Texas casualties was Democrat Charlie Stenholm, the House Ag Committee's
ranking penny-pincher.

All this GOP largesse continues to carry a price for farmers and ranchers today.

First, it put farmers and farm programs on the Post's front page - and not
unfairly. After all, since the Republican-written Freedom to Farm in 1996 became
the guiding U.S. farm policy, farm spending has become a raging river.

In the 1980s, federal farm programs cost an average of $8.6 billion per year. In
the 1990s, including the first three years (1997-1999) of F2F, it was $10.4
billion per year. Since 2000, however, it has gushed to $18.1 billion per year.

Second, politicizing emergency farm assistance helps politicians as much as
farmers. The 2002 drought program, and its looser 2003 rules, led to a fat 2004
for farmers and ranchers but an even fatter year for Republicans who
strengthened their hold on the House and retook the Senate.

Echoes of that victory are heard yet today as severe drought again scorches the
High Plains. Because there are no political benefits - no winnable House or
Senate seats left in the area - House Republicans have killed any chance for
2006 drought aid.

Guebert's e-mail address: agcomm@sbcglobal.net.

LOAD-DATE: July 23, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                              June 27, 2008 Friday

Pa. Bill Aims To Aid Organic Farmers

BYLINE: Michael Yoder

SECTION: A; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 781  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


Roman Stoltzfoos got into organic farming more than 20 years ago not because it
was profitable but because he felt it was the right way to handle the land.

The Kinzers resident switched from conventional to organic farming in 1987 after
herbicides failed to clear up a weed infestation.

Today the proprietor of Spring Wood Farm said his dairy farm of 100 cows and 400
acres has turned into a lucrative operation, but he still feels he's saving the
farm for future generations of his family.

I'm doing what I believe in, and that's the main thing, Stoltzfoos said. I feel
good about what I'm doing, and I feel like the food that we're producing is
safer and better for my farm and my family.

Now members of the Pennsylvania Legislature are making a push to promote organic
farming across the state.

On Tuesday, the House Agriculture and Rural Affairs Committee advanced
legislation proposed by state Rep. David Kessler that would provide temporary
financial aid to farmers who choose to convert to organic agriculture.

Kessler, a Berks County Democrat, said H.B. 2347 is designed as a safety net to
help farmers through the switch to organic farming.

The transition period, which involves getting nutrients back into the soil and
increasing crop yields, can take up to three years, Kessler said.

Kessler said farmers could receive up to $20,000 per year to cover any lost
revenues during the switch. He said the funding formula is based on the last
three years of revenue on a participating farm.

The bill has been in the works for 10 months, said Kessler, who consulted with
farmers and scientists at the Rodale Institute in Berks County, which has been
working on organic and sustainable farming issues for 60 years.

Kessler said a switch to organic farming will improve the quality of water and
air in the state.

Up to 5.5. million acres of farmland are tilled in Pennsylvania, Kessler said,
and if farmers switched to organic no-till methods, it would be the equivalent
of removing 2 to 3 million cars from the state's roads.

Besides the environmental issues, Kessler said, there's no better way to
preserve farmland than to make it more profitable. He said having organic farms
close to large cities and large food markets such as New York City and
Washington, D.C., could be a boon for farmers.

A lot of other states are taking advantage of (the organic) market, and this is
a way for us to take advantage of the market, especially when we're not that far
away from large populations, Kessler said.

Not everyone is convinced a switch to organic farming is the complete answer for
the farming community.

State Rep. Gordon Denlinger, a member of the House Agriculture and Rural Affairs
Committee, said he voted against advancing the bill because its stated policy
direction of encouraging farmers to switch most farming to organic methods.

Denlinger, a Caernarvon Township Republican, said the benefits of organic
farming methods are still an open question, and he would rather let market
forces dictate whether farmers are willing to go organic.

I think there's a lot of merit in changing our farming practices and moving
toward the organic direction, but can we do that and still supply the quantities
of food that are needed for the masses? Denlinger said. That question is still
very much present in my mind.

Philip Landis, who helps run the 115-acre Meadow Run Farm outside Lincoln, said
he feels some people in the organic movement don't go far enough in caring for
animals.

Landis raises grass-fed beef and lambs on the farm, limiting the use of
fertilizers. He sells to markets and restaurants in Philadelphia, using the
niche market of grass-fed animals to remain profitable.

Landis said he has some philosophical differences with the organic movement,
saying many farmers believe that mimicking nature will provide the best product.
He said having access to other tools, including hormones to rehabilitate sick
animals, does not take away from the organic movement.

Stoltzfoos, who said he is experiencing terrific consumer support compared to
when he started 20 years ago, said niche markets of organic products have proved
to be a better income source for smaller producers.

His major concerns with legislation promoting organic farming, Stoltzfoos said,
are the possible overproduction of organic products and the switching by farmers
who see dollar signs rather than ethical reasons for going organic.

I think that a farmer that does this because he really believes it's a better
way and he should make a safer living and a safer product for the people that
buy it is a much better reason than getting in it because they are going to get
a free ride, Stoltzfoos said.

E-mail: myoder@lnpnews.com

LOAD-DATE: June 27, 2008

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                    December 22, 1995, Friday, ALL EDITIONS

Olympic Weekly;
210 DAYS;
EQUESTRIAN

BYLINE: Martha Woodham; STAFF WRITER

SECTION: STATE OLYMPICS

LENGTH: 801 words



No plan on ban, yet
Horse owner says parasite shouldn't keep Olympians away

A small brown mare with a black mane switches her tail and munches hay
contentedly in a pasture north of Atlanta. In her veins, she carries a parasite
that has put Olympics officials and U.S. horse owners at odds.

In Brussels, Belgium, recently, officials from the United States and U.S.
Department of Agriculture, ACOG and the International Equestrian Federation met
- but failed to agree - on the ban on horses testing positive for piroplasmosis,
the same disease the mare has.

The officials continue to hash out conditions under which infected horses would
be allowed to compete in the Games - and who would pay for implementing the
conditions. Georgia Commissioner of Agriculture Tommy Irvin estimates the cost
to quarantine up to 50 horses could be as much as $ 1 million, and no one yet
knows exactly how many Olympic horses are carriers.

"We are well aware that there is great concern," said Irvin, stressing that, to
him, the issue is the quarantine's cost. "The nicest thing that could happen to
us is that the price would be so high, they decided not to come."

Get facts before protesting

Horse owners fearing Olympic horses will unleash the sometimes deadly disease
into this country have been bombarding government officials, trying to keep the
infected international competitors out.

But the disease is already among them. Unaware of the controversy, Doctrina, a
championship mare valued at $ 40,000, lives in quarantine, where she has been
for the past year.

For two years before her disease was discovered, Doctrina traveled to horse
shows throughout the Southeast without infecting other horses. (The disease must
pass from a carrier horse like Doctrina to a tick, and then the tick must bite
another horse for the disease to be transmitted.)That's why her owner came
forward, hoping to offer a calm voice and stem some of the hysteria.

"I understand that it is easy to panic when there is disease, be it AIDS or
piro," said Sally Fuller. She said she wanted people to get the facts before
they protest the Olympic horses coming to the $ 20 million Georgia International
Horse Park.

Vets check up regularly

Fuller's horse is living in a tick-free environment with a companion horse.
Their pasture is surrounded by buffer pastures, and state and federal vets check
them regularly. During tick season, the mare is sprayed daily.

"If I really thought in my heart of hearts that this horse is a threat to my
other horses or to my neighbors' horses, I would hope that I could look at this
dispassionately," Fuller said. She and her husband agree that they would
humanely destroy the horse before risking others, but "we can't afford to lose $
40,000. Also, I happen to love her."

Fuller's horse, imported from a South American country where piroplasmosis is a
fact of life, probably was already infected when she entered the United States
in 1986. Somehow, the disease was not discovered at the Miami quarantine
station. After acquiring the horse in 1990, Fuller showed her and bred her
before discovering in a random veterinary test the mare had piro.

"This mare had been in contact with hundreds of horses at national shows," said
Fuller. Not one, she said, has contracted the disease.

Fuller vetoed treating Doctrina, now 13, opting to keep her quarantined instead.
The treatment, a kind of chemotherapy to kill the parasites, can have severe
side effects. Horses have a life span of 20 to 25 years.

"It has an element of danger," said Dr. Ralph Knowles of the Maryland Department
of Agriculture, considered an expert on piroplasmosis. One of few vets in the
United States who has seen the disease, Knowles frequently travels to Europe to
treat horses and supervised Fuller's case.

"It's toxic to the blood parasites and can be toxic to the horse," he said.
"It's not an easy treatment, and sometimes it has to be repeated."

Playing a numbers game

Knowles does not support waiving the ban on the Olympic horses. Not only are
there ticks in Georgia known to spread the disease, he said, there are other
ticks that have not been researched.

"I consider it a risk," Knowles said, adding that international riders and
grooms from countries where horses have immunity may not understand the serious
threat to American horses. They may not be careful about upholding quarantine
conditions, especially during the excitement of competition.

Knowles said waiving the ban is a numbers game. Quarantining one horse in North
Georgia is a lot easier than controlling dozens at the Olympics, he said, and
"we don't know whether there will be 50 horses that are carriers or 200."

But for now, at least one piro-positive horse lives in isolation in North
Georgia.

LOAD-DATE: July 18, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                           September 15, 2006 Friday
                                  City Edition

Ag states' lawmakers urge drought relief

BYLINE: JOSH SWARTZLANDER, For the Lincoln Journal Star

SECTION: B; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 316 words

DATELINE: Washington, DC


WASHINGTON - Rep. Tom Osborne on Thursday joined fellow lawmakers from
agricultural states in urging Congress to pass a disaster bill for U.S. farmers
and ranchers struggling through a prolonged drought.

Osborne, R-3rd District and a member of the House Committee on Agriculture, said
it was unlikely such a bill would pass before the midterm congressional
elections in November.

The only chance to get a disaster bill through would be to attach it to a larger
appropriations bill, he said. But lawmakers are running out of time, with
Congress scheduled to recess in two weeks.

"Our options are not many, if any," said Rep. Jerry Moran, R-Kan.

At Thursday's press conference on Capitol Hill, a bipartisan group of members of
Congress from Texas, Colorado, Kansas, Missouri, Oklahoma, Wyoming, Minnesota
and Nebraska pleaded for a nationwide disaster aid package worth at least $3
billion.

"We need to fire up everyone to work together," said Rep. Frank Lucas, R-Okla.

At the end of last month, Agriculture Secretary Mike Johanns pledged about $780
million to farmers and ranchers, including $50 million in drought aid to
livestock producers.

Osborne and other lawmakers said that isn't enough.

The lawmakers' case for more funding took a hit earlier this week, when the Ag
Department boosted its monthly forecasts for soybeans by 6 percent and for corn
by 1 percent.

Nebraska's corn crop forecast rose 3 percent over the August forecast, to 1.25
billion bushels. The forecast for soybeans rose 11 percent, to 240 million
bushels, from August to September.

Still, Osborne said, he talked recently with House Speaker Dennis Hastert to
keep the issue of struggling farmers on his radar screen.

"But they've got a lot on their radar screen - homeland security, Iraq," Osborne
said.

Josh Swartzlander, a University of Nebraska-Lincoln student, is an intern for
the Scripps Howard Foundation Wire in Washington, D.C.

LOAD-DATE: November 17, 2006

                              912 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                           Greeley Tribune (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            August 1, 2009 Saturday

USDA to aid dairy farmers

BYLINE: Bill Jackson, Greeley Tribune, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 554 words


Aug. 1--The U.S. Department of Agriculture, at the urging of several
Congressional members, announced Friday that it was coming to the aid of dairy
farmers who are in the middle of one of the worst crises in decades.

The USDA said it will be increasing the amount paid for dairy products through
the Dairy Product Price Support Program.

Les Hardesty of Greeley, chairman of the Dairy Farmers of America Mountain Area
Council, lauded the move and said he hopes it will lead to a reform in federal
dairy product pricing.

"This is temporary relief for the dairy industry nationwide that is hurting
badly," said Hardesty, who milks 650 cows northwest of Greeley. "It will help
out on the short term and hopefully give us time to work on long-term reform in
pricing within the industry."

The price increase, he said, will remain in effect for the next three months.

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said Friday the price increase will provide
immediate relief, helping to keep dairy farmers on the farm while they weather
what he called "one of the worst dairy crises in decades."

The USDA increased the price paid for nonfat dry milk by 12 cents a pound,
cheddar cheese blocks by 18 cents a pound, and price for barrels of cheddar
cheese by 18 cents per pound.

According to Sen. Michael Bennet, D-Colo., the increase in the support price
will have an immediate effect on the dairy farmers' bottom line. Temporarily
raising the price of the products increases the price that dairy farmers receive
for milk.

Hardesty said Vilsack and Congressional members "have been doing what they can
for what's best for dairy farmers and we appreciate that."

"Between falling commodity prices and continued concerns about the economy,
Colorado's dairy producers are feeling the pain," Bennet said in a press
release. He pointed out that agriculture is a vital part of the state's economy,
and "we need to do everything we can to make sure the industry remains strong."

The USDA estimates the move will increase the milk price received by dairy
farmers and should result in the government purchase of an additional 150
million pounds of non-fat dry milk and an additional 75 million pounds of
cheese.

According to Rep. Betsy Markey, D-Colo., the move will increase dairy farmers'
revenue by $243 million.

"This is great news for Colorado dairy farmers," she said in a press release.

The price of milk crashed late last year and dropped to some of the lowest
levels dairy farmers have seen in several years. The drop in price was driven by
several factors, including the world economy and recession. As a result, dairy
farmers have seen an average price of $4.80 per 100 pounds below the U.S.
average cost of production, according to federal officials.

Vilsack has said the department is reviewing dairy policy to determine what
changes are needed to reduce price volatility and enhance farmer profits.

Associated Press contributed to this story.

To see more of the Greeley Tribune, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.greeleytribune.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Greeley Tribune, Colo.

LOAD-DATE: August 3, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                         Copyright 2009 Greeley Tribune


                              913 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                The Denver Post

                      September 4, 1994 Sunday 1ST EDITION

Farmers reaping millions in aid 'Disaster' program a virtual entitlement

BYLINE: Mark Obmascik, Denver Post Environment Writer

SECTION: A SECTION; Pg. A-01

LENGTH: 986 words


Whether it's hot or cold, wet or dry, icy or dusty or windy, the U.S. Department
of Agriculture still reaches the same conclusion: Every year is a disaster for
Colorado farmers.

Although there were no major floods, tornadoes or swarms of locusts, 52 of
Colorado's 63 counties were determined by the USDA to have suffered natural
disasters in the past three years, federal records show.

That finding allowed 11,198 farms and ranches - nearly half the state total - to
reap a bumper crop of $ 37.9 million in government disaster payments, records
show. Millions more in federal handouts are likely this year because of sparse
rainfall, agriculture officials say.

Farm disaster payments are coming under increased fire in Washington, where the
Clinton administration and congressional leaders have voiced concern over
escalating costs.

In 1986, farm officials say, only two Colorado farm counties received crop
disaster payments. But today, critics say, disaster declarations have become so
routine that they virtually have become another federal entitlement program.

Members of Congress have introduced bills to change the federal farm disaster
program. But Colorado agriculture leaders worry that they could be hurt by
sweeping law changes.

Many farmers are struggling financially, they note, and cutbacks in disaster aid
will leave them with an even tougher row to hoe.

"Is this the most equitable way it can be done? It's the most equitable way
that's been invented," said Colorado Agriculture Commissioner Tom Kourlis. "Farm
income is so marginal in Colorado. Farmers are extremely vulnerable to any
natural disaster."

Kourlis has first-hand experience with federal disaster relief. A Moffat County
sheep and cattle rancher, Kourlis said he got about $ 10,000 in government aid
because of dry weather in 1977, and another $ 10,000 because of dry weather in
1987.

"I don't think I would have gone out of business (without federal compensation).
But it would have made us more vulnerable," Kourlis said.

Farmers and ranchers qualify for federal disaster aid if a "natural disaster"
claims at least 40 percent of their crop or livestock feed supply. But it often
is tricky to measure a 40 percent loss.

When a harvest looks bad, there can be a temptation to ease up on the best
farming techniques, so the crop falls below the 40 percent threshold and thus
qualifies for disaster relief, agriculture officials admit.

No farmer is supposed to increase profits through disaster, said Tom Wingfield
of the Colorado Agricultural Stabilization and Conservation Service. "The
magnitude of the crop disaster payments hardly accounts for the loss suffered by
farmers." On the Eastern Plains, the most common disaster is a hail storm.

Last year, 375 Yuma County farmers reaped the state's biggest disaster payments,
a total of $ 5.2 million, after hail pelted northeast Colorado. Kit Carson
County farmers got $ 3.1 million last year for hail damage.

"Even in a real good year in eastern Colorado, hail is going to hit somebody,"
Wingfield said.

On the Western Slope, food producers seem most susceptible to dry weather and
frost. A 1991 cold snap in Mesa County yielded $ 942,890 in disaster payments,
mainly to fruit growers in the Grand Valley. A 1990 frost in Delta County
resulted in $ 766,572 in disaster relief, mainly to orchard owners.

Department of Agriculture officials declined to make public the names of farmers
and ranchers who received the biggest disaster payments, saying that is
proprietary information. It also was unclear whether any individual farms or
ranches received payments for more than one disaster.

The most common criticism of the disaster program is that it undermines another
federal program - government crop insurance. Because disaster relief is
dispensed so often, farmers are less likely to purchase disaster protection
policies from the Federal Crop Insurance Corp.

Nationally, only about a third of all eligible farmers purchase crop insurance,
federal officials said. In Colorado, fewer than one in four farmers or ranchers
buys crop insurance, records show.

"What incentive does a person have to pay for insurance if they can get disaster
aid anyway?" asked Ray Christensen of the Colorado Farm Bureau.

Partly because of the low participation rate, the federal crop insurance program
is a money loser that, like the disaster program, requires taxpayer subsidy. As
a result, the USDA has been requiring disaster-aid recipients to buy crop
insurance the following year.

Last year, 6,074 Colorado farmers paid $ 10.9 million for federal crop insurance
coverage. They received $ 13.1 million in payments.

A farmer who buys crop insurance also can receive disaster payments; one
advan-tage in buying crop insurance is that a farmer must suffer only a 35
percent loss to be eligible for disaster payments, federal officials said.
Several bills in Congress would push farmers to rely less on disaster payments
and more on crop insurance.

One bill, approved last month by the House of Representatives, would ban
Congress from enacting sweeping farm disaster payment legislation. It also would
require insurance to be purchased by any farmer receiving government subsidies
to grow surplus crops, such as corn and wheat. A similar reform bill cleared the
Senate Agriculture Committee in June. That bill is awaiting consideration by the
full Senate.

"A beefed-up insurance program is the much better way to go," said Dave Carter
of the Rocky Mountain Farmers Union. "With good, solid insurance, you won't have
Congress dinking around with the program every year."

As it is, Colorado agriculture officials are waiting for Congress to authorize
some kind of farm disaster program for 1994. With Colorado baking under the
second-warm-est August on record and annual precipitation 35 percent below
normal, many farmers with wilted fields are hoping for federal help.

                              916 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                             National Mortgage News

                                 July 26, 1993

Flood Has Impact on Value of Farmland

SECTION: Pg. 9

LENGTH: 650 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


With an estimated eight million acres of Midwestern farmland underwater at some
time, lenders and agricultural experts are beginning to wonder what impact the
flood of 1993 will have on the value of the farmland and on the ability of
borrowers to repay loans.

The Secretary of Agriculture estimated that eight million acres of farmland were
underwent last week and an additional 12 million acres are "affected" by the
flooding in the Midwest, bringing the total area possibly damaged to 20 million
acres.

The Federal Crop Insurance Corp. estimated that it would face an indemnity of $
721 million in the eight states most affected by flooding.  If all farms with
Federal Crop Insurance in those states had a total loss, the liability would be
about $ 5 billion.

Only about 35% of farmers in those states are covered by Federal crop insurance.

Nobody knows at this point what the total crop losses will be or how much impact
they will have on agricultural lenders.

Lenders will likely see the impact in the Fall, when many agricultural loans
come due.

Clinton has pledged $ 2.5 billion in aide to the midwest, but already there is
controversy about the government's proposed aid package.  An early version would
compensate farmers $ .21 for each dollar of crop damage, a figure that was
criticized by midwestern political leaders as inadequate.

Gov. Tommy Thompson, R., Wis., said a proposal to provide farmers with emergency
loans would not help farmers who are already saddled with debt.

"Another loan to Wisconsin farmers is the same as telling them there is no aid
at all," he told reporters.

Sen. Patrick Leahy, D., Vt., chairman of the Senate agriculture committee, said
Congress will provide aid but must do so in a "fiscally responsible" way.

"This emergency bill will mark the sixth time in the last six years that bad
weather has moved Congress to adopt an agricultural emergency relief bill," he
said.

From 1980 to 1990, Congress spent almost $ 9 billion on emergency relief, half
of it for the 1988 drought.

That total does not include emergency loans and other regular programs, Sen.
Leahy said.

Sen. Leahy questioned the practice of farming some low-lying land that is
frequently vulnerable to flooding.  Particularly vulnerable land should be
enrolled in the Wetland Reserve Program, he said.

"There are tens of thousands of acres in the Mississippi valley that are often
flooded.  When these fields are flooded, low-interest farm loans are often
forgiven under one program, crop insurance payments are paid from a second
program, and field renovation is subsidized under a third program," he said.

Jon Foley, head of Lawson Bank in Lawson, Mo., said the agricultural damage
appears to be of devastating proportions.  His county alone has an estimated
57,000 to 60,000 acres of damaged crop land, he said.

"A lot of our river-bottom farmers have lost everything.  Losses have been
tremendous in our area."

He said it is too early to assess all the damage.  River-bottom farmers may have
sand deposits to deal with, while farmers uphill have lost soil to erosion.

Mr. Foley said bankers hope the Farmers Home Administration will provide
emergency help so that farmers can obtain the credit they need to stay in
business and deal with the losses.

Most of the farmers in the river valley do not have flood insurance, he said.

Sam Callahan, president of Iowa Bankers Mortgage Corp. in Des Moines, Iowa, said
it was too early to know the extent of the damage, but he said he did not
anticipate major delinquency problems for most of the agricultural borrowers in
their portfolio.

Last week, he said the office was operating for four hours a day with 50% staff,
no running water and limited electricity.

They had not received calls from borrowers affected by the flooding yet.

"I suspect those people who are impacted have not had a chance to call yet," he
said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LOAD-DATE: February 24, 2017


                              918 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                              The Bismarck Tribune

                            April 22, 1993 Thursday

LENGTH: 920 words


DES MOINES, Iowa (AP) Ä Willie Nelson presents Farm Aid VI on Saturday, a
marathon concert that has as much to do with raising awareness about rural
America as it does with raising money to help family farmers. While the farm
economy no longer is on its knees, as it was in 1985 when Farm Aid was born, an
estimated one in 10 farmers remain overwhelmed by debt and times are getting
tougher for many others. Some economists believe the farm recovery peaked in
1989, after just three years. ""Agriculture is just the bottom rung on the
economic ladder,'' Nelson says.

""Once the farmers go under, then everyone over them starts.'' It is the
entertainment that draws the crowd and provides a forum for that message. Dozens
of performers are scheduled to join Nelson, including Johnny Cash, Merle
Haggard, Waylon Jennings, Kris Kristofferson, Neil Young, John Mellencamp, Ricky
Van Shelton and Dwight Yoakam. Hosts include Roseanne and Tom Arnold, Yakov
Smirnoff, Lou Diamond Phillips and Williams & Ree. The concert begins at noon
CDT and runs until 11 p.m. at the 50,000-seat Cyclone Stadium of Iowa State
University in the central Iowa community of Ames. The Nashville Network will
televise the concert to cable viewers, joining the program at 3 p.m. Because the
concert coincides with the Drake Relays track meet in nearby Des Moines and the
annual spring student celebration at Iowa State, hotel rooms throughout central
Iowa have been booked for weeks. But plenty of Farm Aid tickets still are
available. Promoters say they're happy with the response, but as they headed
into the final week of sales, Iowa State said more than a third of the tickets
had yet to be sold. Ticket sales were picking up, however, according to Andy
Long at the Iowa State Center. Reserved seats remain for sale at $27.50 each,
although the 2,000 choice preferred seats, at $46 each, quickly sold out. Even
before the entertainment begins, concert organizers have found ways to get out
their message that family farmers are vital to the stability of rural America.
On the eve of the concert, a House agriculture subcommittee meets in Ames at
Nelson's invitation to take testimony on how the U.S. Department of Agriculture
can become more responsive to the needs of family farmers. On concert day, fans
are being urged to deposit nonperishable food at the gate for the hunger relief
organization Feed the Children. Even groups that have yet to share in the nearly
$11.2 million distributed in the past seven years by Farm Aid applaud the way
the concerts help focus attention on rural issues. ""I think the proportion of
farmers in a crisis situation is less today than in 1985, but it's still a
problem. The more public awareness of this the better,'' says Don Ralston,
administrative director of the Center for Rural Affairs in Walthill, Neb. In the
1980s, only generous federal payments kept many farmers on the land, and most of
those who survived now rely on off-farm employment to make ends meet. Off-farm
income represented more than 85 percent of a farm household's total income in
1991, the government says.The struggles in the 1980s also were marked by an
exodus of one of every four U.S. farm residents. That followed a similar flight
from the farm in the 1970s, according to Census Bureau estimates. Nelson says
Farm Aid will be needed as long as the United States keeps losing farmers.
Advocates for black farmers, whose ranks are shrinking at an even faster rate,
call Farm Aid a ""lifeblood'' of their organization. ""Without them it would
have been impossible Ä not only for us but for others Ä to provide support,''
says Ralph Paige, executive director of the Atlanta-based Federation of Southern
Cooperatives and Land Assistance Fund. The network of 75 cooperatives throughout
the Southeast provides technical assistance, financing and counseling to family
farmers, concentrating on minority groups. ""All 2 million farmers are in
trouble, but the plight of the minority farmer is twice or three times as bad,''
Paige says. Farm Aid last year provided $75,000 of the federation's $600,000
budget. It also has bought eyeglasses for two elementary school girls in south
central Iowa, helped support the Oklahoma Ag-Link Farm Crisis Hotline, stocked
emergency food pantries across rural America and financed legal services and
rural rights organizations. In all, Farm Aid has provided $10.7 million to
farmer and rural organizations since 1987. It has paid almost $500,000 more for
educational and advisory services, such as a mailing advising more than 80,000
farmers of their rights in foreclosure proceedings. The organization reports
raising almost $14.2 million since 1985 through concerts, television programs
and contributions. It has spent about 17 percent, or about $2.3 million on
management and fund-raising. Most of the remaining $682,000 is in a special
scholarship account created by the Des Moines-based Younkers chain of Midwest
department stores. But since its founding, it has never equaled the financial
support of its first year, when Farm Aid I brought in about $7 million. Nelson
says his group has not been getting many new donors and that the same people
have been giving year-in, year-out. ""Once you get so far away from the farm and
you're in Detroit or you're somewhere in New York City and you have your own
problems you're not aware of the farmers problems,'' he says. Neil Harl, an
economist at Iowa State University, says Farm Aid serves as an important
reminder of farm strife past and yet to come.

LOAD-DATE: May 9, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved


                              919 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                           Greeley Tribune (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             August 3, 2009 Monday

USDA to provide temporary aid to dairy farmers

BYLINE: Bill Jackson, Greeley Tribune, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 554 words


Aug. 3--The U.S. Department of Agriculture, at the urging of several
Congressional members, announced Friday that it was coming to the aid of dairy
farmers who are in the middle of one of the worst crises in decades.

The USDA said it will be increasing the amount paid for dairy products through
the Dairy Product Price Support Program.

Les Hardesty of Greeley, chairman of the Dairy Farmers of America Mountain Area
Council, lauded the move and said he hopes it will lead to a reform in federal
dairy product pricing.

"This is temporary relief for the dairy industry nationwide that is hurting
badly," said Hardesty, who milks 650 cows northwest of Greeley. "It will help
out on the short term and hopefully give us time to work on long-term reform in
pricing within the industry."

The price increase, he said, will remain in effect for the next three months.

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack said Friday the price increase will provide
immediate relief, helping to keep dairy farmers on the farm while they weather
what he called "one of the worst dairy crises in decades."

The USDA increased the price paid for nonfat dry milk by 12 cents a pound,
cheddar cheese blocks by 18 cents a pound, and price for barrels of cheddar
cheese by 18 cents per pound.

According to Sen. Michael Bennet, D-Colo., the increase in the support price
will have an immediate effect on the dairy farmers' bottom line. Temporarily
raising the price of the products increases the price that dairy farmers receive
for milk.

Hardesty said Vilsack and Congressional members "have been doing what they can
for what's best for dairy farmers and we appreciate that."

"Between falling commodity prices and continued concerns about the economy,
Colorado's dairy producers are feeling the pain," Bennet said in a press
release. He pointed out that agriculture is a vital part of the state's economy,
and "we need to do everything we can to make sure the industry remains strong."

The USDA estimates the move will increase the milk price received by dairy
farmers and should result in the government purchase of an additional 150
million pounds of non-fat dry milk and an additional 75 million pounds of
cheese.

According to Rep. Betsy Markey, D-Colo., the move will increase dairy farmers'
revenue by $243 million.

"This is great news for Colorado dairy farmers," she said in a press release.

The price of milk crashed late last year and dropped to some of the lowest
levels dairy farmers have seen in several years. The drop in price was driven by
several factors, including the world economy and recession. As a result, dairy
farmers have seen an average price of $4.80 per 100 pounds below the U.S.
average cost of production, according to federal officials.

Vilsack has said the department is reviewing dairy policy to determine what
changes are needed to reduce price volatility and enhance farmer profits.

Associated Press contributed to this story.

To see more of the Greeley Tribune, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.greeleytribune.com. Copyright (c) 2009, Greeley Tribune, Colo.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

LOAD-DATE: August 4, 2009

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20090803-GY-DAIRY-FARMERS-AID-20090803

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: GY


                         Copyright 2009 Greeley Tribune


                              920 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                   Roll Call

                            August 2, 2012 Thursday

Senate May Nix House Aid Package;
Rural Lawmakers Push for Drought Relief Deal

BYLINE: Meredith Shiner

LENGTH: 852 words



Lawmakers, especially from rural districts and states, don't want to go home
empty-handed to their drought-plagued constituents at week's end without making
some effort to approve agriculture disaster aid.

But as of Wednesday, they were on track to do just that, given that Senate
Democrats are reluctant to pass the pending $383 million House disaster bill
that still needs to garner a two-thirds vote today to even be sent to the
Senate. And if Congress fails to send any sort of legislation to the president's
desk, with about 80 percent of the country suffering from an historic drought,
then it will be a blame-game free-for-all when Members return home for the
month.

"In the aggregate, yes, we'll get beat to death going home without having done
something, but most of these guys on this floor don't represent rural districts,
and they're not going to face anybody affected by this," said Rep. Mike Conaway
(R-Texas), a member of the Agriculture Committee.

Senate Majority Leader Harry Reid (D-Nev.), who met with Agriculture Secretary
Tom Vilsack at the Capitol on Wednesday, has said he will consider a stand-alone
drought relief package only if it is exactly like the provisions included in the
bipartisan farm bill the Senate approved in June.

The House proposal, however, only addresses livestock disaster and tree
assistance programs - two of the most pressing issues in current drought
conditions. The Senate's five-year extension - which was supported by 16 GOP
Senators - is broader and includes measures to help fruit growers affected by
frost and freezes, sweeping improvements to crop insurance and permanent funding
for livestock disaster programs.

The House plan would offset the increased spending by cutting conservation
programs dear to Democrats. A litany of farm groups and some Democrats released
a joint statement Wednesday against the bill, while expressing support for both
emergency aid to farmers and a long-term bill.

"If the House simply passed the five-year farm bill reported out of Committee on
a bipartisan basis, this bill would not be necessary. While we understand that
will not happen before the August recess, this bill potentially costs more than
$600 million and would only provide relief to livestock producers a month or two
earlier than a farm bill debated and passed in September," wrote the groups,
including the American Farm Bureau Federation and 12 other prominent
organizations. "Agriculture will already provide a minimum of $23 billion in
deficit reduction by passing the farm bill. We do not need to provide additional
deficit reduction in this package only a few months before we provide far more
than agriculture's 'fair share.'"

The other groups included the American Soybean Association, National Association
of Wheat Growers, National Barley Growers Association, National Corn Growers
Association, National Farmers Union, National Milk Producers Federation,
National Sunflower Association, United Fresh Produce Association, U.S. Canola
Association, USA Dry Pea & Lentil Council and Western Growers.

Late Wednesday, the Senate showed no sign of flinching, and it was not clear
that House GOP leaders would have the votes to approve their own measure, which
faces a two-thirds threshold for passage. If the House were to change the offset
structure of the bill, however, they could put increased pressure on the Senate
to take up their bill.

Though a rarity during the past year and a half, recent Congresses have approved
emergency aid bills without offsets, and House Republicans earlier this year
agreed to an extension of the payroll tax cut that was not paid for.

To make matters more complicated, because the current drought is persistent, the
costs of aid continues to increase every day, and according to sources, has
increased even since the Senate passed its bill.

There are significant political points to be scored, particularly in close races
across the Midwest, on the farm assistance issue.

Senate leaders have long felt as if they had the upper hand in the negotiations
with the House on the bill, considering that the House gave up on trying to
approve a one-year extension.

House sources gave no indication they intend to pass a clean aid bill without
the controversial offsets, but if they were to do so, Democrats still may not go
along for fear of losing leverage on the longer-term bill. The five-year
extension likely will face opposition from House conservatives, especially
without the drought aid sweetener.

When asked whether passing the disaster aid bill would make it more difficult to
convince his conservative colleagues to back a long-term farm bill, Conaway
demurred.

"Well, that kind of second-guessing doesn't do us any good. We're going to pass
it tomorrow, if it doesn't get the two-third votes, then we'll see," said the
Texas Republican, who helped approve a five-year bill out of committee.

"But we've got to pass a five-year bill, we've got to find 218 votes whether
they're conservatives, liberals, or whatever in the House and that's not easy
under any circumstances," Conaway said.

Daniel Newhauser contributed to this report.

LOAD-DATE: August 2, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper


                         Copyright 2012 Roll Call, Inc.

                           January 22, 2015 Thursday

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Bulk
Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 305  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International Food Aid
Programs."

Solicitation no. AG-INAG-S-13-0010                      Posted on: January 22,
2015

Notice Type: Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 424

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AG-INAG-S-13-0010 (2000001605) for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after January 16, 2014, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near January 23, 2014.

Set Aside: N/A

Deadline for All responses: Jan 23, 2014 2:15 pm Central

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205
Mail Stop 8698
Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s):
Dan Webber,
Contracting Officer
dan.webber@kcc.usda.gov
Phone: 816-926-2847

                                US Official News

                            December 14, 2014 Sunday

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Bulk
Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 305  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International Food Aid
Programs."

Solicitation no. AG-INAG-S-13-0010                      Posted on: December 14,
2014

Notice Type: Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 424

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AG-INAG-S-13-0010 (2000001605) for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after January 16, 2014, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near January 23, 2014.

Set Aside: N/A

Deadline for All responses: Jan 23, 2014 2:15 pm Central

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205
Mail Stop 8698
Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States
