                              940 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     June 25, 1992, Thursday, City Edition

AIDS patient refused dental treatment

SECTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE; STATE DIGEST; Pg. 5B

LENGTH: 448 words

DATELINE: KISSIMMEE; MIAMI



An AIDS patient who was refused treatment by a dentist is suing for damages and
asking a judge to forbid the dentist from discriminating against others infected
with the AIDS virus. The attorney for the 40-year-old man, identified in court
papers only as James B., says the discrimination lawsuit may be the first in
Florida and joins a handful of similar cases nationwide. James B., an Orlando
native living in Lakeland, has a full-blown case of acquired immune deficiency
syndrome, according to the lawsuit. He was treated by Dr. Irwin Bergman at least
15 times between July 1986 and December 1990 for a variety of dental problems.
On Dec. 3, 1990, the patient was waiting to have a cavity filled and told
Bergman he was infected with the virus. Bergman refused to treat him and
referred him to a Gainesville dentist, court papers show.  Bergman recently
closed his practice in Lakeland and could not be reached for comment.
 Sugar growers to get 'Glades documents
 MIAMI Sugar cane farmers, who have been ordered to pay for much of the
Everglades cleanup plan, hope state documents made available Wednesday will show
a lack of scientific evidence to support the plan. After numerous court battles,
the state Department of Environmental Regulation and the South Florida Water
Management District agreed Wednesday to make documents available to the Florida
Sugar Cane League. Those documents involve negotiations between the U.S.
Department of Justice and the two state agencies on an Everglades lawsuit
settlement. The lawsuit was filed by the federal government against the state in
1988 for failing to protect the Everglades from farm runoff, much of it from
sugar growers. The league thinks the DER and the district were trying to hide
the documents because they show no scientific evidence to support the Everglades
settlement.
 Inmate denied request to donate organs
 MIAMI A convicted murderer volunteering for execution so he can donate his
organs for transplants should take his plea to the state Legislature instead of
court, a judge said Wednesday. Daniel Faries, who is serving a 37-year sentence
and facing trial in a jail house credit-card scam that was featured on 60
Minutes, wants non-toxic lethal injection. But Circuit Judge Alan Postman
rejected the motion for lack of jurisdiction and recommended that attorney Ellis
Rubin pursue changes with the Legislature. Florida currently bars organ
donations by all state prisoners because those who die in custody are subject to
autopsies. Rubin said he would take the judge's advice. The attorney also has
suggested giving prisoners time off their sentences for donations of extra
organs, such as kidneys.

LOAD-DATE: November 3, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DISTRIBUTION: TAMPA BAY AND STATE

TYPE: DIGEST

                            Times Publishing Company


                              941 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                          Accurate Hearing Systems LLC

                                     Ste 3
                              Anchorage,  AK 99503
                                 United States

                              942 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                       The Record ( Stockton, California)

                     Distributed by Tribune Content Agency

                           February 10, 2015 Tuesday

Farmers eligible for drought aid

BYLINE: Reed Fujii, The Record, Stockton, Calif.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 312 words


Feb. 10--Declaring 55 of California's 58 counties drought disaster areas,
federal farm officials have effectively opened relief programs to farmers and
ranchers throughout the state, as well as adjoining areas of Oregon, Nevada and
Arizona.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture declaration last week makes qualified
producers eligible for low interest emergency loans from the U.S. Farm Service
Agency. Producers have eight months to apply for such loans to help cover part
of their losses.

There are other programs from the FSA as well, including the Livestock Forage
Disaster Program, which helps offset the higher cost of feed when drought
deprives ranchers of their usual supply of natural forage.

Justin Oldfield, government relations vice president of the California
Cattlemen's Association, said all those programs can help ranchers affected by
the drought.

The biggest concern currently, however, is how much rain will the state receive
this year, he said.

California's cattle industry has seen its livestock count drop by an estimated
20 to 25 percent over the past few years because of the drought's impact on
pasture and forage.

"Is this the year we come out of drought and add more cows back to the cow
herd?" Oldfield asked.

With a wet December followed by a record dry January, the remaining weeks of the
rainy season will be key to answering that question, he said.

For information on emergency loans and other USDA programs, farmers may contact
their local USDA Service Center at 3422 W. Hammer Lane, Suite A, Stockton, or
telephone the office at (209) 472-7127. Help is also available online at
disaster.fsa.usda.gov.

-- Contact reporter Reed Fujii at (209) 546-8253 or rfujii@recordnet.com Follow
him on Twitter @ReedBiznews.

___ (c)2015 The Record (Stockton, Calif.) Visit The Record (Stockton, Calif.) at
www.recordnet.com Distributed by Tribune Content Agency, LLC

LOAD-DATE: February 11, 2015

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

ACC-NO: 20150210-SK-Farmers-eligible-for-drought-aid-0210-20150210

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

JOURNAL-CODE: SK

                            October 17, 2014 Friday

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Bulk
Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 325  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International Food Aid
Programs."

Solicitation no. AG-INAG-S-13-0010                      Posted on: October 17,
2014

Notice Type: Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 424

Description: USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AG-INAG-S-13-0010 (2000001605) for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after January 16, 2014, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near January 23, 2014.

Set Aside: N/A

Deadline for All responses: Jan 23, 2014 2:15 pm Central

Contact Details: P.O. Box 419205
Mail Stop 8698
Kansas City, Missouri 64141-6205
United States

Point of Contact(s):
Dan Webber,
Contracting Officer
dan.webber@kcc.usda.gov
Phone: 816-926-2847

For more information visit:
https://www.fbo.gov/index?s=opportunity&mode=07470146905a03b615a12804176883c5&ta

located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near January 23, 2014.

located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near February 26, 2013.

                              967 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                   Bluefield Daily Telegraph (West Virginia)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 22, 2007 Monday

Drought aid brings much-needed good news to Va. farmers

BYLINE: Charles Owens, Bluefield Daily Telegraph, W.Va.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 436 words


Oct. 22--TAZEWELL, Va. -- Help could soon be on the way for Southwest Virginia
farmers impacted by the prolonged drought conditions.

Gov. Timothy M. Kaine announced last week that the Acting U.S. Secretary of
Agriculture has designated 78 additional Virginia counties and 34 independent
cities as primary natural disaster areas due to reductions in farm production
caused by drought and high temperatures that occurred from January 1, 2007, and
continuing.

The state had previously designated only 15 counties as primary natural disaster
areas. With the additional designation, Kaine said all Virginia counties are now
covered with the exception of Arlington and York.

The disaster designations make farmers eligible for low-interest loans and any
supplemental relief that may be provided by Congress.

Bill Rasnick, chairman of the Tazewell County Board of Supervisors, said the
declaration is good news for local farmers.

"I'm really pleased because as you know we have already declared the county as
such and passed a local resolution and sent it along, and encouraged our
governor to approve it," Rasnick said. "Our farmers and people really need it."

Because agriculture across the Commonwealth has been impacted by the drought,
Kaine and the Commissioner of the Virginia Department of Agriculture and
Consumer Services Todd P. Haymore had requested a statewide primary natural
disaster designation.

"Because of the statewide disaster designation, farmers with qualifying crop
losses across Virginia are now eligible to apply for low-interest loans that can
help provide critical assistance," Kaine said in a press release.

Disaster declarations make farm operators in both primary and contiguous areas
eligible to be considered for low-interest emergency loans from the Farm Service
Agency of the U.S. Department of Agriculture, provided they meet certain
eligibility requirements, the governor's release said.

Kaine said the FSA will consider each application on its own merits by taking
into account the extent of the losses, security available, and repayment
ability. Local FSA offices can provide affected farmers with additional
information.

-- Contact Charles Owens at cowens@bdtonline.com

To see more of Bluefield Daily Telegraph, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go
to http://www.bdtonline.com/. Copyright (c) 2007, Bluefield Daily Telegraph,
W.Va. Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                              968 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                               The New York Times

                          September 29, 2007 Saturday
                              Late Edition - Final

As Prices Soar, U.S. Food Aid Is Buying Less

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER

SECTION: Section A; Column 0; Foreign Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1204 words


Soaring food prices, driven in part by demand for ethanol made from corn, have
helped slash the amount of food aid the government buys to its lowest level in a
decade, possibly resulting in more hungry people around the world this year.

The United States, the world's dominant donor, has purchased less than half the
amount of food aid this year that  it did in 2000, according to new data from
the Department of Agriculture.

''The people who are starving and have to rely on food aid, they will suffer,''
Jean Ziegler, who reports to the United Nations on hunger and food issues, said
in an interview this week.

Corn prices have fallen in recent months, but are still far higher than they
were a year ago. Demand for ethanol has also indirectly driven the rising price
of soybeans, as land that had been planted with soybeans shifted to corn. And
wheat prices have skyrocketed, in large part because drought hurt production in
Australia, a major producer, economists say.

The higher food prices have not only reduced the amount of American food aid for
the hungry, but are also making it harder for the poorest people to buy food for
themselves, economists and advocates for the hungry say.

''We fear the steady rise of food prices will hit those on the front lines of
hunger the hardest,'' said Josette Sheeran, executive director of the United
Nations World Food Program. The United States is the biggest contributor to the
agency.

She warned that food aid spending would have to rise just to keep feeding the
same number of people. But the appropriations bill for the coming year now
moving through Congress does not promise any significant increases in the food
aid budget.

The impact of rising food prices on food aid is part of a broader debate about
the long-term impact on the world's poorest people of using food crops to make
ethanol and other biofuels, a strategy that rich countries like the United
States hope will eventually reduce dependence on Middle Eastern oil.

Some advocates for the poor say rising food prices could benefit poor farmers in
developing countries, providing them with markets and decent prices for their
crops. But others warn that the growing use of food crops to make fuel,
especially if stoked by large subsidies in rich countries, could substantially
increase food prices. That could push hundreds of millions more poor people into
hunger, especially landless laborers and subsistence farmers, according to a
recent article in Foreign Affairs magazine. The authors were Benjamin Senauer
and C. Ford Runge, food policy analysts and professors at the University of
Minnesota.

Production of food crops to make biofuels will also tend to favor growers with
plenty of capital and large land holdings, they say, rather than small-scale,
impoverished farmers lacking modern grain storage facilities in poor countries.
''The policies put in place are going to be crucial to whether the small
producer and the people who live where hunger is concentrated can benefit,'' Mr.
Senauer said.

But for now food aid is suffering, as are poor people in poor countries,
economists say. And their situation may get even tougher next year, relief
agencies warn. The United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization is
projecting that low-income countries reliant on food imports, including most of
sub-Saharan Africa, will see the amount they pay to import cereals rise 14
percent.

The world's ability to absorb fresh price shocks has shrunk along with  food
stocks. ''We're very worried,'' said Henri Josserand, who heads the
organization's global information and early warning system. ''World food stocks
are much smaller than they used to be.''

The food aid declines may also continue. Catholic Relief Services, a major
distributor of American food aid, has projected substantial increases in what
the federal government pays for food aid next year, based on an analysis of the
futures market for the wheat, corn and soybean products that are mainstays of
aid. ''It's bad news and it's not just going to affect U.S. food aid, but food
aid from every source,'' said Frank Orzechowski, a retired commodity trader who
now advises Catholic Relief Services.

This year's decline in food aid follows a period when the sharply escalating
costs of shipping American-grown food aid to Africa and Asia  already reduced
the tonnage supplied. The United States Government Accountability Officementnd
this year that the number of people being fed by American food aid had declined
to 70 million in 2006 from 105 million in 2002, mainly because of rising
transportation and logistical costs.

Now food prices are also playing a role. New data from the Department of
Agriculture show that the cost of food for the federal government's main food
aid program, Food for Peace, rose 35 percent over the past two years.

The amount of food bought for American food aid programs has fallen to 2.4
million metric tons this year from 4 million metric tons in 2005 and 5.3 million
metric tons in 2000. Thomas Melito, who supervised the Government Accountability
Office's food aid investigation this year, called the escalating costs of food
aid ''frightening.''

''In a situation where there are 850 million hungry people in the world and the
program was only providing enough for 70 million people in 2006, the new totals
will be even lower,'' he said.

Congress is considering changes to the food aid program as part of the omnibus
farm bill that some economists and advocates for the hungry say would improve
the efficiency of the program and allow it to feed more people. They point to a
Bush administration proposal that would allow the government to use up to $300
million of the food aid budget to buy food in African countries close to hunger
emergencies rather than shipping it from the United States on mainly
American-flagged vessels as current law requires.

In his speech to the United Nations this week, President Bush said the proposal
would speed delivery and help provide a market for poor farmers in developing
countries.

The House version of the farm bill includes no such provision. The Senate
Agriculture Committee has not produced a farm bill.

''To my mind, that's the way out of this pincer,'' said Emmy Simmons, an
agricultural economist and retired senior manager at the United States Agency
for International Development.

''But the shipping guys are hanging tough,'' she added. ''They're defending that
little chunk of revenue. They aren't super concerned whether you feed less
people.''

Groups representing shipping companies and agribusiness interests have opposed
using the budget of the main food aid program to buy food in developing
countries instead of relying on American food shipped overseas.

Gloria Tosi, who represents most of the American ship owners involved in the
food aid system, said buying commodities abroad would erode domestic political
support for the program and lead to lower food aid budgets from Congress. She
said it was ''politically naive'' to think the food commodity groups and ship
owners  that have for decades supported food aid in Congress would favor buying
commodities abroad.

''None of us will be working toward that,'' she said.

URL: http://www.nytimes.com

LOAD-DATE: September 29, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                              969 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                                The Toronto Star

                           October 17, 2009 Saturday

Brief

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. B05

LENGTH: 579 words


Royal Bank

Insurance stays online

Royal Bank of Canada will keep marketing insurance on its website until it gets
clarity on proposed government rules that may block the practice.

Finance Minister Jim Flaherty has written to banks asking them to drop their
online insurance marketing, because it violates government rules that bar banks
from selling insurance in branches.

The Canadian Bankers Association, which represents the lenders, is in talks with
the department.

Magna

EC balks at German aid

The European Commission has voiced concern over Germany's planned aid for a
consortium led by Aurora, Ont.-based Magna International to take a majority
stake in car maker Opel.

Germany offered $6.7 billion (U.S.) to support the deal, and hopes other
European countries that have Opel plants will contribute.

But Neelie Kroes, the EU competition commissioner, said the aid was subject to
the precondition that a specific bidder, Magna/Sberbank, was selected and
therefore would be "incompatible with ... state aid and internal market rules."

Pork

Fund promotes exports

Canada will spend $550,000 to promote pork exports and help the country's hog
farmers, the agriculture ministry said on Friday.

The investment will help Canadian Pork International, an Ottawa-based trade
group, promote the meat and open international markets, Agriculture and
Agri-food Canada said.

Canadian pork producers will also get better market information and sales
support.

Nickel

Royalty sues Vale Inco

Vale Inco, the Canadian unit of Vale SA, under-reported the value of
Newfoundland and Labrador nickel sales, resulting in underpayments of royalties,
International Royalty Corp. said.

International Royalty, based in Colorado, said it sued Inco in the Supreme Court
of Newfoundland and Labrador to recover $26 million in royalties that it's owed.
The company also asked the court to order Inco to correct the calculations of
future payments.

Timminco

Laid off staff return

Silicon processor Timminco Ltd. says it will recall some of the laid-off workers
at its plant in Becancour, Que., in response to receiving additional orders.

The Toronto-based company purifies silicon metal for use in solar panels that
convert sunlight into electricity. Demand for solar grade silicon dropped off
during the severe slowdown that began to seriously affect the global economy
about a year ago.

Timminco announced Friday that it shipped 103 tonnes of solar grade silicon in
the quarter, mostly to an affiliated company, at an average of $39 per kilogram.

Toronto City Airport

Extra flights considered

The Toronto Port Authority is reviewing additional commercial flights at the
Toronto City Centre Airport after receiving several inquiries from different
airlines.

A 1983 agreement limits the number of commercial flights that can be operated
daily at the airport. A study is reviewing the number of additional flights that
can be accommodated in the next few years, Alan Paul, president and CEO of the
port authority, said.

German stocks

DAX slides on GE losses

German stocks declined after Bank of America Corp. reported a third-quarter
loss, sales from General Electric Co. missed analysts' estimates and confidence
among U.S. consumers fell more than forecast.

Deutsche Bank AG and Commerzbank AG dropped at least 2.1 per cent. Siemens AG
also retreated. Steelmakers Salzgitter AG and ThyssenKrupp AG slid with metal
prices. The DAX Index fell 1.7 per cent to 5,731.35, trimming its weekly gain to
0.4 per cent.

From the Star's wire services

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                 March 18, 2000, Saturday, 2 Late Tampa Edition

80-unit apartment project planned for migrants

BYLINE: LINDA GIBSON

SECTION: TAMPA & STATE; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 462 words

DATELINE: TAMPA



The project on church-donated land will allow some farm worker families to
escape "horribly substandard" trailers.

A $ 6-million building project is under way near the eastern Hillsborough
community of Dover that will move 80 migrant farm worker families from
dilapidated trailers into new apartments.

The project will be built on a 34-acre site that houses the offices of a handful
of social service agencies that provide day care, adult education, family
counseling and legal aid.

"We're bringing services to their doorstep, spanning the whole plethora of needs
they might have," said Joe Citro, spokesman for the Catholic Diocese of St.
Petersburg, which donated the land.

A market survey found 1,300 migrant families in that part of eastern
Hillsborough County who were living in "horribly substandard housing," Citro
said.

"We're not talking about a leaky faucet," he said. "We're talking about broken
windows, no running water, no air conditioning."

Families have doubled up in these trailers because they can't afford the rent
otherwise, said Rosa Ramirez, a social worker with the diocese. They also face
eviction at the end of the harvest.

The apartments will give up to 500 people a stability in housing many have not
experienced, Citro said. In addition, the diocese has sought to involve
potential residents in the development phase through focus groups and town
meetings over the past three years.

Migrants told them they needed three or four bedrooms for their large families,
that they would like to have a place where they could fix and wash their cars
and that their kids would love a soccer field.

As a result, the apartments will have from two to four bedrooms. There will be
plazas between the buildings for people to gather, a 4,000-square-foot
recreation center and a soccer field with lights so it can be used at night. The
buildings will be designed to evoke Southwestern styles.

"We want them to feel they have a place of their own that they can be proud of,"

 Ramirez said.

Part of the rent families pay will be put into an escrow fund available for down
payments on houses.

"This will be stepping-stone housing," Citro said. "We don't want people to stay
there for the rest of their lives. When people are up and on their feet, they'd
make way for another family."

The hard part will be choosing which 80 families will be the first to move in,
he said. That will be done by committee.

Groundbreaking should be in three months, Citro said, with construction taking
another nine months. Funding includes a grant of $ 3.25-million from the Florida
Department of Community Affairs, as well as federal and county grants and
private sources.

- Linda Gibson can be reached at (813) 226-3382 or at gibson@sptimes.com.


LOAD-DATE: March 18, 2000

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

DISTRIBUTION: TAMPA & STATE; METRO & STATE; CITY & STATE

Hillsborough County (ran Tampa & State)

                              973 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                     Sunday News (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                           September 23, 2012 Sunday

Farm Aid Board Plows Ahead;
Press Conference Brings Out Their Fervor For Agriculture And Buying Local.

BYLINE: Jon Ferguson

SECTION: A; Pg. 7

LENGTH: 721  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


News Editor

HERSHEY - Neil Young - always passionate, always articulate - made an
impassioned plea Saturday for more young people to get involved in farming.

"We have to make farming sound like it's a mission from God," Young said. "We
need young blood; we need new blood on the farm."

Young and his fellow musicians who sit on the board of directors of Farm Aid -
Willie Nelson, John Mellencamp and Dave Matthews - kicked off the organization's
annual benefit concert with a noontime press conference at the old Hersheypark
Arena.

The actual concert started in a sold-out Hersheypark Stadium when Nelson, his
long, gray hair flowing from a straw cowboy hat emblazoned with the Farm Aid
logo, strode onto the stage at 2:15 p.m. and sang "The Lord's Prayer." Aside
from the headliners, other musicians scheduled to perform at the concert
included Jack Johnson, who participated in the press conference, Kenny Chesney,
Grace Potter and Jamey Johnson.

Though the musicians are accustomed to entertaining people from a stage, they
seemed equally comfortable at the crowded press conference, which lasted for
about 50 minutes.

Actually, to call it a press conference was something of a misnomer as no
questions were taken from the media and it was moderated by Bryan Snyder,
executive director of Pennsylvania Association for Sustainable Agriculture, and
Carolyn Mugar, Farm Aid's executive director.

Nonetheless, the musicians, who were joined by three farmers from central
Pennsylvania, spoke knowledgeably about American family farmers and the hard
times they believe a lot of them face.

Farm Aid, which held its first concert in 1985 at the University of Illinois,
was started by Nelson, who recruited Young and Mellencamp to help him organize
it and recruit musicians. It was designed as a one-time event.

During the 1980s, Mellencamp addressed the problems of family farmers in songs
like "Scarecrow" and his rural Indiana roots in tunes like "Small Town."

Mellencamp, 60, said he's sees a lot of the same problems facing family farmers
today that he did almost three decades ago.

"We were all young men when we started this," Mellencamp said. "But I don't
think things have gotten much better."

Nelson made a comment that mirrored Mellencamp's.

"On behalf of all the guys," Nelson, 79, said, "we're glad to be here. On the
other hand, we're very sorry we have to be here. This problem should have been
solved many years ago."

Farm Aid, which says it has raised more than $40 million since 1985, describes
its mission as keeping family farmers on their land. Its mission statement also
says it wants to help maintain an agricultural system that ensures family
farmers make a fair living, strengthens communities, protects natural resources,
and delivers "good food for all."

Matthews, 45, said people can help accomplish that by buying locally. The
rocker, who has made Hershey a regular stop when he tours with his band, said
people should resist buying products just because they're name brands and
instead purchase products from their neighbors.

"Say, 'I don't want the same,' " he said. Say 'I want to know where I am, and I
want to support the local people. I want to support the local farms ,and I want
to support the local community.'

"And I want that to be part of a greater community that has the same philosophy.
And that's what I want the future of America to be."

Young, 66, said helping family farmers should revolve around encouraging young
people to take up agriculture as a career and organizing.

"We really need to get much more organized and get some farm leaders that stand
up for the small farmer," said Young, who read a letter from an Iowa dairy
farmer during the press conference.

"In this country you can do just about anything you want. The fact is, we need
independent family farmers to be represented within our government in a way
that's similar to unions, in a way that's similar to what some people are trying
to get rid of."

Though they've been at this for 27 years, it was clear that the musicians who
started Farm Aid and have kept it going don't plan on abandoning their cause
anytime soon.

"We've been here for a long time," Young said, "and some people say we're not
going anywhere. We're not going anywhere. We're staying right here."

Said Nelson, "It might take another 27 years, but what else are we going to do?"

LOAD-DATE: September 24, 2012

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: L Neil Young Reads A Letter From A Small Farmer In Need At The Press
Conference Saturday Afternoon. From Left, Willie Nelson, John Mellencamp, Dave
Matthews And Jack Johnson. Jeff Ruppentha

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                                US Official News

                          September 10, 2014 Wednesday

US Contract Notice: Department of Agriculture Issues Solicitation for "Bulk
Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International Food Aid Programs"

LENGTH: 324  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Department of Agriculture, Farm Service Agency Officer has issued requirement
for "Bulk Agricultural Commodities for use in U.S. International Food Aid
Programs."

Solicitation no. AG-INAG-S-13-0036      Posted on: September 10, 2014

Notice Type:  Solicitation

The NAICS code number for this requirement: 424

Description:  USDA's Farm Service Agency, Kansas City Commodity Office (KCCO)
intends to issue solicitation AG-IN (AG-S-13-0036 (2000001870)  for bulk
agricultural commodities to be used in U.S. international food aid programs.
Deliveries are for various locations in the United States. The solicitation's is
expected to be available on or after June 14, 2014, and will be available
electronically through USDA's Web Based Supply Chain Management (WBSCM) system
located at https://portal.wbscm.usda.gov/publicprocurement and also through a
link to the aforementioned website in the document package attached to the
solicitation notice on the Federal Business Opportunities (FBO) website
(http://www.fbo.gov). A hard copy of the solicitation will not be available for
the acquisition. All future information regarding this acquisition, including
solicitation amendments and award notices, will be published both through WBSCM
and FBO. Interested parties shall be responsible for ensuring that they have the
most up-to-date information about this acquisition. The anticipated date of
receipt for offers will be on or near June 19, 2014.

                           Investor's Business Daily

                               February 21, 2001

BYLINE: By, Investor's Business Daily

SECTION: A; Pg. 2

LENGTH: 530 words


U.S. sub commander won't talk to investigators from nat'l board Cmdr. Scott
Waddle was skipper of the U.S. submarine that surfaced under a Japanese fishing
boat. Nine are thought dead after the accident. On his lawyer's advice, Waddle
refused to talk with investigators from the National Transportation Safety Board
about the accident. He offered to answer written questions from the NTSB about
the sub's part in the rescue. Waddle and two other officers on the sub will
appear before a Navy Court of Inquiry on Thursday.  Five senators travel to
Ecuador to talk about drug-fighting plans Four Republicans and one Democrat,
including Sen. John McCain, R-Ariz., discussed "Plan Colombia" with top
government officials in Quito. The $ 1.3 billion program aids the Colombian
government in its quest to stamp out coca production. But the government's
success has pushed drug-driven strife from Colombia across the Ecuadorian
border. The senators and Ecuadorian officials also planned to discuss funding
for development in the border areas. People in the region are receiving threats
from groups based on the Colombian side of the border.  High court won't hear
gun case, also rejects property rights case The Supreme Court rejected a
constitutional challenge to California's assault weapons ban. Gun collectors and
manufacturers said the law banning the sale, manufacture and distribution of
military-style firearms was too vague. Specifically, they objected to the law's
provision that gave California's attorney general the power to add weapons to a
list of banned firearms. The court also turned away a North Carolina case that
would have examined the Endangered Species Act's impact on private landowners. A
group of farmers had complained that laws covering the killing of red wolves
were unconstitutional.  In an 8-1 ruling, the court ruled police could bar
suspects from entering their own homes to prevent them from destroying evidence
while officers obtained a search warrant.  Farmers to get assistance checks Some
$ 500 million in aid will be paid by the Agriculture Department to 590,000
farmers of soybeans, sunflowers and other oil-producing crops, the department
said. Low prices for those crops caused Congress to award the aid last year, and
left the USDA to distribute the money. The aid will primarily benefit Midwestern
states, with the most aid going to Iowa and Illinois.  GAO rips Marines over
Osprey The General Accounting Office said the Marines failed to conduct key
tests of its MV-22 Osprey aircraft. Two of the Ospreys, which take off and land
like a helicopter but fly like an airplane, crashed last year, killing 23
Marines. The GAO said only 33 out of 103 tests to examine a mechanical
malfunction were actually done. The watchdog agency blamed cost-cutting and time
pressures. The report said not enough was known about the Osprey before
production started. It comes on top of charges that the head of the Marines'
sole Osprey squadron told subordinates to fake maintenance records.  Secretary
of State Colin Powell held talks with German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer,
who faces official inquiries at home into his left-wing past.

                              977 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                  The State Journal-Register (Springfield, IL)

                             August 12, 2005 Friday

Durbin to focus on more aid for drought victims

BYLINE: TIM LANDIS Business Editor

SECTION: MARKETPLACE; Pg. 27

LENGTH: 506 words

DATELINE: BERLI


Rain clouds gathered as U.S. Sen. Dick Durbin met with more than two dozen area
farmers Thursday to discuss a drought that has cut local corn yields by more
than half on some fields.

To a farmer, they told the Springfield Democrat the damage already is done.
"This corn looked pretty bad in '88. The difference now is our input costs are
tremendously higher, for the feed, the fertilizer and the seed," said Steve
Walter, who hosted the Durbin visit on his farm at the west edge of Berlin.

Walter, who farms 1,600 acres of corn and soybeans, estimated his corn yields
have been cut to 50 to 60 bushels per acre, compared to an average of 187
bushels per acre last year. Unless rain comes soon, soybean yields will suffer
as well, he said.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture last month declared 101 of 102 counties in
Illinois federal disaster areas as a result of one of the worst droughts to hit
the state since record-keeping began in 1895. Only Alexander County at the
southern tip of the state was not included.

A federal disaster declaration qualifies farmers for low-interest emergency
loans, but Durbin said if the drought persists, emergency loans would not be
enough to carry some farmers into the next planting season.

Durbin said he would consider a request for emergency federal aid, possibly in
the form of grants to help offset some of the losses when Congress reconvenes
next month. But he conceded it could be a tough sell politically, because
effects of the drought do not appear to have been as severe in surrounding
states.

"It's one of the few times since I've been in Congress and the Senate that the
entire state has been hit. If this is Illinois' misfortune, it's tougher
politically," said Durbin, who visited a farm near McLean earlier in the day.

Durbin said he plans to begin discussions with state and federal agricultural
officials and representatives from surrounding states on the extension of
emergency aid provisions scheduled to expire in mid-September.

"The budget is tight. I don't want to over-promise, but we'll work on it," he
said.

The visit included a brief walk through one of the worst hit sections of a
cornfield, which had stunted stalks, ears of corn shriveled to a quarter of
normal size, and hard, cracked ground.

Sangamon County corn yields probably will average 50 to 150 bushels per acre
this year compared to 155 to 160 in a normal year, said Robert Irlam, county
executive director for the U.S. Department of Agriculture Farm Service Agency.

"We've been getting a lot of calls on what kind of disaster relief there may
be," Irlam said.

Several farmers said the quality as well as the quantity of grain has suffered,
which also could result in lower prices. They also said loss of farm income
could spread to other areas of the local economy, including implement dealers,
grain elevators, fertilizer companies and even retail businesses.

Edward Cowman, who also farms near Berlin, said, "They're going to discount us
on grain prices for what we do bring in."

LOAD-DATE: August 17, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: LOCAL

                   Copyright 2005 The State Journal-Register

                              979 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                            The Philadelphia Inquirer

                     AUGUST 24, 1995 Thursday FINAL EDITION

SLIM HARVEST CONGRESS USES A DULL SCYTHE ON FARM SUBSIDIES.

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. A16

LENGTH: 329 words


It's sad to see how Congress plans to tighten up on agriculture programs.
Between now and the year 2000, the Republican budget cuts an average of $3.5
billion a year from food stamps. But when it comes to subsidies to farmers
through the Commodity Credit Corp., the cuts are only $1.7 billion a year;
that's half as much.

If lawmakers had the backbone to slash subsidies to farmers, the extra savings
could be used to safeguard food stamps for poor people. But that's not in the
cards because most poor people don't vote Republican. Besides, the party wants
to protect the freshmen in 23 rural congressional districts that
went Republican last November.

In fairness, the Republican timidity on farm supports looks like statesmanship
compared with the token cuts proposed by President Clinton. He's pandering to
farm-state voters by calling the Republican cuts too severe.

Next month, House and Senate committees will work on how to achieve the gradual
savings promised in the budget.

In one promising development, the chairman of the House Agriculture Committee,
Rep. Pat Roberts (R., Kan.), has proposed a sensible approach.

The Roberts bill would sweep aside most of the rules that restrict which major
crops farmers can grow - and in what amounts. Various forms of federal aid would
be consolidated into an annual payment based on a percentage of what the grower
received in an average year.

This gets at one of the disadvantages of current farm policy: the sharp
variations in federal costs in some years due to the unpredictability of crops.
Meanwhile, it gives growers - the vast majority of whom have above- average
incomes - an assured, though declining, amount of federal aid.

By backing the government out of the crop-control business, the Roberts bill
would prod the agricultural industry toward the free-market principles that
Republicans tout for the rest of the economy. The pace isn't fast enough - but
the direction is right.

LOAD-DATE: October 28, 2002

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: EDITORIAL

                  Copyright 1995 Philadelphia Newspapers, LLC
                              All Rights Reserved

                              983 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec)

                   September 22, 1991, Sunday, FINAL EDITION

Be generous with food for Soviets

BYLINE: GAZETTE

SECTION: EDITORIAL/OP-ED; Pg. B2

LENGTH: 439 words


Washington's new plan for a "professional Peace Corps" for the Soviet Union, as
U.S. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady described it, is a good idea. It would
help supply a key need over the longer run: teaching the basic skills of
business and economic management to a willing but unskilled population, just as
the Peace Corps taught modern farming and other skills in developing countries.

But limiting aid to this sort of thing would be a mistake. That would do little
to help the Soviet Union through the coming winter, the most pressing immediate
requirement.

Senior Soviet officials have now told a somewhat startled European Community how
much they figure they need in food aid from its members, and from other members
of the Group of 7 including Canada, the United States and Japan. The amount is $
14.7 billion U.S.

That is, in Mr. Brady's words, "awfully high." It is also roughly twice the
amount mentioned by Soviet officials just one week earlier. There was some
confusion over whether that earlier $ 7.2 billion was to come from everybody.
But the officials now stress it was always just the European portion.

It would be easy to say the Soviets don't really know what their real needs for
food aid are, so perhaps we should wait until they do. Perhaps they don't know
very accurately, and there is certainly debate among Western experts.

Jacques Delors, the European Community president, recently estimated some $ 2.4
billion was needed. The London-based International Wheat Council says the Soviet
people will be eating bread and potatoes during the winter if Western countries
fail to respond with massive aid, but terms fears of actual famine unfounded.

A team from the U.S. agriculture department, just returned from a fact-finding
trip, also discounts widespread famine but anticipates "food hardship" in the
Russian republic and some other areas. A European Community commissioner, Frans
Andriessen, also a recent visitor to the Soviet Union, notes there have been
great difficulties in distributing just $ 300 million in food aid agreed to by
the Europeans last December.

Nevertheless, it is vital that the rich industrialized countries be generous and
humane in responding to Soviet appeals for short- term emergency food aid as
well as for technical assistance.

A hungry people in a still heavily armed country going through a political
revolution is a dangerous combination. A failure by the new democratic
governments of the various parts of the Soviet Union to feed their populations
this winter could bring on an autocratic counter-revolution.

This would be in nobody's interests.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

               Copyright 1991 CanWest Interactive, a division of
                      CanWest Global Communications Corp.
                              All Rights Reserved


                              984 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                     January 31, 1993, Sunday, City Edition

Pa. Health Department wants AIDS patients' names reported

SECTION: NATIONAL; MEDICAL DIGEST; Pg. 18A

LENGTH: 618 words

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA; CARROLLTON, Ga.; BELLEVILLE, Ill.; WASHINGTON



The Pennsylvania Department of Health wants medical laboratories to report  the
names, addresses, ages, sex and race of patients with white blood-cell  counts
low enough to signal possible AIDS infections. Critics said reporting  such
cases by name tramples on individuals' rights to privacy and may  discourage
people from getting tested or treated for AIDS. It also could lead  to mistaken
identification of AIDS among people who suffer from other  disorders affecting
white blood cells. The request - which is not mandatory -  was issued by the
health department on Jan. 4. It was drafted to better track  the spread of AIDS
under an expanded definition of the disease the federal  government began using
last year. Dr. Bobby Jones, state director of AIDS  epidemiology, said all names
would be kept confidential. States are required  by law to report their number
of AIDS cases to federal health officials. But  not all doctors comply.

Meningitis strikes Ga. town

CARROLLTON, Ga. - Panic swept through this west Georgia city when bacterial
meningitis struck seven people. One person died, and the state spent $ 180,000
to help pay for immunizations this weekend for 20,000 residents. The Centers
for Disease Control and Prevention investigated the outbreak and found that
none of the victims knows each other, lives near each other or had any other
discernible links. Meningitis, which isn't transmitted through water, is
inflammation of the fluid and membrane that surround the brain and spinal  cord.
Bacterial meningitis, the most severe form of the disease, can kill or  cause
permanent brain damage. It typically strikes people under 30, although  doctors
don't know why. The germs that cause meningitis aren't really that  rare - as
many as 10 percent of Americans carry the bacteria in their throats.  But there
are only about 2,600 active cases a year.

Tobacco firm wins liability suit

BELLEVILLE, Ill. - A dying man lost his fight to hold the tobacco industry
responsible for smoking's ills, but anti-smoking forces say the war has just
begun. The 10-week trial had gained national attention because it was the  first
of its type since the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that warning labels do  not
protect cigarette makers from lawsuits. St. Clair County jurors late  Friday
rejected Charles Kueper's claims that R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Co. and the  Tobacco
Institute conspired to conceal the dangers of smoking and thereby  helped cause
his lung cancer. Kueper's attorney had sought as much as  $ 48-million in
damages. Tobacco attorneys argued that Kueper, 51, chose to  smoke almost two
packs of Winstons a day even though he knew about warning  labels on cigarette
packages that began appearing in 1966. As many as 60 more  liability cases are
set to be heard.

USDA meat guidelines defended

WASHINGTON - Secretary of Agriculture Mike Espy says the government has a
"moral responsibility" to the victims of food-borne illnesses in the Pacific
Northwest but thinks federal safety guidelines were obeyed. At a news
conference Friday, Espy said he planned no immediate changes in the way meat
and poultry are inspected "until all the research is in." Two children died  and
250 other people became sick this month from a rare strain of E. coli  bacteria,
mostly traced to meat served at Jack in the Box restaurants. Jack in  the Box
said the tainted meat went to Washington, Idaho, California, Nevada,  Hawaii,
Hong Kong and Mexico. Consumer advocates say the outbreak is due to  the failure
of the Agriculture Department's Food and Safety Inspection Service  to analyze
meat for microbes.

LOAD-DATE: February 5, 1993

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: DIGEST

                            Times Publishing Company


                              985 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                           August 1, 1990, Wednesday

US PROBES ROLE OF AGENT IN SHIPMENTS OF FOOD AID

BYLINE: ROSE A. HOROWITZ; Journal of Commerce Special

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 1032 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The U.S. Department of Agriculture is investigating alleged conflicts of
interests by a shipping agent handling transportation of U.S. government food
aid for several African countries, a USDA official said.

Universal Shipping Co., Arlington, Va., is under investigation by the USDA's
office of the inspector general, David Dickson, director of the program
investigations division, told The Journal of Commerce. He said the agency is
ooking at two instances, involving shipments to Senegal and Madagascar.

Robert K. Powell, Universal Shipping president, said he was not aware of the
USDA's investigation of the company. Mr. Powell denied any allegations of
conflict of interest and said the company acted properly.

"We encourage as much competition as possible," said Paul F. Hannum, executive
vice president of Universal, when asked about charges involving possible
conflict of interest. "Our objective is to get the lowest price or rate that we
can obtain," he said.

Universal represents Senegal, Zambia and Yemen as agents in the Food for Peace
program for the present fiscal year, USDA records show. Mr. Hannum said the
company also represents Madagascar, Mozambique and Ecuador.

Universal booked about $ 8.6 million in ocean transportation financed by the
U.S. government as agent for Senegal and Madagascar in the last several years,
according to figures from the USDA. The department's investigation of Universal
involves the company's representation of these two countries in the program.

Despite years of allegations about possible fraud and inefficiencies in the
transportation system for shipping food to countries suffering from famine, the
program continues to be riddled with problems. "It's a hornet's nest," said one
government official.

The biggest shipping agent in the Food for Peace program, Star Trading & Marine
Inc., is under investigation by the U.S. attorney in the District of Columbia
for possible violation of conflict-of-interest laws and questions involving
commission fees.

As reported previously in The Journal of Commerce, the USDA inspector general
submitted a report Sept. 12, 1988, to the U.S. attorney on Washington- based
Star Trading. The company represents Egypt, the biggest recipient of U.S. food-
aid cargoes.

"It's not a case of it sitting at the U.S. attorney's," said Mr. Dickson. "It's
under active investigation." The U.S. attorney's office for the District of
Columbia declined to comment on the case.

Star Trading did not respond to calls and written requests for comment. Its
president, Saeed M. Sheik, has said in the past that the company acted properly.
Star Trading has said the investigation will show that it has followed all
guidelines and obeyed all laws.

The company has booked about $ 184 million in ship transportation financed by
the U.S. government for relief cargoes during the past six years, according to
USDA records. Using an estimate of a maximum commission set by the USDA, those
bookings resulted in at least $ 3 million in commission fees for the company.

The questions raised about the Food for Peace program have led to proposed
congressional legislation that would reform the transportation system for the $
1.5 billion program as part of the 1990 farm bill.

The Food for Peace program, established under Public Law 480, is designed to
deliver commodities like grain and rice to needy countries at the lowest cost.
Recipient countries generally appoint shipping agents to handle bidding and
contracting for commodities and transporting the food-aid cargoes. The USDA
administers the loan sales under the program.

SUIT LAUNCHED PROBE

The USDA case opened this year concerning Universal stems from a lawsuit filed
in federal court by Connell Rice & Sugar Co., of Westfield, N.J. The lawsuit
charges Universal with racketeering and conspiracy to defraud Connell, Senegal
and the U.S. government.

"I can confirm we're looking into aspects of the Connell suit," said Mr.
Dickson. "If we believe there are criminal aspects, it will be referred to the
Department of Justice," he said.

The USDA's second investigation of Universal regards a potential conflict of
interest involving its role as shipping agent for Madagascar and shipping broker
(an agent for a shipowner or operator) for Intermarine Ltd. of Piraeus, Greece,
a foreign shipping company, on the same Food for Peace transaction, according to
documents obtained by this newspaper.

Mr. Dickson confirmed the USDA also was investigating allegations involving
conflict of interest in Universal's arrangements for bagging food-aid cargoes
for Madagascar.

In the lawsuit filed this year, Connell charges Universal with conflict of
interest in representing Senegal as a shipping agent and awarding the freight
bid to carry rice to a vessel, the Calrice Transport, while acting as a ship
broker for the Calrice in a food-aid shipment for Sierra Leone. Connell also
claims that Universal had commercial interests in booking the Calrice.

'A NORMAL TRANSACTION'

Asked about Connell's charges, Mr. Powell said, "I certainly deny all of that,
and the group that's been hurt is Senegal and, frankly ourselves, as a result of
all of this. This transaction was handled as a normal transaction under PL-480
regulations," he said.

Mr. Powell said the operator of the Calrice had assured the USDA and Universal
that it could return from its voyage to Sierra Leone to load rice for Senegal at
U.S. Gulf ports by Sept. 30, 1987, the day the freight contract expired. The
ship arrived 27 days late at the U.S. port.

Of all the freight bids submitted for the shipment for Senegal, the Calrice was
"in excess of $ 12 (a ton) cheaper than the next U.S.-flag (vessel)," Mr. Powell
said. "It's absurd to say it's a conflict of interest because the vessel was
offered to Senegal for $ 12 less," he said.

"We deny all of it," said Thomas Olp, a partner with the law firm Ross & Hardies
in Washington, which is representing Universal in the Connell lawsuit. "In our
view, they (Connell) show a misunderstanding of the industry and the facts of
this transaction. They're 180 degrees wrong on every issue they talk about," Mr.
Olp said.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE: FOOD FOR PEACE? FOOD FOR PROFIT? UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                  July 22, 1995, Saturday, THREE STAR Edition

CONGRESS OKS '95 CUTBACKS; BILL SLASHES $ 16.4 BILLION FROM SPENDING TILL OCT. 1

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 614 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The Senate ended four months of partisan wrangling over a bill to cut this
year's spending by $ 16.4 billion, passing it Friday on a 90-7 vote and sending
it to the White House.

The support for the bill, which President Bill Clinton has said he will sign,
belied the rancorous debate that raged in both houses - and between the
president and the Republican-controlled Congress.

Cuts for education, job training and several programs that help the poor were
the main points of contention in the so-called rescissions bill, which rolls
back spending in the $ 1.5 trillion budget for the current fiscal year, which
ends Sept. 30.

"If you think this was a struggle, wait'll you see what's coming," said Sen.
Paul Wellstone, D-Minn., who had held up the rescissions bill since early July
in an unsuccessful attempt to restore $ 319 million in home heating and cooling
subsidies to low-income people, a program known as LIHEAP. "This is just the
beginning."

In its original effort, the bill cut even deeper into domestic spending to
offset the cost of disaster aid for California's earthquake , the Oklahoma City
bombing and 36 other states. Clinton, on June 7, vetoed that bill.

After nearly a month of negotiations between the White House and Republican
congressional leaders, the House passed a recycled version of the bill that
restored $ 772 million in education, job-training, environmental and other
domestic programs favored by the administration.

But the bill got snagged in the Senate when Wellstone and Sen. Carol
Moseley-Braun, D-Ill., objected to cuts in the heating and energy assistance
program for low-income people and some inner-city school construction funds.

After weeks of haggling, Senate Majority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., agreed to give
the dissident senators an up-or-down vote on separate amendments to put back
money for the energy assistance and school programs.

Those amendments were defeated Friday, on largely party-line votes. But the
Wellstone-Braun rebellion clearly demonstrated that future efforts to cut
spending mainly at the expense of low-income families will be met with ferocious
opposition.

In its final form, the bill going to the president's desk provides $ 6.5 billion
in disaster aid to California, Oklahoma and 36 other states. The measure also
contains $ 275 million in new spending to relieve part of Jordan's debt to the
United States.

It slashes federal housing programs for the poor and cuts spending for space
programs, job training, transportation, schools and colleges, child care, drug
enforcement, community service, and housing for AIDS victims.

Other Measures

Fiscal conservatives and urban liberals in the House failed in a 261-154 vote to
kill the Agriculture Department's $ 110 million Market Promotion Program, which
has helped big food companies advertise overseas.

Then, by 313-78, the House passed a $ 62.5 billion measure financing the
Agriculture Department and the Food and Drug Administration. The bill would cut
spending $ 5.5 billion from current levels, mostly from lower farm payments and
elimination of a $ 2.5 billion reserve for food stamp spending.

The White House has threatened a veto because of changes in the food stamp
program and cuts in money for rural housing, water and sewer plants and economic
development.

The Senate approved 84-10 an $ 11.2 billion military construction measure
boosting this year's spending by $ 2.5 billion. The bill included $ 774 million
in projects senators added that were not requested by the Pentagon.

The bill now goes to House-Senate negotiators, who will resolve differences
between it and a similar measure passed by the House.

LOAD-DATE: July 24, 1995

LANGUAGE: English

GRAPHIC: Photo by AP - Slum children demonstrate outside a government office in
Port au Prince, Haiti, Friday against the exploitation of children. The sign, in
Creole, reads "Bourgoisie, stop making money off our backs." More than 100
children took part in the protest.

                                   USA TODAY

                            November 20, 2006 Monday
                                 FINAL EDITION

Food banks have less to work with as they try to meet holiday demand;
Donations of U.S. surplus food, private cash down

BYLINE: Wendy Koch

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 386 words


The nation's food banks are scrambling to serve a growing demand for help during
the holidays at a time when government food donations and private cash
contributions have fallen.

More people are asking for food even as the amount of government commodities
available -- milk, cheese, canned goods and other staples -- is down 55% from
2005, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture. A second USDA program of
emergency food aid has stayed about the same. Together, they supply about
one-fourth of what food banks give away.

USDA buys fewer commodities when it has less need to boost farm prices. It gives
80% of purchases to America's Second Harvest, a network of more than 200 food
banks.

The loss of USDA commodities is "huge," says Paul Ash of the San Francisco Food
Bank. He says his group is increasing visits to stores to pick up food with
"sell by" dates about to expire.

Ash says the Bay Area's cost of living is forcing more low-income workers to
seek help. He has managed to increase his holiday distribution 35% this year but
says that remains "far short" of the need.

High rents have increased demand in Hawaii, doubling it in some areas, says Dick
Grimm, president of Hawaii Foodbank.

Demand is up 34% from two years ago in the Dallas area, says Colleen Brinkmann
of the North Texas Food Bank, and 39% from five years ago in Washington, D.C.,
and its suburbs, says Brian Smith of the Capital Area Food Bank.

"We have a lot of empty racks in our warehouse. That's unusual," says Carey
Miller of the Food Bank of Iowa.

Despite reports of higher demand, a USDA report last week said the number of
people who couldn't put food on the table at least part of the year fell in 2005
to 35 million, down from 38 million in 2004. It was the first decline in six
years. But the report found the number of those worst off increased slightly.

High fuel prices this year have hurt many low-wage earners by forcing them to
choose between heating their homes or buying food, says Maura Daly of America's
Second Harvest.

Daly says the network is trying to expand programs, relying partly on a 3% rise
this year in private food donations. She says financial donations this year are
down 9% from 2005, not counting relief funds received after Hurricane Katrina.

"Every food bank will tell you," she says, "they need more food."

LOAD-DATE: November 20, 2006

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: GRAPHIC, Color, Karl Gelles, USA TODAY, Source: Dept. of Agriculture
(bar graph)

                           Star News (Wilmington NC)

                            February 7, 2005, Monday

CAPITAL IDEAS / Hard-fought race makes appointments attractive

BYLINE: Mark Schreiner

SECTION: Local/State; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 672 words


RALEIGH | One day before the weeks-long struggle to name a winner in the North
Carolina agriculture commissioner's race finally ended, state Sen. Charlie
Albertson proposed that it be an appointed job.

That was a big step considering the great weight the state's agricultural
community gives the commissioner's job and that Mr. Albertson, as Senate
agriculture chairman, is often the voice of the farm and agribusiness
communities in that chamber.

The senator, a Democrat from Duplin County, has filed a bill that would ask
voters to drastically cut the number of statewide elected officials. He said the
drawn-out elections for ag chief and state school superintendent provided some
of the inspiration for Senate Bill 56.

"And it's also about government efficiency," the senator said. "It's about
streamlining the government."

The bill would ask voters to convert the posts of secretary of state, state
school superintendent, commissioner of labor, commissioner of insurance and
agriculture commissioner to appointive, rather than elective, jobs. With 10
state elected offices, North Carolina has more than any other state except North
Dakota, which also has 10.

On Friday, the N.C State Board of Elections ended the uncertainty in the
agriculture commissioner race, which had been caused by the loss of about 4,400
votes in Carteret County, by certifying Republican challenger Steve Troxler as
the winner. Britt Cobb, the Democratic candidate and current ag commissioner,
conceded the race almost immediately.

Mr. Alberton's notion is not a new one. When news came last session that the
state school superintendent wasn't going to seek re-election, senators took up a
measure to convert the job to an appointive one. Of all the state offices, it
was figured, that one made the most sense to change since the elected
superintendent must carry out policies of a state Board of Education, which
could be appointed by officials from a different political party. The bill
passed the Senate but died in a House committee.

So the superintendent's post remains an elected one, and that race was still
unsettled last week. The state Supreme Court appeared to hand a victory to the
Republican candidate, Bill Fletcher, on Friday by ruling that provisional
ballots cast in the wrong precinct can't be lawfully counted. But the effect on
his race with Democrat June Atkinson was unclear late last week.

INCLUDED, TOO: Much of last week's discussion at the legislature about hurricane
relief rightly centered on the western part of the state devastated by Hurricane
Ivan. But included in the proposed relief bill are two lines that draw
Southeastern North Carolina into the effort.

Senate Bill 7 (and its House companion, House Bill 24) includes references to
2004's Tropical Storm Bonnie and Hurricane Charley. It notes in an extensive
preamble that these storms hit the southeastern part of the state and caused
damage. The bill's drafters also noted that federal aid was denied and that the
area may become eligible for some sort of state aid.

Further down, a section lists the counties eligible for the hurricane relief
fund established by the bill. Included are counties covered by federal disaster
declarations, and that includes Bladen and Columbus counties, brought into the
Hurricane Frances declaration because they are contiguous to Robeson County,
where damage was significant.

Federal aid has flowed the counties, particularly to Bladen, even through
emergency management officials say there was no damage reported there to them
after the storm. Federal officials maintain that the $ 2.5 million in damage
claims meet specifications.

State Rep. Edd Nye, D-Bladen - an insurance agent - said he knew of no private
insurance adjusters who visited the county after Hurricane Frances.

At the end of last week there was no indication when the bills would be debated.

Mark Schreiner is chief of the Star-News bureau in Raleigh. Reach Mark at (919)
835-1434 or mark.schreinerstarnewsonline.com.



LOAD-DATE: February 24, 2005

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                            Copyright 2005 Star News

                      The Financial Post (Toronto, Canada)

                     March 9, 1989, Thursday, DAILY EDITION

Daimler-Benz wins aid for Airbus consortium

BYLINE: Financial Times of London and Reuters

SECTION: SECTION 2, INVESTMENT AND FINANCE; Pg. 17

LENGTH: 316 words

DATELINE: Brussels,Belgium


  The European Community yesterday approved a West German subsidy package for
the Airbus project that could exacerbate U.S. frustration over government aid.

Bonn is to pay about 3.9 billion deutschemarks in subsidies to a
yet-to-be-created subsidiary of aerospace firm Messerschmitt-Boelkow-Blohm. The
subsidiary will oversee West Germany's 37.9% stake in the four-nation Airbus
Industrie consortium.

The aid package, part of which will cover MBB's share of Airbus's currency risks
until the year 2000, was demanded by Daimler-Benz as a condition for agreeing to
take over MBB, 51% of whose capital is in public hands.

This is one of the biggest state subsidies ever given the go-ahead from the
Brussels authorities and represents the removal of an important potential
barrier to what the Commission considers a strategically important takeover for
the European aircraft industry.

The plan is also awaiting clearance from West Germany's national cartel office
but an official said the office has no objection to the bid.

Daimler, maker of Mercedes cars, will initially buy 30% of MBB before increasing
its stake to more than 50%.

The new aid package brings Bonn's total subsidies to about 10 billion
deutschemarks for the project.

Beginning in the year 2000, Daimler will take over all financial responsibility
for West Germany's share in the consortium, effectively privatizing the
country's participation in the project.

But, using criteria that could infuriate U.S. aerospace firms, the commission
made it clear it had based its decision on the need to strengthen European
aeronautics.

Seattle-based Boeing Co. and McDonnell Douglas Corp. of St. Louis have
complained about the subsidies. Former trade representative Clayton Yeutter, now
Agriculture secretary, called Bonn's aid package ''very disturbing'' when it was
first unveiled in November.




LOAD-DATE: December 9, 1997

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: NEWS

                       Copyright 1989 Financial Post Ltd.


                              991 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                      The Atlanta Journal and Constitution

                            March 10, 1992, Tuesday

THE SOUTH IN BRIEF 3 indicted in poultry plant fire deaths

BYLINE: By Darryl Maxie STAFF WRITERfires; food; industry; deaths; trials;
congressmen; retirement; aid; blacks; agriculture; georgia; education; aid;
military; families

SECTION: NATIONAL NEWS; Section A; Page 3

LENGTH: 423 words


NORTH CAROLINA: The owner of Imperial Food Products Inc., his son and an
employee were indicted Monday by a Richmond County grand jury on 25 counts each
of involuntary manslaughter in connection with a 1991 poultry-processing plant
fire that killed 25 people.

Indicted were owner Emmett J. Roe; his son, Brad M. Roe, who was director of
operations at the Hamlet plant where the fire occurred Sept. 3; and plant
manager James N. Hair. The fire at the plant in Hamlet, a community 60 miles
southwest of Fayetteville, injured 56. Federal officials said the plant had no
fire alarm or sprinkler system and that its exits were unmarked and its doors
were locked.

The grand jury rejected District Attorney Carroll Lowder's request to indict the
plant's maintenance supervisor, Kimlee B. Mangus, on the same charges.

ALABAMA: Longtime congressman to retire. U.S. Rep. William L. Dickinson, the
senior Republican on the House Armed Services Committee, has announced that he
will not seek a 15th term from his southeast Alabama district because he doesn't
want to oversee dramatic military cutbacks. Mr. Dickinson, whose district
includes major Army and Air Force installations, said in Montgomery on Monday
that he spent his entire 28- year congressional career building a strong
military force. "I'm not anxious to take part in the dismantling of our defense
establishment," Mr. Dickinson said. He said he would resume practicing law.

GEORGIA: Black farmers to rally for aid. Black farmers plan to hold rallies at
state capitols throughout the Southeast over the next five months in an effort
to mobilize 5,000 people to march on Washington to seek funds to save the
shrinking number of black-owned farms. According to the U.S. Department of
Agriculture, blacks owned 15 million acres in the South in 1920, compared to 3.5
million today. In 1978 there were 57,271 black farmers, compared to 22,954
today. The group plans to go to the nation's Capitol in August, Ralph Paige,
executive director of the Federation of Southern Cooperatives Land Assistance
Fund, said Monday in Atlanta.

VIRGINIA: Confederate scholarship awarded. Dr. Rebecca G. Watts, a medical
researcher at the Medical College of Virginia, is one of 14 scholars nationwide
to get a $ 12,000 fellowship from a fund established to aid the kin of people
who served in the Confederate army. Dr. Watts is the great-great-granddaughter
of John Binford Knibb, who was a chaplain in the Confederate infantry when Gen.
Robert E. Lee surrendered at Appomattox in April 1865.

LOAD-DATE: March 11, 1992

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

GRAPHIC: Photo: mug of Emmett Roe

                    Copyright 1992 The Atlanta Constitution

                  New Orleans City Business (New Orleans, LA)

                           October 22, 2015 Thursday

USDA expands drought aid in Louisiana, Mississippi

BYLINE: The Associated Press

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 399  words


Farmers and ranchers in two-thirds of Louisiana's parishes and nearly 60 percent
of Mississippi's counties are now eligible for drought disaster aid, the U.S.
Department of Agriculture said.

In a news release Wednesday, the department named 25 Louisiana parishes as
primary drought disaster areas. Another 16 are eligible because they're adjacent
to those parishes. Eight of those 41 parishes also are contiguous with primary
disaster areas in Mississippi.

In Mississippi, USDA named 19 counties as primary disaster areas, and 27 as
contiguous. Eleven, including two that were not already on Mississippi's list,
are adjacent to drought disaster areas in Louisiana, for a total of 48.

Parishes and counties now eligible for aid:

Louisiana primary: Allen, Avoyelles, Beauregard, Catahoula, Concordia, East
Baton Rouge, East Carroll, East Feliciana, Evangeline, Franklin, Grant, LaSalle,
Livingston, Madison, Pointe Coupee, Rapides, Sabine, St Helena, St Landry,
Tangipahoa, Tensas, Vernon, Washington, West Carroll, West Feliciana.

Louisiana contiguous: Acadia, Ascension, Calcasieu, Caldwell, De Soto,
Iberville, Jefferson Davis, Lafayette, Morehouse, Natchitoches, Richland, St.
John the Baptist, St. Martin, St. Tammany, West Baton Rouge, Winn.

Mississippi primary: Adams, Amite, Bolivar, Choctaw, Covington, Jasper,
Jefferson, Jefferson Davis, Jones, Lamar, Marion, Montgomery, Neshoba, Newton,
Pearl River, Pike, Walthall, Wilkinson, Winston.

Mississippi contiguous: Attala, Carroll, Claiborne, Clarke, Coahoma, Copiah,
Forrest, Franklin, Grenada, Hancock, Harrison, Kemper, Lauderdale, Lawrence,
Leake, Lincoln, Noxubee, Oktibbeha, Perry, Scott, Simpson, Smith, Stone,
Sunflower, Washington, Wayne, Webster.

Mississippi contiguous to Louisiana primary drought areas and not on other
lists: Issaquena, Warren.

Farmers in those areas have eight months to apply for low-interest emergency
loans from the Farm Service Agency.

The agency also has other programs to help farmers and ranchers. It said those
include the Livestock Forage Disaster Program, the Livestock Indemnity Program,
the Emergency Assistance for Livestock, Honeybees, and Farm-Raised Fish Program,
and the Tree Assistance Program.

from this resource.

                September 24, 1995, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

Votes in Congress

SECTION: Section 1;  Page 50;  Column 1;  Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 611 words


Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

House

1. Park System: Vote on a bill to create a special commission to recommend which
of the country's national parks might be closed. Rejected 231 to 180, Sept. 19.

2. Speed Limits: Vote on an amendment to a major highway bill that would delete
a provision repealing the Federal speed limit of 55 miles per hour for all
vehicles. Rejected 313 to 112, Sept. 20.

3. Cuba: Vote on a bill that would tighten the trade embargo against Cuba.
Approved 294 to 130, Sept. 21.

1. Welfare: Vote on a welfare reform bill that would abolish the basic Federal
guarantee of assistance for every poor family that qualifies and replace it with
a block grant to the states that would give them broad discretion in the design
of their programs. Approved 87 to 12, Sept. 19.

2. Poultry: Vote to kill a provision in an Agriculture Department appropriation
bill that would block a new department rule that says chickens and turkeys
cannot be sold as fresh if they have been chilled below 26 degrees. Rejected 61
to 38, Sept. 19.

3. Mink: Vote to kill an amendment to an Agriculture Department appropriation
bill that would eliminate the Government's annual $2 million subsidy to the mink
industry for overseas fashion shows. Rejected 78 to 18, Sept. 19.

4. Pakistan: Vote on an amendment to a foreign aid appropriation bill that would
lift all economic sanctions and some important military sanctions imposed on
Pakistan five years ago because of its secret nuclear weapons program. Approved
55 to 45, Sept. 21.

it's website thusly: "South Kitsap Fire and Rescue is currently governed by a
Board of five elected Fire Commissioners. They manage and oversee the general
operation of the South Kitsap Fire and Rescue, as well as the financial
oversight. The Commissioners are elected for six year, staggered terms, and
provide a direct"
