                         The Land (Mankato, Minnesota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             April 8, 2010 Thursday

Murdock-area farmer tackles D.C. bureaucratic challenges

BYLINE: Dick Hagen, The Land, Mankato, Minn.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1124 words


Apr. 8--April 8, 2010

Murdock-area farmer tackles D.C. bureaucratic challenges

--Murdock farmer Mike Yost is back home being a Swift County farmer. But
beginning in 2006 he had a most intriguing, and challenging three-year hitch in
Washington, D.C., heading up the Foreign Agricultural Service, a vital arm of
the U.S. Department of Agriculture that directly impacts U.S. agricultural
trade. Yost was the first farmer to ever lead the FAS, a government agency
dating back to 1953.

Getting acclimated to the bureaucracy of Washington, D.C., is itself a
challenge, especially for a Minnesota farmer more comfortable growing corn,
soybeans and alfalfa. Yost told the audience at a Feb. 16 marketing seminar
sponsored by the Linder Farm Network in Willmar, that the FAS currently has more
than 90 offices around the world. Yet it's a relatively small agency by
Washington standards with less than 900 employees. "It is so under-appreciated
for what it brings to the table," Yost said.

The FAS is made up of people constantly looking for marketing opportunities for
American agriculture. They handle all international issues that enter the USDA.
They visit foreign ministry of agriculture offices pointing out when certain
trade rules simply don't make good sense. They also assist when U.S. farmers do
overseas travels to promote trade.

Yost often traveled to these foreign offices and said U.S. agriculture continues
to be envied. "They respect both our tremendous production agriculture and our
ability to move that production to markets around the world."

That same respect seems lacking in Washington. "Very few people in Washington
understand agriculture, and it's getting worse," Yost said, indicating that
agriculture's future with D.C. policy makers is being affected negatively.

"Common sense and good business judgment have limited value in Washington.
Granted there are a lot of well-intended people in Washington, D.C., but they
don't understand production agriculture. Their interaction with agriculture is
their local farmers market."

Yost isn't optimistic that major media will ever get involved telling the real
story about agriculture. "They thrive on 'shock-type' articles. Too often they
have the story written and then come out looking for a tag line that best fits
their angle. We have to go on the offense to get engaged with media people.
Farmers are still considered to be credible spokespeople. Equally significant,
America agriculture has a terrific story to tell."

As expected, there are still turf battles within the USDA and Congress. When
southern Congressmen were key power brokers on ag committees, southern
agriculture usually won. Yost cited for example that in 2002-04 rice growers
were getting 99 cents in government payments for each $1 they received from the
market. But U.S. corn-soybean growers received 11 cents in government payments
for each $1 they received from the marketplace. Thanks to 'southern politics'
$10 billion turned up for the tobacco buyout, albeit this money was assessed to
tobacco companies and not taxpayers.

Yost said that "worm has turned" with the selection of Congressman Collin
Peterson as chairman of the House agriculture committee. "Congressman Peterson
knows production agriculture. He's not an issue, but Sens. Klobuchar and Franken
need to be better informed. They haven't had much experience outside of the
seven-county Twin City metro area. We need to visit them, we need to send them
letters and, equally important, we need to make an impression on their staff
aids," Yost said.

He pointed out that more often than not it's the staff who tees up the issues
for their political bosses. Besides their D.C. staff, Minnesota Congressional
members also have aids at their various state offices and Yost said these
locations are quite accessible, if D.C. isn't.

"Most aides are younger people with pre-conceived ideas and very little
background in agricultural business."

Does President Obama relate to the importance of U.S. agriculture in the total
U.S. economy? "I really don't know," was Yost's blunt response. "My read is that
we are concentrating on issues that can affect agriculture very negatively. In
simpler terms, I think they take for granted where their food comes from. Yet
cap and trade could devastate parts of agriculture. We've got three trade
agreements pending but will there be action on any? Frankly, I don't think the
White House pays much attention to agriculture."

Yet Yost stays optimistic about U.S. agriculture, especially the opportunities
it offers to younger people. "I've been involved in production agriculture my
entire life, both agribusiness and farming, plus this 'government tour' just
concluded. The future for agriculture has never been brighter; global demand for
food is accelerating at a rapid pace and biofuels represent an unprecedented
shift in increased demand for our products.

"But I would tell young people that today and tomorrow's farm is not going to be
like your father's farm. Technology is expanding rapidly, along with changing
consumer demands. And those who accept and adopt to change are the successful
farmers of tomorrow."

Yost projects that the next farm bill will focus more on social issues of
feeding people, food safety, protecting the environment and fiscal restraints on
commodity issues. He is concerned that the Environmental Protection Agency is
becoming a major problem for agriculture. He also questions the public and
political push toward more organic food production. "Going organics means at
least 30 percent more land under cultivation to produce the equivalent amount of
what U.S. farmers are doing today. American consumers can afford organic food,
but the vast majority of the world population cannot."

The FAS is hiring a few people. Historically, education requirements are masters
or PhDs in ag economics. Today that has been expanded to people with
post-graduate degrees in international studies, international trade,
developmental aid or in some cases science such as biotech or food safety. A new
FAS hire would work on market access and trade issues, market promotion and
analysis, developmental and food aid. Most would stay in the D.C. area and would
need to join the foreign service to serve overseas. These are career jobs with
no age discrimination. Salary depends on level of entry.

Text Only

To see more of The Land, or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.thelandonline.com/. Copyright (c) 2010, The Land, Mankato, Minn.
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For reprints, email
tmsreprints@permissionsgroup.com, call 800-374-7985 or 847-635-6550, send a fax
to 847-635-6968, or write to The Permissions Group Inc., 1247 Milwaukee Ave.,
Suite 303, Glenview, IL 60025, USA.

                              997 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                                   USA TODAY

                      July 6, 1990, Friday, FINAL EDITION

Summit focuses on trade, Soviet aid

BYLINE: Mark Memmott

SECTION: MONEY; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 399 words


President Bush arrives in Houston today for an economic summit whose greatest
accomplishment could be a push toward freer trade.

Most experts would be happy if the leaders of the seven countries only agree to
tell their trade negotiators to work harder toward eliminating trade barriers.

That might not sound like much, but such marching orders could eventually
produce important trade agreements, says C. Fred Bergsten, director of the
Institute for International Economics.

The 16th economic summit officially opens Monday.  Attending with Bush: leaders
of Canada, France, Italy, Japan, United Kingdom and West Germany, and Jacques
Delors, president of the Commission of the European Communities.

Two major issues:

- Trade. Bush wants to prod the other leaders into agreeing to give top priority
to a successful conclusion, by late December, of trade talks under way in
Geneva. Those talks aim to liberalize and expand the global system of trade
rules, known as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

The summit nations, and the European Community, are at loggerheads on many GATT
issues. The biggest: agriculture. The USA wants free trade in agriculture.
Japan, however, doesn't want to end its ban on rice imports. And the Europeans
don't want to quickly eliminate subsidies to farmers.

Most likely outcome, experts say: Bush wins a pledge for free trade, but the
agricultural issues are left unsettled. Negotiators are told to work hard and
settle them by December.

- Soviet aid. France, West Germany and the EC want the Western powers to pledge
$ 15 billion to $ 20 billion in aid to the Soviet Union to bolster its economy
and prolong Mikhail Gorbachev's political life. ''The (U.S.S.R.) is hanging by
its threads,'' says William Martin, an EC official in Brussels. ''We've got to
help.''

Bush believes a major aid package would be a waste of money until the U.S.S.R.
has a free-market economy. Japan won't chip in due to a 45-year-old dispute with
the U.S.S.R. over a group of Pacific islands.

Likely compromise: A general agreement to help the Soviets without many
specifics.

Experts say the heads of state will have a tough time coming up with any
substantial agreements. ''When the dust clears, they may not be a lot further
along on any of the issues,'' says Tucker Adams, chief economist at Central
Banks of Colorado.
Contributing: John Hillkirk

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                      Copyright 1990 Gannett Company Inc.


                              998 of 999 DOCUMENTS

                              Journal of Commerce

                             June 30, 1989, Friday

INDUSTRY SPLIT ON OPEN BIDDING TO MOVE FOOD-RELIEF CARGOES

BYLINE: MARIE PRAT; Journal of Commerce Staff

SECTION: FRONT, Pg. 3A

LENGTH: 889 words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


A month-old U.S. policy requiring open transportation bids on some food-aid
shipments is drawing widely varying reactions, including criticism that the
system is open to abuse.

Initial views - based on five openings in the first month - ranged from strong
support of open bidding to criticism that the lowest bidder doesn't lways get
the cargo.

Many industry officials have mixed feelings about the open bidding. "I like the
open system. At least now I know who is shooting me," said Nadeem kramullah,
president of Washington-based broker Ned Chartering & Trading Inc.

The new policy, put into effect May 25 by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, is
aimed at ending years of government and industry criticism of the previous
closed bidding process.

In the first month of the program the bid openings under the new system covered
transportation of cargoes, mostly wheat, to Tunisia, Guyana, Jamaica, Sudan and
Sri Lanka.

Twice, in the Tunisian and Jamaican tenders, the process had to be repeated as
carriers and officials encountered problems in adapting to it.

But the Sri Lankan bidding stirred the most controversy because the lowest
bidder did not get the business.

The lowest bid came from Marine Bulk Carriers Inc. of Secaucus, N.J., and the
second lowest, which got the business, came from Liberty Shipping Group Limited
Partnerships of Lake Success, N.Y. It cost the U.S. government more than $
500,000.

The food aid, or "Food for Peace," program was created in 1954 by Public Law 480
and is administered by the USDA.

Under the previous closed bid procedure, most transportation bids weren't made
public and negotiations were allowed between the importing country and those
bidding.

That raised questions about the process because it left open the possibility
that the importing country - or the agent hired to represent it - could favor
one transportation interest over another in closed-door negotiations.

There were also concerns about potential conflicts of interest because of the
continuing dual system under which agents can represent a country on one bid and
then turn around and represent a vessel in another bid.

The new policy requires bids to be opened and read aloud when the U.S.
government is paying the freight tab. It specifically applies to the program
under Title I of Public Law 480.

That title authorizes the U.S. government to provide low-interest loans with
long repayment periods to developing countries for the purchase of U.S.
agricultural commodities. U.S. shipping law requires that 75 percent of the
cargoes be transported on U.S.-flag vessels.

While the public bidding requirement applies primarily to U.S.-flag vessels, it
would also include foreign-flag carriage financed by the U.S. government.

Some industry officials said the program has already proven itself because it
puts everyone on a level playing field and assures the government pays the
lowest rate possible for transportation.

Others said the program gives no consideration to service and questions such as
the availability of the vessels offered. Still others suggested that, without
negotiations, the government could pay more for transportation.

"Certainly even in this little bit of time it's proven itself," said Tom Maloney
of International Navigation Corp., a Bethesda, Md., a broker that represents
vessel operators in bidding.

In an open bidding process, Mr. Maloney said, there is limited potential for
wrongdoing. He also noted that open bidding forces carriers to offer their best
rate at the outset.

"When a carrier wants a particular business you're going to see some very low
rates offered. It's going to save the government money," said Mr. Maloney.

But another broker, who didn't want to be identified, said it could backfire and
cost the government more because of the absence of negotiations after the
bidding process.

He explained that the business is so closely tracked that carriers generally
know who will be bidding on a given parcel of cargo.

It's possible, he said, that a U.S.-flag carrier could tell when only its vessel
would meet the bid specifications.

"Then the carrier could come in with an absurdly high rate," he said.

This skeptic said that ocean carriers are a shrewd lot dealing "with
multimillion-dollar assets." It's likely they will figure out a way to spread
out bids, eliminating competition and resulting in higher rates, he said.

Because of that potential, the broker said it might be better to have open
bidding with limited ability to negotiate.

Ali Kamani of Canadian Maritime Carriers Ltd., an Ontario-based company that
operates non-U.S.-flag vessels, said open bidding has raised some questions, but
he views the process as fair.

"You have to give the best possible rate - that's only fair," said Mr. Kamani.
But he said there are questions about whether the recipient country has any
leeway in selecting a bid.

Agents, carriers and brokers agreed that the open bidding requires close
attention to detail on the offers. "All the i's must be dotted," said one
broker.

"It's making people stay a little more on their toes as far as giving complete
details on the offer they submit," said Henry J. Bonnabel of International
Chartering Services Inc. of New York, a company that represents vessel owners in
bidding.

LOAD-DATE: December 19, 1996

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

EDITOR-NOTE: FOOD FOR PEACE? FOOD FOR PROFIT? UNITED STATES OF AMERICA

                  Copyright 1989 The Journal of Commerce, Inc.


                              999 of 999 DOCUMENTS


                          The Decatur Daily (Alabama)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                          September 6, 2006 Wednesday

Farmers need federal drought aid, Sparks says

BYLINE: Eric Fleischauer, The Decatur Daily, Ala.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 508 words


Sep. 6--Absent federal drought relief for farmers, some North Alabama farmers
will be out of business next year, said the state's agriculture commissioner.

Ron Sparks, in Hillsboro on Tuesday, said this year's cotton crop is one of the
worst he has seen.

"The drought, the high temperatures and winds have just burned up our cotton
crop," he said, after touring area cotton farms. "It's a serious, serious
situation."

Sparks is running for re-election in November on the Democratic ticket.

"Even if some of it is picked," Sparks said, "it's going to be poor quality."

He said some cotton farms in North Alabama have fared better than others, either
because of erratic rains or irrigation.

"But the norm is that we've been hit hard," Sparks said. "We need a disaster
relief package to help these guys get to another year."

A $4 million federal disaster relief package for Alabama farmers has passed the
U.S. Senate but not the House.

Sparks said the drought's financial impact on farmers has been particularly
severe because of the high cost of putting in this year's crop, especially due
to increased fuel and fertilizer prices.

Sparks' call for financial assistance comes when the world community is
complaining of excessive U.S. cotton subsidies, a significant portion of which
go to North Alabama farm operations. The United States last week delayed a World
Trade Organization probe initiated by Brazil into U.S. cotton subsidies.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture is pushing for a new farm bill that would,
among other things, revise agricultural subsidies to reflect WTO rules.

Sparks said Congress should leave the existing farm bill intact until it has
arrived at a comprehensive foreign trade policy. Reducing subsidies before
negotiating such a policy would give away bargaining position while hurting
farmers.

"Can (Alabama cotton farmers) compete without subsidies? My feeling, no," said
Sparks.

He said Alabama has great potential in producing alternative fuels like ethanol
and biodiesel. In addition to corn, Sparks would like to see the state encourage
ethanol production from soybeans, cellulose (tree fiber), poultry litter and
switchgrass.

"My vision is you'll see an explosion of alternative fuels in the next two
years," Sparks said. "You'll see ethanol plants in Alabama. ... I think you'll
see an ethanol plant in Decatur."

He said he would like the state to require the use of gasoline that contains 10
percent ethanol.

The greatest problem facing agriculture in the state, Sparks said, is the
inability to maintain profitability.

"Farmers struggle. They don't control the price. Most industries can raise the
price; they can't," Sparks said. "It's going to cost them what it's going to
cost them, and it's going to sell for what it sells."
